From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jan  1 08:26:41 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 1 Jan 2005 08:26:41 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] A Resource for New Knoppix Users
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501010818590.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   From /.:

Posted by michael on Saturday January 01, @08:23AM
from the learning-to-love-linux dept.
chronicon writes "Knowing Knoppix is a beginner-friendly, 134 page freely
downloadable book (released under the GNU Free Documentation License in PDF
format) designed to familiarize new users with the Knoppix LiveCD
distribution, GNU/Linux in general, and (as listed first on the description)
Windows disaster recovery using Knoppix."

   It's a bit over 4M (contents, front cover, rear cover) so I guess now that
when we distribute Knoppix it's a 2-cd set. The author used the 3.3 version;
I've no idea of any differences between that and the current, 3.7 version.

   Find the URL here:
             <http://www.knoppix.net/forum/viewtopic.php?p=71597>

Rich

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  1 11:25:07 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 01 Jan 2005 11:25:07 -0800
Subject: News Flash! Re: [PLUG] Novice question - mounting USB Drive
In-Reply-To: <200412312030.08416.griffint@pobox.com>
References: <1104435902.783.26.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
	<200412311559.56361.griffint@pobox.com> <41D62262.10903@znark.com>
	<200412312030.08416.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <86y8fdc5po.fsf_-_@coulee.tdb.com>


I just booted 2.6.10 last night and was initially surprised and
confused when my USB storage (actually a SmartMedia reader) wasn't
appearing at the usual /dev/sda1 location.  Turns out, it is showing
up at /dev/uba1 instead.  That is new, at least since 2.6.8.1 which
this box was running until a few days ago.  

Just a heads up for other usb-storage users.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

On Fri, 2004-12-31 at 12:11 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>    Never a dull moment here. :-) I was waiting for the machine to do its
> thing so I used a finger to wipe dust off the ledge where the floppy drive
> is mounted. My finger went a little too far and brushed against the
> surface-mounted reset switch just enough to trip it. So much for up-time,
> eh?
> 
>    Does anyone know of an after-market switch cover that can be glued onto
> the case and prevent klutzes like me from inadvertently rebooting the
> machine? If there is no such thing, I'll just have to fabricate a custom
> solution.

If you are like me, you hardly ever actually use the reset button, so
why not just unplug it from your motherboard?  You can always power
cycle if you lock-up the machine.

Just a thought,

Derek Loree



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  1 12:08:30 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 01 Jan 2005 12:08:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Oops! After-market Switch Covers?
In-Reply-To: <1104609574.24047.2.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

Message-ID: <86sm5kdi9t.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> writes:

Derek> If you are like me, you hardly ever actually use the reset
Derek> button, so why not just unplug it from your motherboard?  You
Derek> can always power cycle if you lock-up the machine.

I once (circa 1995) rewired a "turbo" switch (which were once a common
feature on PC cases) to select either 5V or 12V for a DC fan cooling
disks.  Turned out, 5V cooled fine and 12V was too noisy anyway, so
the selector was mostly useless after the first 5 minutes of use.

On Sat, 1 Jan 2005, Keith Nasman wrote:

>> The old hard disks used Grub.

> I've never done serial terminals but I did see the following section when
> I was looking at the grub manual, maybe it will give you some leads.

   This is an opening for me to ask a question about grub versus lilo. I know
that grub offers more than lilo in several contexts. My impression, however,
and based on limited grub experience is that it really doesn't matter which
loader one uses if there's only a single OS on the system. Is this correct?

   I used to triple-boot PC-DOS/7, NT/4 and Red Hat-4.x using lilo with no
problems. For the past several years I've booted only linux, and usually
only a single kernel version. In this situation I fail to see any difference
between the two. And, when I trashed /usr on my new notebook (please don't
ask how I did such a stupid thing!), and restored it from the rescue
partition, grub was replaced with lilo. Woiks just fine.

   No flame war intended, just curiosity.

Thanks,

Rich

From rich at paranoid.org  Sat Jan  1 15:01:49 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sat, 01 Jan 2005 15:01:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Unusual Process Message
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501011303580.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501011303580.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41D72BDD.20702@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   For some reason not yet identified, I cannot ping outside my network from
> my notebook (but I can from this host). While trying to find out what's not
> running on the server that may be affecting the notebook I ran 'ps ax' and
> see this:
> 
>  1411 ?        S      0:00 readproctitle service errors: ...ccess 
> denied?multilog: fatal: unable to lock directory ./main: access 
> denied?multilog: fatal:
> unable to lock directory ./main: access denied?multilog: fatal: unable 
> to lock directory ./main: access denied?multilog: fatal: unable to lock 
> directory ./main:
> access denied?multilog: fatal: unable to lock directory ./main: access 
> denied?multilog: fatal: unable to lock directory ./main: access denied?
> 
>   This is all related, I think, to Dan Bernstein's svscan. But, I've not
> seen it before so I don't know what it's telling me to fix.
> 
>   I also have a zombie process:
> 
> 28393 ?        Z      0:00 [multilog] <defunct>
> 
> which may, or may not, be related.

It's not the cause of the network problem, but it's possibly a result.

I've never seen that error, but I Googled for this and got a lot of hits:

   multilog fatal: unable to lock directory:

It sounds like one cause of that error is when there is a multilog 
process running and another one tries to start, the new one can't get 
the lock.

Did you restart Qmail while you were troubleshooting? Is there more than 
one multilog process running? You may want to do that same Google and 
dig through the results.

As for the pinging issue, can you ping the gateway even? Can you access 
outside web sites, email, etc.? If you can do other things but not ping, 
then there is probably packet filtering that is blocking at least some 
ICMP traffic. If you can't use the web, email, etc., then you'll want to 
check and make sure you have the right gateway, DNS servers, etc.


Rich

On Sat, 1 Jan 2005, Rich Burroughs wrote:

> It's not the cause of the network problem, but it's possibly a result.

Rich,

   Well, I need to resolve both so the order doesn't matter to me. :-)

> I've never seen that error, but I Googled for this and got a lot of hits:
>
>  multilog fatal: unable to lock directory:

   Nuts! I should have thought of that, too. Thanks.

> It sounds like one cause of that error is when there is a multilog process 
> running and another one tries to start, the new one can't get the lock.

   I don't know what is a 'multilog' process. Guess I need to learn that
fast, eh?

> Did you restart Qmail while you were troubleshooting? Is there more than
> one multilog process running? You may want to do that same Google and dig
> through the results.

   Don't run qmail. But, yesterday, I stopped postfix, upgraded from 2.1.4 to
2.1.5, then restarted it. Perhaps that's the issue? I'll stop postfix, look
at the process list, and restart it.

> As for the pinging issue, can you ping the gateway even?

   Yes. I can ping internal hosts with no problem.

> Can you access outside web sites, email, etc.?

   No. It was when I tried to load a Web page from that host that I
discovered the problem. And, both 'netstat -rn' and 'route' show me that the
proper gateway is up and available. '/etc/resolve.conf' also has both the
server IP address and an external dns server as a backup.

> If you can do other things but not ping, then there is probably packet
> filtering that is blocking at least some ICMP traffic. If you can't use
> the web, email, etc., then you'll want to check and make sure you have the
> right gateway, DNS servers, etc.

   I thought -- still think -- it's a dns issue. Perhaps that got mangled the
last time I used the machine, which was when I was away from the office and
using the WiFi link. I'll copy /etc/resolv.conf from the server to the
notebook and try again.

   Stay tuned for reports on both the multilog (wonder if that's like
multi-grain bread?) and dns issues.

Many thanks,

Rich

From rich at paranoid.org  Sat Jan  1 15:26:28 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sat, 01 Jan 2005 15:26:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] unwedge this one without using a screwdriver!
In-Reply-To: <86k6qwdbyj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86oeg8dhy2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <41D707BF.6010708@ahapala.net>
	<86k6qwdbyj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <41D731A4.5000002@paranoid.org>

Russell Senior wrote:
>>>>>>"Keith" == Keith Nasman <keith at ahapala.net> writes:

> Keith> http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/html_node/Serial-terminal.html#Serial%20terminal
> 
> Yeah, that would be useful *after* I was able to type at it.  Problem
> is getting to type anything at it at all.  The serial console was
> working on the old hard disk.  Oh, and throw in a malfunctioning
> floppy drive and no locally available monitors to plug in.
> 
> How far back, chronologically, is a USB key type device likely to work
> as a boot device?

Do you not have a CD drive?

You will need to boot something to get to the point to install GRUB on 
the new drive. I like this rescue CD a lot, and it has GRUB on it:

http://www.sysresccd.org/

I did find this page that has info on rolling your own version of it 
with a kernel that supports serial output:

http://www.sysresccd.org/howto/sysresccd-howto-advanced-customization.php

It looks like it should be pretty bootable to burn yourself a CD that 
would do what you need. You could skip the grsecurity patch he mentions. 
You might ask for more help on their forums if you run into problems.

Their manual has a lot of good info, too, including info on how to boot 
it from a USB stick.


Rich

From rich at paranoid.org  Sat Jan  1 15:39:19 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sat, 01 Jan 2005 15:39:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Unusual Process Message
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501011505330.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501011303580.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<41D72BDD.20702@paranoid.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501011505330.8026@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41D734A7.7050704@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I don't know what is a 'multilog' process. Guess I need to learn that
> fast, eh?
> 
>> Did you restart Qmail while you were troubleshooting? Is there more than
>> one multilog process running? You may want to do that same Google and dig
>> through the results.
> 
>   Don't run qmail. But, yesterday, I stopped postfix, upgraded from 
> 2.1.4 to
> 2.1.5, then restarted it. Perhaps that's the issue? I'll stop postfix, look
> at the process list, and restart it.

I wouldn't think it has anything to do with Postfix. You said you're 
using svscan though, right? People usually use that with Qmail, they are 
both written by DJB. Multilog and svscan are both part of his daemontools:

http://cr.yp.to/daemontools.html

>> As for the pinging issue, can you ping the gateway even?
> 
>   Yes. I can ping internal hosts with no problem.
 >
>   I thought -- still think -- it's a dns issue. Perhaps that got mangled 
> the
> last time I used the machine, which was when I was away from the office and
> using the WiFi link. I'll copy /etc/resolv.conf from the server to the
> notebook and try again.

If you really can ping the gateway address that netstat -rn shows, but 
you can't get to outside hosts, then it may be DNS. One way to 
troubleshoot that would be to ping an outside host using it's IP 
address. You could look something up from the box that's working to get 
an IP to use.

Hopefully the new resiolv.conf fixes it, though.


Rich

error mess in the process list. Shrug. The zombie, of course, does no harm,
but the readproctitle access error is still there. Do I do a SIGHUP on that
process ID? Can't hurt, can it?

> If you really can ping the gateway address that netstat -rn shows, but you
> can't get to outside hosts, then it may be DNS. One way to troubleshoot
> that would be to ping an outside host using it's IP address. You could
> look something up from the box that's working to get an IP to use.

   It does. I had an ineffective backup (/etc/resolv.conf.staticIP) for
situations like this. Used scp to get the one from the server and that fixed
the problem.

   Interesting. When I'm at the hotels in Corvallis (Hilton Garden Inn or
Salbasgeon Suites), I use dhcpcd to get an IP address that works while I'm
there, but it leaves /etc/resolv.conf alone. This last trip, to the Hood
River Inn, ended up adding a new dns server to the file and leaving the
static, local IP address not working. But, it's fixed now. At least, after
all these years I've learned that such issues are related to dns and to look
at the resolv.conf file. :-)

   Now, about that readproctitle ....

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat Jan  1 18:01:43 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 1 Jan 2005 18:01:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Putting the grub boot loader on an rsync-restored disk
Message-ID: <20050102020143.GA24124@gate.kl-ic.com>


Here is the magic stuff I do, as part of my restore script:

/sbin/grub --batch --device-map=/dev/null << EOF
device (hd1) ${DISK}
root (hd1,0)
setup (hd1)
quit
EOF

My whole (ad hoc, setup specific)  restore script is at
http://www.keithl.com/dirvishfiles/recover.sda.

Russell, how would you like to help me gen up a more general restore tool
that works with rsync and dirvish?  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  1 18:08:35 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 01 Jan 2005 18:08:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] unwedge this one without using a screwdriver!
In-Reply-To: <41D731FA.3080402@paranoid.org>
References: <20050101230718.11FE78F13@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
	<41D731FA.3080402@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <86fz1kd1lo.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Burroughs <rich at paranoid.org> writes:

Galen> Are you certain that rsync copied /boot/grub.conf?  Did you
Galen> remember to install grub on the boot partition of the new disk?

Rich> It doesn't sound like it. I think he needs to boot from some
Rich> other media to get to the point where he can run grub-install...

Okay, I'll come clean.  The problem is solved already, and in pretty
much exactly the way Galen suggests (the latter part, anyway, I had
successfully rsync'd the old /boot/grub stuff).

I was previously unaware of how to install grub on a new disk when it
was not in the final working position.  That is, I knew how to boot
from a Grub floppy and "grub-install /dev/hda" and presto-chango, it
worked fine.  My initial attempt was to build a grub floppy with its
own filesystem.  Usually I just do the:

  # dd if=stage1 of=/dev/fd0 bs=512 count=1
  # dd if=stage2 of=/dev/fd0 bs=512 seek=1

But in order to get a boot floppy with its own menu.lst (aka
grub.conf) so that you can tell it to talk to the serial console,
you've got to do something like this instead:

  # mount /dev/fd0 /mnt
  # mkdir -p /mnt/boot/grub
  # cp stage1 stage2 /mnt/boot/grub

  # cat > /mnt/boot/grub/menu.lst <<EOF
  serial --unit=0 --speed=9600
  terminal console serial
  EOF  
 
  # grub
  grub> root (fd0)
  grub> setup (fd0)
  grub> quit

  # umount /mnt

Now, that'll give you a grub boot floppy that should work... if the
floppy/floppy-drive is working.  If (like, say, after the third
floppy) nothing comes up on the serial console during boot, and you
don't know why, and the only attachable monitor in the office is dead,
you might get annoyed and drive home and get your spare monitor.

Then once you plug in the working monitor, you might (hypothetically,
of course) figure out that you seem to be getting a consistent error
reading the floppy during stage2 loading.  Maybe some dust in the
pretty-much-unused-for-three-years floppy drive.  Then you might
scratch your head for a few minutes and think about what you just did,
and then adapt that to the situation where you install grub boot
sector stuff to a random device.  Boot off the old hard disk, which
naturally still works, with the new one plugged in at /dev/hdc, and do
something like:

  # grub
  grub> root (hd1,0)
  grub> setup (hd1)
  grub> quit

then connect the new disk back to /dev/hda and boot fine.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  1 18:24:56 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Putting the grub boot loader on an rsync-restored disk
In-Reply-To: <20050102020143.GA24124@gate.kl-ic.com>

Message-ID: <86brc8d0uf.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> Here is the magic stuff I do, as part of my restore script:

Keith> [...]

Keith> My whole (ad hoc, setup specific) restore script is at
Keith> http://www.keithl.com/dirvishfiles/recover.sda.

Yeah, I went and looked at your backup/restore stuff while thinking
about this.  I remembed that you had dealt with this problem.  I still
don't quite understand the significance of "root" in the context of
"setup", nor precisely what "setup" is doing.  I should do some more
reading.

Just thinking about how grub _has_ to work, something you write to the
boot sector has to tell grub where to look for the menu.lst file.  The
"root" line must be doing that.  

Another unrelated grub mystery is where the "savedefault" value gets
stored between boots.  It'd be kind of handy to be able to mutate that
value to get a set-next-default kind of utility.

Keith> Russell, how would you like to help me gen up a more general
Keith> restore tool that works with rsync and dirvish?

Seems pretty general to me.  How more general do you want to make it?

>> main directory located? How do I fix this? It's obviously not fatal, but
>> it's also not clean. A google search on the phrase, "unable to lock
>> directory ./main" returns 7 hits; all qmail related.
>> 
>>    Does this mean that daemontools should be removed? In my naivety it
>> struck
>> me as a useful inet service controller.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jan  2 09:58:04 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 09:58:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Unusual Process Message
In-Reply-To: <E1CkxtK-0000yt-00@pop-a065c10.pas.sa.earthlink.net>
References: <E1CkxtK-0000yt-00@pop-a065c10.pas.sa.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501020952550.1713@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 1 Jan 2005, Piet van Weel wrote:

> My google must be different from yours...
> (search "multilog: fatal:" -qmail) :)

   Obviously was, Piet.

>> Find the log directory your  .../tinydns/log/run file is specifying and
>> make sure it's owned by the user the run file is using (as Paul said).

   I'm running dnscache, but not tinydns. Regardless, running 'locate run'
showed on in /etc/dnscache/log. When I looked in that directory I discovered
that the main/ subdirectory was owned by 508.508 (and so was the 0 byte
status file). I changed owner.group to root.root on main/ and all its
contents. That should do it, thank you very much.

   Yesterday I ran 'kill -HUP <procreadtitle pic>' and that removed the
process. The defunct multilog zombie is still there, but that's OK with me.
I don't think I'll see the access error again whenever procreadtitle is
again run, which may not be until the system is re-booted.

   So much to learn, ... so little time. I wonder how many other incorrect
owner.group IDs are hanging around.

Again, thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From bthoen at gisnet.com  Sun Jan  2 10:27:43 2005
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 11:27:43 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail Filter for a Word or its Plural
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501021112480.20312-100000@gisnet.com>

I'm trying to create a procmail filter to add one to the score every time
it sees a word or its plural.

Say the word was "dog" (it's not, but I don't want to trigger everyone's 
spam filter!) and I want to catch all messages with at least 4 occurrences 
of the word "dog" in them.

I try this:

:0:
* -3^0
* 1^1 HB ?? ()\<dog\>
CANINE-MAIL

And it traps messages like:

The dog chased the other dog out of his dog house into the dog kennel.

But I want it to pass message like:

It's a doggone world in which doggerel is preached to dogfaces, though 
Omidog.

(and BTW, why does "dog dog dog dog" pass through? It shouldn't)

But ultimately, I want it to be able to trap a message like this:

The dog chased the other dogs out of his dog house into the dog kennel.


Anyone know how to specify a full word or its plural without having to 
make two entries?

- Bill Thoen

--- Jim Karlock <Jkarlock at earthlink.net> wrote:
> Fry's is offering a "Great Quality" brand laptop for $499.
> 
> Obviously, at this low price, I am suspicious of the quality.
> 
> Does anyone know of quality data about this item?

Anecdotal data:  I bought one of their "Great Quality" PCs for $100. 
The hardware is low quality and the USB controller has a Via chipset
that's caused me a bit of grief but the latest drivers seem to have
resolved the issues.

All things considered, I think I got a fair deal.  I didn't pay a lot. 
I didn't get a lot.  Once I added some extra ram and got rid of Lindows
(er, Linspire), everything was just fine.

Cheers,
Ovid

In-Reply-To: <86y8fdc5po.fsf_-_@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <1104435902.783.26.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>	<200412311559.56361.griffint@pobox.com>
	<41D62262.10903@znark.com>	<200412312030.08416.griffint@pobox.com>
	<86y8fdc5po.fsf_-_@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <41D83EE6.1070709@comcast.net>

Russell Senior wrote:

>I just booted 2.6.10 last night and was initially surprised and
>confused when my USB storage (actually a SmartMedia reader) wasn't
>appearing at the usual /dev/sda1 location.  Turns out, it is showing
>up at /dev/uba1 instead.  That is new, at least since 2.6.8.1 which
>this box was running until a few days ago.  
>
>Just a heads up for other usb-storage users.
>
>  
>
The 2.6.10 announcement mentions some USB work.

http://kerneltrap.org/node/4450

    Mel



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jan  2 10:33:45 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 02 Jan 2005 10:33:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] how to tell when the filesystem is borken?
In-Reply-To: <200412172137.iBHLbGpU068755@m5p.com>
References: <200412172137.iBHLbGpU068755@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <86acrr8yuu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Elliott" == Elliott Mitchell <ehem at m5p.com> writes:

Elliott> 3> As Russell Senior mentioned, filesystems should deal with
Elliott> some hardware funkyness. I tend to make very sure I've got
Elliott> working hardware, but failures do occur. ReiserFS is a bit
Elliott> fragile (but *very* fast, you determine the tradeoff).

Heh.

E.g., This morning I discovered that one of my reiserfs partitions was
failing (hard disk i/o errors).  I wonder why smartd didn't tell me
about this?  I only noticed it because I happened to wake up unusually
early and was present when updatedb was running and heard the
chirping.  Checking the logs, it only started about a week ago when
the affected disk space got used (just 12 4k blocks, near the end of
the media).

I was able to rsync off everything that was valuable (only
affected directory was in a kernel source tree), but trying to repair
the filesystem (in order to facilitate data recovery) failed because
one of the bad blocks was in a system area.  I could have dd_rescue'd
the whole disk image onto reliable media and reiserfsck
--rebuild-tree'd, but because of the limited and (it turns out)
unimportant damage, it wasn't necessary.  Luckily, I just bought a
couple spare 80 gig drives on new years eve, so I had a place for the
data to land.

The dying drive is another IBM Deskstar (DTLA-307030), which according
to Hitachi is now 7 months out of warranty.

seniorr at aracnet.com

And, for reference, I have a Deathstar 75GXP (*the* model that initiated
the lawsuit)...

It's been running virtually nonstop for a few years now without any real
issues.  Every few months it starts chirping or clicking... giving me
cause for concern... but every time it settles back down within a few
days.

However, early this morning it started clicking again - only this time a
different click.  They're shorter sounding and higher pitched than
before.  No data loss yet, SMART (as usual) doesn't say anything is
wrong... so I'll let it continue on.  I'm thinking about decommissioning
the box it's in, though, it doesn't get used very much any more, only
acting as my VPN server and for a few automated scripts that could
easily be moved to a different server.

Of course, then what would I do with the box?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jan  2 19:42:58 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 19:42:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel Config for HIGHMEM?
In-Reply-To: <200501021931.05270.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501021812550.1601@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200501021931.05270.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sun, 2 Jan 2005, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Lazy man, why don't you tediously click through all the kernel configs like
> the rest of us.

   'Cause I knew you experts had the answer on the tip of your brains.
Especially those of you who have just completed highly detailed books.

> For the 2.4 kernel, look under Processor type -> features -> High Memory
> Support. I dunno for 2.6.

   Thanks.

> gigabyte.

but for whatever reason the kernel only likes just under 900M worth. Seems a
rather strange cut-off value for me, too.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sun Jan  2 22:14:38 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun, 2 Jan 2005 22:14:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Booting into console mode
In-Reply-To: <20050103054443.87357.qmail@web50603.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050103054443.87357.qmail@web50603.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200501022214.38915.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 02 January 2005 9:44 pm, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I am trying to boot into console mode (no X-server) to
> install something on Debian Sarge. Ordinarily one
> modifies inittab for this purpose, but it says
> 
> id:2:initdefault:
> 
> Since runlevel 5 is usually X mode, I'm not sure why X
> is coming up now! Anyhow, what is the easiest way to
> do this? 
> 

In Debian, runlevels 2-5 are all the same. So whatever you select at 
installation- text or graphical login- applies to all runlevels. Debian 
assumes you are smart enuff to customize it however you like. Or something 
like that.

Anyway you want the 'update-rc.d' command. For example, to make runlevel 5 the 
graphical runlevel, and all others text, assuming gdm is your graphical login 
manager:

# update-rc.d -f gdm remove
# update-rc.d gdm start 99 5 . stop 01 0 1 2 3 4 6 .

First remove all startup links for gdm, then explicitly assign gdm start and 
stop for each runlevel. A smart Debian noobie would buy my book and have all 
these answers at his fingertips. ;)

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
http://www.tuxcomputing.com
check out my new book, the "Linux Cookbook", the ultimate Linux user's 
and sysadmin's guide! http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxckbk/
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

                               An Introduction
                                      to
                    High Performance Cluster File Systems

                                      by

                                 Michael Ewan
                          Senior Systems Programmer
                              Intel Corporation
                            michael.ewan at intel.com



      This will be an overview of High Performance Cluster File 
      Systems including storage aggregation, high performance file 
      servers using protocols other than NFS, and availale free 
      cluster file systems such as PVFS, PVFS2, Lustre, and commercial 
      offerings such as GPFS, GFS, CXFS, TerraScale and Ibrix Fusion.

Yeah, your memory is right, although the 2.4 config help isn't too clear on
this.  (They give a lower number as the LOWMEM limit.)  But the 2.6 config
help does advise you to use HIGHMEM if you have more than 1GB of RAM.

And yes, I've tried building a 2.4 kernel with 1GB of RAM and with HIGHMEM set,
and no, it didn't help my memory addressing problem.

Ali

From mhewan1 at comcast.net  Mon Jan  3 12:32:14 2005
From: mhewan1 at comcast.net (Michael Ewan)
Date: Mon, 03 Jan 2005 12:32:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Novice question - mounting USB Drive
In-Reply-To: <4.2.2.20050103033136.0420ed60@mail.earthlink.net>
References: <41D62262.10903@znark.com> <1104435902.783.26.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
	<200412311559.56361.griffint@pobox.com> <41D62262.10903@znark.com>
	<4.2.2.20050103033136.0420ed60@mail.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <1104784334.442.8.camel@linux.site>

On Mon, 2005-01-03 at 03:37 -0800, Jim Karlock wrote:

> I could not duplicate most of the suggestions including the one below that 
> 'Prefreneces' has a 'Removable Storage' entry. I appear to be running 
> Gnome, but do not know how to find which Fedore, but I now suspect that I 
> installed FC1 since that was included with the Sams book that I got.
> 

Do "cat /etc/*release", on SuSE this file is /etc/SuSE-release, on
Redhat it should be /etc/redhat-release, fedora should have something
similar.

I just moments ago read an article in this months Linux Magazine that
described a problem mounting the Apple iPod on Linux, that may be
related, since I've ssen similar lock up problems trying to access my
camera and thumb drive on SuSE 9.1.

In a nutshell the problem is with the EFI partition table support in the
2.6 kernels, the EFI partition table is stored at the last block of the
drive rather than the first.  If the USB device reports an incorrect
number of blocks and the EFI code goes looking for a partition table
there, you get a locked out drive.  The suggestion in the article was to
disable CONFIG_EFI_PARTITION and rebuild the kernel.

ME



From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Jan  3 13:46:28 2005

From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 18:27:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Sarge Kernel Compilation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501031808260.5175@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <20050104003013.40235.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501031808260.5175@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <200501031827.40404.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Monday 03 January 2005 6:10 pm, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Mon, 3 Jan 2005, Robert Kopp wrote:
> 
> > If you go for 2.6 you need to switch to ALSA and stuff like that. Is 
> > this a problem?
> 
> I switched my wife's Debian (testing) box to 2.6 and there were 
> absolutely no hiccups whatsoever. I have a vague memory that I 
> followed a HOWTO to ensure that I'd installed all the correct 
> supporting packages -- but the switchover was incredibly trouble-free. 
> Kudos to all the developers who made that bit of sweetness possible!
> 

See Pluggers, mixed marriages can work! Even Red Hat/Debian marriages.

Debian users can have 'make menuconfig' or 'make xconfig' just like the other 
Linuxes. 'make config' is for masochists. There are some Debian-specific 
kernel-building utilities that are quite nice; somewhere in the docs on 
http://www.debian.org/doc/ is a howto or two.

One issue I recall reading about with the 2.6 kernel is problems with 
cdrecord; dunno if those are resolved yet.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
http://www.tuxcomputing.com
check out my new book, the "Linux Cookbook", the ultimate Linux user's 
and sysadmin's guide! http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxckbk/

by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail

From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jan  3 19:32:51 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 19:32:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Sarge Kernel Compilation
In-Reply-To: <20050104003013.40235.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050104003013.40235.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20050104033251.GA6995@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Jan 03, 2005 at 04:30:13PM -0800, Robert Kopp wrote:
> rtk at timothy:~$ uname -r
> 2.4.27-1-386
> rtk at timothy:~$
> 
> Suppose I were to compile a kernel for Sarge because I
> needed a feature changed. Should I stick with the
> above, or use a different one? If this enabled me to
> use my present hardware, it would probably justify the
> trouble. 

It doesn't really make much difference.  If you like, you can install
the kernel-source package, which will give you the exact same treei
that was built from, or use a tarball from kernel.org, which will also
work nicely, and may work better with external patches and drivers.

> If you go for 2.6 you need to switch to ALSA and stuff
> like that. Is this a problem?

Not really.  ALSA emulates OSS so you don't have to change your
programs.  You'll need module-init-tools, that's about it.  Best way
is to install kernel-image-2.6 and see how it works.

> I note that Debian seems to use a text-based
> configuration tool for the 2.4 kernel. That seems unfortunate.

You can config however you like--xconfig, menuconfig, whatever.
If you want a Debian package for your kernel, just install
kernel-package and from the kernel tree, do :
  make-kpkg --rootcmd fakeroot kernel_image

Have fun,
  Aaron

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Jan  3 20:25:15 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)

On Monday 03 January 2005 8:07 pm, William A Morita wrote:
> I am currently running RH9.  
> *  I am looking to load a new server with Linux and was wondering about
> issues such as  stability.   
> *  I am seeking a distribution that has good plug/play USB support.
> 
> I was wondering about Fedora core 2 vs 3.
> 
> Suggestions/thoughts?

In my nearly-humble opinion, Fedora is good if you are a seasoned Red Hat 
admin and don't mind working around the broken bits. Because Fedora always 
has broken bits.

Have you looked at any of the RHEL derivatives? Quite a number of folks are 
grabbing the RHEL SRPMs and rolling their own RHEL clones:

http://lwn.net/Articles/69534/

From bmurdock at gmail.com  Mon Jan  3 21:57:10 2005
From: bmurdock at gmail.com (Bryan Murdock)
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 21:57:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] dumb hardware question
Message-ID: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>

I feel dumb asking this, but, I bought a cheap IDE removeable drive
tray from Fry's today without thinking too much about it.  This is for
my home computer, I just want to be able to swap a second hard drive 
in and out, for backups and stuff.  There's no way this would be hot
swap-able, right?  I mean, I'm thinking in Linux I could just unmount
it, turn the key (which turns of the power) and slide it right out,
but something tells me that probably isn't going to work.  Does anyone
know for sure?

Bryan


From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jan  3 23:10:58 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 23:10:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] dumb hardware question
In-Reply-To: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>
References: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20050104071058.GA8377@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Jan 03, 2005 at 09:57:10PM -0800, Bryan Murdock wrote:
> I feel dumb asking this, but, I bought a cheap IDE removeable drive
> tray from Fry's today without thinking too much about it.  This is for
> my home computer, I just want to be able to swap a second hard drive 
> in and out, for backups and stuff.  There's no way this would be hot
> swap-able, right?  I mean, I'm thinking in Linux I could just unmount
> it, turn the key (which turns of the power) and slide it right out,
> but something tells me that probably isn't going to work.  Does anyone
> know for sure?

Not supposed to be hot-swappable, but if it's on its own channel and
you use the hdparm -R/-U/-w commands, you may be able to hot-swap
without immediately crashing your system.

Since IDE wasn't designed for it, you also run a small risk of
damaging the controller or drive.

In other words: might work, don't do it with anything valuable.

From dale at zeutenhorst.com  Mon Jan  3 23:28:07 2005
From: dale at zeutenhorst.com (Dale Zeutenhorst)
Date: Mon, 3 Jan 2005 23:28:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] dumb hardware question
In-Reply-To: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>
References: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200501032328.07364.dale@zeutenhorst.com>

On Monday 03 January 2005 09:57 pm, Bryan Murdock wrote:
> I feel dumb asking this, but, I bought a cheap IDE removeable drive
> tray from Fry's today without thinking too much about it.  This is for
> my home computer, I just want to be able to swap a second hard drive 
> in and out, for backups and stuff.  There's no way this would be hot
> swap-able, right?  I mean, I'm thinking in Linux I could just unmount
> it, turn the key (which turns of the power) and slide it right out,
> but something tells me that probably isn't going to work.  Does anyone
> know for sure?
> 
> Bryan
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 
> 
I have used umount and then removing the drive OK, but IDE controllers
generally are not designed to allow restarting the drive. You can get IDE
PCI cards that do support hot swap. I have tried (just curious) to hot start
a drive and some of the time the system locks up. The rest of the time,
provided the drives are identical, it worked. To use a different drive
requires changing the drive parameters, which if you get them wrong is
a great way to FUBAR the data. 

It is much easier to do this with SATA or SCSI, even some of the on-board
controllers support hot swap.

What I am using now is a external USB box I bought that uses an IDE hard
drive. Got it from Neutron Express for $33-$34. If you want to use it on a
laptop you will need an external power supply.
http://www.neutronexpress.com/prod.cfm/239147/STARTECH/IDECASE25U2/EXTERNAL_USB_IDE_CASE

Have fun--

Dale


From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jan  4 00:27:06 2005
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 00:27:06 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Stupid SCSI.  Stupid DVDROM
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0501040022470.14897@shaft.bitmine.net>


So, my DVDROM drive is hanging open.  No idea how long it's been that way.
Could be months.  I tried to put it back in and it just spits right back
out again.  This happens whether it's got a disc or not.

If I put a DVD disc in there and then run something like

mplayer DVD://1

then it takes in the disc and spits it out again with this in the output
of mplayer (as well as in syslog):

sr1: CDROM not ready.  Make sure there is a disc in the drive.
cdrom: open failed.

Tres frustrating.  I fear the hardware has failed, but I'd like to exhaust
software possibilities.

`sg_reset /dev/sg1` appears to do nothing.

Anyone?

J.

From wamorita at hevanet.com  Tue Jan  4 08:04:31 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 08:04:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] dumb hardware question
In-Reply-To: <477eba8c05010321572e1fed65@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200501041604.j04G4Xe08080@pop.hevanet.com>

Bryan,

Why don't you buy a USB 2.0 external drive enclosure.  You can mount the
drive in directly or mount your drive drawer.  You can "hot swap" by
disconnecting the USB, swap drive drawers and plug the USB back in.  I
suggest that you power down the drive enclosure before drive swapping
however.

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Jan  4 10:04:13 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 10:04:13 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Free Geek in the News
In-Reply-To: <200501040857.51552.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501040930190.526-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 4 Jan 2005, Richard C. Steffens wrote:

> Congratulations to the fine folks at Free Geek for making the front page of 
> the Living section in today's Oregonian (Jan. 4, 2005 - for the archives). 
> 
> I haven't been down there in many months, but it sounds from the article that 
> everything is the same, but bigger and better. 

I've seen Free Geek mentioned many times on this list and it finally sunk 
into the grey-matter that this is exactly what we need up here in the 
Coeur d'Alene, ID and Spokane, WA area.
   We've had several discussions at our user group ( North Idaho Linux
Users Group -- NILUG ) about recycling computers.  I saw on the about 
page that Free Geek does Oregon and the World :-) so I'm wondering if 
there is anyway we can cooperate.
   I have a garage sale planned for this spring ( going to be advertised
as "Guy Stuff" ) with the proceeds going to a local non-profit /
not-for-profit I provide other support to (North Idaho Communities ONline 
- nicon.org ).  This will work for a one off but there is a lot of old 
semi-usable computers floating around here that could use a more permanent 
process.

So I'm looking for any suggestions.


Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

> So I'm looking for any suggestions.

Go to http://lists.freegeek.org/listinfo and sign up on the startup list
and introduce yourself. Of course, this will pull you over the event
horizon and you will end up starting a local Free Geek. ;)

-Ron
Former Free Geek staff person in process of moving to Vancouver, BC.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jan  4 12:45:02 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 12:45:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] IDE swap tray info
Message-ID: <20050104204502.GA30565@gate.kl-ic.com>


Bryan Murdock writes:

> I feel dumb asking this, but, I bought a cheap IDE removeable drive tray
> from Fry's today without thinking too much about it.  This is for my home
> computer, I just want to be able to swap a second hard drive in and out, for
> backups and stuff.  There's no way this would be hot swap-able, right?  I
> mean, I'm thinking in Linux I could just unmount it, turn the key (which
> turns of the power) and slide it right out, but something tells me that
> probably isn't going to work.  Does anyone know for sure?
                                                                                
> Bryan

Bryan:  Not a dumb question at all.  Only the subject line "dumb
hardware question" was dumb (irrelevant and insufficent information),
but then, you warned us.  In the future, skip the self-deprecation,
(you are no dummy, you are here, aren't you?) concentrate on "direct
and informative".  On to your question ...

IDE hotswap is indeed possible, but only with the later 2.4.X series
of kernels.  Alan Cox put code in there to permit live hotswap of IDE
drives;  the 2.5.X and 2.6.X kernel folk took it back out again.  I
think they did it to impress Jodie Foster.

With a 2.4.X kernel from late 2003 or 2004, such as RH9 or Fedora Core 1
(not 2 or 3!) you can do this:

   umount /dev/hde   (for example)
   hdparm  -b 0 /dev/hde
   (turn key, pull drive, insert drive, turn key)
   hdparm -zb 1 /dev/hde
   mount  /dev/hde  /mnt/tempdrive

The "hdparm" instruction tristates the bus that the drive is on, to
protect it from damage.  You should only have one drive on the cable.  
The "z" for the re-attach is important, it tells the kernel to rebuild
the drive parameter table, which is otherwise left over from the previous
drive.

The kernel developers will probably remain fixated on Jodie Foster, or
the little voices in their heads, rather than users or Alan Cox, so
don't count on this being fixed in 2.6.X any time soon.  Meanwhile, a
more modern way to do this is to follow wamorita's suggestion and use
a USB2 enclosure, where hot swap is supported.  The problem with the
USB2 approach is that a significant number of the chipsets are not
properly supported by the kernel, and external drives will hang for
minutes in the middle of transfers.  Two known-bad enclosures are the
Maxtor USB2 enclosure, and the Sanmax InClose USB2 enclosures at Fry's.
A known-good enclosure is the ViPower, which unfortunately is a little
hard to find;  you may find it at ENU, or you may have to mail-order
some of these.  Go for the slide switch rather than the key switch!

I gave a talk on using swappable hard drives for backups at the March
2004 PLUG meeting;  I will be presenting an updated version of that
talk to PANUG later this month, and to the Oregon IEEE Consultant's
Network (members.eeconsult.org).  Some of the information can be found
at www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html, and some can be found in a three
part article about dirvish, starting with the January 2005 Sys Admin
magazine, available at Powell's Technical and other places.

I hope that answers your question in effusive detail.  Note the change
in subject line - my answer will be in the PLUG email archives forever,
and I want other Googlers to be able to find it!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From lowbassman at gmail.com  Tue Jan  4 13:43:25 2005
From: lowbassman at gmail.com (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 14:43:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Rebuilding software RAID after disk failure
Message-ID: <9e0a3578050104134376e371f4@mail.gmail.com>

I have a RedHat 7.2 server with two disks that was setup with software
RAID level 1.  One of the disks failed and was replaced.  There are
three partitions, root, data, and the swap partition.  Now I'm trying
to rebuild the array.  Using the info in /etc/raidtab, I tried to
rebuild the md0 array with this command:

raidhotadd /dev/md0 /dev/sdb2
/dev/md0: can not hot-add disk: invalid argument.

This is a new disk so /dev/sdb2 doesn't exist yet.  So I assume that I
need to partition it first and then run raidhotadd?  If so, how do I
give the new disk the same parition info as the other disk?

Out of curiosity, I ran the following command and it worked, but
/proc/mdstat shows that the entire new disk was used for md0:

raidhotadd /dev/md0 /dev/sdb

But when I try to remove sdb with raidhotremove /dev/md0 /dev/sdb, I get:

/dev/md0: can not hot-remove disk: disk busy!

Here's my /etc/raidtab:

raiddev             /dev/md1
raid-level                  1
nr-raid-disks               2
chunk-size                  64k
persistent-superblock       1
nr-spare-disks              0
    device          /dev/sda1
    raid-disk     0
    device          /dev/sdb1
    raid-disk     1
raiddev             /dev/md0
raid-level                  1
nr-raid-disks               2
chunk-size                  64k
persistent-superblock       1
nr-spare-disks              0
    device          /dev/sda2
    raid-disk     0
    device          /dev/sdb2
    raid-disk     1
raiddev             /dev/md2
raid-level                  1
nr-raid-disks               2
chunk-size                  64k
persistent-superblock       1
nr-spare-disks              0
    device          /dev/sda3
    raid-disk     0
    device          /dev/sdb3
    raid-disk     1

Thanks,
~M

-- 
Get Firefox!
http://getfirefox.com/


From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jan  4 13:55:11 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 13:55:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Rebuilding software RAID after disk failure
References: <9e0a3578050104134376e371f4@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <pan.2005.01.04.21.55.09.138989@nakedape.cc>

On Tue, 04 Jan 2005 14:43:25 -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I have a RedHat 7.2 server with two disks that was setup with software
> RAID level 1.  One of the disks failed and was replaced.  There are
> three partitions, root, data, and the swap partition.  Now I'm trying
> to rebuild the array.  Using the info in /etc/raidtab, I tried to
> rebuild the md0 array with this command:
> 
> raidhotadd /dev/md0 /dev/sdb2
> /dev/md0: can not hot-add disk: invalid argument.
> 
> This is a new disk so /dev/sdb2 doesn't exist yet.  So I assume that I
> need to partition it first and then run raidhotadd?

Right.

> If so, how do I
> give the new disk the same parition info as the other disk?

Well, considering that you've got on a couple partitions, you could write
down the geometry from 'fdisk -l /dev/sda'.  Alternatively, you can use
'sfdisk' to dump the geometry from one and restore on the other.  Then you
call raidhotadd.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

 -- Alex Martelli

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jan  4 18:18:22 2005
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 4 Jan 2005 18:18:22 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Stupid SCSI.  Stupid DVDROM
In-Reply-To: <41DAC542.4010908@comcast.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0501040022470.14897@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<41DAC542.4010908@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0501041815190.14897@shaft.bitmine.net>


On Tue, 4 Jan 2005, Garl Grigsby wrote:
> What brand DVD drive? I have seen a couple of Toshiba's do this when
> when of the switches inside the drive failed. This usually means that
> the drive is toast.

It is, in fact, a Toshiba.

But what switch would make the tray come back out and say the drive's not
ready?

And why would it be toast?  I've replaced and "repaired" microswitches
before with really great results.  My minidisc deck, for example, kept
telling me there was no disc and wouldn't eject or play or anything.  I
pulled the thing apart, wrapped some electrical tape around the little
lever arm that pressed the switch to make it press even further... work
like bear-bone charm.

I'm going to move on to Galen's suggestions and report back.

J.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jan  4 19:03:45 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 04 Jan 2005 19:03:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Lightning Talks]
Message-ID: <1104894225.9928.10.camel@denk.nakedape.cc>

-------- Forwarded Message --------
From: Josh <josh at naked-ape.com>

The Portland Perl Mongers are giving Lightning Talks, January 12th, 2004
6:30pm at Free Geek, 1741 SE 10th Ave

Feel free to sign up to give a lightning talk on the sign-up sheet,
http://pdx.pm.org/kwiki/

What is a Lightning Talk?

About Lightning Talks

Q: What is a lightning talk?

Any Perlish or geekish lecture, rant, speech, poem, droll witticism, or
(hopefully) constructive criticism that you can fit into N MINUTES (where
N usually equals 5, 8, 10 or 15).

Q: Who talks?

You do!

Q: Why would you want to do this?

(Copied from Perl Paraphernalia verbatim; minor edits)

Maybe you've never given a talk before, and you'd like to start small. For
a Lightning Talk, you don't need to make slides, and if you do decide to
make slides, you only need to make four.

Maybe you're nervous and you're afraid you'll mess up. It's a lot easier
to plan and deliver a eight minute talk than it is to deliver a long talk.
And if you do mess up, at least the painful part will be over quickly.

Maybe you don't have much to say. Maybe you just want to ask a question,
or invite people to help you with your project, or boast about something
you did, or tell a short cautionary story. These things are all
interesting and worth talking about, but there might not be enough to say
about them to fill up thirty minutes.

Maybe you have a lot of things to say, and you're already going to give a
long talk on one of them, and you don't want to hog the spotlight. There's
nothing wrong with giving several Lightning Talks. Hey, they're only eight
minutes.

Q: What do I talk about?

Why not take a look at prior lightning talks? A sampling:

Here's a list of the talks from last time we did this:

    * Allison Randal - On her upcoming book, Perl 6 Essentials
    * Annett Sullivan - Perl and Water Quality (with GD animations!)
    * Jeff Zucker - Everything is database. Nothing is database
    * Josh Heumann - Perljxta, an implementation of Sun's JXTA P2P protocols
    * Michael G. Schwern - MakeMaker Is Doomed
    * Brian Ingerson - Two Tails of OOP Adventures in Data-Driven Design
    * Brian Ingerson - Lightn-ingy Strikes Twice
    * Ben Marcotte - From the Dark Side Back to the Light How having to
use Win32::TieRegistry led to experimenting with "hierarchical" hashes
    * Clint Moore - Experiences Gained From Working Alone on a Large Project

There are even more examples at Perl Paraphernalia.

Q: I still have questions! Mark-Jason probably answers your question on
Perl Paraphernalia's "Lightning Talks" page: http://perl.plover.com/lt/


-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                      http://naked-ape.com
* * * * * Portland's premier open source consultancy * * * * *

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jan  5 01:51:29 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 05 Jan 2005 01:51:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] strange crashes/power-offs
Message-ID: <86vfac2ogu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


Remember the box with the serial console I was talking about the other
day?  Well, it has taken to (apparently) shutting itself off in the
middle of the night.  The three times it has occurred were all during
a scsi DAT tape backup.  Three crashes for three tape backup attempts
since Jan 1.  So far, I haven't captured anything from the serial
console, but that is probably next.  Seems to run during the day as a
Samba server with no problems.  Unfortunately, I don't have access to
the building at night, so have to wait until morning for a manual
power cycle.

The descriptions I am getting are that there are LED lights on the
back (associated with the RJ45 ethernet jack), but no fan noise and
apparently shutdown.  The box reboots (with fan noise) after a power
cycle.  Other devices plugged into the same UPS give the appearance of
not having lost power.  Somewhat baffled.  The machine, identical
except for a new HD, had just been up for 280 days straight and made
innumerable tape backups.  I had upgraded the kernel from 2.4.25 to
2.4.28, but just downgraded again to check and got the same "crash".

This is on an Intel D815 motherboard.

Any ideas?

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From miken at hotsushi.com  Wed Jan  5 10:46:25 2005
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 10:46:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] strange crashes/power-offs

Message-ID: <20050105190201.1A2B91C9F@haus.nakedape.cc>

Hi,

We had similar symptoms from an underpowered box.  Problem solved with a
higher wattage power supply.

Cheers,
Mike

At 01:51 AM 1/5/2005 -0800, you wrote:
>
>Remember the box with the serial console I was talking about the other
>day?  Well, it has taken to (apparently) shutting itself off in the

From fpikus at gmail.com  Wed Jan  5 11:09:19 2005
From: fpikus at gmail.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Wed, 5 Jan 2005 11:09:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] strange crashes/power-offs
In-Reply-To: <20050105190201.1A2B91C9F@haus.nakedape.cc>
References: <86vfac2ogu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20050105190201.1A2B91C9F@haus.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <a4fbdc7b05010511091266929f@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, 05 Jan 2005 10:46:25 -0800, Mike Neal <miken at hotsushi.com> wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> We had similar symptoms from an underpowered box.  Problem solved with a
> higher wattage power supply.
Sometimes it's not just the wattage, but the quality: I had a 430W
supply, good brand too (Antec), and I started to have crashes, more
when PC was busy doing something, especially with disks. Then I
started having disk errors on boot. So I started testing disks one by
one and noticed that I never have errors with just one disk, but with
more disks I get more errors. I checked voltages in BIOS, they were
low (12V was only about 11.2). So I got an Enermax supply, 450W,
almost the same power, but from the high end of their line. Stable
voltages, and no more crashes.

> 
> Cheers,
> Mike
> 
> At 01:51 AM 1/5/2005 -0800, you wrote:
> >
> >Remember the box with the serial console I was talking about the other
> >day?  Well, it has taken to (apparently) shutting itself off in the
> >middle of the night.  The three times it has occurred were all during
> >a scsi DAT tape backup.
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

catch an oops tonight, and if nothing appears, I'll look more closely
at the power supply.

This is just a plain-jane Intel P3 motherboard with integrated video,
lan, and sound.  The only PCI card in it is an old NCR SCSI and it has
one hard disk and a floppy.  The power supply is probably just 250W
(or maybe 300W) and has been chugging along reliably for about 3 or 4
years.  The tape drive is external, and the only thing on the SCSI bus.

From hhoult at cpcbsa.org  Wed Jan  5 15:03:28 2005
From: hhoult at cpcbsa.org (Hoult, Harlan)
Date: Wed, 5 Jan 2005 15:03:28 -0800 
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
Message-ID: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A979315232E@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>

With all of the glowing comments about Debian on this list I just had to
switch my Dell C800 from dual boot XP/FC1 to XP/Debian. Currently I have
beat it into submission except for wireless, which I haven't been able to
get working. Where I am at:

- Sarge with kernel 2.6.8 using netinstall
- the card is a Linksys WPC11 ver. 3
- built in ethernet works fine.
- lsmod shows, among other things: orinco_cs, orinco, hermes, ds
- cardinfo shows the card in socket 1 and ready
- ifconfig doesn't show the interface
- the GUI Network Administration tool under Add doesn't list the card.

Google has turned up several things to try - some of which appear to my
"noobie" eye to contradict each other. I have tried to install the driver
from Linksys which looks like the wlan-ng driver that I also tried. I did
find references that said to avoid those drivers with this kernel. 


Thank you for any tips, pointers or clues
Harlan 


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan  5 15:34:14 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 5 Jan 2005 15:34:14 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SCO Insight
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501051528400.12018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   A fellow in Alabama posted a request for help on the SQL-Leger mail list
and mentioned that he was in transition from Maytech on SCO-UNIX to
SQL-Ledger on linux for his paper distribution business.

   Being the curious sort I wrote and asked if he was leaving SCO for linux
all-together. He replied that he is; that from what he's learned he thinks
it's in his best interests. For comparison, he told me that the previous
owner paid $33,000 for the Maytech accounting/inventory software, plus $425
per month. Now they're raising the monthly protection payment to $550 and
he's decided that's enough.

   I have been wondering if the mad-SCO disease is causing existing customers
to abandon the company and, at least this one is. I thought it was
interesting and worth while sharing with you. And, look at the cost savings!

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

From hilsy at hilsy.com  Wed Jan  5 16:39:49 2005
From: hilsy at hilsy.com (hilsy at hilsy.com)
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 16:39:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
Message-ID: <20050106003949.7B495EDF0E@ws6-1.us4.outblaze.com>

I have a linksys wireless-g card and found that no linux drivers even exist for this card.  Though I still haven't done it, what I'll need to do is load ndiswrapper which will, supposedly, allow me to use the wintel binary drivers.

You may have to go a similar route.  If so, try googling "ndiswrapper" and linksys. I found a couple of forums where folks gave step-by-step instructions.

Jim Hilsenteger

From colonel_panic at softhome.net  Wed Jan  5 17:14:53 2005
From: colonel_panic at softhome.net (Dan McDonald)
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 17:14:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
In-Reply-To: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A979315232E@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>
References: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A979315232E@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>
Message-ID: <41DC910D.5050700@softhome.net>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hoult, Harlan wrote:
| - the card is a Linksys WPC11 ver. 3

This looks like a job for ndiswrapper <http://ndiswrapper.sf.net>. I
have had my troubles with it in the past on Gentoo (works fine now), but
it has worked flawlessly in my limited experience with Debian (Knoppix,
actually). Although, I don't have the same card as you.

ndiswrapper is a kernel module (with a userspace configure utility) that
lets you use Windows wireless drivers on Linux. I looked up your card on
the ndiswrapper's wiki and the closest match I found was for the WPC11
ver. 4. Do a `lspci -n` and if '1186:3300' is listed, this should work.

The chipset in your card is a RealTek and they provide Linux drivers for
the 2.4.x kernel and a few variations of Windows. The chipset I use (TI
1130) only works with the XP drivers and ndiswrapper but YMMV. Aside
from a normal ndiswrapper setup, to use the good RealTek driver, you
need to go out of your way and modify an .INF file packaged with the
driver: <http://www.xs4all.nl/~bsamwel/dwl-510-on-linux-2.6.html>

Good Luck!

	Dan
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----
Version: GnuPG v1.2.6 (GNU/Linux)

iD8DBQFB3JEN652I2TecBrYRAmdsAJ0aLKRKD+41G0aTDtBsqaPa0OdREgCeM8GW
Fo9QCDMUqvxo32e08O7Gfyw=
=R71/
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----

Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
In-Reply-To: <20050106003949.7B495EDF0E@ws6-1.us4.outblaze.com>

Message-ID: <1104976183.4176.163.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Wed, 2005-01-05 at 16:39 -0800, hilsy at hilsy.com wrote:
> I have a linksys wireless-g card and found that no linux drivers even exist for this card.  Though I still haven't done it, what I'll need to do is load ndiswrapper which will, supposedly, allow me to use the wintel binary drivers.
> 
> You may have to go a similar route.  If so, try googling "ndiswrapper" and linksys. I found a couple of forums where folks gave step-by-step instructions.
> 

Note that ndiswrapper only works for 32bit versions of Linux.  It is not
an option if you are using a 64 bit kernel.  (Like the one on my laptop
with the broadcomm wireless chipset.)

> Jim Hilsenteger
> 
> 
> 
> ----- Original Message -----

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Jan  5 18:50:28 2005
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed, 5 Jan 2005 18:50:28 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Playing .mid
Message-ID: <20050106025028.59373.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>

Oddly enough, I haven't yet been able to play .mid
files on Sarge. I have a Creative Labs PCI512 and
sound is generally working.

Kmid reports that it can't access /dev/sequencer
(which exists) and that another device is using it. I
have no idea what it means. (The error message here
causes a funny noise to play.)

TiMidity has been my strength and refuge on other UNIX
clones, including SuSE and FreeBSD. When I install it
using apt-get, however, what do I get? It's looking
for a freepats.cfg file in /etc/timidity that's not
there, and what I thought was a default file I found
on the Web doesn't work. I'm not particular about
which application I use, but the compactness of .mid
files encourages their widespread use, and I don't
want to be without this functionality.

Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/


From aaron at bavariati.org  Wed Jan  5 19:07:57 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed, 5 Jan 2005 19:07:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
In-Reply-To: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A979315232E@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>
References: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A979315232E@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>
Message-ID: <20050106030757.GA20126@bavariati.org>

On Wed, Jan 05, 2005 at 03:03:28PM -0800, Hoult, Harlan wrote:
> With all of the glowing comments about Debian on this list I just had to
> switch my Dell C800 from dual boot XP/FC1 to XP/Debian. Currently I have
> beat it into submission except for wireless, which I haven't been able to
> get working. Where I am at:
> 
> - Sarge with kernel 2.6.8 using netinstall
> - the card is a Linksys WPC11 ver. 3

Should work with the linux-wlan-ng drivers, which are in Sarge.
Unfortunately, those are only compiled against the 2.4 kernel.  
I run 2.6 and compile my own from: 
ftp://ftp.linux-wlan.org/pub/linux-wlan-ng/


Good luck,
  Aaron

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Jan  5 21:31:03 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Wed, 05 Jan 2005 21:31:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Playing .mid
In-Reply-To: <20050106025028.59373.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050106025028.59373.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1104989464.5217.7.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Wed, 2005-01-05 at 18:50 -0800, Robert Kopp wrote:
> Oddly enough, I haven't yet been able to play .mid
> files on Sarge. I have a Creative Labs PCI512 and
> sound is generally working.
> 
> Kmid reports that it can't access /dev/sequencer
> (which exists) and that another device is using it. I
> have no idea what it means. (The error message here
> causes a funny noise to play.)

Try `/usr/sbin/lsof /dev/sequencer` to find out what has it open.

If you do not have lsof installed, you should.  it is a very useful
debugging tool.

It looks like the CTL refurbs are priced fairly.

>>>>> "Don" == Don Buchholz <buchholz at easystreet.com> writes:

Russell> This is just a plain-jane Intel P3 motherboard with
Russell> integrated video, lan, and sound.  The only PCI card in it is
Russell> an old NCR SCSI and it has one hard disk and a floppy.  The
Russell> power supply is probably just 250W (or maybe 300W) and has
Russell> been chugging along reliably for about 3 or 4 years.  The
Russell> tape drive is external, and the only thing on the SCSI bus.

Don> Any chance some "power management" features in the BIOS are
Don> turned on?

I didn't change *anything* in the BIOS on the box and it was just up
for 280 days straight.  And of course, without a monitor I can't
confirm what the BIOS settings are.

I got to four-for-four this evening, but it failed early enough that I
was able to get in and take a look.  No oops.  I was able to confirm
lack of fan noise.  The reset button did nothing.  The front panel
switch did nothing.  I had to power off with the power supply rocker
switch and then back on to get it to come back up.

I tried to get it to fail while I was watching, by running the tape
forwards and backwards while running bonnie, etc, but naturally it was
fine then.  It's been up for about 4 hours now, rerunning a tape
backup, so maybe I'll shatter my perfect record just to make diagnosis
even less tractable.

I even shut off the power going to the UPS, and the UPS held it up
fine for the 20 seconds or so of my test.

If I can't think of anything else, maybe I'll try the power supply.
And given the symptoms, it seems plausible, but what is the trigger??
why doesn't it fail all the time rather than just in the middle of the
night?  A little voodoo here and there is acceptable, but please, no
one suggest that I defragment my hard disk.


--

Specs and description from the manufacturers site

Description: Designed for the discriminating professional, the CTL 7Tx 17" LCD 
flat panel monitor is on the cutting edge of Monitor technology. The CTL 7Tx 
17" LCD flat panel monitor incorporates power user features such as 
integrated speakers and dual DVI/Analog input with a stylish black and silver 
design that clearly sets this monitor apart. Max resolution 1280 x 1024. 

Specs:  TFT  	 Type  	 Amorphous Active Matrix
	Viewable Size 	17 Inch (Diagonal)
  	Resolution 	1280 x 1024
	Backlight 	4 Lamps
  	Color Depth 	16.7 Million colors
	Contrast Ratio 	450:1
	Viewing Angle 	(H)+-75?/(V)+-70? (CR>=10) Typ.
	Response Time 	16ms
	Luminance 	260 cd/m2
	Mulimode Supported 		VGA,SVGA,XGA,SXGA,VESA,NEC,APPLE
	Signal Input 	Video Input 	Analogue RGB
	(H/V) Freq. 	(H)24-80KHz/(V)56-75Hz
	Power Consumption 		On 54W Max / Off 5W Max
	Video Cable 		1.5M with 15-pin D-Sub Connector

	Phase, Clock, Auto-Expansion, Color Temp.,
	Auto-Center, Auto-Clock, Auto-Phase, Recal, Graph Text, Analog
	Brightness, Contrast

	Weight (Pounds) 		13.89 (Net)/ 18.96 (Gross)
	Safety and EMI 	  	UL, CUL, TUV/GS, T-Mark, ISO9241-3/-7/-8

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Jan  6 01:24:02 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 01:24:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Solution to an ugly ssh tunneling problem
Message-ID: <1105003442.14034.4.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>


I have an ssh tunnel that I use for piping mail to my laptop over a wifi
connection.

It stopped working, giving me weird errors about bind not being able to
bind the port.  (But not telling me which end of the tunnel it could not
bind.)

It turns out "lo" had gotten unbound from 127.0.0.1 and had to be
reconnected.

I have seen this happen once before.

I have no clue why it happens.  It causes all sorts of subtle nastiness
when it does.

/sbin/ifconfig lo 127.0.0.1
route add -host 127.0.0.1 lo

fixed the problem.
-- 
"If any sign of pleasure is exhibited,
 report to me and it will be prohibited.
 So shall it be! This is the Land of the Free!"
                  - George W. Firefly

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jan  6 08:07:54 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 08:07:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Tape Drives and Power Supplies ( was strange crashes ... )
Message-ID: <20050106160754.GA18405@gate.kl-ic.com>


Russell Senior is having problems with his computer during tape backups.
The power supply VERY likely is the problem, but the tape drive may also
be the problem.  And it WILL behave strangely.  I have seen system 
failures because of tape drives, at odd times in odd ways.

Unless a tape drive is designed specifically with power supply
friendliness in mind, it is probably the nastiest power load in your
box.  The problem is that it takes a heap of energy to get a spool full
of tape moving.   Motors have a phenomena called "slip", which is 
where the rotating magnetic field moves but the mechanical part isn't
moving as fast.  Worst case is when the motor is just starting.
Electically, a stopped motor has infinite slip and looks like a dead
short, and if the tape drive designer is clueless, they will connect
this shorted motor directly to the 12V supply, causing large currents
to flow during startup, limited only by the circuit and wiring resistance.

Another way to think about it for a motor is that current causes force,
velocity causes voltage.  That is why the lights dim when a refrigerator
motor stops up from zero velocity;  it thinks it is a short circuit.
And that is why "green" motor controllers are cool - these electronic
gizzies convert high-voltage low-amp grid power to low-voltage high-amp
motor startup power, improving efficiency and reducing voltage sag.

What this means to your debugging process is that the amount of tape on
each spool will affect the inertia of the tape, and hence the time and
acceleration and force and voltage and current drawn.  So depending on
where the tape is on the spool, it may fail or not.  Combined, of course,
with the power draw for the CPU and everything else, which is dependent
on what kinds of computation it is doing.  And whether the heads are
seeking on the hard drive.  Etc.  Etc.

Even worse, something in that cabinet could be close to failure.  One 
of the power transistors in a motor controller or a drive servo could
be partly shorted, and drawing a lot of excess current during some
motion operation.  

And if that wasn't enough, there is a question of power regulation. 
Historically, PC power supplies were made to regulate on only one
supply (usually 5V), and the 12V and other supplies were left to flop
around in tandem with the power needs of the 5V supply.  So if the
5V power draw jumped from 10 amps to 20 amps, the power supply would
work harder, and cause the +12V supply to increase voltage a little
bit (or a large bit) as a result.  The power supply would make little
response to a 12V power surge, besides sagging.  I assume more modern
supplies are not as "5V centric".

And to add insult to injury, there is the "winter" problem.  Remember
the power sag associated with motor starts?  That happens with your
furnace motor, too.  When it kicks in early in the morning, while the
tape drive is starting and stopping and the heads are thrashing and
the CPU is calculating MD5 checksums and the like, the power surges and
voltage sags added together can cause some power supplies to give up.

The solution to all these problems is to GET A BIGGER POWER SUPPLY.
*Especially* a bigger supply on the 12V rail, which is the one that
gets all the power variation from tape drive and head seek motors.
MORE AMPS!

Then, if there IS a problem with excess power draw in a failing
motor controller circuit, it will have less effect on power supply
operation.  It also means that power will be available to finish
toasting any balky power transistors on your drives, making further
debugging easy - look for smoke!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> wrote:

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Thu Jan  6 09:01:34 2005

Subject: [PLUG] FTP Client Recommendations
Message-ID: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

For a number of years, I've been hand building my web sites with a text 
editor, but transferring them to my space on Comcast using Dreamweaver's ftp 
tool. For my next project, I'm endeavoring to remain completely winfree. So 
for, I've succeeded, having developed the site using a Linux text editor 
(Kate), and have been testing it on my local Apache server.

I will soon want to post it to one of my Comcast sites. I recall from previous 
discussions on this list that plain ftp is a less preferred alternative, but 
don't recall what is preferred. From the list archives I see mentions of 
SFTP, ncftp, and IglooFTP. What do you folks use for an ftp client, 
particularly anyone who is also maintaining a Comcast user web site?

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Jan  6 09:07:36 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 09:07:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FTP Client Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
References: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200501060907.36729.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 06 January 2005 9:01 am, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> I will soon want to post it to one of my Comcast sites. I recall from > 
previous 
> discussions on this list that plain ftp is a less preferred alternative, but 
> don't recall what is preferred. From the list archives I see mentions of 
> SFTP, ncftp, and IglooFTP. What do you folks use for an ftp client, 
> particularly anyone who is also maintaining a Comcast user web site?
> 

Command-line FTP is really obnoxious, IMO, unless you're scripting something. 
A nice graphical client is fast and easy. I like gftp, though you'll probably 
find there are a lot of good FTP clients. gftp has a bookmark feature that 
lets you saves your logins, and automatically switches to whatever local 
directory you like. A nice timesaver. gftp also supports SSH and HTTP 
transfers.

--

From plug at merlot.com  Thu Jan  6 09:09:52 2005
From: plug at merlot.com (plug at merlot.com)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 09:09:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FTP Client Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
References: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20050106170952.GP15130@merlot.com>

Richard C. Steffens (rsteff.l at comcast.net) typed this ...
> For a number of years, I've been hand building my web sites with a text 
> editor, but transferring them to my space on Comcast using Dreamweaver's ftp 
> tool. For my next project, I'm endeavoring to remain completely winfree. So 
> for, I've succeeded, having developed the site using a Linux text editor 
> (Kate), and have been testing it on my local Apache server.

If you're using Kate, you're probably using KDE, right? There's a
fantastic IDE for web projects called Quanta, written by a Portlander
even. I just updated to 3.3.1 yesterday, but I've been using it for
about 4 years and it just keeps getting better. 

One of the features it inherits from KDE is the ability to load and save
project files (HTML, scripts, CSS, etc.) via any installed kioslave. I
use the 'fish' kioslave (ssh/scp) almost exclusively, but one client
requires the use of ftp. 

> I will soon want to post it to one of my Comcast sites. I recall from previous 
> discussions on this list that plain ftp is a less preferred alternative, but 
> don't recall what is preferred. From the list archives I see mentions of 
> SFTP, ncftp, and IglooFTP. What do you folks use for an ftp client, 
> particularly anyone who is also maintaining a Comcast user web site?

It's not the ftp program that is a problem, it's the ftp protocol,
specifically cleartext logins and the requirement for PASV connections
from behind a NAT router. Some NAT routers handle the FTP connections
better than others...

If Comcast only supports FTP, it doesn't matter what you use. I think
you can use fish in the file save dialog on Kate if they support ssh, or
ftp if they don't.

E.g. file/save as, in the 'Location' box enter
ftp://my.comcast.server/dir/path/file.html and save it. Easy.

--Kurt
--

    Merlot Research Group, Inc               http://www.merlot.com
