From plug at merlot.com  Thu Jan  6 09:46:08 2005
From: plug at merlot.com (plug at merlot.com)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 09:46:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FTP Client Recommendations
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501060910460.18000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <200501060901.34223.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501060910460.18000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050106174608.GR15130@merlot.com>

Rich Shepard (rshepard at appl-ecosys.com) typed this ...
>   I've used only ncftp and it's great. You can automate 'puts' and 'gets',
> take up where a download left off and more. Stable, solid, secure and highly
> functional.

A nice thing about ncftp is that you can build a Makefile to send over
only the files that have changed since you last updated. You'll have to
have a shell open, but that shouldn't be a problem, right?

By using 'touch -r file .filedep' (replace 'file' with the filename) you
can set up a rule that copies only changed files. 

Makefiles are not just for C code...

--Kurt

    Merlot Research Group, Inc               http://www.merlot.com

                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                    7 PM Thursday Jan 6, 2005
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)

      **********************************************************
          
                                 PRESENTATION

                               An Introduction
                                      to
                    High Performance Cluster File Systems

                                      by

                                 Michael Ewan
                          Senior Systems Programmer
                              Intel Corporation
                            michael.ewan at intel.com



      This will be an overview of High Performance Cluster File 
      Systems including storage aggregation, high performance file 
      servers using protocols other than NFS, and availale free 
      cluster file systems such as PVFS, PVFS2, Lustre, and commercial 
      offerings such as GPFS, GFS, CXFS, TerraScale and Ibrix Fusion.

      **********************************************************

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects 
                   including PLUG's monthly Advanced Topics meetings, 
                   PLUG's monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for Education,
                   etc.
                   Microsharp is no longer hosting pdxLinux.org.
                   This task has gone to our good friends at 
                   www.NakedApe.cc.  We will discuss the going 
                   conversion to their server(s).

                   on room reservations for 2005.

                   future meetings.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan  6 10:25:10 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 06 Jan 2005 10:25:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Tape Drives and Power Supplies ( was strange crashes ... )
In-Reply-To: <20050106160754.GA18405@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050106160754.GA18405@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <86acrmxvnd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> Russell Senior is having problems with his computer during tape
Keith> backups.  The power supply VERY likely is the problem, but the
Keith> tape drive may also be the problem.  And it WILL behave
Keith> strangely.  I have seen system failures because of tape drives,
Keith> at odd times in odd ways.

Keith> Unless a tape drive is designed specifically with power supply
Keith> friendliness in mind, it is probably the nastiest power load in
Keith> your box.  [...]

The only problem with this scenario I see is that the tape drive is an
external unit and it is being powered independently from the computer,
but it is the computer that is powering "off".  Is it plausible that a
problem in the tape drive could affect the box across the SCSI bus
(through an external cable)?  After a few hours of tape operation?

I am not against swapping out the power supply, as it might have
incidental benefits, but the more you describe the scenario where it
might be the problem, the less it seems to match my observables.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jan  6 10:39:39 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 10:39:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: strange crashes/power-offs
Message-ID: <20050106183939.GA19262@gate.kl-ic.com>


Russell Senior and his amazing disappearing computer continued ...


Although Russell's problem sounds like the PC power supply, another 
source of strange crashes in the early morning that appears this time
of year is weak batteries on the UPS.  We discussed this source of
"scheduled" crashes on the PLUG list about this time last year.

The cause is similar; power line sags from furnace blowers turning on. 
The specific pathway is different - the sags cause the UPS to kick in,
attempting to draw battery power that is no longer there due to weak
batteries.  You can test for this - make sure your whole computer
setup is properly grounded, and your UPS is connected to power through
a switched power strip.  Turn off the power strip.  See what happens.

Rich led a recent discussion about the replacement of UPS batteries.
Refer to that if you end up needing replacements.

- - - - -

BTW, this is an opportunity to write a bit of useful software.  PC
laptops can sense when the AC adapter is no longer providing power,
and this information is available to the O.S., causing a switchover
from charge to discharge mode.  So if the line power sag is extreme,
enough to trip the switchover, the exact time of the event can be
logged.  With my thinkpad T30 laptop, this effect can be enhanced. 
The T30 is designed for a 72W AC adapter, but it is plug compatable
with the 35W adapters for older Thinkpads.  When the power even flickers
using one of those old adapters, it toggles the switchover on the PC. 
Quite distressing to watch, clicking in and out 5 times a minute, with
the power-saver on the screen dimming and brightening ...

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

frustration with not being able to finish, the move.

wordprocessing, macros, and boiler-plate to OpenOffice or WordPerfect on 
Linux.

Informix SE (v4.x) and SCO Integra database applications.  The problem 
is not the databases themselves. He has Oracle and MySQL databases 
running on his Linux server.  The problem is he really needs a means to 
migrate the ton of Informix/Integra forms and reports.  He just can not 
afford the time/money required to rewrite all this. Ideally, he wants to 
run a Linux version/replacement of Informix and/or Integra that would 
only require recompiling and minor fixes to get things working.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jan  6 11:00:50 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 11:00:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Tape Drives and Power Supplies ( was strange crashes ... )
In-Reply-To: <86acrmxvnd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050106160754.GA18405@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<86acrmxvnd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20050106190050.GA19396@gate.kl-ic.com>

> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:
> 
> Keith> Unless a tape drive is designed specifically with power supply
> Keith> friendliness in mind, it is probably the nastiest power load in
> Keith> your box.  [...]

On Thu, Jan 06, 2005 at 10:25:10AM -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> The only problem with this scenario I see is that the tape drive is an
> external unit and it is being powered independently from the computer,
> ...

Huh.  Well, one theory all shot to hell ... ;-)

Check the note I just sent out about UPS battery failures.  While a
voltage sag in the tape box can lock up the SCSI bus (I have seen that
happen), I've never seen it take out the whole OS.  Unless your disks
are on the same SCSI bus, too, in which case all sorts of nonsense
can result.

Associated story of tapes in external boxes:  I have a largish heap
of old DC300/DC600 cartridge tapes, with lots of tiny little backup 
images on them.  To copy them onto disk, I built "tapezilla", an
external box with 4 half-height drives in it.  The power supply in
the box was designed for one tape and one disk.  I found I could only
reliably read two tape drives at once - three or more would sag the
supply and hang the SCSI bus.  The connected Linux box stayed up 
just fine after the SCSI hang, though it needed to be power-cycled
to clear the hang.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Randall,

   Not advice, but suggestions. Python has a module that integrates with
postgres; not sure about the others. It also has a selection of UI
development tools. There is also gambas <http://gambas.sourceforge.net/>, a
better Visual Basic for linux that can be used to develop forms and reports.
Unfortunately, it will cost time and/or money to move to anything other than
what he has.

   For a word processor, go with OO.o. The last I read, Microsoft bought a
stake in Corel to help save the company, insisted that WP/Linux be killed,
then pulled their financial interest out. Classic Microsoft. OO.o is the
future for an office suite.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan  6 11:40:15 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 06 Jan 2005 11:40:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: strange crashes/power-offs
In-Reply-To: <20050106183939.GA19262@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050106183939.GA19262@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <86652axs68.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> [...] You can test for this - make sure your whole computer
Keith> setup is properly grounded, and your UPS is connected to power
Keith> through a switched power strip.  Turn off the power strip.  See
Keith> what happens.

For what it's worth, I tried exactly this (I think this was even
during a tape operation) and got nary a flicker on the computer or the
tape drive.

The tape drive *is* plugged into the same rather small UPS (an APC
Backup-UPS ES 500, I think), so it is possible that some high-torque
tape operation plausibly could overload the UPS and kill the computer.
Wouldn't that be likely to blow a fuse in the tape drive though?  We
are planning to try to swap in a different tape drive (another Seagate
STD624000N) and see what comes out the other side.

On the other hand, I repeatedly ran 'mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1 ; mt -f
/dev/nst0 rewind' last night while I was there and nothing nefarious
occurred.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jan  6 11:53:46 2005
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 06 Jan 2005 11:53:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Preferences?
In-Reply-To: <1105031993.10840.16.camel@nessus.chemeketa.edu>
References: <1105031993.10840.16.camel@nessus.chemeketa.edu>
Message-ID: <41DD974A.60102@dimstar.net>

Jeff Moore wrote:

>Hi all,
>
> Just a quick question as to what firewall software or iptables scripts
>you all recommend. I am looking to upgrade one of my machines to a 2.6
>kernel and I think I have evolved enough that I dont need to have any X
>programs running on the new system. I want to get rid of that GUI
>crutch... ;)
>
> I currently use a really nice KDE program called guarddog along with
>guidedog for ip masquerading and I dont want to lose the granularity
>that I have with these. I have been doing a little reading and gshield
>seems to get a bit of press. 
>
Are you running a firewall on a separate box?

I recommend ipcop (www.ipcop.org). It has minimal hardware requirements, 
configures with a web based gui, and just generally runs once it's set 
up. On top of that, it's linux, and you have full control through ssh if 
you so desire. It's in active development, so updates are coming out as 
needed.

One of the advantages of a firewall distribution is that it's ONLY a 
firewall. It's not trying to be a print/file/mail/etc server as well. 
Services don't belong on a firewall. :)

I've been using it for over a year now.

Russ

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Jan  6 15:08:48 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 15:08:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SCO Insight
In-Reply-To: <20050106194115.5E3F95B35@ulke.nakedape.cc>

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Thu Jan  6 15:34:49 2005
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 16:34:49 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Using variables for procmail matches
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501061615420.6841-100000@gisnet.com>

I'm trying to get a Procmail recipe to use a variable in the match
expression, but I can't seem too get it to expand correctly. It works with
egrep (which is what I thought Procmail uses), but I can't make it work in 
Procmail. Here's a short example:

# This recipe is supposed to catch any mail that has the string "pills" 
# in it, with the 'i' spelled in any one of the spammish variations.

FILT_=[i1jl:\!|]
:0:
* 1^0 HB ?? p${FILT_}lls
TESTFOLDER


But it doesn't seem to work. It appears that it is comparing against the 
literal string "p{FILT_}lls", not the string "p[i1jl:\!|]lls" 

This doesn't work either:

FILT=p[i1jl:\!|]lls
:0B:
* $FILT_
TESTFOLDER

How do I get it to expand that FILT_ variable?

I've searched the man pages (procmailrc, procmailsc, procmailex, etc.) and
tried various combinations of "procmail match variables" on Google, but I
think I don't know how to search for this because I don't know the
terminology.

I'm using Procmail 3.22 on RH 9.

Can anyone here help?

TIA,
- Bill Thoen

Bill,

   The metacharacter '.*' should match 0 or more of anything. I'd try:
                                    p[.*]ll

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Thu Jan  6 16:27:17 2005
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 17:27:17 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Using variables for procmail matches
In-Reply-To: <1105054108.1092.69.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501061702420.6841-100000@gisnet.com>

On Thu, 6 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

> On Thu, 2005-01-06 at 15:23 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >    The metacharacter '.*' should match 0 or more of anything. I'd try:
> >                                     p[.*]ll
> 
> That will catch pull, poll, pll, pall, pyll, powerfull, etc.... 
> 
> Is that what's wanted?

Actually no. I'm trying to use a variable because I'd rather not hard code
the test string for every occurrence of 'i' spelled sideways, or e (as in
[e3]) or 'o' (as in [o0].)  The reason I'd like to do this with a variable
is so I can change the string easily from one place should I want to...  
and it's less to type if I can get it to work. For example, if I have
variables like:

I_=[i1jl:\!|]
A_=[a at 4]

Then I can use filters like v${I_}${A_}gr${A_}, or even
v.?${I_}.?${A_}.?g.?r.?${A_}, and catch every madly spelled reference to
the little blue quicker dicker upper so I can trash the message
automatically. I don't want to filter too loosely like ".*" would
(although that would work, it would literally be throwing the baby out
with the bath water.)

But I'm not even sure if Procmail allows variable expansion in the match
conditions. Like I said, I've searched and found no reference to that, but
as the lawyers say, "Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence."

- Bill Thoen

>   A fellow in Alabama posted a request for help on the SQL-Leger mail list

> SQL-Ledger on linux for his paper distribution business.

Actually, he is in Arkansas, but not that it really matters. :)
 
>   Being the curious sort I wrote and asked if he was leaving SCO for linux
> all-together. He replied that he is; that from what he's learned he thinks
> it's in his best interests. For comparison, he told me that the previous
> owner paid $33,000 for the Maytech accounting/inventory software, plus $425
> per month. Now they're raising the monthly protection payment to $550 and
> he's decided that's enough.

I am the one who steered him in this direction. A little over a year ago, I helped move his database from an old Motorola w/ System V to his way overpriced system that he has now running SCO. He got a real bad taste in his mouth after spending so much money on the new system, and the software company couldn't even move his data from one system to another. I had to figure it out for them. You can actually check the archives on PLUG for SysV networking where I was trying to figure it all out. 

Once our test system is fully functional, I will be formating SCO off his drive and installing Debian, then moving all info from the test system. Once the whole project is complete, he will only have one M$ machine to run his FedEx software and that's it. Mission "almost" completed.
 
>   I have been wondering if the mad-SCO disease is causing existing customers
> to abandon the company and, at least this one is. I thought it was
> interesting and worth while sharing with you. And, look at the cost savings!

The mad-SCO disease definately had an impact on his decision, plus the fact that there was an available solution with in Linux. And yes, his savings will be huge. Even after paying me. :)

Jeff

P.S. I know it doesn't really matter, but if your wondering why someone from Arkansas is on the PLUG list, I actually cut my first teeth on Linux while living in Portland. PLUG was the first list I joined, and I attended several meetings while there.

expression? Something like the following?

MYVAR=[ilj1:]
:0:
* 1^0 HB ?? p${MYVAR}lls
TESTFOLDER

and I have several words I'm looking for that need to make one or more
tests for alternate spellings of 'i'.

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jan  6 17:25:39 2005
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)

Subject: [PLUG] Using variables for procmail matches

On Thu, 06 Jan 2005, Bill Thoen wrote: 
> On Thu, 6 Jan 2005, Sandy Herring wrote:
> 
> > :0:
> > * 1^0 HB ?? p(i|1|j|l|:|!|\|)lls
> > TESTFOLDER
> > 
> > should work.
> 
> Yes, but I must not be making myself clear. This works too, no problem:
> :0:
> * 1^0 HB ?? p[i1jl:\!|]lls
> TESTFOLDER
> 
> But I don't want it hard-coded. I'm hoping there's a way that I can use a 
> varialble for alternate character expressions in square brackets.
> Is it possible to set a variable that can be expanded in the match 
> expression? Something like the following?

Okay. Try...

I_='(i|1|j|l|:|!|\|)'
PILL_="P($I_)ll(s)?"
:0:
* 1^0 HB ?? $PILL_
TESTFOLDER
 
> MYVAR=[ilj1:]
> :0:
> * 1^0 HB ?? p${MYVAR}lls
> TESTFOLDER
> 
> In reality, the definition of MYVAR will be at the top of a long recipe
> and I have several words I'm looking for that need to make one or more
> tests for alternate spellings of 'i'.
> 
> > You'll find plenty of online resources that are somewhat less cryptic
> > than the `man' pages. Here's a start...
> > 
> > http://www.herring.org/techie.html#procmail

> Thanks! I'll check it out directly.

You're welcome. pm.tips is one of the better resources.

From bthoen at gisnet.com  Thu Jan  6 18:03:01 2005
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 19:03:01 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Using variables for procmail matches
In-Reply-To: <20050107012539.GB29594@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501061856000.7163-100000@gisnet.com>

On Thu, 6 Jan 2005, Sandy Herring wrote:

> Okay. Try...
> 
> I_='(i|1|j|l|:|!|\|)'
> PILL_="P($I_)ll(s)?"
> :0:
> * 1^0 HB ?? $PILL_
> TESTFOLDER

I thought of that, but it dint work. Same problem. The variable is not 
expanded.

But I *think* I may have found it deep under your Procmail tips page. I'm 
looking at an Aug 25 message from the Procmail mailing list. Here's the 
relevant bit:

> Yes.  It's in the procmailrc(5) man page.  Put an extra dollar sign at 
> the beginning of the condition, like so:
> 
>   # make sure my email address is in the To: header
>   * $ ^To:.*$LOGNAME@
> 
> That will make procmail do variable substitution (for later dollar
> signs) and command substitution (for backquotes) on the condition before
> using it.

 
That looks like what I'm searching for... I'll know in a few minutes...

- Bill




From bthoen at gisnet.com  Thu Jan  6 18:23:36 2005
From: bthoen at gisnet.com (Bill Thoen)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 19:23:36 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Using variables for procmail matches
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501061856000.7163-100000@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0501061905320.7276-100000@gisnet.com>

On Thu, 6 Jan 2005, Bill Thoen wrote:

> But I *think* I may have found it deep under your Procmail tips page. I'm 
> looking at an Aug 25 message from the Procmail mailing list. Here's the 
> relevant bit:
> 
> > Yes.  It's in the procmailrc(5) man page.  Put an extra dollar sign at 
> > the beginning of the condition, like so:
> > 
> >   # make sure my email address is in the To: header
> >   * $ ^To:.*$LOGNAME@
> > 
> > That will make procmail do variable substitution (for later dollar
> > signs) and command substitution (for backquotes) on the condition before
> > using it.

Bingo! That's it! Here's how I managed to fix my earlier script.

# This Procmail script will catch all messages with the string 
# "pills" in the body.

# create a varible that contains alternate spellings for 'i'
I_=[i1lj:\!|]

# the '$' by itself in the front of the match expresion
# tells Procmail to expand following variables
:0B:
* 1^0 $ p${I_}lls
TESTFOLDER

Still haven't figured out where to place the '$' in the following (it's 
not all that obvious):
:0:
* 1^0 HB ?? p${I_}lls
TESTFOLDER

But I guess now at least I have a key...

- Bill Thoen




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jan  6 20:17:18 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 20:17:18 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501062009350.3371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   I'd scratch my head over this but I cannot afford the hair loss. My
newish Slackware-10 box boots only part way. That is, only some of the
daemons called to be started by /etc/rc.d/rc.M are; it stops after calling
postfix.

   It doesn't start anything after that (including what's in rc.local). But,
after logging in as boot I can manually start each daemon with no problem.
The file rc.M is attached.

   In the years I've been running linux I've not encountered this. All the
daemons are executable and owned by root.root. As you'll see in rc.M, it is
only executable files that are invoked with the 'start' command.

   Why a text file should execute part of the way, then stop and complete the
boot process to a login prompt is beyond my understanding. This past Monday
I sent a request for help to support at slackware.com but have not seen
anything from anyone there. My experience with comp.os.linux.slackware has
been less than satisfactory. I know that we have the premier group of
SysAdmins here on this list so I would appreciate insight or suggestions
that will lead me to understand what's broken so I can fix it.

Many thanks,

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863
-------------- next part --------------
#!/bin/sh
#
# rc.M		This file is executed by init(8) when the system is being
#		initialized for one of the "multi user" run levels (i.e.
#		levels 1 through 6).  It usually does mounting of file
#		systems et al.
#
# Version:	@(#)/etc/rc.d/rc.M	2.23	Wed Feb 26 19:20:58 PST 2003
#
# Author:	Fred N. van Kempen, <waltje at uwalt.nl.mugnet.org>
#		Heavily modified by Patrick Volkerding <volkerdi at slackware.com>
#

# Tell the viewers what's going to happen.
echo "Going multiuser..."

# Screen blanks after 15 minutes idle time, and powers down in one hour
# if the kernel supports APM or ACPI power management:
/bin/setterm -blank 15 -powersave powerdown -powerdown 60

# Set the hostname.
if [ -r /etc/HOSTNAME ]; then
  /bin/hostname $(cat /etc/HOSTNAME | cut -f1 -d .)
else
  # fall back on this old default:
  echo "darkstar.example.net" > /etc/HOSTNAME
  /bin/hostname darkstar
fi

# Save the contents of 'dmesg':
/bin/dmesg -s 65536 > /var/log/dmesg

# Start the system logger.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.syslog -a -x /usr/sbin/syslogd -a -d /var/log ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.syslog start
fi

# Initialize PCMCIA devices:
#
# NOTE: This used to be started near the top of rc.S so that PCMCIA devices
# could be fsck'ed along with the other drives.  This had some unfortunate
# side effects, however, since root isn't yet read-write, and /var might not
# even be mounted the .pid files can't be correctly written in /var/run and
# the pcmcia system can't be correctly shut down.  If you want some PCMCIA
# partition to be mounted at boot (or when the card is inserted) then add
# the appropriate lines to /etc/pcmcia/scsi.opts.
#
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia ] ; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia start
  # The cards might need a little extra time here to initialize.
  if [ -r /var/run/cardmgr.pid ]; then
    sleep 5
  fi
fi

# Initialize the networking hardware.  If your network driver is a module
# and you haven't loaded it manually, this will be deferred until after
# the hotplug system loads the module below.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.inet1 ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.inet1
fi

# Initialize the hotplugging subsystem for Cardbus, IEEE1394, PCI, and USB devices:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.hotplug -a -r /proc/modules ]; then
  # Don't run hotplug if 'nohotplug' was given at boot.
  if ! grep nohotplug /proc/cmdline 1> /dev/null 2> /dev/null ; then
    echo "Activating hardware detection:  /etc/rc.d/rc.hotplug start"
    . /etc/rc.d/rc.hotplug start
  fi
fi

# Start networking daemons:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.inet2 ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.inet2
fi

# Remove stale locks and junk files (must be done after mount -a!)
# /usr/local/pgsql/data/postmaster.pid added by RBS 2005-01-01
/bin/rm -f /var/lock/* /var/spool/uucp/LCK..* /tmp/.X*lock /usr/local/pgsql/data/postmaster.pid /tmp/core /core 2> /dev/null 

# Remove stale hunt sockets so the game can start.
if [ -r /tmp/hunt -o -r /tmp/hunt.stats ]; then
  echo "Removing your stale hunt sockets from /tmp."
  /bin/rm -f /tmp/hunt*
fi

# Ensure basic filesystem permissions sanity.
chmod 755 / 2> /dev/null
chmod 1777 /tmp /var/tmp

# Update all the shared library links:
if [ -x /sbin/ldconfig ]; then
  echo "Updating shared library links:  /sbin/ldconfig"
  /sbin/ldconfig
fi

# Update the X font indexes:
if [ -x /usr/X11R6/bin/fc-cache ]; then
  echo "Updating X font indexes:  /usr/X11R6/bin/fc-cache"
  /usr/X11R6/bin/fc-cache
fi

# Start the print spooling system.  This will usually be LPRng (lpd) or CUPS.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.cups ]; then
  # Start CUPS:
  /etc/rc.d/rc.cups start
elif [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.lprng ]; then
  # Start LPRng (lpd):
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.lprng start
fi

# Start netatalk. (a file/print server for Macs using Appletalk)
#if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.atalk ]; then
#  /etc/rc.d/rc.atalk
#fi

# Start smartd, which monitors the status of S.M.A.R.T. compatible
# hard drives and reports any problems.  Note some devices (which aren't
# smart, I guess ;) will hang if probed by smartd, so it's commented out
# by default.
if [ -x /usr/sbin/smartd ]; then
  /usr/sbin/smartd
fi

# Monitor the UPS with genpowerd.
# To use this, uncomment this section and edit your settings in
# /etc/genpowerd.conf (serial device, UPS type, etc).  For more information,
# see "man genpowerd" or the extensive documentation in the
# /usr/doc/genpower-1.0.3 directory.
# You'll also need to configure a similar block in /etc/rc.d/rc.6 if you want
# support for stopping the UPS's inverter after the machine halts.
#if [ -x /sbin/genpowerd ]; then
#  echo "Starting genpowerd daemon..."
#  /sbin/genpowerd
#fi

# Turn on process accounting.  To enable process accounting, make sure the
# option for BSD process accounting is enabled in your kernel, and then
# create the file /var/log/pacct (touch /var/log/pacct).  By default, process
# accounting is not enabled (since /var/log/pacct does not exist).  This is
# because the log file can get VERY large.
if [ -x /sbin/accton -a -r /var/log/pacct ]; then
  /sbin/accton /var/log/pacct
  chmod 640 /var/log/pacct
  echo "Process accounting turned on."
fi

# Start crond (Dillon's crond):
# If you want cron to actually log activity to /var/log/cron, then change
# -l10 to -l8 to increase the logging level.
if [ -x /usr/sbin/crond ]; then
  /usr/sbin/crond -l10 >>/var/log/cron 2>&1
fi

# Start atd (manages jobs scheduled with 'at'):
if [ -x /usr/sbin/atd ]; then
  /usr/sbin/atd -b 15 -l 1
fi

# Slackware-Mini-Quota-HOWTO:
# To really activate quotas, you'll need to add 'usrquota' and/or 'grpquota' to
# the appropriate partitions as listed in /etc/fstab.  Here's an example:
#
# /dev/hda2      /home      ext3     defaults,usrquota      1   1
#
# You'll then need to setup initial quota files at the top of the partitions
# to support quota, like this:
# touch /home/aquota.user /home/aquota.group
# chmod 600 /home/aquota.user /home/aquota.group
#
# Then, reboot to activate the system.
# To edit user quotas, use 'edquota'.  See 'man edquota'.  Also, the
# official Quota Mini-HOWTO has lots of useful information.  That can be found
# here:  /usr/doc/Linux-HOWTOs/Quota

# Check quotas and then turn quota system on:
if grep -q quota /etc/fstab ; then
  if [ -x /sbin/quotacheck ]; then
    echo "Checking filesystem quotas:  /sbin/quotacheck -avugm"
    /sbin/quotacheck -avugm
  fi
  if [ -x /sbin/quotaon ]; then
    echo "Activating filesystem quotas:  /sbin/quotaon -avug"
    /sbin/quotaon -avug
  fi
fi

# Start the postfix daemon:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.postfix ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.postfix start
fi

# Start the sendmail daemon:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.sendmail ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.sendmail start
fi

# Start the APM daemon if APM is enabled in the kernel:
if [ -x /usr/sbin/apmd ]; then
  if cat /proc/apm 1> /dev/null 2> /dev/null ; then
    echo "Starting APM daemon:  /usr/sbin/apmd"
    /usr/sbin/apmd
  fi
fi

# Start the ACPI (Advanced Configuration and Power Interface) daemon:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.acpid ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.acpid start
fi

# Load ALSA (sound) defaults:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.alsa ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.alsa
fi

# Load a custom screen font if the user has an rc.font script.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.font ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.font
fi

# Load a custom keymap if the user has an rc.keymap script.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.keymap ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.keymap
fi

# Initialize HP Officejet support:
#if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.hpoj ]; then
#  . /etc/rc.d/rc.hpoj start
#fi

# Start the MySQL database:
#if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.mysqld ]; then
#  . /etc/rc.d/rc.mysqld start
#fi

# Start Apache web server:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.httpd ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.httpd start
  echo "Starting httpd ..."
fi

# Start Samba (a file/print server for Win95/NT machines).
# Samba can be started in /etc/inetd.conf instead.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.samba ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.samba start
  echo "Starting samba ..."
fi

# Start the GPM mouse server:
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.gpm ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.gpm start
  echo "Starting gpm ..."
fi

# Start spamd -- RBS 2005-01-01
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.spamassassin ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.spamassassin start
  echo "Starting spamd ..."
fi

# Start the database backend -- RBS 2005-01-01
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.postgresql ]; then 
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.postgresql start
  echo "Starting postgres ..."
fi

# Start the VMware daemons -- RBS 2005-01-01
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.vmware ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.vmware start
fi  

# If there are SystemV init scripts for this runlevel, run them.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.sysvinit ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.sysvinit
fi

# Start the local setup procedure.
if [ -x /etc/rc.d/rc.local ]; then
  . /etc/rc.d/rc.local
fi

# All done.

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Jan  6 20:40:43 2005
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 20:40:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501062009350.3371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501062009350.3371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200501062040.43540.griffint@pobox.com>

On Thursday 06 January 2005 8:17 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
>    I'd scratch my head over this but I cannot afford the hair loss.
> My newish Slackware-10 box boots only part way. That is, only some of
> the daemons called to be started by /etc/rc.d/rc.M are; it stops
> after calling postfix.
>
>    It doesn't start anything after that (including what's in
> rc.local). But, after logging in as boot I can manually start each
> daemon with no problem. The file rc.M is attached.
>
>    In the years I've been running linux I've not encountered this.
> All the daemons are executable and owned by root.root. As you'll see
> in rc.M, it is only executable files that are invoked with the
> 'start' command.
>
>    Why a text file should execute part of the way, then stop and
> complete the boot process to a login prompt is beyond my
> understanding. This past Monday I sent a request for help to
> support at slackware.com but have not seen anything from anyone there.
> My experience with comp.os.linux.slackware has been less than
> satisfactory. I know that we have the premier group of SysAdmins here
> on this list so I would appreciate insight or suggestions that will
> lead me to understand what's broken so I can fix it.
>
> Many thanks,
>
> Rich

Is this the normal Slackware rc.M? It's written in an odd way.
The leading dot before each /etc/rc.d/rc.whatever is making rc.M
vulnerable to the rc scripts terminating themselves with an "exit" 
command. If rc.postfix is terminating with an exit that would expain
what you are seeing.

When you start the services manually do you include the leading dot
or not? If not, try it again with the dot and see what happens when
you start postfix. If your shell closes then an exit in rc.postfix
is your problem.

Terry


From hhoult at cpcbsa.org  Thu Jan  6 20:44:48 2005
From: hhoult at cpcbsa.org (Hoult, Harlan)
Date: Thu, 6 Jan 2005 20:44:48 -0800 
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless on Sarge
Message-ID: <B25EB91B53A5CD46A39AB3A58E5A9793152359@172_17_23_15.c17.netbsa.org>

On Thurs, 5 Jan 2005, Derek Loree wrote:

> If iwconfig has it listed, then you are almost there.  A 
> correct entry in /etc/network/interfaces should do it.  What 
> didn't work about it? How are you testing?  What kind of 
> setup are you trying to do?
> 
> Please give us more to go on.

Sorry about the lack of information. I got it working by adding entries in
/etc/network/interfaces:
 auto eth2
 iface eth2 inet dhcp
 name wireless LAN card
 wireless_essid laptop

Then ifconfig eth2 up followed by pump. Even works on the reboot.

Thanks again everybody for all of your help.

Harlan

From dbridges at austin.rr.com  Fri Jan  7 07:28:35 2005
From: dbridges at austin.rr.com (David Bridges)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 09:28:35 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem

I don't have a slackware box around to help with your problem, but I 
believe the . is the equivalent of  running the command  "source 
some_file", basically it brings in all variables in the script and also 
runs all commands which are included in the script.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jan  7 07:53:40 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 07:53:40 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem
In-Reply-To: <CBE85580-60C0-11D9-B5E1-000D9334A220@austin.rr.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501062009350.3371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200501062040.43540.griffint@pobox.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070659100.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<CBE85580-60C0-11D9-B5E1-000D9334A220@austin.rr.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070752420.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   Well then, what's left out when the script is executed without the leading

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Jan  7 08:57:24 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 08:57:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 07 Jan 2005 07:53:40 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070752420.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20050107165729.6E1C68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

> On Fri, 7 Jan 2005, David Bridges wrote:
> 
> > I don't have a slackware box around to help with your problem, but I
> > believe the . is the equivalent of running the command "source some_file",
> > basically it brings in all variables in the script and also runs all
> > commands which are included in the script.
> 
> David,
> 
>    Well then, what's left out when the script is executed without the leading
> dot?
> 
>    I'm not challenging you, just trying to learn.
> 


With the leading dot the commands are executed within the current shell
process, thus an exit an would cause the script to exit.

Without the dot, the commands are executed in a new child process.  An
exit causes the child to exit, which causes the parent to resume execution
with the next line.

galen


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jan  7 09:06:09 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 09:06:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem 
In-Reply-To: <20050107165729.6E1C68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20050107165729.6E1C68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070902060.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 7 Jan 2005, Galen Seitz wrote:

> With the leading dot the commands are executed within the current shell
> process, thus an exit an would cause the script to exit.
>
> Without the dot, the commands are executed in a new child process.  An
> exit causes the child to exit, which causes the parent to resume execution
> with the next line.

galen,

   I just learned this from reading my ORA bash book (i.e., '.' == 'source')
and information about source. So, this leads to the obvious question: Why
are some daemon startup commands run within the current shell and some in a
subshell?

   Since sourcing the script will cause the shell to exit to a login prompt
when the script is completed, I wonder why this did not happen earlier in
the init process.

   While I'm still trying to grok the rationale for sourcing vs. running in a
subshell during boot, I'll look at rc.postfix and see how that's exiting
that's different from other scripts.

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Jan  7 11:21:58 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri, 07 Jan 2005 11:21:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Perplexing Boot Problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501071107430.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20050107165729.6E1C68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070902060.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070908130.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1105122960.1563.9.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501071107430.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1105125718.1563.19.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2005-01-07 at 11:10 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 7 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:
> 
> > Whatever rc.postfix you may have was written by something who isn't Pat.
>
>    That's true! It was written by Manolis Tzanidakis on 2003-08-28. It came
> as a gift when I upgraded the 2.1.4 installed postfix with the 2.1.5
> Slackware package from linuxpackages.net. Dummy me didn't compare init
> scripts at the time.

I would be somewhat careful dealing with lp.net packages.  After
conversing with Jim Simmons, the owner of linuxpackages.net, I really
have to question the quality.

There are no real controls in place.  Jim tests to make sure the
packages are in the format he likes.  The packages are *not* tested to
see if they contain any malicious code.

Additionally, Jim is an old-school script kiddie.  If you have an IRC
client installed, you might sit back and idle on #linuxpackages on
Freenode for a few days... it's rather... enlightening.

At first I didn't realize why he was intent on attacking SlackSec, but
after I got to know him a bit more, I realized it was because we didn't
even think of working together with lp.net, as our mission and
requirements were so different.

If you know and trust the packager from lp.net, great... keep using
it... but just be a bit careful is all.  The best way to install
something in Slackware if it doesn't come on the CDs is to compile it
from source.  :-)

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.

From bmurdock at gmail.com  Fri Jan  7 11:45:24 2005
From: bmurdock at gmail.com (Bryan Murdock)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 11:45:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] sourcing vs. running in a sub-shell
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070902060.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20050107165729.6E1C68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.60.0501070902060.13018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <477eba8c0501071145737fd876@mail.gmail.com>

On Fri, 7 Jan 2005 09:06:09 -0800 (PST), Rich Shepard
<rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>    While I'm still trying to grok the rationale for sourcing vs. running in a
> subshell during boot,

You source a script when you want it to modify your current shell
and/or environment, for example, setting an environment variable,
set-ing or unset-ing shell options, or adding aliases or functions.  A
script that tries to do any of those for you in a sub-shell that goes
away once the script exits won't be much help to you.

Bryan

Subject: [PLUG] tool for reading raw sectors from diskette?
Message-ID: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>


Does anyone know of a tool which I can use to read raw sectors from
a floppy diskette?  I've got one which apparently got mangled (won't
"dd if=/dev/fd0") and there's some stuff on there which is only
backed up via hardcopy.  I'd rather not re-enter the data.

individual sectors (perhaps via specification of head/cyl/sect #).

Thanks,
- Don



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jan  7 16:39:24 2005
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 16:39:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tool for reading raw sectors from diskette?
In-Reply-To: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
References: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <350-42287@sneakemail.com>

On Fri, 07 Jan 2005 15:46:02 -0800, Don Buchholz wrote:
 
> Does anyone know of a tool which I can use to read raw sectors from
> a floppy diskette?  I've got one which apparently got mangled (won't
> "dd if=/dev/fd0") and there's some stuff on there which is only
> backed up via hardcopy.  I'd rather not re-enter the data.

I apologize for the vague references-- if nobody comes up with
something better I'll dig around for more specifics.

I used to use a free tool for DOS that would read a floppy to an
image, bypassing the BIOS for speed.  One of its features was a
configurable number of error retries before giving up.  On moderately
damaged floppies, setting this to a few hundred gave pretty reliable
reads.  Eventually the floppy would be read in such a way that the
embedded ECC would correct the errors.

I can probably find the name of it given a 30-60 minute search through
my Ancient Software collection-- if nobody comes up with something
better.  ;-)

  -- Steve

Hi Don,

I've never had to do that, but I did some poking around and found this 
mini-Howto:

http://www.praeclarus.demon.co.uk/tech/e2-undel/howto.txt

It mentions a pprogram called fsgrab. I don't think it's exactly what 
you're looking for, but it may work. Maybe not if dd won't, though.

BTW, I found that link at the site for The Coroner's Toolkit, which 
jumped to my mind when I read your message:

http://www.fish.com/tct/

But Lazarus is also more oriented towards recovering deleted data from a 
working disk, I don't think it will be of help to you. It's cool, though :)

Good luck,


Rich






From techmage at aracnet.com  Fri Jan  7 19:32:19 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Slackware 10 ISO Install issues
Message-ID: <200501080332.j083WJTm029347@jade.spiritone.com>


HI,

I've been trying to get Slackware to install from the ISO cd I burned.
The cdrom sees the disc , but won't boot from it.
The Kernel gives an error that it can't find the cdrom, which is SCSI.
I've even tried several different CD -Rom drives, to no avail.
Is there a work around for this, like in the Suse 9.0 case were I built a set of
boot floppies?

TIA,

Harry





From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Jan  7 19:46:45 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Fri, 7 Jan 2005 19:46:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tool for reading raw sectors from diskette?
In-Reply-To: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
References: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <20050108034645.GA4345@patch.com>

Don Buchholz wrote:
> Does anyone know of a tool which I can use to read raw sectors from
> a floppy diskette?  

What about using dd with the options to just read N blocks after skipping 
X number?


       count=BLOCKS
              copy only BLOCKS input blocks
 
       of=FILE
              write to FILE instead of stdout
 
       seek=BLOCKS
              skip BLOCKS obs-sized blocks at start of output
 
       skip=BLOCKS
              skip BLOCKS ibs-sized blocks at start of input
 

-- 
    Michael Rasmussen, Portland Oregon

 http://meme.patch.com/memes/BicycleRiding

in a chair and chewing gum simultaneously.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan  7 19:50:13 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 07 Jan 2005 19:50:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tool for reading raw sectors from diskette?
In-Reply-To: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
References: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <86zmzklgui.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Don" == Don Buchholz <buchholz at easystreet.com> writes:

Don> Does anyone know of a tool which I can use to read raw sectors
Don> from a floppy diskette?  I've got one which apparently got
Don> mangled (won't "dd if=/dev/fd0") and there's some stuff on there
Don> which is only backed up via hardcopy.  I'd rather not re-enter
Don> the data.

Don> Am hoping someone can point me to a tool which can accept
Don> retrieve individual sectors (perhaps via specification of
Don> head/cyl/sect #).

I once did this manually for a whole stack of rotting floppy disks
containing old data transmissions to us.  By manually, I mean I used
dd, but when I found errors I seek'd around them (i.e. started at a
block after the error, usually a multiple of 2 sectors would be bad).

In my recent disk recovery work, I discovered a thing called
dd_rescue.  I initially assumed that it would have the same interface
as dd.  It didn't, but it did the job.  Here's the man page
description:

  dd_rescue is a program that copies data from one file or block
  device to another, it is a tool to help you to save data from
  crashed partition.  It tries to read and if it fails it will go on
  with the next sectors, where tools like dd will fail.  If the
  copying process is interrupted by the user it is possible to
  continue at any position later.  It can copy backwards.

Sounds like just the thing for you.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

Try specifying a SCSI capable kernel.
Boot using 'scsi.s' or something, Tab shows you a list of different 
pre-built SCSI kernels you can try, depending on your controller.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan  7 22:14:48 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 07 Jan 2005 22:14:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Slackware 10 ISO Install issues
In-Reply-To: <200501080501.j0851UTm009335@jade.spiritone.com>

>>>>> "Harry" ==   <techmage at aracnet.com> writes:

Rich> This may be a rhetorical question, but did you burn the cd-rom
Rich> as bootable? IIRC, that's not standard and it requires an option
Rich> to be set on the cdrecord command line.

Harry> Yep thought of that too.  I now have TWO sets of cd's for
Harry> Slackware 10.

It is an option to mkisofs, not cdrecord.  See, e.g.:

  <http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Bootdisk-HOWTO/cd-roms.html

If you've got iso's, their bootable-ness has already been established
(or not).

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Sat Jan  8 08:36:54 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 08:36:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
Message-ID: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

I have a large number of image files for which I wish to create a consistent 
naming convention whereby I put a date in front of any other part of the 
name. For example, I have a series of pictures, taken on April 28, 2001, near 
Bend, named Crooked-River-Gorge-1.jpg, Crooked-River-Gorge-2.jpg, and so 
forth. What I want is to prepend each filename with the string 20010428-, so 
I'd end up with 20010428-Crooked-River-Gorge-1.jpg, etc.

The tool I learned to use to rename files is mv. However, when I try to rename 
multiple files, mv is not happy with my instructions, telling me that, "when 
moving multiple files, last argument must be a directory"

I tried rename, which never complained about any of the ways I tried to tell 
it to work, but also never did anything.

Is there another command for this kind of procedure? Or do I need to write (or 
find) a script to do it?

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

> part of the name. 
<snip>
> I tried rename, which never complained about any of the ways I tried to
> tell it to work, but also never did anything.

I tried rename again, this time using as an example instructions from the 
archives. This command gave me what I wanted:

rename "Crooked-River-Gorge-" "20010428-Crooked-River-Gorge-" *.jpg

From mikeraz at patch.com  Sat Jan  8 09:53:13 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 09:53:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
In-Reply-To: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20050108175313.GB11784@patch.com>

Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> What I want is to prepend each filename with the string 20010428-, so 
> I'd end up with 20010428-Crooked-River-Gorge-1.jpg, etc.
> 
> The tool I learned to use to rename files is mv. However, when I try to rename 
> multiple files, mv is not happy with my instructions, telling me that, "when 
> moving multiple files, last argument must be a directory"

You can use a shell for loop to do them all.  In the example case you described:

for i in Crooked*.jpg
do
   mv $i 20010428-$i
done

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  8 10:03:07 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 08 Jan 2005 10:03:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
In-Reply-To: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <86acrjlrxg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Richard" == Richard C Steffens <rsteff.l at comcast.net> writes:

Richard> I have a large number of image files for which I wish to
Richard> create a consistent naming convention whereby I put a date in
Richard> front of any other part of the name. For example, I have a
Richard> series of pictures, taken on April 28, 2001, near Bend, named
Richard> Crooked-River-Gorge-1.jpg, Crooked-River-Gorge-2.jpg, and so
Richard> forth. What I want is to prepend each filename with the
Richard> string 20010428-, so I'd end up with
Richard> 20010428-Crooked-River-Gorge-1.jpg, etc.

[...]

Richard> Is there another command for this kind of procedure? Or do I
Richard> need to write (or find) a script to do it?

If the files are still timestamped with the date they were taken, then
you can do something like this:

$ for i in *.jpg ; do NEWFN=`date -r $i +'%Y%m%d'`-$i ; echo $i ${NEWFN} ; done

When you are certain this is doing what you want, replace "echo" with
"mv" and you'll be done.  You can add a --interactive option to mv if
you want to be prompted before overwriting a file with the new filename.

Salt to taste.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From mikeraz at patch.com  Sat Jan  8 11:41:51 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 11:41:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
In-Reply-To: <86acrjlrxg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<86acrjlrxg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com>

Russell Senior wrote:
> If the files are still timestamped with the date they were taken, then
> you can do something like this:
> 
> $ for i in *.jpg ; do NEWFN=`date -r $i +'%Y%m%d'`-$i ; echo $i ${NEWFN} ; done
> 
> When you are certain this is doing what you want, replace "echo" with
> "mv" and you'll be done.  You can add a --interactive option to mv if
> you want to be prompted before overwriting a file with the new filename.

If you're going to go to that length, why not just pull the exif data?

for i in *jpg
do
   NEWFN=`exif -t 0x9003 $i | grep Value: | cut -d\  -f4`-$i
   mv -i $i $NEWFN
done

No relying on memory from when the image was made.

Michael 'wishing exif had a quiet option that would just return the value' R

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  8 13:00:08 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 08 Jan 2005 13:00:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
In-Reply-To: <20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<86acrjlrxg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com>
Message-ID: <868y73iqlj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael Rasmussen <mikeraz at patch.com> writes:

Michael> If you're going to go to that length, why not just pull the
Michael> exif data?

[...]

Michael> No relying on memory from when the image was made.

Yeah that's probably better if you've got the exif-pulling software
available; date and mv are pretty ubiquitous.  Although, sometimes
your memory is better than the camera's if the camera's clock is
wrong.  Data recording devices, such as cameras, ought to be equipped
with GPS receivers to get atomic clock time from space, or some other
automatic and robust clock synchronization mechanism.

Frankly, though, prepending the date wouldn't be my preferred method.
Personally, I'd be inclined to retain the original camera-given
filenames and create directories of links (hard or symbolic) to supply
other characterizing information.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From wamorita at hevanet.com  Sat Jan  8 13:33:08 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 13:33:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] QTParted Question
In-Reply-To: <41E01123.7080009@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <200501082133.j08LX9568719@pop.hevanet.com>

Don,

You were right, Knoppix had started using the swap partition (hda3).
So I did a "swapoff /dev/hda3"; exited and restarted QTParted.
Now hda shows as "available", but when selected none of the partitions on
hda enable the resize option.  
They are all primary partitions (hda1-3)and were generated by the default
partitioning in the White Box Linux load.
I still seem to be missing something.  Any suggestions.

- Bill 
wamorita at hevanet.com

From mikeraz at patch.com  Sat Jan  8 13:53:34 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 13:53:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files - exif wrinkle
In-Reply-To: <20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<86acrjlrxg.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com>
Message-ID: <20050108215334.GA14404@patch.com>

Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> If you're going to go to that length, why not just pull the exif data?
> 
> for i in *jpg
> do
>    NEWFN=`exif -t 0x9003 $i | grep Value: | cut -d\  -f4`-$i
>    mv -i $i $NEWFN
> done
> 
> No relying on memory from when the image was made.
> 
> Michael 'wishing exif had a quiet option that would just return the value' R

I thought it was a shame that you couldn't just ask the exif program to return
a tag value without having to parse a bunch of information.  The grep and cut
in the example I gave above are because the standard exif output for a single
tag request looks like:

   mikeraz at swift:~$ exif -t 0x9003 img_1645.jpg
   EXIF entry 'Date and Time (original)' (0x9003, 'Date and Time (original)') exists in IFD 'EXIF':> Tag: 0x9003 ('DateTimeOriginal')
     Format: 2 ('Ascii')
     Components: 20
     Size: 20
     Value: 2004:07:06 12:19:20
   mikeraz at swift:~$

So I wrote to the program author and he responded quickly:

   On Sat, 2005-01-08 at 12:07 -0800, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
   > consider adding a -q option for quiet, less verbose, output.
   >
   > Example to explain what I'm thinking of:
   >
   > mikeraz at swift:~$ exif -t 0x9003 img_1645.jpg
   > EXIF entry 'Date and Time (original)' (0x9003, 'Date and Time (original)') exists in IFD 'EXIF':> Tag: 0x9003 ('DateTimeOriginal')
   >   Format: 2 ('Ascii')
   >   Components: 20
   >   Size: 20
   >   Value: 2004:07:06 12:19:20
   > mikeraz at swift:~$ exif -q -t 0x9003
   > 2004:07:06 12:19:20
   > mikeraz at swift:~$
                                                                                                     
   Committed to CVS. Thanks for the suggestion!
                                                                                                     
   2005-01-08  Lutz Mueller <lutz at users.sourceforge.net>
                                                                                                     
           Suggestion by Michael Rasmussen <mikeraz at patch.com>:
                                                                                                     
           * exif/main.c: Make '-m' together with '--tag' only print the value of
             the tag, nothing else.


Gawd I love open source and the people who make it possible.

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Sat Jan  8 14:09:21 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sat, 8 Jan 2005 14:09:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming batches of files
In-Reply-To: <868y73iqlj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <200501080836.54572.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<20050108194150.GB13001@patch.com> <868y73iqlj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <200501081409.21666.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

On Saturday 08 January 2005 1:00 pm, Russell Senior wrote:

> Frankly, though, prepending the date wouldn't be my preferred method.
> Personally, I'd be inclined to retain the original camera-given
> filenames and create directories of links (hard or symbolic) to supply
> other characterizing information.

A prepended date is what the camera uses when naming the files. Actually, it's 
what the download software uses. I haven't tried a different convention as 
yet. I don't have a reader for the kind of memory this camera uses, so I've 
always downloaded using the camera's USB connection. Also, I have yet to 
download to my Linux machine, so I don't know what it would see for a name.

I use a date convention on the directories for my photos, and include 
something about the subject matter. So far, all but a few collections of 
images were made during trips, so the date and the location we visited works 
pretty well for me. I am, as I type, uploading some images to RitzPix for 
printing. I'm doing all those from a folder that has links to images in a 
variety of other folders. The link concept did occur to me, and I'll be using 
that concept for other purposes.

Thanks to all for all the ideas. Now that I've gotten the hang of the rename 
command, it works well for me. It took me a bit to realize that what it 
wanted was two strings and the subset of files on which to work. Once I 
understood that, it was much easier.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

HI,

I've been trying to get Slackware to install from the ISO cd I burned.
The cdrom sees the disc , but won't boot from it.
The Kernel gives an error that it can't find the cdrom, which is SCSI.
I've even tried several different CD -Rom drives, to no avail.
Is there a work around for this, like in the Suse 9.0 case were I built a
set of boot floppies?

TIA,

Harry
============================================================================
===================

I had a similar issue when I installed Slackware, except I had an old IDE
CDROM.

had the same problems with that drive

drive anyway!

Hope that helps.

:upper and :lower commands, yes?

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan  8 22:01:36 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 08 Jan 2005 22:01:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Tape Drives and Power Supplies ( was strange crashes ... )
In-Reply-To: <20050106190050.GA19396@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050106160754.GA18405@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<86acrmxvnd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20050106190050.GA19396@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <86oefzgmyn.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


An update on the funny powering-off box.  It is clearly related to
running the tape backup.  On the two nights in the last 9 days that we
didn't run tape backups, the box remained operating.  On 7 of 7 tape
backup attempts, it has killed the box (after a variable amount of
time).  In the last two permutations, I moved the tape drive power
supply off the UPS and tried swapping in a different external tape
drive (and terminator), respectively.

I guess it could still be some fault on the SCSI card or the cable,
but I guess I am coming back to the power supply as the currently most
likely culprit.  I am still not clear how the tape backup could be
inducing a dodgy power supply to shut off the computer, particularly
when the failure occurs well (like hours in some cases) into the
backup, but then again *nothing* about this is clear.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Jan  8 22:31:05 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun, 9 Jan 2005 06:31:05 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: QTParted Question
References: <41E07B1D.8000803@paranoid.org>
	<200501090415.j094Fx541082@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <slrncu1gmf.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-09, William A Morita <wamorita at hevanet.com> wrote:
> Rich,
>
> The file systems in question are all ext3.
> You are correct.  It would appear that resize is not supported for ext3.
> What a bitch. Looks like I will have to copy the partition content out,
> delete, repartition and copy back.
>
> Thanks for pointing this out.  So much for assumptions.

I don't know much about QTparted, but ext3 itself can be resized.  If
you see support for ext2, then ext3 can be resized also--there is little
difference between the two format-wise and ext3 is backwards compatible
with ext2 (you can umount an ext3 and remount it as ext2, for
example).  On my EL3 systems, I generally set them up with LVM, leaving
only swap and /boot out and size everything on-demand.  With FC3 support
on-line resizing, it's even easier.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Jan  8 23:01:04 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun, 9 Jan 2005 07:01:04 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Converting Mixed-Case File Names
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501081826030.14297@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <slrncu1kvk.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-09, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>    I've received a whole bunch of code from a Winduhs coder. File names are,
> literally, mixed cases. Some names are uppercase with uppercase extensions,
> some uppercase names with lowercase extensions. Others are every possible
> combination of cases.

Pretty straight-forward:

for FiLe in *; do
    file=$(echo "${FiLe}"|tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')
    echo mv -i "${FiLe}" "${file}"
done

(Remove the 'echo' once you've checked that it works.)

It gets slightly more interesting if you have a lot of directories, but
not too much.

It doesn't matter whether the name or extension is the wrong case--as
far as a shell is concerned they're just parts of a string.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

Nope.  This is a bare box, with only one HD, a floppy and a SCSI card
in a PCI slot.  LAN, Audio and Video are all on the motherboard, but
of those only the LAN has anything connected.  Otherwise, only a
serial console and the SCSI cable to the external tape drive.

I tried to induce a load with heavy disk seeking and it didn't seem to
bother it in the least.  Also, I just removed two IDE drives and
replaced them with one IDE drive.  You'd think the electrical load
would have gone down from that.

The tape-related failures started immediately after the disk change.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501091053100.4418@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 9 Jan 2005, Rich Shepard wrote:

>> ftp://ftp.zytor.com/pub/hpa/downcase

   This is a follow up report for archive archeologists.

   On a source directory with two levels of subdirectories I used both the
shell script as provided by Wil and the perl script pointed to by Carla. The
latter is both faster and traverses the directory structure in one fell
swoop. The shell script needed to be run from within each directory.

   I know that there is a way to modify the shell script to traverse the
directory tree. However, they both work and the perl script was finished in
an eye blink.

Thanks Carla and Wil!

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From rich at paranoid.org  Sun Jan  9 12:23:19 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sun, 09 Jan 2005 12:23:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: QTParted Question
In-Reply-To: <slrncu1gmf.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
References: <41E07B1D.8000803@paranoid.org>	<200501090415.j094Fx541082@pop.hevanet.com>
	<slrncu1gmf.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <41E192B7.4050705@paranoid.org>

Wil Cooley wrote:

> I don't know much about QTparted, but ext3 itself can be resized.  If
> you see support for ext2, then ext3 can be resized also--there is little
> difference between the two format-wise and ext3 is backwards compatible
> with ext2 (you can umount an ext3 and remount it as ext2, for
> example). 

Yeah, that page on the QTParted site says it will not resize either ext3 
or ext2. I'm actually not 100% sure that's current. I thought it would 
resize them but that you could not move the start point of the 
partition, just the end. It may have changed, I'm not sure.

I believe it will work using parted.

> On my EL3 systems, I generally set them up with LVM, leaving
> only swap and /boot out and size everything on-demand.  With FC3 support
> on-line resizing, it's even easier.

Another option is to covert ext3 to ext2 and then use ext2resize:

http://ext2resize.sourceforge.net/

I have never tried that, just read about it :)


Rich




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Sun Jan  9 13:05:37 2005
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Sun, 9 Jan 2005 13:05:37 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] sshd attacks
Message-ID: <3896.216.99.218.67.1105304737.squirrel@sautez.com>

Happy Sunday all,

Well spending some time going over logs and updating some tools and I
notice that there is again a renew attack on the server on the sshd
protocol.  It is a dictionary attack to get into the system and I have
my logs getting filled up with:

Illegal user <someuser> from <some IP>

Is there a way in SSHD to automatically ban an IP from my system if I
see this sort of attack?  My only guess is that I would need to write
a script to look at the logs and then put then in the hosts.deny file.
 I'm sure I'm the only one that is getting these and wondered what
some of you may be doing about it.

I do have sshd setup to only allow on user and to use RSA
authenication only so it would difficult although I'm sure not
impossible to get in this way.  Just would like to stop them sooner.

Thanks,

Josh

================
Using /dev/hda
                                                                          
Information: The operating system thinks the geometry on /dev/hda is
7753/240/63.  Therefore, cylinder 1024 ends at 7559.999M.
                                                                          
(parted) print
Disk geometry for /dev/hda: 0.000-57241.898 megabytes
Disk label type: msdos
Minor    Start       End     Type      Filesystem  Flags
1          0.031    103.359  primary   ext3        boot
2        103.359  55245.585  primary   ext3        
3      55245.586  57238.945  primary   linux-swap  
                                                                          
(parted) resize
2
                                                                          
No Implementation: This ext2 filesystem has a rather strange layout!  Parted
can't resize this (yet). 
================

According to the parted documentation, it can handle ext3, but somehow the
partitions made parted burp.

- Bill 

wamorita at hevanet.com

Cell: (503) 260-3876



-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Rich Burroughs
Sent: Sunday, January 09, 2005 12:23 PM
To: General Linux discussion and assistance
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Re: QTParted Question

Wil Cooley wrote:

> I don't know much about QTparted, but ext3 itself can be resized.  If 
> you see support for ext2, then ext3 can be resized also--there is 
> little difference between the two format-wise and ext3 is backwards 
> compatible with ext2 (you can umount an ext3 and remount it as ext2, 
> for example).

Yeah, that page on the QTParted site says it will not resize either ext3 or
ext2. I'm actually not 100% sure that's current. I thought it would resize
them but that you could not move the start point of the partition, just the
end. It may have changed, I'm not sure.

I believe it will work using parted.

> On my EL3 systems, I generally set them up with LVM, leaving only swap 
> and /boot out and size everything on-demand.  With FC3 support on-line 
> resizing, it's even easier.

Another option is to covert ext3 to ext2 and then use ext2resize:

http://ext2resize.sourceforge.net/

I have never tried that, just read about it :)


Rich

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Jan  9 13:27:01 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 9 Jan 2005 13:27:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
References: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>


Russell Senior writes:
> Nope.  This is a bare box, with only one HD, a floppy and a SCSI card
> in a PCI slot.  LAN, Audio and Video are all on the motherboard, but
> of those only the LAN has anything connected.  Otherwise, only a
> serial console and the SCSI cable to the external tape drive.
> 
> I tried to induce a load with heavy disk seeking and it didn't seem to
> bother it in the least.  Also, I just removed two IDE drives and
> replaced them with one IDE drive.  You'd think the electrical load
> would have gone down from that.
> 
> The tape-related failures started immediately after the disk change.


Since this is after a drive change, and since you are presumably using
a +80GB drive to replace a couple of 10's or 20's, you may be taxing
something in the disk formatting, or in the BIOS;  backups may be
thrashing areas of disk space or memory that were not used before,
and are only accessed during backups.

You mentioned originally that you were using an Intel D815.  A bit of
Googling for "D815" and "shutdown" found a vague reference to the need
for a BIOS upgrade.  Look into that.  Perhaps older, smaller disks did
not stretch the BIOS quite as much, or tickle the memory space that
throws the power-off switch.

Of course, do an fsck -c to find/heal bad blocks, and check your
partitions.  Given your earlier comments about grub and disk setup,
there may a mismatch between the partition tables and the filesystems
stored on them.  

You did remember to do a "mkswap" on your swap partition, yes?  Is the
swap partition the same size as before?  What happens to available
memory as the backup program runs?  

Also try a dd if=/dev/hda of=dev/null and see if the drive gets 
unhappy as you read its entire length.

You mentioned that you reseated the connectors.  I would do that with
ALL the connections, including the RAM and CPU and mobo power connectors
and PCI slots.  Something might have pulled /almost/ loose during the
disk replacement adventure.  Or the flexing the mobo made an internal
wire intermittent. You may kill the mobo with the extra stretching and
squeezing, but better to spend $100 replacing a mobo than losing client
data.

Last, if nothing else worked, I would put the old disks back in for
a weekend, run the backups again, and see if the problem goes away.
I would also try the new hard disk on another system, and repeat some
of the above tests.

Fascinating problem you have.  I look forward to your exultant bragging
about a clever solution, preferably soon.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From jack at bonyari.com  Sun Jan  9 13:33:47 2005
From: jack at bonyari.com (Jack Morgan)

Subject: [PLUG] sshd attacks
In-Reply-To: <3896.216.99.218.67.1105304737.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <3896.216.99.218.67.1105304737.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1105306427.6543.41.camel@saitama.bonyari.com>

On Sun, 2005-01-09 at 13:05 -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Happy Sunday all,
> 
> Well spending some time going over logs and updating some tools and I
> notice that there is again a renew attack on the server on the sshd
> protocol.  It is a dictionary attack to get into the system and I have
> my logs getting filled up with:
> 
> Illegal user <someuser> from <some IP>
> 
> Is there a way in SSHD to automatically ban an IP from my system if I
> see this sort of attack?  My only guess is that I would need to write
> a script to look at the logs and then put then in the hosts.deny file.
>  I'm sure I'm the only one that is getting these and wondered what
> some of you may be doing about it.
> 
> I do have sshd setup to only allow on user and to use RSA
> authenication only so it would difficult although I'm sure not
> impossible to get in this way.  Just would like to stop them sooner.

Another option is to run sshd on a different port say 2222 instead of
port 22. All you need to do is specifiy the port when you connect to the
box...

ssh user at domain.com -p 2222

or 

scp -P 2222 user at domain.com


--
Jack Morgan



From sean.whitney at gmail.com  Sun Jan  9 13:45:18 2005
From: sean.whitney at gmail.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Sun, 09 Jan 2005 13:45:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] sshd attacks
In-Reply-To: <3896.216.99.218.67.1105304737.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <3896.216.99.218.67.1105304737.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1105307118.1755.10.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Since this box is on the Internet I would look at defense in depth....

I would make sure that I have a firewall box (which doens't respond to
SSH from the internet) set up (using PIX, iptables, ipchains, or
whatever).  It should forward all ssh requests to port 22 on this
server.  I would set up iptables then to deny the IP address.  This will
lessen the load on the ssh server and allow the firewall box to drop the
packets silently.


Sean

Josh,

   This has been going on for quite a while. It did drop off significantly,
but for a while the script was being tried by numerous cretins on the 'Net.

> Is there a way in SSHD to automatically ban an IP from my system if I see
> this sort of attack?  My only guess is that I would need to write a script
> to look at the logs and then put then in the hosts.deny file. I'm sure I'm
> the only one that is getting these and wondered what some of you may be
> doing about it.

   If sshd is configured to allow only specific users in, the names tried in
the script (user, admin, guest, nobody, etc.) fail. I just shrug and let it
go. The IP addresses are blocked by postfix but not by my floppyfw.

> I do have sshd setup to only allow on user and to use RS authenication
> only so it would difficult although I'm sure not impossible to get in this
> way.  Just would like to stop them sooner.

   I think you need to put deny rules in your iptables/net filter setup.

Rich

> >and place in the iptables filter or do it manually or just forget
> >about it and let it be.

> You could also setup Port Knocking to only open port 22 after a 
> successful knock.
> 
> http://techrepublic.com.com/5100-22_11-5481894.html

Thing is port knocking merely amounts to another password. An interesting
one, but still simply a password. If port knocking was to become really
popular, the scripts would simply start attempting to attack it. Like
passwords, port knocking is completely vulnerable to sniffing.
