From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 10 12:28:31 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 12:28:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] sshd attacks
In-Reply-To: <200501102013.j0AKDtex040178@m5p.com>
References: <200501102013.j0AKDtex040178@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <41E2E56F.7040503@paranoid.org>

> Thing is port knocking merely amounts to another password. An interesting
> one, but still simply a password. If port knocking was to become really
> popular, the scripts would simply start attempting to attack it. Like
> passwords, port knocking is completely vulnerable to sniffing.

Sure, but it's another layer. The attacker would need to compromise it 
just to get the sshd port open, and then they would still need to 
compromise the service it's protecting. That's kind of the point of 
thinking in terms of defense in depth - you don't expect (or count on) 
any one measure to be enough to protect the system on its own.

I've never used port knocking, but it looks interesting. Generally with 
sshd I'd want to restrict access to it to as few IPs as possible, both 
through sshd itself and through the firewall. That's harder to do if 
you're in a situation where people need access from multiple or dynamic IPs.

Another helpful option is to turn off password access for sshd and 
require keys. That might work better for someone who is travelling but 
will have their laptop with them.


Rich




From rlucas at tercent.com  Mon Jan 10 13:11:50 2005
From: rlucas at tercent.com (Randall Lucas)
Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 13:11:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] sshd attacks
In-Reply-To: <20050110200009.B8CF95B9B@ulke.nakedape.cc>
References: <20050110200009.B8CF95B9B@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <41E2EF96.1030404@tercent.com>

> Thanks all.  I see I either have to write a script to read the logs
> and place in the iptables filter or do it manually or just forget
> about it and let it be.

I'm fairly sure that this is exactly what portsentry does.  When it 
detects an attack signature, it writes an iptables rule and inserts it. 
  You can set up things like "whitelists," so that you don't lock 
yourself out whilst nmapping.

The only problem with portsentry is that it's sort of incompatible with 
a strict firewall -- it usually (to my understanding) relies upon seeing 
a bunch of ports opened from the same host in order to spot an attack 
script, and a good firewall will have those ports blocked off, so it's 
kind of a wash.

Randall

-- 
Randall Lucas			DF93EAD1
Tercent, Inc / SuperSurvey Online Surveys
http://www.supersurvey.com

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jan 10 16:01:06 2005

> the box to install our new firewall using Linux.
>
> Any clues to get around this and have it execute the boot disk would
> really help.

I assume you want to boot to a CD-ROM to install Linux?  (Sorry, I've
never tried to install Linux on a Sun, just Solaris.)  Typically to boot
to cdrom you type 'boot cdrom' at the OpenBoot prompt.  If you don't
care about the current status of the filesystems (because you're going
to wipe them anyway), you can just hit Stop-A to drop into the boot
monitor.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

From jack at bonyari.com  Mon Jan 10 18:38:08 2005
From: jack at bonyari.com (Jack Morgan)
Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 18:38:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Convert Sun Ultra5 to Linux
In-Reply-To: <00a801c4f764$cc334980$4901a8c0@mango>
References: <00a801c4f764$cc334980$4901a8c0@mango>
Message-ID: <1105411088.6543.69.camel@saitama.bonyari.com>

On Mon, 2005-01-10 at 14:36 -0800, Steven D. Coffman wrote:
> Hi All..
> Hope someone knows this. I have a Sun Ultra5 system and I am trying to
> install Linux over it. The danged OpenBoot system just won't let me
> execute a different boot disk, etc. It keeps going to it's default Sun
> system.
> I don't want to keep the data or the OS, it's old stuff and I'm using
> the box to install our new firewall using Linux.
> 
> Any clues to get around this and have it execute the boot disk would
> really help.

First, do stop + A to get to the OBP. Then type "probe-scsi"[1] to get a
list of installed hard disks. You can also type "printenv" to get a list
of environment variables and "help" should do just that :)  

As already mentioned, can do "boot cdrom" to boot from the cdrom
(assuming you have one) or "boot disk" to boot of the first disk, "boot
disk1" to boot off the second disk.

Here are a few links...

Debian sparc linux:

http://www.debian.org/releases/stable/sparc/install


Aurora sparc linux:

http://www.auroralinux.org/


Gentoo sparc linux:

http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-faq.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-obpreference.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-netboot-howto.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/handbook/handbook-sparc.xml


--
Jack Morgan

[1] probe-ide if it's a Sun blade which has ide disks



From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jan 10 20:08:57 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 10 Jan 2005 20:08:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] LCD Projector
Message-ID: <20050111040857.GA13366@gate.kl-ic.com>


Rich writes:
> Staples has the 3M Digital Projector S10 SVGA 800x600 1200 lumens 6.6lb for
> a low $724.99 after $375 easy rebate. Free shipping. Free $150 gift check
> through 1/15.   > $375 rebate Exp 1/16/05.

A good price, but ...  before buying a projector, check out:

http://www.projectorcentral.com/

A good site with lots of projector data.  It is good to check user reviews
before buying a projector;  it is also good to check for noise, maximum
resolution, reliability, lamp life, and lamp cost.  The lamps for some
of these projectors cost $500, so an extra 1000 hours of lamp life may
make up for $200 of initial price.

Also check the warranty;  some of the "3 year" warranties only apply to
the original purchaser, or have other noxious restrictions.  

All that said, the 3M unit looks a little better than average, and the
sale price is half of MSRP.  You might be able to get a little better
prices for similar units mail-order, but there is an advantage to being
able to pound on the counter if you need to return it.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From chgenly at verizon.net  Tue Jan 11 18:27:23 2005
From: chgenly at verizon.net (Chris Genly)
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 18:27:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix command line disk ghosting
Message-ID: <1105496843.8908.17.camel@gimli>

I reinstall windows 98 on my sons system every 9 months or so.  He uses
it to play games, listen to music, instant message, edit documents and
browse the web.  It takes about a day of elapsed time to get the system
back up to speed: installing win98, and all the necessary drivers,
setting up the printer, anti-virus program, open office, mozilla, yahoo
messenger, etc.  So I was motivated to looking in to getting an image of
his disk.  

I was tickled pink when I found a way to do it without any special
tools.  I just needed a Knoppix disk.  Here's how I did it.


# Boot knoppix, su to root.

# Mount the windows partition, hda1.  hda1 is the only partition.
mkdir /mnt/local
mount /dev/hda1 /mnt/local
cd /mnt/local

# Fill all unused blocks with zeros to allow them to 
# be compressed when imaging.
for i in 1 2 3 4 5; do cat /dev/zero >zero$i; done

# Free up the space.
rm zero?

cd /
umount /mnt/local

# Image the whole disk by copying it to another machine after 
# compressing it.
gzip - </dev/hda | ssh chgenly at 10.0.0.10 'cat >r2d2_image.gz'


I could even run 'sshdstart' and then do the whole backup thing
remotely.  Just too cool.  The image fit on to one CD.  Very convenient.

Restoring it is easier.

# Boot knoppix, su to root.
ssh chgenly at 10.0.0.10 'cat r2d2_image.gz' | gunzip - >/dev/hda


Surprisingly it takes about three times longer to reload the image with
gunzip, than to create the image with gzip.   I have tested the restore
by zeroing the whole hard drive first.  It worked great.  You get the
boot block, partition table and win98.  Everything.

I had such great success I thought I'd image my wifes system.   I use
the same procedure, but it fails to create a tidy image.  She is using
2Gb on a 10Gb drive.  But when I try the backup procedure described
above, the image file gets up to about 4.6Gb before I abort the imaging.
I found this very strange.  So I tried doing a disk defrag, and then
doing the whole imaging procedure including zeroing unused blocks.
Still a no go.   Anyone have any idea what might be going wrong?

Chris

Update.  Still no final resolution, but a little more information.  I
got in on Monday afternoon, updated the BIOS (an Intel D815EEA2L
motherboard) from P10 to P21.  Swapped in a different powersupply (a
300W puppy I had pulled from a box when installing a P4-capable
powersupply).  I am back on a 2.4.28 kernel (fwiw).

I tried a backup to file rather than backup to tape, writing the file
to a third (unbackedup) partition.  Did both 'create' and 'diff'
operations on both backups.  Both of these succeeded without death.

Next, my backup script ran, but rapidly failed with errors like:

  Jan 11 21:25:01 hostname kernel: st0: Error with sense data: Info fld=0x1, Current st09:00: sense key Medium Error
  Jan 11 21:25:01 hostname kernel: Additional sense indicates Excessive write errors

Looked like a dirty tape drive, so I requested a run of the cleaning
cartridge today, which reportedly occurred.  Tried again this evening
and got the same thing, so I am requesting new and/or different media
for tomorrow's attempt.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Jan 11 22:53:20 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue, 11 Jan 2005 22:53:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] untar multiple files
In-Reply-To: <1105511497.8060.5.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
References: <1105511497.8060.5.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
Message-ID: <1105512800.1557.92.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Tue, 2005-01-11 at 22:31 -0800, David Phillips wrote:
> Does anyone know of an easy way to untar/zip multiple files at once?  I
> figure a script is probably the best solution but unfortunately my
> scripting skills are about non-existent at this point.

Learn for loops:

bash$ for i in *.tar.gz; do tar -xvzf $i; done

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 12 07:18:24 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 07:18:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com> <864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501120712220.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 11 Jan 2005, Russell Senior wrote:

> Next, my backup script ran, but rapidly failed with errors like:
>
>  Jan 11 21:25:01 hostname kernel: st0: Error with sense data: Info fld=0x1, Current st09:00: sense key Medium Error
>  Jan 11 21:25:01 hostname kernel: Additional sense indicates Excessive write errors

Russell,

   I saw the sense data errors when my tape drives were failing. I don't
recall the brand/model that I had before going to the Tandberg, but it was a
failing drive that gave me those errors in the log.

   The Tandbergs have been flawless. The original, SLR-5, worked, but I
discovered a year or so later that it's one of the slowest drives ever made.
Tandberg allowed me to purchase a SLR-60 for evaluation at 50% off and I've
been using that for the past three or so years. No errors at all.

   What Tandberg tech support told me is that too much cleaning kills the
drive. The original instructions were to clean the drive after every 8 or so
hours of use. So, I cleaned the silly thing each week. Turns out that's a
no-no. The SLR-60 now tells me (with an orange light on the front panel)
when it wants a cleaning. This occurs about every eight months or so. The
only nights the drive is not used are Saturday and Sunday.

   It may not be the most modern or least expensive technology, but the
Tandberg SLR drives have been rock solid and the tech support unsurpassed.
And, restores using BRU continue to work flawlessly when I screw up or when
I move everything onto a new system.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jan 12 08:55:34 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 08:55:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix command line disk ghosting 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 11 Jan 2005 18:27:23 PST."
	<1105496843.8908.17.camel@gimli> 
Message-ID: <20050112165539.330048F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Chris Genly <chgenly at verizon.net> wrote:

> 
> # Image the whole disk by copying it to another machine after 
> # compressing it.
> gzip - </dev/hda | ssh chgenly at 10.0.0.10 'cat >r2d2_image.gz'

> # Boot knoppix, su to root.
> ssh chgenly at 10.0.0.10 'cat r2d2_image.gz' | gunzip - >/dev/hda

If your local network is secure, you might want to try using NFS or
Samba to transfer the file.  The ssh encrypt/decrypt may or may not
be slowing the transfer.

galen

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Jan 12 09:03:07 2005
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 09:03:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] untar multiple files
In-Reply-To: <1105511497.8060.5.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
References: <1105511497.8060.5.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
Message-ID: <20050112170307.GA6613@aracnet.com>

On Tue, Jan 11, 2005 at 10:31:37PM -0800, David Phillips wrote:
> Does anyone know of an easy way to untar/zip multiple files at once?  I
> figure a script is probably the best solution but unfortunately my
> scripting skills are about non-existent at this point.
> 
> Thanks
> 

The xargs utility might be what you want:

  ls *.tar | xargs -n 1 tar xf

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 12 09:31:06 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:31:06 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: untar multiple files
References: <1105511497.8060.5.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
	<1105512800.1557.92.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <slrncuaml1.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-12, AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> wrote:
> On Tue, 2005-01-11 at 22:31 -0800, David Phillips wrote:
>> Does anyone know of an easy way to untar/zip multiple files at once?  I
>> figure a script is probably the best solution but unfortunately my
>> scripting skills are about non-existent at this point.
>
> Learn for loops:
>
> bash$ for i in *.tar.gz; do tar -xvzf $i; done

Or if you want them to be done in parallel:

bash$ for i in *.tar.gz; do tar -xvzf $i & done

Or if you have a lot and you want to run a few in parallel at a time,
see 1.5 on my ShellHacks page:

http://nakedape.cc/wiki/ShellHacks

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jan 12 11:55:27 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 11:55:27 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Main Board recommendations 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 12 Jan 2005 10:24:34 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.33.0501121010590.27269-100000@main.cyber-office.net> 
Message-ID: <20050112195532.6AC6B8F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

>    What are good dual AMD 64 bit CPU ( 2 GHz+ ) main boards?  Must support
> 1 GByte RAM minimum and I'm recommending SATA drive(s) so an onboard SATA
> controller ( RAID or no ) would be nice but not a requirement.

If you are interested in using SATA, I highly recommend reading about the
current state of Linux SATA support.

http://linux.yyz.us/sata/

Capsule summary:
  Many so called RAID controllers are really software RAID, where you 
  would be better off using the md driver.

  Most of today's controllers do not support TCQ/NCQ.


galen



From aaronb at personaltelco.net  Wed Jan 12 12:09:57 2005
From: aaronb at personaltelco.net (Aaron Baer)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 12:09:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] IBM donates 500 patents to Open Source
Message-ID: <1105560598.5325.7.camel@localhost.localdomain>

http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/1201.html

IBM Corp. the nation?s top patent receiver, and tech giant, announced
yesterday that it will be donating 500 technology patents to open source
software developers. 

...

Open source groups developing free software for the masses and business
that are always looking for alternatives to such programs as Microsoft
Windows now have an ally in IBM. The patents will be available to any
individual, community, or company working on or using software that
meets the definition of open source software now or in the future. They
will have access to these patents without fear of being sued for
infringement.


Awesome.

From norm.coder at gemstone.com  Wed Jan 12 13:28:53 2005
From: norm.coder at gemstone.com (Norm Coder)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 13:28:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding a SCSI tape drive
Message-ID: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B71CDD@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>

I just installed a SCSI card in a Dell PowerEdge 2850 without so much as
using a screwdriver, wow. Now I need to add a tape drive. The tape drive is
currently connected to the SCSI card.

Funny thing is that the tape drive has absolutely not markings on it to give
me a clue what brand it is. It takes a DDS4 (DG4-150 tape was in it when I
started using it) tape. It is beige with four rubber grips on the sides of
it. 

Anyway that is not as important, I think anyway, as how to get it working.
It is currently set to target 6. I think I should execute commands something
like:

# ln -s /dev/st6 /dev/ftape - to create a tape drive device symbolic link
# mt -f /dev/ftape command - to mount it
 
Is this right, enough, should I do something else first? Someone please
point me in the right direction. Are there ways to see if the tape drive was
found by the system when it booted?


Norman Coder
System Administrator
Gemstone Systems, Inc.
1260 NW Waterhouse St.
Beaverton, OR 97006
503-533-3367



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 12 13:56:04 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 13:56:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding a SCSI tape drive
In-Reply-To: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B71CDD@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B71CDD@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121350520.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 12 Jan 2005, Norm Coder wrote:

> Funny thing is that the tape drive has absolutely not markings on it to
> give me a clue what brand it is. It takes a DDS4 (DG4-150 tape was in it
> when I started using it) tape. It is beige with four rubber grips on the
> sides of it.

Norm,

   How strange that there isn't a manufacturer's plate on it with model and
serial number.

> # ln -s /dev/st6 /dev/ftape - to create a tape drive device symbolic link
> # mt -f /dev/ftape command - to mount it

   It is not a floppy tape; that would be connected to the floppy drive
connector on the mother board, not the SCSI bus. However, if you want to
name the mount point 'ftape' that's OK.

> Is this right, enough, should I do something else first? Someone please
> point me in the right direction. Are there ways to see if the tape drive
> was found by the system when it booted?

   Look at dmesg to see what the kernel found on the SCSI bus. My server
shows:

sym53c8xx: at PCI bus 0, device 5, function 0
sym53c8xx: setting PCI_COMMAND_PARITY...(fix-up)
sym53c8xx: 53c895 detected with Tekram NVRAM
sym53c895-0: rev 0x1 on pci bus 0 device 5 function 0 irq 11
sym53c895-0: Tekram format NVRAM, ID 7, Fast-40, Parity Checking
scsi1 : sym53c8xx-1.7.3c-20010512
   Vendor: TANDBERG  Model: SLR60             Rev: 0420
   Type:   Sequential-Access                  ANSI SCSI revision: 02
   Vendor: PLEXTOR   Model: CD-R   PX-W1210S  Rev: 1.01
   Type:   CD-ROM                             ANSI SCSI revision: 02
st: Version 20040102, bufsize 32768, max init. bufs 4, s/g segs 16
Attached scsi tape st0 at scsi1, channel 0, id 4, lun 0
sym53c895-0-<6,*>: FAST-20 SCSI 20.0 MB/s (50.0 ns, offset 16)
sr0: scsi3-mmc drive: 32x/32x writer cd/rw xa/form2 cdda tray
sym53c895-0-<4,*>: FAST-20 WIDE SCSI 40.0 MB/s (50.0 ns, offset 15)
st0: Block limits 1 - 262144 bytes.

   If you don't have the driver loaded you won't see anything useful. I'm not
sure how one probes for the appropriate driver; more hardware-knowledgeable
folks here can tell you that.

   To test the drive, once you know the proper driver loaded, are the 'mt'
(move tape) commands. Read 'man st' for details. You can rewind, seek,
retention and so forth from the command line.

HTH,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 12 13:59:45 2005

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jan 12 14:10:55 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 12 Jan 2005 14:10:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding a SCSI tape drive
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121350520.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B71CDD@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121350520.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86zmzeuwls.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Norm> Funny thing is that the tape drive has absolutely not markings
Norm> on it to give me a clue what brand it is. It takes a DDS4
Norm> (DG4-150 tape was in it when I started using it) tape. It is
Norm> beige with four rubber grips on the sides of it.

Rich>    It is not a floppy tape; that would be connected to the
Rich> floppy drive connector on the mother board, not the SCSI
Rich> bus. However, if you want to name the mount point 'ftape' that's
Rich> OK.

That's not a "mount point".  You don't "mount" tapes.  The interface
with tape is through a character device.  Probably the tape device is
at /dev/st0 or /dev/nst0 (I use the latter, a non-rewinding device
which doesn't rewind after every operation, you do it manually
instead).

As for device, check dmesg output.

Rich>    To test the drive, once you know the proper driver loaded,
Rich> are the 'mt' (move tape) commands. Read 'man st' for
Rich> details. You can rewind, seek, retention and so forth from the
Rich> command line.

"man mt".  Typically, you want to check the status before you do
anything else:

 # mt -f /dev/nst0 status

Also, don't be surprised if your device doesn't support all of the mt
commands.  My DDS3 doesn't do retentioning, for example.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 12 14:40:02 2005

> That's not a "mount point".  You don't "mount" tapes.  The interface with
> tape is through a character device.  Probably the tape device is at
> /dev/st0 or /dev/nst0 (I use the latter, a non-rewinding device which

   True. I use both st and nst. The weekly, full backups rewind the tape and
write from the beginning; the daily, incremental backups start at the end of
the last one.

> "man mt".  Typically, you want to check the status before you do anything
> else:

   Careless fingers.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jan 12 14:59:33 2005
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 14:59:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake netprofiles
Message-ID: <41E5ABD5.5010209@dimstar.net>

I'm using Mandrake 10.1 official download version.

I'm trying to use netprofile on my laptop.

I've found docs that say you can put append="PROFILE=profile" in
lilo.conf, run lilo and it will choose that profile upon boot. This
was for Mandrake 9.2...

Netprofile does appear to change the files it's supposed to change,
according to the profile specified in lilo.conf, but the changed files
were too late to make a difference during boot. Rebooting with the
same profile works the second time, because the changed files are now
in place before the boot.

On RPMFind, I see in the latest version changelog some reference to
another place to specify profile, but no mention of what that place is.

Booting and then changing profiles is a hassle, especially when you
are trying to attach to a YP server... One must then go through and
manually restart services to connect to the server etc.

I'm finding little or no documentation, and a how-to link on the
Mandrake website just says it needs to be written... Uh, yeah... I'll
write it if I can get it working...

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

Russ

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Wed Jan 12 15:54:05 2005
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Tony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:54:05 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] UPS Automatic Shut-down
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200501121754.05265.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Wednesday 12 January 2005 17:46, Rich Shepard wrote:
>    I know that apc makes a utility to shut-down systems when the power goes
> out, and there's at least one other utility to do the same thing.
>
>    If folks are using these I'd appreciate any hints or gotcha's before I
> set up the system here. The UPS-HOWTO is not very helpful.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Rich

I've successfully used "apcupsd" daemon for monitoring the APC UPSs we have in 
our office. It works with the older UPSs we have that use a serial port for 
signaling as well as the newer APC models which use USB. All of the UPSs we 
have are the "smart" ones that provide a variety of information regarding 
battery charge, load, time remaining, etc.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jan 12 17:05:53 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 12 Jan 2005 17:05:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86r7kquoi6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> Looked like a dirty tape drive, so I requested a run of the
Russell> cleaning cartridge today, which reportedly occurred.  Tried
Russell> again this evening and got the same thing, so I am requesting
Russell> new and/or different media for tomorrow's attempt.

Okay, more wackiness.  The drive is a Seagate STD624000N.  I have two
drives to test.  Both behave indistinguishably.  When I initially saw
the write errors on the tape device, I started to do some testing
using dd, to take filesystem interaction out of the picture.  Because
of the hardware data compression on the device, I didn't want to just
write zeros because the built-in compression would have a field day
with that.  So I did this instead:

  # mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 512
  # dd if=/dev/urandom of=/dev/nst0 obs=512 count=32768

Given the experience I've subsequently had, I recommend *NEVER* doing
that in the future!  At least until I figure out what is going wrong.
I don't know why, but that seems to nuke the cartridge.  Even if I
completely disconnect the drive from the SCSI bus, inserting a
"treated" tape cartridge drives the device insane.  Lights continually
blink on and off slowly and I never get access to the device.  Even
manually ejecting the tape takes a *loooong* time.

Inserting a fresh tape, right out of the shrink wrap and the tape
drive behaves normally.  Insertion goes normally, a little
blinky-blinky and then stops to wait for instructions.  This time I
turned off compression and writing zeros instead of random bytes:

  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 0
  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 obs=512 count=32768

which takes about 20-25 seconds.

I can only assume that the tape drive is interpretting the
/dev/urandom data as data corruption.  Or maybe the random data is
causing the hardware compression algorithm to go insane.  I've got no
idea.  Has anyone seen anything like this before?

Going to give the backup another whirl tonight.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From Jkarlock at earthlink.net  Wed Jan 12 17:51:31 2005
From: Jkarlock at earthlink.net (Jim Karlock)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 17:51:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD Burning & Power Supply
In-Reply-To: <86r7kquoi6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <4.2.2.20050112173704.04133af0@mail.earthlink.net>

I downloaded the 5 CD set for Fedora Core3, checked them with md5sum and 
burned a set of 5 CDs. Three of the five failed the CD test. (on a windows 
98 machine) I tried redoing some with the same problem. Disk one & the 
rescue disk burned OK, but the others would not.

So I downloaded another set of iso filed to my Linux machine and burned CDs 
there. Same problem. Only disk one worked. (didn't try rescue disk)

I also noticed that a hard drive in one slot (all my drives are removable, 
so they get moved around a bit) would click (head returning noise) several 
times on startup. Turns out that slot shared power cable with the CD/DVD 
burner. (That drive slot was EMPTY) during the filed burn attempts above)

I replaced the 250watt power supply with a 450 watt unit, loaded up all 
three cages with hard drives and booted with no problem.

I tried burning a CD. No problem. Did a whole set.

I did not attempt to find if the supply is defective or if a 250 watt 
supply just can't power three 15 watt hard drives, a 30 watt CD/DVD burner 
+ mother board.

Maybe the Linux machine needs a new supply too.

I just posted this in hopes it might help someone else, but any comments or 
similar experiences?

Thanks
JK








From charlie at schluting.com  Wed Jan 12 18:17:21 2005
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 18:17:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD Burning & Power Supply
In-Reply-To: <4.2.2.20050112173704.04133af0@mail.earthlink.net>
References: <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>	<20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<4.2.2.20050112173704.04133af0@mail.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <41E5DA31.3050809@schluting.com>

Jim Karlock wrote:
> I replaced the 250watt power supply with a 450 watt unit, loaded up all 
> three cages with hard drives and booted with no problem.
> 
> I tried burning a CD. No problem. Did a whole set.
> 
> I just posted this in hopes it might help someone else, but any comments 
> or similar experiences?
> 

Yep.. I had a PSU go up in flames (literally) about 4 months ago. Before that 
happened, some of my 15K RPM scsi drives would click-n-seek many times during 
boot, and sometimes not be recgonized.
I woke up one morning to the smoke detector, and noticed smoke pouring out of 
my office. It took me about 30 seconds to figure out it was coming from MY 
computer, and when I pulled it out, smoke was rolling out like crazy. Not a 
good smell.
Ran to Fry's (ugh) to grab an emergency motherboard and PSU. After dinking with 
windows so I wouldn't have to reinstall (this is my gaming desktop :)) it 
booted fine and I haven't seen anything strange with the HDs since.
I've also seen the loud click-n-seek be a result of crappy molex Y connectors.

Good times.

-Charlie

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Wed Jan 12 19:03:48 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 19:03:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
Message-ID: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>

yo pluggers,

I rarely have the luxury of a healthy budget for buying or building new boxes; 
like most of us, I've made a career out of coaxing a little more life out of 
old Frankenhardware. Well, I'm starting a new project where there is actually 
enough budget to purchase some decent hardware. I am giddy with excitement. 
There will be two standalone servers: one IMAP and one Apache web server. The 
mailserver will have about 300 accounts. Not sure yet how much traffic is 
expected for the Web server, or if it is going to be burdened with horrid 
scripts or what. These are not quite mission-critical, maybe one step below 
mission-critical.

Would it make sense to go for server-quality mainboards, NICs, power supplies, 
and all those good things? We already decided on tower cases, for easy 
maintenance and future expansion, so box real estate is not a problem. What 
do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway that you don't get in the cheep 
stuff?

thanks!

--

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 12 19:01:04 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 03:01:04 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: UPS Automatic Shut-down
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-12, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>    I know that apc makes a utility to shut-down systems when the power goes
> out, and there's at least one other utility to do the same thing.
>
>    If folks are using these I'd appreciate any hints or gotcha's before I set
> up the system here. The UPS-HOWTO is not very helpful.

I recomment NUT: http://us1.networkupstools.org/

Unlike the free APC PowerChute (I don't know about apcupsd; APC does make
expensive editions that are network-aware), it operates in client/server mode,
so the monitoring host can inform other hosts of the power outage and they,
too, will shutdown.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

From charlie at schluting.com  Wed Jan 12 19:52:57 2005
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 19:52:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
In-Reply-To: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <41E5F099.7050506@schluting.com>

Carla Schroder wrote:
> 
> Would it make sense to go for server-quality mainboards, NICs, power supplies, 
> and all those good things? We already decided on tower cases, for easy 
> maintenance and future expansion, so box real estate is not a problem. What 
> do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway that you don't get in the cheep 
> stuff?
> 

Reliability, or course!
And depending on what you mean by cheap, performance. If you meant cheap, 
but with good specs; you probably won't notice a huge difference.

I'm sure people will post lots of links, so I'll leave that to them/google.
We recently bought 2 3.0GHz P4's and threw them in an Intel server board 
with 2GB of 400MHz RAM. Talk about sweet. With appropriate tweaks, 900Mb/s 
between the two is very possible.

Oh, and you get the ability to redirect the console to a serial port with 
server motherboards!

Many more.. but I must run and eat dinner now :)

-Charlie

> servers: one IMAP and one Apache web server. The mailserver will have
> about 300 accounts. Not sure yet how much traffic is expected for the
> Web server, or if it is going to be burdened with horrid scripts or
> what. These are not quite mission-critical, maybe one step below
> mission-critical.
>
> Would it make sense to go for server-quality mainboards, NICs, power
> supplies, and all those good things? We already decided on tower
> cases, for easy maintenance and future expansion, so box real estate
> is not a problem. What do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway
> that you don't get in the cheep stuff?
>

For me what makes a server is the hard drive subsystem, namely a
top-of-the-line SCSI controller with top-of-the-line SCSI drives.
Generally you'll get better results if you get a SCSI controller on
the mainboard instead of using an add-on card. So that's the main
consideration for the mainboard.

Next put your money toward top-quality power supplies and fans,
and select your case for good airflow.

After that I tend to go for the same commodity components that you
might find in a typical desktop PC, but things that some people
would look for depending on the intended use include:

- Server management functionality on the mainboard such as IPMI
- Wake-on-LAN feature in the NICs
- Hardware RAID

And more things that are not coming to my mind at the moment.

Terry


From redhat at crisponions.com  Wed Jan 12 20:04:11 2005
From: redhat at crisponions.com (David Phillips)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 20:04:11 -0800
Subject: [AthlonRob@axpr.net: Re: [PLUG] untar multiple files]
In-Reply-To: <20050112171027.GB10477@patch.com>
References: <20050112171027.GB10477@patch.com>
Message-ID: <1105589051.5452.1.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>

On Wed, 2005-01-12 at 09:10 -0800, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> ----- Forwarded message from AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> -----
> 
> On Tue, 2005-01-11 at 22:31 -0800, David Phillips wrote:
> > Does anyone know of an easy way to untar/zip multiple files at once?  I
> > figure a script is probably the best solution but unfortunately my
> > scripting skills are about non-existent at this point.
> 
> Learn for loops:
> 
> bash$ for i in *.tar.gz; do tar -xvzf $i; done
> 
> ----- End forwarded message -----
> 
> 
> I'll enthusiastically second Rob's recommendation.  Once you start to use
> loops they become second nature and you'll find lots of uses for them.
> 
> Incidently this could also look something like this if you hit enter
> rather than semicolon:
> 
> [mrasmuss at cmc02020 tmp]$ for i in *tgz
> do    
>    tar ztf $i 
> done
> <output of the command
> [mrasmuss at cmc02020 tmp]$
> 

That work great, Thanks!  A new door has opened :-)

Dave P



From plug at merlot.com  Wed Jan 12 20:30:22 2005
From: plug at merlot.com (plug at merlot.com)
Date: Wed, 12 Jan 2005 20:30:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
In-Reply-To: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20050113043022.GB10782@merlot.com>

Carla Schroder (carla at bratgrrl.com) typed this ...
> There will be two standalone servers: one IMAP and one Apache web server. The 
> mailserver will have about 300 accounts. Not sure yet how much traffic is 
> expected for the Web server, or if it is going to be burdened with horrid 
> scripts or what. These are not quite mission-critical, maybe one step below 
> mission-critical.

What are the requirements for uptime, response time, expansion, time
before upgrading is reasonable/expected? How much downtime is allowed in
the event of a failure? How much planned downtime will  your customers
allow?

How much admin time have you allocated for these boxes and the services
running on them? Will they be in your facility or a colo?

You can buy uptime, but it's very expensive unless you have written
contract guaranteeing that you will be lucky. If you find the gods who
issue those contracts, let me know. #:)

You can run both email and web on one server and use drbd and heartbeat
to make the other a hot spare. Apply a 4x multiplier to your normal
admin time if you go this way.  Actually, I think it's close to n^2
where n is the number of services you're using heartbeat to fail over. I
started down this path about a year ago then went a lower-reliability
path to save my sanity. I couldn't afford that much uptime. #:)

The Google formula is to use so many cheap computers that when a few of
them fail, it doesn't affect you. Of course, they wrote their software
to facilitate this behavior and you may not have this option. And they
have teams of contractors sitting in their data centers rebuilding
failed systems 24/7, another cost you probably don't want to bear.

Bottom line: it's a balance, and I don't know enough about what you've
got on each side of the equation to make a detailed suggestion. Except
to say that my last pair of servers have dual LAN onboard, one 10/100
and 1 gigE. I used the gigE as a back net for communication between the
two, and it works VERY well. If they have to talk to each other (for
authentication? backups?), I suggest that you use a motherboard with
dual LAN ports like my Tyan S2099 (though I'm not a big Tyan fan, this
board works very well).

--Kurt
-- 
----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Merlot Research Group, Inc               http://www.merlot.com
    kls[at]merlot.com       GPG key 82505A74      Jabber: MerlotQA

and memory.  What maybe a low end server now could be a middle/high end 
server faster than expected.

say that I'm using a board with SATA controller built in that handles 
1600+ email accounts with no problem.

Russell> I can only assume that the tape drive is interpretting the
Russell> /dev/urandom data as data corruption.  Or maybe the random
Russell> data is causing the hardware compression algorithm to go
Russell> insane.  I've got no idea.  Has anyone seen anything like
Russell> this before?

Galen> feel like experimenting, I'd try using a much larger blocksize,

Just rereading what I wrote, I started trying to think of alternative
interpretations.  I was able to write, error, rewind and write again
dd'd data from /dev/urandom last night with one tape.  The one thing I
didn't do last night was eject/reinsert.  Then we put in another tape
today and did the same thing.  The tape drive "does something" when
you insert it, probably reads some user-invisible information in a
tape preamble or something.  Then this afternoon I took a shrink
wrapped cartridge and put that in, was able to write my /dev/urandom
data, got an error, rewound, and ejected.  Reran a cleaning cartridge
and when I put the just-unwrapped, just-written tape back in, the
insertion-reading business went insane.  I *think* I'd seen the same
thing when I'd put in the second of the two previous tapes this
afternoon, but am not sure now and will have to check later.  The
behavior was totally unexpected.  I'll try again after I get this poor
guy's machine backing up reliably again.  Maybe try out the "broken"
tapes on my drive at home.

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu Jan 13 05:31:20 2005
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Tony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 07:31:20 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Re: UPS Automatic Shut-down
In-Reply-To: <slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <200501130731.20905.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Wednesday 12 January 2005 21:01, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On 2005-01-12, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
> >    I know that apc makes a utility to shut-down systems when the power
> > goes out, and there's at least one other utility to do the same thing.
> >
> >    If folks are using these I'd appreciate any hints or gotcha's before I
> > set up the system here. The UPS-HOWTO is not very helpful.
>
> I recomment NUT: http://us1.networkupstools.org/
>
> Unlike the free APC PowerChute (I don't know about apcupsd; APC does make
> expensive editions that are network-aware), it operates in client/server
> mode, so the monitoring host can inform other hosts of the power outage and
> they, too, will shutdown.
>
> Wil

"apcupsd" also supports monitoring over a network. We have several systems 
powered on some of our larger UPSs and so I have one server dedicated as the 
monitoring server with the signaling cable connected to it. The remaining 
systems are clients monitoring the UPS through the server.

The only caveat with this approach is that the network switch that is used for 
the interconnect needs to also be plugged into an UPS so no signaling is lost 
between any server and its associated clients in the event of a powerfailure.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From rlucas at tercent.com  Thu Jan 13 10:45:28 2005
From: rlucas at tercent.com (Randall Lucas)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 10:45:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
Message-ID: <41E6C1C8.9060209@tercent.com>

> What do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway that you don't 
 > get in the cheep stuff?

For one, you don't get "floor sweeps."  Literally, the pieces in the 
"free after rebate" NICs you get at Fry's may have been swept off the 
floor of a factory.

Another example is that with HP (Compaq) servers, you get ILO 
(integrated lights-out), which provides remote console access and remote 
power-off via a separate on-board NIC.

Another benefit (this more with a "system" than an individual board) is 
the availability of *exactly* the same part, by part number, be it from 
the manufacturer or off eBay -- not a putatively "compatible" part for 
replacement.  Also, others have likely tested your OS on *exactly* that 
same hardware -- no combinatorical nightmares with varying chipsets, etc.

With a complete server system, furthermore, you're getting something 
that's engineered, not just assembled.  Someone took the time to map the 
airflow through the case, measure the power demands of the RAID array, 
etc., not just plug things together until it boots OK.

Look at the resellers on eBay who sell new or refurb stuff that's still 
under warranty from IBM, HP, Dell (caveat lector, Dell has had in the 
past a mixed reputation on servers, including using the same model 
number for different grab-bags of parts).  Check 2 "speed increments" 
down from the blistering fastest new stuff, and you can fly 
business-class for nearly coach-price.

I hate to sound like a server sales rep, but I've had multiple white box 
clone PSUs and RAM sticks fail over many years, but I'm still waiting 
(with a box of factory-supplied backups) for any of the server-grade 
stuff to fail.

Best,

Randall

-- 
Randall Lucas			DF93EAD1
Tercent, Inc / SuperSurvey Online Surveys
http://www.supersurvey.com


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jan 13 11:07:56 2005

   Having done just that (it arrived yesterday), allow me to recommend
www.refurbups.com. I purchased a Smart-UPS 1400 for $189 + shipping. New
battery, guarantee, and a _lot_ less than new. This unit accommodates up to
950W so it will work with my server and workstation here at my desk.

   The sales staff there was candid and helpful in spec'ing my needs. The
data cable wasn't in the box but a quick e-mail exchange with them (it was
after 5:00 pm New York time) was followed by a message this morning that the
replacement has been sent and will be here Monday.

   I'll even donate the mouse pad they sent. :-)

I've recently been searching for a suitable motherboard for a server.
The board I found is a Supermicro P8SAA.  It's not an official server
motherboard, but it covers most of my wishlist.

  ECC
  SATA with NCQ support (Intel ICH6R)
  Intel Gbit ethernet
  serial ports
  no onboard video, but the BIOS can be redirected to a serial port

All of my previous systems have been SCSI, but I've decided to give SATA
a try.  I will probably install a Seagate SATA drive.

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Thu Jan 13 11:48:12 2005
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Tony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 13:48:12 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
In-Reply-To: <41E6C1C8.9060209@tercent.com>
References: <41E6C1C8.9060209@tercent.com>
Message-ID: <200501131348.12633.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Thursday 13 January 2005 12:45, Randall Lucas wrote:
> > What do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway that you don't
> >
>  > get in the cheep stuff?
>
[snip]

> Another example is that with HP (Compaq) servers, you get ILO
> (integrated lights-out), which provides remote console access and remote
> power-off via a separate on-board NIC.
>
> Another benefit (this more with a "system" than an individual board) is
> the availability of *exactly* the same part, by part number, be it from
> the manufacturer or off eBay -- not a putatively "compatible" part for
> replacement.  Also, others have likely tested your OS on *exactly* that
> same hardware -- no combinatorical nightmares with varying chipsets, etc.
>
> With a complete server system, furthermore, you're getting something
> that's engineered, not just assembled.  Someone took the time to map the
> airflow through the case, measure the power demands of the RAID array,
> etc., not just plug things together until it boots OK.
>
> Look at the resellers on eBay who sell new or refurb stuff that's still
> under warranty from IBM, HP, Dell (caveat lector, Dell has had in the
> past a mixed reputation on servers, including using the same model
> number for different grab-bags of parts).  Check 2 "speed increments"
> down from the blistering fastest new stuff, and you can fly
> business-class for nearly coach-price.
>
> I hate to sound like a server sales rep, but I've had multiple white box
> clone PSUs and RAM sticks fail over many years, but I'm still waiting
> (with a box of factory-supplied backups) for any of the server-grade
> stuff to fail.
>
> Best,
>
> Randall

I never thought about this much until working at a startup I was the lone 
Linux resource at the company at the time. We needed a system that was 
reliable and had a certain level of redundancy in it. We ended up going with 
HP/Compaq DL380G3 systems. Our requirements were for a server that could be 
used for our CVS repository, in house WIKI, and Bugzilla database.

The system is very critical and the HP server gave us the following features 
for reliability.

o Dual hot-swappable power supplies

o Built-in support for hardware RAID. We run hardware RAID-5 so we can hot 
swap a failed disk.

o The DIMMs are installed in pairs and so if one fails the system runs on the 
secondary. In fact we had a DIMM failure in one of our critical DL380G3 
system and the system just failed over to the spare DIMM in the pair and the 
amber system health LED was lit on the system. Obviously we replaced the 
failed DIMM at the earlest opportunity. The mainboard has numerous fault LEDs 
on it and so identifying the failed DIMM was trivial once we opened the case.

o The cooling fans are hot swappable and so the 2U rack system can be slide 
out, the top cover removed and cooling fans popped out and replaced.

Critical systems are connected to large UPSs and we have UPS monitoring 
enabled on all of our Linux servers. This allows us to have a clean shutdown 
if for some reason a poweroutage lasts longer than our UPS's battery 
capacity.

Obviously the HP DL380G3 systems are not cheap but it's nice that they have 
proven to be very reliable and they afford us the ability to hotswap some of 
the components without having to down a system to replace them.

After having DL380G3 systems running for nearly the last 1 1/2 years, the only 
reason any of our DL380G3 systems have gone down was to get new Linux kernels 
installed or the case of the one that had a failed DIMM.

I'm actually a developer at my company but since we lack knowledgeable Linux 
people in our small IT group I get tasked with doing most of the SA work for 
our Linux servers. I like to spend as little time as I can on Linux SA work 
and so having reliable servers keeps me doing what I like best which is 
software development.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

Message-ID: <20050113201351.GA12510@aracnet.com>

On Thu, Jan 13, 2005 at 06:18:13AM -0800, Jim Karlock wrote:
> I installed FC3 on a hard drive in one machine and moved that hard drive to 
> another machine. It hangs on power up.
> 
> Is this normal?
> 
> Is there a way to tell it that it is on a new machine?
> 
> The "new machine" is currently runing FC1, so it should not be a hardware 
> issue.
> 

Possibly a processor mismatch between the old and new machine. A binary
kernel can be very particular about wanting to run on the processor for
which it was compiled.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/


From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Jan 13 12:26:04 2005
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 12:26:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FedoraCore3 - moving to a new machine
In-Reply-To: <4.2.2.20050113054705.03e03880@mail.earthlink.net>
References: <slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<4.2.2.20050113054705.03e03880@mail.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <41E6D95C.4030000@ahapala.net>

Jim Karlock wrote:

> I installed FC3 on a hard drive in one machine and moved that hard 
> drive to another machine. It hangs on power up.
>
> Is this normal?
>
> Is there a way to tell it that it is on a new machine?
>
> The "new machine" is currently runing FC1, so it should not be a 
> hardware issue.
>
> Thanks
> JK
>
>
Jim,

My first thought is that the harddrive was a different IDE device on the 
install machine than on the new machine. If you installed FC3 while the 
HD was master on 2nd IDE channel(/dev/hdc) and then installed it as 
master on 1st IDE channel (/dev/hda) then the boot loader would try the 
wrong device.

Keith



From s.coffman at tradetrans.net  Thu Jan 13 12:34:06 2005
From: s.coffman at tradetrans.net (Steven D. Coffman)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 12:34:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Convert Sun Ultra5 to Linux
In-Reply-To: <1105411088.6543.69.camel@saitama.bonyari.com>
Message-ID: <013001c4f9af$3a6dbd80$4901a8c0@mango>



Thanks to all that responded. Tried some of those options and then
some.. Discovered what my real problem was is trying to load x86
platform software on a "risk ? " OS environment so it has no way of
reading the boot files (no x86 bios).

Thanks again for the quick response, just thought I'd update what I
discovered.

Steve

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Jack Morgan
Sent: Monday, January 10, 2005 6:38 PM
To: General Linux discussion and assistance
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Convert Sun Ultra5 to Linux

On Mon, 2005-01-10 at 14:36 -0800, Steven D. Coffman wrote:
> Hi All..
> Hope someone knows this. I have a Sun Ultra5 system and I am trying to
> install Linux over it. The danged OpenBoot system just won't let me
> execute a different boot disk, etc. It keeps going to it's default Sun
> system.
> I don't want to keep the data or the OS, it's old stuff and I'm using
> the box to install our new firewall using Linux.
> 
> Any clues to get around this and have it execute the boot disk would
> really help.

First, do stop + A to get to the OBP. Then type "probe-scsi"[1] to get a
list of installed hard disks. You can also type "printenv" to get a list
of environment variables and "help" should do just that :)  

As already mentioned, can do "boot cdrom" to boot from the cdrom
(assuming you have one) or "boot disk" to boot of the first disk, "boot
disk1" to boot off the second disk.

Here are a few links...

Debian sparc linux:

http://www.debian.org/releases/stable/sparc/install


Aurora sparc linux:

http://www.auroralinux.org/


Gentoo sparc linux:

http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-faq.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-obpreference.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gentoo-sparc-netboot-howto.xml
http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/handbook/handbook-sparc.xml


--
Jack Morgan

[1] probe-ide if it's a Sun blade which has ide disks

_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Thu Jan 13 13:27:58 2005
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)

From Steve.Daggett at Fiserv.com  Thu Jan 13 12:51:38 2005
From: Steve.Daggett at Fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 12:51:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Convert Sun Ultra5 to Linux
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D425C@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Steven D. Coffman wrote:
> 
> Thanks to all that responded. Tried some of those options and 
> then some.. Discovered what my real problem was is trying to 
> load x86 platform software on a "risk ? " OS environment so 
> it has no way of reading the boot files (no x86 bios).

  The SPARC's use a completely different processor chip than WinTel boxen.
The executables have to be compiled for the architecture.  

SPARC - Scalable Processor ARChitecture
RISC - Reduced Instruction Set Computer 

See the Wikipedia:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RISC

  It not just using the correct install disks.  You'll also need to locate
SPARC binaries or compile any programs which are not on the install media.  

Steve D...

IBM xSeries servers have a "press F2 for Diagnostics" option when the 
system boots.

Too many white-box, desktop systems come with no diagnostics at all!  
(Not even
a companion CD.)  So if the system is behaving flaky, you're unable to 
do anything
to verify the hardware.  Built-in mem and disk checkers are probably the 
sub-diag
sections I use most.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jan 13 21:00:57 2005
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu, 13 Jan 2005 21:00:57 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel upgrade
Message-ID: <20050114050057.55831.qmail@web50610.mail.yahoo.com>

I presently use Sarge, whose default kernel is 2.4.27,
but since I would like to try my hand at UDF packet
writing, I wanted to install one of the latest
kernels. I downloaded 2.6.9 kernel sources from
kernel.org and configured them in my home directory.

Upon booting the new kernel, it looked just like the
other one. Or so I thought. The digital camera didn't
work, and I noted that there was no support for
CONFIG_USB_UHCI or CONFIG_USB_OHCI in my .config, and
that's probably why. So now I want to rebuild the
kernel with just those changes (for now).

Do you have to put a dash in the "extraversion"
variable in the Makefile in order for it to appear in
the kernel version? In other words, if you put just
"A" after =, would it appear as 2.6.9A or 2.6.9-A?

According to one source, it is "necessary" to add such
a line as this to fstab when using a 2.6 kernel:

none  /sys   sysfs   defaults  0   0

I have /sys, but not the new line in fstab. I am
thinking about keeping a 2.4 kernel in /boot, just in
case a worthwhile program still needs it. Would a 2.4
kernel still boot properly if that line were added to
fstab?

 

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/


From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 13 21:17:47 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 Jan 2005 21:17:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <86acrdvkhi.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86acrdvkhi.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86zmzcsi6c.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> I'll try reverting (b) and (c) one at a time until I get
Russell> another failure (or don't).  I can't revert the BIOS as Intel
Russell> doesn't distribute old BIOS (and I don't really want to
Russell> anyway).  I particularly would like to get my tape drive
Russell> back.

Swapped client's tape drive back in and now I can't write more than
about a meg and a half, which is extremely reminiscent of the behavior
I was seeing a couple days ago.  And it appears that must be stuck in
a buffer anyway (and never makes it to tape), because:

  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=32768 count=1    
  dd: writing `/dev/nst0': Input/output error
  1+0 records in
  0+0 records out
  dd: closing output file `/dev/nst0': Input/output error

and because even after:

  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 obs=512 count=32768
  dd: writing to `/dev/nst0': Input/output error
  2944+0 records in
  2943+0 records out
  dd: closing output file `/dev/nst0': Input/output error

which apparently writes the ~1.5 meg to tape, a rewind is nearly
instantaneous.

It is possible there is a faulty connection at the tape drive.  I
noticed today that one of the wire retention mechanisms on the
connector didn't close.  The connector felt and looked seated, but I
couldn't get the wire (for those not familiar with the 50-pin
centronics connectors, think the printer end of a parallel port cable)
into the little holder ears on one side.

  <http://www.cablestogo.com/images/connectors/c50F.jpg>

I'll check again tomorrow.  Anyway, the plot thickens.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Jan 13 21:34:17 2005

On Thursday 13 January 2005 9:00 pm, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I presently use Sarge, whose default kernel is 2.4.27,
> but since I would like to try my hand at UDF packet
> writing, I wanted to install one of the latest
> kernels. I downloaded 2.6.9 kernel sources from
> kernel.org and configured them in my home directory.
> 
> Upon booting the new kernel, it looked just like the
> other one. Or so I thought. The digital camera didn't
> work, and I noted that there was no support for
> CONFIG_USB_UHCI or CONFIG_USB_OHCI in my .config, and
> that's probably why. So now I want to rebuild the
> kernel with just those changes (for now).
> 
> Do you have to put a dash in the "extraversion"
> variable in the Makefile in order for it to appear in
> the kernel version? In other words, if you put just
> "A" after =, would it appear as 2.6.9A or 2.6.9-A?

2.6.9A. There are no built-in spaces or anything, so type in exactly what you 
want.

> 
> According to one source, it is "necessary" to add such
> a line as this to fstab when using a 2.6 kernel:
> 
> none  /sys   sysfs   defaults  0   0
> 
> I have /sys, but not the new line in fstab. I am
> thinking about keeping a 2.4 kernel in /boot, just in
> case a worthwhile program still needs it. Would a 2.4
> kernel still boot properly if that line were added to
> fstab?
> 

No problem, it will boot fine. Any filesystems that it does not find simply 
won't be mounted, and you'll see some complaining in dmesg.

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> It is possible there is a faulty connection at the tape
Russell> drive.  I noticed today that one of the wire retention
Russell> mechanisms on the connector didn't close.  The connector felt
Russell> and looked seated, but I couldn't get the wire (for those not
Russell> familiar with the 50-pin centronics connectors, think the
Russell> printer end of a parallel port cable) into the little holder
Russell> ears on one side.

The office light was on, so I stopped in this evening and checked.
Although the wire retention mechanism doesn't close on one side, that
looks innocuous.  I moved the cable to the other connector, swapping
with the terminator.  When I powered up the drive and reinserted the
tape cartridge, it was still blinking when I left the office, and now
from home I am seeing the same ~1.5meg write behavior and then error,
e.g.:

  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=1024 count=2048
  dd: writing `/dev/nst0': Input/output error
  1440+0 records in
  1439+0 records out
  dd: closing output file `/dev/nst0': Input/output error

Hmm.  But now, my short writes are succeeding, e.g.:

  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=1024 count=1 
  1+0 records in
  1+0 records out
  
Double hmm:

  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  mt: /dev/nst0: Input/output error
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=1024 count=1024
  1024+0 records in
  1024+0 records out
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  mt: /dev/nst0: Input/output error
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # dd if=/dev/nst0 of=/tmp/test.out bs=1024 count=1024
  dd: reading `/dev/nst0': Input/output error
  0+0 records in
  0+0 records out

One clue.  Specs indicate the drive has a 2meg buffer.

Sigh.  I'll try the other drive again tomorrow.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From Jkarlock at earthlink.net  Fri Jan 14 00:38:04 2005
From: Jkarlock at earthlink.net (Jim Karlock)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 00:38:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FedoraCore3 - moving to a new machine
In-Reply-To: <41E6D95C.4030000@ahapala.net>
References: <4.2.2.20050113054705.03e03880@mail.earthlink.net>
	<slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501121544240.5972@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<slrncubo6t.v24.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<4.2.2.20050113054705.03e03880@mail.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <4.2.2.20050114003710.00d562d0@mail.earthlink.net>

At 12:26 PM 1/13/2005 , you wrote:
>Jim Karlock wrote:
>
>>I installed FC3 on a hard drive in one machine and moved that hard drive 
>>to another machine. It hangs on power up.
>>
>>Is this normal?
>>
>>Is there a way to tell it that it is on a new machine?
>>
>>The "new machine" is currently runing FC1, so it should not be a hardware 
>>issue.
>>
>>Thanks
>>JK
>>
>Jim,
>
>My first thought is that the harddrive was a different IDE device on the 
>install machine than on the new machine. If you installed FC3 while the HD 
>was master on 2nd IDE channel(/dev/hdc) and then installed it as master on 
>1st IDE channel (/dev/hda) then the boot loader would try the wrong device.
>
>Keith

Thanks, both slots are pri master.

Thanks
JK

>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

> moved that hard drive 
> >>to another machine. It hangs on power up.

I mentioned earlier on this list that I formerly had
FC2 installed, and, when I changed the display
adapter, Kudzu removed nearly all the hardware and I
never used the installation again. "Normal" may have
at least two meanings: Does it indicate that
everything is all right, or is it something you can
expect. In the latter sense, yes.

Problem:

I have a question regarding installing a Sony SDT-10000 tape drive in a Dell

adaptec SCSI controller showing up. It even displays that if finds the Sony
tape drive complete with the model SDT-10000
>From System Tools, Hardware Browser, SCSI devices I can see the following:
AHA-2940WPRO/AIC-788X
Manufacture: Adeptec
Driver: aic7xxx
I even checked to make sure that the device is showing up by pressing Ctrl A
during external SCSI controller card was displaying on boot up. It shows up
exactly where it should on target 6
The problem I am having is using the thing.

[root at boomer log]# /sbin/modprobe st - to load the 'st' driver, the SCSI

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Fri Jan 14 09:11:54 2005
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 09:11:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tool for reading raw sectors from diskette?
In-Reply-To: <1105162358.21204.10.camel@hermes.braithwaites.net>
References: <41DF1F3A.9090200@easystreet.com> <86zmzklgui.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1105162358.21204.10.camel@hermes.braithwaites.net>
Message-ID: <41E7FD5A.3010607@easystreet.com>

Ron Braithwaite wrote:

>On Fri, 2005-01-07 at 19:50 -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
>  
>
>>In my recent disk recovery work, I discovered a thing called
>>dd_rescue.  I initially assumed that it would have the same interface
>>as dd.  It didn't, but it did the job.  Here's the man page
>>description:
>>
>>  dd_rescue is a program that copies data from one file or block
>>  device to another, it is a tool to help you to save data from
>>  crashed partition.  It tries to read and if it fails it will go on
>>  with the next sectors, where tools like dd will fail.  If the
>>  copying process is interrupted by the user it is possible to
>>  continue at any position later.  It can copy backwards.
>>
>>Sounds like just the thing for you.
>>    
>>
>
>Found the source at: http://www.garloff.de/kurt/linux/ddrescue/
>  
>
Russell, Ron --

Thanks for the info.  "dd_rescue" is exactly what was needed!

I've grabbed all the nice ASCII text fragments.  Next chore will
be trying to find, piece together, and decipher an OpenOffice.org
spreadsheet ....

- Don



From ron at nutriware.com  Fri Jan 14 09:32:20 2005
From: ron at nutriware.com (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 09:32:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Cool FreeBSD sysadmin job for someone!
Message-ID: <1105723940.6322.49.camel@hermes.braithwaites.net>

Well, I saw a posting on a list for a sysadmin job with www.truthout.org
and foolishly applied for it. And they hired me.

Why did I do that? I have too much to do in too short a period of time
to take this on. I'm moving to Canada and studying for the LPI exam
(that's why I quit Free Geek). I must have been nuts.

If I could give them a lead or two for the sysadmin position, we would
all feel better about it.

Here's the scoop. They've got a bunch of FreeBSD machines (and 1 W2K box
you don't have to touch) hosted at rackspace. They want someone to
install Scoop (a very cool Perl app - http://scoop.kuro5hin.org/) on a
new machine and to answer their editors' technical questions. You
generally wouldn't need to deal with end users, just the folks working
on the site. This is a work from home gig, too.

If you want more info, please send an email to Marc Ash
<director at truthout.org> and tell him about yourself. This is a left-wing
news aggregation site, so bear that in mind...

If you want any more info on this, just give me a call at 503-267-3250.

-Ron




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jan 14 10:01:07 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 18:01:07 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Sony SDT - 10000 tape drive connected and can't find
	device name
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B71F49@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <slrncug26m.l17.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-14, Norm Coder <norm.coder at gemstone.com> wrote:
> Problem:
> Tape drive connected and not able to identify what device it is.

[Norm, please subscribe to the list so I don't have to manually approve
your posts.]

Does 'lsmod' show the 'st' driver?  If not, then you'll have to manually
load it--'modprobe st'.  Then see if dmesg shows anything.

Wil

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Fri Jan 14 11:57:30 2005

> Dick Steffens wrote:
> >
> > I've grabbed all the nice ASCII text fragments.  Next chore will be 
> > trying to find, piece together, and decipher an OpenOffice.org 
> > spreadsheet ....
> 
> I recall reading somewhere that OpenOffice uses XML for their 
> file formats. 

  Correct... An OpenOffice spreadsheet is a multi-part file, in XML,
contained in a ZIP archive.  

  Thusly...

[steve at linux Temp]$ ls
temp.sxc

[steve at linux Temp]$ file temp.sxc 
temp.sxc: Zip archive data, at least v2.0 to extract

[steve at linux Temp]$ unzip temp.sxc 
Archive:  temp.sxc
 extracting: mimetype                
  inflating: content.xml             
  inflating: styles.xml              
 extracting: meta.xml                
  inflating: settings.xml            
  inflating: META-INF/manifest.xml   

[steve at linux Temp]$ ls
content.xml  META-INF  meta.xml  mimetype  settings.xml  styles.xml
temp.sxc

[steved at linux-dev Temp]$ head content.xml

e:table-row table:style-name="ro1"><table:table-cell
table:value-type="float"
table:value="7"><text:p>7</text:p></table:table-cell></table:table-row><tabl
e:table-row table:style-name="ro1"><table:table-cell
table:value-type="float"
table:value="8"><text:p>8</text:p></table:table-cell></table:table-row><tabl
e:table-row table:style-name="ro1"><table:table-cell
table:value-type="float"
table:value="9"><text:p>9</text:p></table:table-cell></table:table-row></tab
le:table><table:table table:name="Sheet2"
table:style-name="ta1"><table:table-column table:style-name="co1"
table:default-cell-style-name="Default"/><table:table-row
table:style-name="ro1"><table:table-cell/></table:table-row></table:table><t
able:table table:name="Sheet3" table:style-name="ta1"><table:table-column
table:style-name="co1"
table:default-cell-style-name="Default"/><table:table-row
table:style-name="ro1"><table:table-cell/></table:table-row></table:table></
office:body></office:document-content>
[steve at linux Temp]$

From pem at nellump.net  Fri Jan 14 17:01:47 2005
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 17:01:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Burning Question
In-Reply-To: <200501142140.j0ELena79301@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <200501142140.j0ELena79301@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <20050115010147.GA13939@nellump.net>

On Fri, Jan 14, 2005 at 01:40:46PM -0800, William A Morita wrote:

> Does anyone have any pointers on burning data to DVD+RW from Linux?
> All I can currently find seems to be limited to CD.
> I am using RH9.

I've used "dvd+rw tools" to great success. They work very similarly to
the mkisofs/cdrecord tools used for burning CDs.

http://fy.chalmers.se/~appro/linux/DVD+RW/


Paul

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan 15 10:19:45 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 15 Jan 2005 10:19:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <86vfa0scys.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86acrdvkhi.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86zmzcsi6c.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86vfa0scys.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86r7kmpnb2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> Sigh.  I'll try the other drive again tomorrow.

Okay, so I go in yesterday.  The tape I tried to write on Thursday
caused drive grief on insertion in my drive too, but with another
pristine tape I was able to write 5 meg of zeros (compression off),
then read it back out.  

  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 0
  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=512 count=10240
  # dd if=/dev/nst0 of=/tmp/test.out bs=512 count=10240

Replace it with clients tape drive and it *very* slowly read it back
out.  My drive read it back in less than 10 seconds.  His drive was
still reading with the read/write light going on/off irregularly for
several minutes before I interrupted the dd read.  When I did
interrupt it, there was some data (circa 1+ meg) that had been read.
I swapped my drive back in and the same tape read fine in a few
seconds, just like before.  So it looks like something wrong with
clients tape drive.  I leave my tape drive connected and prepare to
go.

Then I think that we might as well test the power supply at the same
time, so I disconnected my temporary 300W power supply and reconnect
the case power supply (still attached to the box) and fire it back up.
Tape backup ran last night.  This morning, I have no contact with the
box again.  Looks (from home) like the same behavior of powering off.
So, it looks like the power supply probably *is* a culprit, but that
the client's tape drive is behaving badly as well.  Or maybe the
poweroff'ing behavior is related to the SCSI card or external cable.
We are definitely seeing a deviation between the tape drives, so that
explains part of the pathology, but evidently not all of it.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From petel at l1.pdxeng.com  Fri Jan 14 08:54:55 2005
From: petel at l1.pdxeng.com (Pete Lancashire)
Date: Fri, 14 Jan 2005 08:54:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
In-Reply-To: <41E5F099.7050506@schluting.com>
References: <200501121903.49469.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<41E5F099.7050506@schluting.com>
Message-ID: <1105721694.20011.53.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

Depends on the applicaton. For example in a cluster, or distributed
configuration single point is lower on the matrix. And even though
high(er) end mother boards, Intel, Serverworks for example may have
higher throughput, or be able to hold more RAM, the cost ratio may
not be all that good.

As in any system analysis, I suggest doing a matrix of requirements,
and then match up the kit you find.

You mentioned towers, did you go with a 'server' quality case ? 400W+
power supplies, extra fans, etc ? Sometimes $150-200 for a
case is worth it.

I'm not knocking higher end kit, there is a reason servers such as
the SUN 280s I filled a a rack with were worth the price.

-pete "Ah to be able to put 16GB-64GB of RAM in a box, database heaven"


On Wed, 2005-01-12 at 19:52, Charlie Schluting wrote:
> Carla Schroder wrote:
> > 
> > Would it make sense to go for server-quality mainboards, NICs, power supplies, 
> > and all those good things? We already decided on tower cases, for easy 
> > maintenance and future expansion, so box real estate is not a problem. What 
> > do you get in a "server" mobo or NIC anyway that you don't get in the cheep 
> > stuff?
> > 
> 
> Reliability, or course!
> And depending on what you mean by cheap, performance. If you meant cheap, 
> but with good specs; you probably won't notice a huge difference.
> 
> I'm sure people will post lots of links, so I'll leave that to them/google.
> We recently bought 2 3.0GHz P4's and threw them in an Intel server board 
> with 2GB of 400MHz RAM. Talk about sweet. With appropriate tweaks, 900Mb/s 
> between the two is very possible.
> 
> Oh, and you get the ability to redirect the console to a serial port with 
> server motherboards!
> 
> Many more.. but I must run and eat dinner now :)
> 
> -Charlie
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug



From dale at zeutenhorst.com  Sat Jan 15 13:55:38 2005
From: dale at zeutenhorst.com (Dale Zeutenhorst)
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 13:55:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "server" quality components
In-Reply-To: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4258@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4258@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <200501151355.38888.dale@zeutenhorst.com>

On Thursday 13 January 2005 09:20 am, Daggett, Steve wrote:
>
>   Get a large expensive UPS unit.  Over-spec the hell out of it.  Having
> clean, reliable power is the biggest indicator of uptime that I've seen.
>
> Steve D...
>

Be careful about over spec-ing a UPS unit - Most units are designed to work in 
the 40% to 90% load range and will not regulate the power correctly out side 
that range. 
I worked on a server in a small business once where they had purchased a used 
2KVA unit with new batteries and one PC server on it that was constantly 
giving them problems. The "fix" was to plug in the server's monitor, their 
switch and three other computers to the UPS, after that I did not touch the 
server for 6 months.

Dale
