From aarontc at gmail.com  Sat Jan 15 18:00:12 2005
From: aarontc at gmail.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Sat, 15 Jan 2005 18:00:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Neighbour table overflow
Message-ID: <41f575d1050115180060bc1528@mail.gmail.com>

I have a linux box doing routing for my network, and it's worked fine
thus far. However, I am starting to experience some problems and
hoping someone knows what I can do. I've googled this message and
everything I found seemed to indicated I needed to enable my loopback
interface - but it is and always has been enabled. /etc/hosts has a
localhost entry.

# uname -a
Linux router 2.4.28-gentoo-r4 #2 Sat Jan 8 19:13:17 PST 2005 i586
Pentium MMX GenuineIntel GNU/Linux

---- log snippit ----
Jan 15 10:03:25 router NET: 41 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:25 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:25 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:25 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:25 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:26 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:26 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:26 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:27 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:27 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:27 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:30 router NET: 28 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:30 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:35 router NET: 74 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:35 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:40 router NET: 144 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:40 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:45 router NET: 180 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:45 router Neighbour table overflow.
Jan 15 10:03:50 router NET: 80 messages suppressed.
Jan 15 10:03:50 router Neighbour table overflow.

TIA for any advice.
Aaron

construction.)

3) We can drink ourselves into an Advanced state.

Any comments?

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jan 16 04:17:26 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 16 Jan 2005 04:17:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] memtest86 interpretation
Message-ID: <86y8eto9ex.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


Someone hates me.

Back in December, I built an NFS server with four 80gig IDE drives, a
gig of RAM and a 2.53 GHz P4 on an Intel D845GBV motherboard.  Two
days ago, after working flawlessly for a month, it oops'd and locked
up.  I didn't notice it right away because I haven't moved anything
crucial to it yet.

I rebooted and it came back up fine.  A few hours later it crashed
again.  I decided to maybe try building a new kernel, however while
doing so I got classic random gcc errors.  When I'd rerun "make" it
would carry on over the same places it had seen errors.  Started
looking like maybe memory errors.  So, I downloaded memtest86 3.2 and
ran it.  Found errors.  There are two memory modules (crucial), and I
tried them one at a time in different slots and get errors on both of
them.  What are the chances two different parts failed at the same
time?  

Tomorrow I plan to test the memory in a different motherboard and see
what I get there.  I could try the CPU too.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sun Jan 16 10:29:51 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 10:29:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] memtest86 interpretation 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "16 Jan 2005 04:17:26 PST."
	<86y8eto9ex.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> 
Message-ID: <20050116182956.C916F8F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> wrote:

> 
> Someone hates me.
> 
> Back in December, I built an NFS server with four 80gig IDE drives, a
> gig of RAM and a 2.53 GHz P4 on an Intel D845GBV motherboard.  Two
> days ago, after working flawlessly for a month, it oops'd and locked
> up.  I didn't notice it right away because I haven't moved anything
> crucial to it yet.
> 
> I rebooted and it came back up fine.  A few hours later it crashed
> again.  I decided to maybe try building a new kernel, however while
> doing so I got classic random gcc errors.  When I'd rerun "make" it
> would carry on over the same places it had seen errors.  Started
> looking like maybe memory errors.  So, I downloaded memtest86 3.2 and
> ran it.  Found errors.  There are two memory modules (crucial), and I
> tried them one at a time in different slots and get errors on both of
> them.  What are the chances two different parts failed at the same
> time?  

Virtually nil.  You might want to swap in a different power supply and
rerun memtest86.  Also double check the BIOS memory settings to be sure
that the memory timing is using the SPD data.

> 
> Tomorrow I plan to test the memory in a different motherboard and see
> what I get there.  I could try the CPU too.
> 

I wouldn't bother swapping CPUs since the memory controller is in the
north bridge.  I think you may end up having to send the board back to
Intel.

galen


From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jan 16 11:13:25 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 16 Jan 2005 11:13:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] memtest86 interpretation
In-Reply-To: <1105898790.8282.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <86y8eto9ex.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1105898790.8282.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <86sm51nq5m.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Dan" == Dan Young <dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us> writes:

Russell> Someone hates me.

Russell> Back in December, I built an NFS server with four 80gig IDE
Russell> drives, a gig of RAM and a 2.53 GHz P4 on an Intel D845GBV
Russell> motherboard.

Dan> Is this the same one you had a bad processor for a while back at
Dan> the Clinic?

Yeah, sort of.  

You might recall that last time I had replaced the motherboard while
trying to find the problem.  The machine wouldn't POST then and it
wasn't clear what the guilty party was.  When I discovered that the
CPU was bad (thanks to your generous loan), I RMA'd the CPU and got a
replacement that has worked since in a desktop box.

The box involved now has the replacement CPU, the pre-clinic
motherboard and brand new memory.  When I built this NFS server, I
ordered a new CPU (a 2.8 GHz) which I put in the desktop box and moved
the 2.53 GHz CPU into the NFS server.

So, actually, none of the physical parts I brought to the clinic are
involved now, except that it involves a motherboard that I had
previously replaced during debugging of that problem and a CPU that I
received as a consequence of that clinic.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jan 16 13:18:49 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 13:18:49 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Lightweight X Graphic Viewers?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501161314350.7062@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   For years I used xv as a quick-loading graphic viewer. I know it does
more, but that's how I used it. However, it's not included in the Slackware
distribution and I'm having fits trying to compile it from source. I wrote
to the author, but the site's not been updated since 2000-2001 (except for
the basset hound pages).

   Are there alternatives that folks like? I use it just to check the odd
icon or other graphic file and to view images attached to e-mail messages.
The GIMP is quite large and takes too long to load for a quick look at an
image when no manipulation is to be done.

TIA,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

ImageMagick is included with most distros.

Terry

From alan at clueserver.org  Sun Jan 16 18:17:15 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Sun, 16 Jan 2005 18:17:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] memtest86 interpretation
In-Reply-To: <86oefpnotq.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050116182956.C916F8F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
	<86oefpnotq.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1105928235.28724.32.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Sun, 2005-01-16 at 11:42 -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:
> 
> Galen> Virtually nil.  You might want to swap in a different power
> Galen> supply and rerun memtest86.  Also double check the BIOS memory
> Galen> settings to be sure that the memory timing is using the SPD
> Galen> data.
> 
> The memory timing stuff is all set to default.  I'll see if I can
> scrounge up another power supply to test.


Do the memory errors appear at the same spot or different ones?  Can you
get some good ram to test?  Possible that something has gone wrong on
the motherboard and its flaking.

Also make sure that your power supply is strong enough for the
motherboard.  Some of the AMD motherboards want a pretty beefy power
supply.

Galen> I wouldn't bother swapping CPUs since the memory controller is
Galen> in the north bridge.  I think you may end up having to send the
Galen> board back to Intel.

Well, this might be interesting then.

Starting configuration (1):

   NFS Box                       Desktop
   Intel D845GBV motherboard     Intel D845GEBV2

   Intel P4 2.53 GHz             Intel P4 2.8 GHz
   Crucial 2x512MG,266,CL2.5     Crucial 2x512MB,333,CL2.5
   Memtest: Failures             Memtest: No Failures

Configuration (2):

   NFS Box                       Desktop
   Intel D845GBV motherboard     Intel D845GEBV2

   Intel P4 2.53 GHz             Intel P4 2.8 GHz
   Crucial    ---------------->  Crucial 2x512MG,266,CL2.5
   Memtest: N/A                  Memtest: No Failures

Configuration (3):

   NFS Box                       Desktop
   Intel D845GBV motherboard     Intel D845GEBV2

   Intel P4 2.53 GHz --------->  Intel P4 2.53 GHz
   Crucial    ---------------->  Crucial 2x512MG,266,CL2.5
   Memtest: N/A                  Memtest: Failures!


Maybe some kind of cache failure?  These CPU's were originally boxed
retail Intel parts, so I am using their bundled heatsink/fans.  The
fans in both boxes spin.  Beyond that, I can't say much.

seeing before.

I think we have enough evidence to indict the CPU at this stage.

>>>>> "Alan" == Alan  <alan at clueserver.org> writes:

Russell> The Err-Bits column in Memtest86 shows 00001000 on all of the
Russell> errors that I've seen.

Alan> Are the contacts clean on the memory slot?

Maybe slightly worn at this point, but I think we can conclude that it
isn't a memory slot issue.  When the 2.8GHz CPU is in (on two
different motherboards), the memory tests fine.  When the 2.53GHz CPU
is in (on the same two different motherboards) the memory tests bad.
Two different sets of RAM.

I think we can conclude it is the 2.53GHz CPU.  I don't quite
understand what would cause it to fail just now, but the behavior
clearly moves with the CPU.  My records indicate the purchase was
about 15 months ago, and (after the original was RMA'd) it has been
performing without obvious flaw over that period, up until last
Thursday evening.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 17 09:48:31 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 09:48:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] memtest86 interpretation
In-Reply-To: <20050117073632.343268F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20050117073632.343268F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <1105984112.7605.38.camel@dell>

On Sun, 2005-01-16 at 23:36 -0800, Galen Seitz wrote:
> If the problem follows the CPU, then it pretty much has to be the CPU.
> It's a bit odd that you are able to run any code at all.

It *is* odd, isn't it?

I had a similar thing happen to me some time back.  I had artifacts
appearing when I watched DVDs or AVIs on my old Duron 650.  They would
get pretty bad, but then drop off to nothing.  If I used VLC on the box,
they were there.  If I used VLS on it, then VLC on a different box, they
weren't there.

Sometimes (not always) mencoder-created files would have these
artifacts.  Sometimes they were clean.  Sometimes mencoder would seg
fault instead of encoding.

I figured it was the video chip on my motherboard, so I swapped
motherboards.  I was wrong.  Eventually I finally replaced the CPU...
and the problem magically disappeared.  I'd never heard of CPUs halfway
going out like that... it was an educational experience.  :-)

I loved that old Duron, though.. it was a good chip.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Jan 17 10:17:35 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 10:17:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] amavisd-new and banned files
Message-ID: <20050117181740.56DA98F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>


I need to let someone mail me a .exe file, but I'm having trouble.  I
added the following line to amavisd.conf and reloaded amavisd, but it is
still blocking the email due to a banned filename.  I am the sole
recipient of the email, so it shouldn't be blocked due to other
recipients.  What am I doing wrong?

@bypass_banned_checks_acl = qw( user at somedomain );

amavis version is amavisd-new-20030616-p10


thanks,
galen


From cooper at gencom.us  Mon Jan 17 11:26:09 2005

Hi,

I've been working on real-time networked strategy game that incorporates
actual Geographic Information Systems (GIS) information and NATO map
symbology standards.

Here's the project's (temporary) web site with screen images here:

  http://www.intrinzix.net

I can map the entire globe this way.

This project has turned out to be a fun way to use work with GIS and
it's reasonable to say that I've learned a good deal about civil
engineering as well.

I'm happy to share the source code; I should have a CVS repository up in
a few days. 

Enjoy!


-Coop

Message-ID: <20050117202703.EBD368F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Richard C. Steffens <rsteff.l at comcast.net> wrote:

> On Monday 17 January 2005 10:17 am, Galen Seitz wrote:
> > I need to let someone mail me a .exe file, but I'm having trouble.  I
> > added the following line to amavisd.conf and reloaded amavisd, but it is
> > still blocking the email due to a banned filename.
> 
> Wouldn't it be easier to have the sender rename the file and change the .exe 
> extension, or just drop it? Or does amavis inspect the content of the file in 
> addition to looking at the filename?
> 

amavis runs the file command to determine the file type, so renaming 
wouldn't help.

I figured out my mistake.  Whitelisting only works on the recipient address,
since the sender address is easily forged.

galen

consider upgrading... There have been lots of improvements.

>
> Have them zip it with a password.
>

That will work with his version of amavisd-new; however, newer versions can
be configured to hold or reject password-protected zip files in response to
the recent virus that sent them.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jan 18 07:15:05 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)

Subject: [PLUG] Andrew Tridgell joins OSDL
Message-ID: <20050118151505.GA8092@gate.kl-ic.com>


This just in:

http://www.osdl.org/newsroom/press_releases/2005/2005_01_17_beaverton.html

Andrew Tridgell, the Australian fellow who started both the Samba and
the Rsync projects, has joined the Open Source Development Labs of
Beaverton as the second appointed Fellow (Linus Torvalds was the first).

tridge, as you may remember, visited us in August and attended the
Advanced Topics meeting for Chris Wright's talk on the Virtualization
of Linux.

The article doesn't mention it, but I assume he will stay in Oz and
work remotely.  Perhaps it is time to lobby OSDL to hire Larry Wall
of Perl fame as their *third* appointed Fellow.  

Then they can set up a subsidiary, the Free Software Development Labs,
and hire Stallman.

Keith

From bspears at easystreet.com  Tue Jan 18 10:22:49 2005
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:22:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Moving evolution data
Message-ID: <1106072570.3669.8.camel@mercury.spears.org>

I'd like to import evolution data from an existing installation to a new
one.  I've tried moving data from the old addressbook to the new one,
but it ignores the data. Trying to import the *.db doesn't work.  Gives
some error like "no such importer".

Any advice?
-- 
Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>



From ron at nutriware.com  Tue Jan 18 10:45:57 2005
From: ron at nutriware.com (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:45:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Moving evolution data
In-Reply-To: <1106072570.3669.8.camel@mercury.spears.org>
References: <1106072570.3669.8.camel@mercury.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1106073957.6351.7.camel@hermes.braithwaites.net>

On Tue, 2005-01-18 at 10:22 -0800, Bill Spears wrote:
> I'd like to import evolution data from an existing installation to a new
> one.  I've tried moving data from the old addressbook to the new one,
> but it ignores the data. Trying to import the *.db doesn't work.  Gives
> some error like "no such importer".
> 
> Any advice?

tar xzvf evolution.tgz ~/evolution  # version 1.x
-or-
tar xzvf evolution.tgz ~/.evolution # v.2.x

I've had problems picking up everything when I wasn't root (but not
consistently, so I don't know what is going on), so watch for error
messages.

-Ron

Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH WS3
Message-ID: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>

I installed RH WS3 on a Dell Optiplex GX280 and noticed I named slice 6 of
the partition of my second disk /hot2 and it should have been /hoth2. Is
there an easy way to rename a file system? 
I reinstalled RH and learned a lot about re-registering with RH and up2date
in the process.
What I am looking for is a link, white paper, or step-by-step directions on
how to change the name on a file system.
 


Norman Coder
System Administrator
Gemstone Systems, Inc.
1260 NW Waterhouse St.
Beaverton, OR 97006
503-533-3367
 


From mel97215 at comcast.net  Tue Jan 18 13:06:48 2005

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Tue Jan 18 13:16:20 2005
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 13:16:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH WS3
In-Reply-To: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <41ED7CA4.4080107@easystreet.com>

Norm Coder wrote:

>I installed RH WS3 on a Dell Optiplex GX280 and noticed I named slice 6 of
>the partition of my second disk /hot2 and it should have been /hoth2. Is
>there an easy way to rename a file system? 
>I reinstalled RH and learned a lot about re-registering with RH and up2date
>in the process.
>What I am looking for is a link, white paper, or step-by-step directions on
>how to change the name on a file system.
> 
>

1) Unmount the file system, and remove it's current mount point.
    # umount /hot2
    # rmdir /hot2

2) Update the entry in /etc/fstab.
    # vi /etc/fstab
        ... use whatever editor you like ... my bias is 'vi'
        ... change the "hot2" in 2nd column to "hoth2"

3) Create a new mount point (an empty directory with the correct pathname),
   and mount it.
    # mkdir /hoth2
    # mount /hoth2

4) ... if you need to change the filesystem label, that easily done, too.
  

- Don




From chaz at bctonline.com  Tue Jan 18 13:08:03 2005
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 13:08:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH WS3
In-Reply-To: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <B0004503109@bct-mail.bctonline.com>

Perhaps I don't understand what your problem is but all you should have to
do is create the directory /hoth2 and edit /etc/fstab to mount your second
disk to it.
umount /hot2
mkdir /hoth2
vi /etc/fstab
mount /hoth2

Let me know if you need more...
-chaz
Charles L. Sliger,    Information Systems Engineer,    chaz at bctonline.com
"no matter where you go, there you are..."

From mikeraz at patch.com  Tue Jan 18 14:07:03 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 14:07:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH WS3
In-Reply-To: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <20050118220703.GB22658@patch.com>

Norm Coder wrote:
> I installed RH WS3 on a Dell Optiplex GX280 and noticed I named slice 6 of
> the partition of my second disk /hot2 and it should have been /hoth2. Is
> there an easy way to rename a file system? 

It sounds like you're looking for the e2label command.

NAME
   e2label - Change the label on an ext2 filesystem

SYNOPSIS
   e2label device [ new-label ]

DESCRIPTION
   e2label  will  display  or  change  the  filesystem  label  on the ext2
   filesystem located on device.

   If the optional argument new-label is not present, e2label will  simply
   display the current filesystem label.

   If  the  optional  argument new-label is present, then e2label will set
   the filesystem label to be new-label.  Ext2 filesystem labels can be at
   most  16  characters  long;  if new-label is longer than 16 characters,
   e2label will truncate it and print a warning message.

   ...


-- 
    Michael Rasmussen, Portland Oregon  
  Be appropriate && Follow your curiosity
 http://meme.patch.com/memes/BicycleRiding
   Get Fixed:  http://www.dampfixie.org
  The fortune cookie says:
If all the Chinese simultaneously jumped into the Pacific off a 10 foot
platform erected 10 feet off their coast, it would cause a tidal wave
that would destroy everything in this country west of Nebraska.



From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue Jan 18 14:10:24 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 14:10:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH WS3
In-Reply-To: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
References: <75D481373A76D311A5790090274F2B5C05B72349@mailsrv1.gemstone.com>
Message-ID: <20050118221024.GC24375@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jan 18, 2005 at 12:43:36PM -0800, Norm Coder wrote:
> I installed RH WS3 on a Dell Optiplex GX280 and noticed I named slice 6 of
> the partition of my second disk /hot2 and it should have been /hoth2. Is
> there an easy way to rename a file system? 
> I reinstalled RH and learned a lot about re-registering with RH and up2date
> in the process.
> What I am looking for is a link, white paper, or step-by-step directions on
> how to change the name on a file system.

OK, some silly semantics: There are two things you could be talking
about: the "mount point" (where the file system shows up in the
directory structure, e.g. /boot) and the "label", which is a name
stuck on a file system.  Red Hat likes to make the label of a
filesystem the same as its mount point, so the filesystem mounted at
/boot would be labeled "/boot", but it don't gotta be that way.

I'm gonna guess you want to do both, so it'd be like this:

Figure out what device is /hot2 (e.g. /dev/hdc3)

Become Root

edit /etc/fstab, find the line that looks something like:
  label=/hot2   /hot2   ext3  blahblah  some numbers
and change both instances of /hot2 to /hoth2

umount /hot2

mv /hot2 /hoth2

If it's ext2 or ext3, do:
  tune2fs -L /hoth2 /dev/hdc3  (or whatever device is /hot2)

mount /hoth2

and Bob's yer uncle.

Disclaimer: No warrantees, not tested on live animals and if flying
monkeys steal your data, please do not sue me.


From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Tue Jan 18 14:13:51 2005
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 14:13:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] changing file system names after installation of RH
 WS 3
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4274@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

 
Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> 
> Norm Coder wrote:
> > I installed RH WS3 on a Dell Optiplex GX280 and noticed I 
> > named slice 
> > 6 of the partition of my second disk /hot2 and it should have been 
> > /hoth2. Is there an easy way to rename a file system?
> 
> It sounds like you're looking for the e2label command.
> 
> NAME
>    e2label - Change the label on an ext2 filesystem
> 
> SYNOPSIS
>    e2label device [ new-label ]

  Or you can use the "tune2fs -L" to change the label.  

  Then edit your /etc/fstab file to match the new partition label.  

Steve D...

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 19 09:26:19 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 09:26:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] postfix, dovecot, thunderbird?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501190910180.13073-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

I'm attempting to move from sendmail, and a logon ( to access pine ) to 
IMAP for my personal mail account.

So far I've got postfix running just fine, calling procmail for the
delivery agent, processing my personal .procmailrc file ( placing messages
in folders ), and Thunderbird connecting to the IMAP server (IMAPS).  The
issue I'm having Thunderbird doens't see folder layout ( Maildir ) that
procmail (?) is creating.  In the directory $HOME/Maildir the messages end
up -- mostly -- in the correct directory(/folder) but in a subdirectory
named cur.

Anyone using this combination that could offer some insight as to why
Thunderbird doesn't see the folders.  I've done this with a different IMAP
server and it works.  ( I know about subscribing to the folders and
refreshing the folder list, etc. )  The main difference is the other IMAP
server uses mbox and I'm trying to use Maildir.

Much as I like pine I'd prefer to use one mail client to access the half
dozen accounts I have to monitor from two different locations ( home and
work ).


TIA,
Rod

    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"




From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Wed Jan 19 10:35:01 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 10:35:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] JavaScript Communication Between Frames
Message-ID: <200501191035.01431.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

Are then any JavaScript guru's out there?

I understand from a book I'm reading (Danny Goodman's JavaScript Handbook) 
that it is possible to put JavaScript code in the head of a frameset page 
that can be called from the other pages loaded by the frameset. I've seen an 
example work, but I don't see what I'm missing to get my example to work. 

Here's my example:

(file name: twoFrame.html)
<html>
	<head>
		<title>Two Frame Test</title>
		<script type="text/javascript" language="javascript">
		<!-- Start Script
			// function to process the click of the button
			function btnClick() {
				document.form1.text1.value = "You clicked this button."
				document.form2.text2.value = "You clicked the button on the other form."
			}
		// End Script -->
		</script>
	</head>
	<frameset frameborder=1 rows="25%,*">
		<frame name="frameOne" src="frameOne.html">
		<frame name="frameTwo" src="frameTwo.html">
	</frameset>
</html>

(file name: frameOne.html)
<html>
	<body>
		This is Frame One<br />
		<form name = "form1" action = "action">
		  <input type = "button" value = "Push this button"
			onclick="parent.btnClick()" />
		  <br />
		  <br />
		  <input type="text" name="text1" size="50" />
		</form>
	</body>
</html>

(file name: frameTwo.html)
<html>
	<body>
		This is Frame Two<br />
		<form name = "form2" action = "action">
		  <input type="text" name="text2" size="50" />
		</form>
	</body>
</html>


I assume there's something important I'm missing. Any idea what? And, any 
recommendation on where to find JavaScript examples that do this sort of 
thing?

Thanks in advance.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/


From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Jan 19 10:42:12 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 10:42:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] postfix, dovecot, thunderbird?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501190910180.13073-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501190910180.13073-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1106160132.7645.20.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Wed, 2005-01-19 at 09:26 -0800, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I'm attempting to move from sendmail, and a logon ( to access pine ) to 
> IMAP for my personal mail account.
> 
> So far I've got postfix running just fine, calling procmail for the
> delivery agent, processing my personal .procmailrc file ( placing messages
> in folders ), and Thunderbird connecting to the IMAP server (IMAPS).  The
> issue I'm having Thunderbird doens't see folder layout ( Maildir ) that
> procmail (?) is creating.  In the directory $HOME/Maildir the messages end
> up -- mostly -- in the correct directory(/folder) but in a subdirectory
> named cur.
> 
> Anyone using this combination that could offer some insight as to why
> Thunderbird doesn't see the folders.  I've done this with a different IMAP
> server and it works.  ( I know about subscribing to the folders and
> refreshing the folder list, etc. )  The main difference is the other IMAP
> server uses mbox and I'm trying to use Maildir.

It isn't Thunderbird not seeing them, it's Dovecot ignoring them.  If
the folder isn't created/subscribed in Dovecot, it doesn't exist to
Dovecot.... you can edit /path/to/Maildir/root/.subscriptions manually
to add these additional folders if you want to.

I'd stop Dovecot while you do that, though.

The way *I* set up new folders is I create them in my MUA *then* set up
Procmail to send mail to them.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.

I've had cases like this under Red Hat and usually find I need to erase the 
following files;

/var/lib/rpm/__db*

Tony

From jonlevitre at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 19 12:12:43 2005
From: jonlevitre at yahoo.com (Jon LeVitre)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 12:12:43 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] JavaScript Communication Between Frames
Message-ID: <20050119201243.40017.qmail@web52706.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm not a JavaScript guru, but I've done something like that.  You
might try accessing the forms using the document.forms array (instead
of by name).

Like so:


document.forms[0].text1.value = "You clicked this button."
document.forms[1].text2.value = "You clicked the button on the other
form."

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 19 13:53:59 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 13:53:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

This will seem pretty lame I'm sure but I'm having a problem with
determining , visually , if the slots on a main board are PCI 2.2 or
earlier ... and if this tells be if they are 5 or 3.3 volt.  I found a
document on the web that talks about the PCI standard ( I can't remember
where I found ) but it says it's by Peripheral Express.  It claims that 
PCI 2.2 was suppose to be in effect 1998 and 2.2 is suppose to be 3.3 
volt.  I'm looking at a couple of main boards ( one fairly new < 1 yr, and 
the other 4+ years old ) and they both have slots that according to the 
document are 5 volt PCI slots.

So to the hardware gurus ; was/is there any significant fudging going on 
with the standard?  And what will happen if I , by mistake , plug a 3.3 
card ( universal form ) into a 5 volt slot and power uP>

And does anyone have a good reference to PCI information.  Something a 
mear mortal could mostly understand?

From fpikus at gmail.com  Wed Jan 19 11:19:57 2005
From: fpikus at gmail.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 11:19:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] rpm: transaction lock and process stuck in D state
In-Reply-To: <1106161985.20105.5.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1106161985.20105.5.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <a4fbdc7b050119111932a727a3@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, 19 Jan 2005 11:13:05 -0800, Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com> wrote:
> I am trying to install acroread on Fedora 3 using a package
> acroread-5.0.10-1.1.fc3.rf.i386.rpm.  First time I tried it, it hung
> after printing preparing. When I ran ps ax, it had a D+ status.
> After killing it, I ran it again and it, now says waiting for
> transaction lock.
> 
> What do I do now?

Remove RPM lock files, it's usually done from rc.sysinit so if you
grep it for "rpm" you should find where they are, on FC1 it's done
like this:

rm -f /var/lib/rpm/__db*

> --
> Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Jan 19 14:12:11 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 14:12:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1106172731.7645.31.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Wed, 2005-01-19 at 13:53 -0800, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> So to the hardware gurus ; was/is there any significant fudging going on 
> with the standard?  And what will happen if I , by mistake , plug a 3.3 
> card ( universal form ) into a 5 volt slot and power uP>

While I can't directly answer your question.... about 99% of the time,
when working with things inside your computer... if it plugs in in, it
won't fry anything, including itself.

It may not *work* ... but it won't cause any damage.

If a 3.3V PCI card would be fried in a 5V slot, it *should* be notched
such that it cannot go in to a 5V slot.

The same is true, generally speaking, of RAM, AGP, CPUs, power supplies
(except I think it was Gateway), etc....

Now, this isn't a steadfast 100% rule... it's a generalization.  :-)

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 19 14:45:58 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 14:45:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2
In-Reply-To: <1106172731.7645.31.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191438410.15342-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 19 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

> It may not *work* ... but it won't cause any damage.

Thanks again !

So look at the POST messages, if it says PCI 2.2, plug in ( after 
powering down ) , make some burnt offerings , and reboot. Hopefully those 
burnt offerings will the only thing that burns.

> If a 3.3V PCI card would be fried in a 5V slot, it *should* be notched
> such that it cannot go in to a 5V slot.
> 
> The same is true, generally speaking, of RAM, AGP, CPUs, power supplies
> (except I think it was Gateway), etc....

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jan 19 14:56:14 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 14:56:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 19 Jan 2005 13:53:59 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net> 
Message-ID: <20050119225619.43F348F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

> This will seem pretty lame I'm sure but I'm having a problem with
> determining , visually , if the slots on a main board are PCI 2.2 or
> earlier ... and if this tells be if they are 5 or 3.3 volt.  I found a
> document on the web that talks about the PCI standard ( I can't remember
> where I found ) but it says it's by Peripheral Express.  It claims that 
> PCI 2.2 was suppose to be in effect 1998 and 2.2 is suppose to be 3.3 
> volt.  I'm looking at a couple of main boards ( one fairly new < 1 yr, and 
> the other 4+ years old ) and they both have slots that according to the 
> document are 5 volt PCI slots.

Both 5V and 3.3V slots are allowed by PCI 2.2.  The keying of a 5V slot
is closer to the center of the motherboard.  The keying of a 3.3V slot
is closer to the edge of the motherboard.  

It's not surprising that both motherboards have 5V slots.  They are
far more common.  3.3V tends to show up in high performance situations.
3.3V is required for 66 MHz PCI.  5V 66MHz slots are not allowed by the
spec.  Once the jump is made to 66 MHz, it's not unusual to see the slots
go to 64 bits at the same time.  BTW, it is legal to install a 32 bit
card into a 64 bit slot.

> So to the hardware gurus ; was/is there any significant fudging going on 
> with the standard?  And what will happen if I , by mistake , plug a 3.3 
> card ( universal form ) into a 5 volt slot and power uP>

A universal PCI card is just that.  It can be plugged into either type
of slot.  5V and 3.3V cards are keyed such that they can only be installed
in an appropriate slot.

> 
> And does anyone have a good reference to PCI information.  Something a 
> mear mortal could mostly understand?  

The Mindshare book "PCI System Architecture" is relatively readable, but
it's probably overkill for your needs.

galen


From aaron at bavariati.org  Wed Jan 19 15:06:17 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 15:06:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191342530.14916-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <20050119230616.GB28703@bavariati.org>

On Wed, Jan 19, 2005 at 01:53:59PM -0800, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> This will seem pretty lame I'm sure but I'm having a problem with
> determining , visually , if the slots on a main board are PCI 2.2 or
> earlier ... and if this tells be if they are 5 or 3.3 volt.

Can't say about PCI version, but there is a notching system to ensure
the right cards go in the right slots.  If you look at a card, you'll
see a notch or two cut in the PCI connector.  If you look at a slot,
you'll see a li'l bar across the connector that slides into the notch.

So the bar keeps the card out of the slot, unless it's notched in the
right place.  And it'll be notched in the right place if the card
voltage is the same as the slot voltage.

Some cards are dual-voltage and have two notches.

So if the card fits, the voltage is OK.

Generally, it seems like I only see 3.3V PCI in server-class machines
with 64-bit PCI slots, and most of those are dual-voltage anyway.

Reminds me of the introduction of unleaded-gas cars, which had special
filler-necks that wouldn't take a leaded gas nozzle.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191514340.15567-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

is doing Asterisk and knows?

From jonlevitre at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 19 15:54:16 2005

Subject: [PLUG] JavaScript Communication Between Frames

Try this:

frameOne.document.form1.text1.value = "You clicked this button."
frameTwo.document.form2.text2.value = "You clicked the button on the
other form."

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jan 19 16:09:07 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 16:09:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 19 Jan 2005 15:35:49 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.33.0501191514340.15567-100000@main.cyber-office.net> 
Message-ID: <20050120000912.DE8CF8F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

> 
> The main board has a 5 volt slot and the card is universal.  So I've just 
> just messaged the supplier to find out if it is 5 or 3.3 volt.

If you are asking whether your universal card is 5V or 3.3V, your
question doesn't make sense.  A universal card is just that.  It can be
used in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.  That's why the edge connector of
your card has two cutouts.  This is to allow it to be installed
in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.

> 
> And I might have saved some electrons if I'd have just said it was a 
> TDM400P for an Asterisk system I'm proto-typing and asked if anyone 
> is doing Asterisk and knows?

The picture on the diginum web site shows two cutouts in the edge
connector.  The card that is pictured is a universal card.

I'm planning to attend tonight's advanced topics meeting.  I can 
explain more there if you like.

galen

From keith at ahapala.net  Wed Jan 19 20:30:37 2005
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 20:30:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Thunderbird public calendaring
Message-ID: <41EF33ED.6010901@ahapala.net>

To add calendaring to Thunderbird, go to the page below and save the 
linux thunderbird calendar extension to your computer. Then in Tbird go 
to Tools->Extensions, click install, and then browse to your download. 
You'll have to restart Tbird to finish the install.

http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/download.html#download_thunderbird

After you restart Tbird there will be a new menu entry (Tools->Calendar) 
to bring up the calendar.

Then you can find public calendars and copy the .ics links for a public
calendar and, in the calendar app, choose File->"Subscribe to Remote
Calendar" and paste in your .ics link.

http://www.apple.com/ical/library/

or the "mother" of all ical sites

http://icalshare.com/

Speaking of public calendars, would this be something that PLUG would 
benefit from for our various events? If we could get all the info in the 
calendar entry then a cron job script could mail the list a day or two 
ahead to keep up the usual notification. Anyone set up the server side 
of public calendars with webDAV?

Thunderbird rocks! :-)
Keith

From keith at ahapala.net  Wed Jan 19 21:49:01 2005
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 21:49:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Should I go unstable?
In-Reply-To: <20050120053618.36214.qmail@web50608.mail.yahoo.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Robert Kopp wrote:
| (Assuming I'm not already.) Anyhow, I'm currently
| using Sarge. But it's not in a production environment,
| and I'd like access to the full range of software.
| Moreover, I have a complete backup of the Sarge
| installation and could recover from "bare metal."
|
| If you go the apt-get route to upgrade to Sid, about
| how long does it take?
|

Well, that depends on how fat your internet pipe is. I guess it also
depends on how much you have installed. I wouldn't be suprised if it was
150Mb for a gnome/kde upgrade to Sid. I've had no trouble upgrading from
testing to unstable in the past.

Once you are on Sid be ready for the occasional blip associated with
updates. As great as the developers/packagers are, sometimes bugs come
through. When a problem does come up, make sure you read the error
message thoroughly, they usually are good pointers to what's gone wrong.
I find the #debian chat channel on irc.debian.org a good place to go.
Many times the #topic will contain info on fixing up to the minute problems.

Also, I'd recommend updating pretty frequently. I'd much rather have a
few updates more often than big, hairy updates less frequently.

Keith

From keith at ahapala.net  Wed Jan 19 22:09:45 2005
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Wed, 19 Jan 2005 22:09:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Thunderbird public calendaring
In-Reply-To: <41EF3D50.9030709@gmail.com>
References: <41EF33ED.6010901@ahapala.net> <41EF3D50.9030709@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <41EF4B29.6040403@ahapala.net>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1


Matt,

I didn't until just now :-) Here's what I did (on my Debian server)

1) aptitude install libapache-mod-dav
2) created /home/keith/public_html/ical
3) chown www-data.www-data /home/keith/public_html/ical
4) create the following file /etc/apache/conf.d/keith-ical with the
following content:

DAVLockDB /var/lock/DAV/DAVLock
DAVMinTimeout 600
<Directory /home/keith/public_html/ical>
~        DAV On
~        AllowOverride None
~        Options None
~        <Limit GET POST OPTIONS PROPFIND>
~            Order allow,deny
~            Allow from all
~        </Limit>
~        <Limit PUT POST DELETE PROPFIND PROPPATCH MKCOL COPY MOVE LOCK
UNLOCK>
#            Require user keith
~        </Limit>
</Directory>

5) Reload apache

****WARNING****
You're gonna want to figure out the security settings on this. Obviously
, my comment above let's anyone post to that directory (I've already
pulled this configuration until I can finish it).

See /usr/share/doc/libapache-mod-dav/README.Debian.gz for more info.

Have fun :-)

Keith

> 

You're right, it shouldn't be a huge amount. I don't know what I was thinking 
of, but 150-200 is more realistic. Never mind. :) Anyway you can find out 
easily enough:

# apt-get dist-upgrade -u

or 

# apt-get dist-upgrade --dry-run

will show you what will happen without changing anything.

--

Carla Schroder

> (Assuming I'm not already.) Anyhow, I'm currently
> using Sarge. But it's not in a production environment,
> and I'd like access to the full range of software.

> installation and could recover from "bare metal."

Well, go for it if you don't mind completely random, possibly severe 
breakage.

> If you go the apt-get route to upgrade to Sid, about
> how long does it take?

How fast is your connection?  Are you using a local (faster) mirror or 
the main, US mirror that Debian tells you not to use unless it's the 
fastest for you (debian.oregonstate.edu is probably your best bet 
around here)?

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Jan 20 09:44:16 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 09:44:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Should I go unstable?
In-Reply-To: <200501200746.06091.baloo@ursine.dyndns.org>

	<200501192150.03087.carla@bratgrrl.com>

Message-ID: <200501200944.18150.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 20 January 2005 7:46 am, Paul Johnson wrote:
> On Wednesday 19 January 2005 09:50 pm, Carla Schroder wrote:
> 
> > Sid works fine, the "unstable" name sounds scarier than it is. My main 
> > workstation is a Sid box. The only drawback is the lack of security 
> > updates- there might be a few, but don't count on them.  
> 
> Security updates are about the only thing that get fast-tracked from sid 
> to sarge.

What do you mean, fast-tracked? As far as I know from hanging out on the 
lists, whatever security updates are made to unstable are few and far 
between. There is a security archive for testing, but it's not very active. 
Or am I missing something?

http://www.debian.org/security/faq#testing
Q: How is security handled for testing and unstable?
A: The short answer is: it's not. 

The lack of security updates in either testing or unstable, and the antiquity 
of stable have me looking for another distribution to use on servers.

From gluebert at comcast.net  Thu Jan 20 09:52:49 2005
From: gluebert at comcast.net (R Haack)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 09:52:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Thunderbird public calendaring
In-Reply-To: <41EF4B29.6040403@ahapala.net>
References: <41EF33ED.6010901@ahapala.net> <41EF3D50.9030709@gmail.com>
	<41EF4B29.6040403@ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <41EFEFF1.1090801@comcast.net>

If you want to take this a step further check out the following:

http://sourceforge.net/projects/phpicalendar/

This will link your webdav folder to the phpicalendar calendars folder 
you'll get a webpage interface to your calendars as well. 

R. Haack

>
> Matt,
>
> I didn't until just now :-) Here's what I did (on my Debian server)
>
> 1) aptitude install libapache-mod-dav
> 2) created /home/keith/public_html/ical
> 3) chown www-data.www-data /home/keith/public_html/ical
> 4) create the following file /etc/apache/conf.d/keith-ical with the
> following content:
>
> DAVLockDB /var/lock/DAV/DAVLock
> DAVMinTimeout 600
> <Directory /home/keith/public_html/ical>
> ~        DAV On
> ~        AllowOverride None
> ~        Options None
> ~        <Limit GET POST OPTIONS PROPFIND>
> ~            Order allow,deny
> ~            Allow from all
> ~        </Limit>
> ~        <Limit PUT POST DELETE PROPFIND PROPPATCH MKCOL COPY MOVE LOCK
> UNLOCK>
> #            Require user keith
> ~        </Limit>
> </Directory>
>
> 5) Reload apache
>
> ****WARNING****
> You're gonna want to figure out the security settings on this. Obviously
> , my comment above let's anyone post to that directory (I've already
> pulled this configuration until I can finish it).
>
> See /usr/share/doc/libapache-mod-dav/README.Debian.gz for more info.
>
> Have fun :-)
>
> Keith
>
> Matt Alexander wrote:
> | This is very cool.  Do you know how I would configure my server so I can
> | access my calendar from anywhere with Thunderbird or Firefox?
> | ~M
> |
> |
> | Keith Nasman wrote:
> |
> |> To add calendaring to Thunderbird, go to the page below and save the
> |> linux thunderbird calendar extension to your computer. Then in Tbird
> |> go to Tools->Extensions, click install, and then browse to your
> |> download. You'll have to restart Tbird to finish the install.
> |>
> |>
> http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/download.html#download_thunderbird
> |>
> |>
> |> After you restart Tbird there will be a new menu entry
> |> (Tools->Calendar) to bring up the calendar.
> |>
> |> Then you can find public calendars and copy the .ics links for a public
> |> calendar and, in the calendar app, choose File->"Subscribe to Remote
> |> Calendar" and paste in your .ics link.
> |>
> |> http://www.apple.com/ical/library/
> |>
> |> or the "mother" of all ical sites
> |>
> |> http://icalshare.com/
> |>
> |> Speaking of public calendars, would this be something that PLUG would
> |> benefit from for our various events? If we could get all the info in
> |> the calendar entry then a cron job script could mail the list a day or
> |> two ahead to keep up the usual notification. Anyone set up the server
> |> side of public calendars with webDAV?
> |>
> |> Thunderbird rocks! :-)
> |> Keith
> |
> |
> | _______________________________________________
> | PLUG mailing list
> | PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> | http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From aarontc at gmail.com  Thu Jan 20 11:04:42 2005
From: aarontc at gmail.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 11:04:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Random? Crashing of router
Message-ID: <41f575d1050120110442226f10@mail.gmail.com>

I'm having some various issues with a system I'm using as a router,
and am hoping for some general advice.

I think part of the problem may be two Compaq dual port Nettelligent
ethernet cards using the thunderlan (TLAN) driver. These cards have
had problems in two seperate systems, running both 2.4 and 2.6
kernels.

When I awoke this morning, no network traffic could go anywhere. I
investigated and found the router box completely locked up. No
messages had been written to console, and upon hard-rebooting and
checking the syslog, I found a bunch of garbage. Here's a snippit:

--- snip ---
Jan 20 03:58:24 router NETDEV WATCHDOG: eth1: transmit timed out

100baseTx-HD 100baseTx-FD<NULL>

--- snip ---

Note the series of messages from NETDEV WATCHDOG to ethX: Link active
occurs several hundred times in the logs prior to the end of logging.
I am guessing the garbage is due to fs corruption after the freeze?

The only conclusions I can draw are related to the TLAN drivers and/or
hardware, since this box ran fine with 2 Realtek gigabit NICs and two
Intel pro100 NICs for months. The more I think about it, all the
problems related to this box have affected networks connected via TLAN
cards. The only time other networks lost connectivity to the router
was today when it locked up completely.

Any advice would be appreciated. Google found some discussions about
TLAN driver issues, especially on other platforms, but nothing seemed
relevant to this. (Maybe I don't know how to search effectively... I
tried "linux (thunderlan OR tlan) problems"

I'm running kernel 2.4.28-gentoo-r5 on this box, patched with
2.4.28-ja2.diff from http://www.ssi.bg/~ja/#combinations

TIA,
Aaron

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Jan 20 15:47:44 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 15:47:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Interesting hardware problem
Message-ID: <1106264864.10312.5.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>


I need to build a small dmz device.  I prefer it being small and cheap.
I may have to "just use an old PC for it.

What I need is a device that runs Linux and has three ethernet ports.

I have two networks that are separate, but they want to share a printer.

What seems to be the only useful solution will be to build a small linux
box with an iptables setup that will nat each network to a dmz network
that has the printer.  (But not allow traffic between the two networks.)

Anyone know of a small cheap piece of hardware that will do this or am I
stuck with an old PC and three ethernet cards?

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Jan 20 16:06:36 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 16:06:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Athlon 64 power dissipation with Winchester core
Message-ID: <20050121000641.805B18F00@tinman.seitzassoc.com>


At the AT meeting last night I mentioned how impressive the Athlon 64
Winchester core power numbers are.  Here's a couple of charts that show
it dissipating just 3W at idle and ~30W under load.  Note that these
numbers are measured while running Windows.  I don't know whether the
Linux numbers would be similar or not.

http://www.tomshardware.com/cpu/20041115/pentium4_570-20.html

galen

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jan 20 16:46:04 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 00:46:04 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Interesting hardware problem
References: <1106264864.10312.5.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <slrncv0jkn.ov6.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-20, Alan <alan at clueserver.org> wrote:
>
> I need to build a small dmz device.  I prefer it being small and cheap.
> I may have to "just use an old PC for it.
>
> What I need is a device that runs Linux and has three ethernet ports.
>
> I have two networks that are separate, but they want to share a printer.
>
> What seems to be the only useful solution will be to build a small linux
> box with an iptables setup that will nat each network to a dmz network
> that has the printer.  (But not allow traffic between the two networks.)
>
> Anyone know of a small cheap piece of hardware that will do this or am I
> stuck with an old PC and three ethernet cards?
>

Soekris net4501: http://www.soekris.com/net4501.htm

http://www.soekris.com/how_to_buy.htm

You'll need to add a wall wart and CompactFlash card; should total around $225.
Of course, you'll also need something on the PC to actually *write* the CF
card--SanDisk makes a PCMCIA for around $12.)

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jan 20 18:31:02 2005

On 2005-01-21, Dan Young <dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us> wrote:
>
> This was in the context of looking for a diskless front-end for a MythTV
> project. I'm noting that these don't have video out, but I suppose you
> could put a VGA card in the PCI slot on the model Wil linked to. Maybe
> an EPIA box would be easier:

You definitely don't want to try to use a Soekris for video stuff; it's
got a mere 133MHz 486-class processor.  Good enough for a firewall,
access point or remote data-collection unit, but not for video or audio.

Subject: [PLUG] Should I go unstable?

On Thursday 20 January 2005 09:44 am, Carla Schroder wrote:

> What do you mean, fast-tracked? As far as I know from hanging out on 
> the lists, whatever security updates are made to unstable are few and 
> far between. There is a security archive for testing, but it's not 
> very active. Or am I missing something?   

Yup.  With exceptions as rare as major lottery jackpot winners, 
everything goes to sid before going anywhere else.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 20 19:55:16 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 20 Jan 2005 19:55:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Interesting hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <1106264864.10312.5.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>
References: <1106264864.10312.5.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <86y8eniggr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Alan" == Alan  <alan at clueserver.org> writes:

Alan> I need to build a small dmz device.  I prefer it being small and
Alan> cheap.  I may have to "just use an old PC for it.

Alan> What I need is a device that runs Linux and has three ethernet
Alan> ports.

Have you considered a Linksys WRT54G?  With OpenWRT (for example) you
can vlan each of the ethernet ports to a separate network.  You can
turn off the radio if you don't want/need it.  You won't be able to
connect your printer to it with USB or parallel, of course.

Also beware that the newest hardware versions break previously working
OpenWRT and similar because of some new components (e.g. new broadcom
ethernet device replaced an adm part).  See <http://openwrt.org/> for
details.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From kens at cad2cam.com  Thu Jan 20 20:32:08 2005
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 20:32:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] vsftpd login problems
In-Reply-To: <3093.134.244.174.76.1106266561.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <3093.134.244.174.76.1106266561.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1106281928.14699.4.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

On Thu, 2005-01-20 at 16:16 -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> I have a client who can not ftp to my server.  I'm using vsftpd and I
> turned on the protocol logging but after he his prompted for a user
> and that returns successful my logs say he is sent the password prompt
> then it says he timesout.
> 
> He reports to me the same behavior.  Any thoughts?  I have tried the
> same user/server and such from many different host and ftp clients and
> they all worked.  He is using WS_FTP Pro, Version 8.03.  I've tried
> and older version of ws_ftp and that worked both passive and not.
> 
> thanks,
> 
> Josh
check your firewall settings.  Could be blocking the data ports after
the establishment of a session.  The user may have to try passive
mode.  

Active mode establishes another session on another port from the client.
You need to have the server establish the session to go through your
firewall.

Ken

I'm running Bind 9.2 and I want to have the master send updates to the
slaves.  I've been poking about and didn't find the exact docs on
this.  Is there a simple flag I just turn on or do I need to setup
trusting master and trusted slaves on both bind configs?

thanks.

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Jan 20 23:05:13 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 23:05:13 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Interesting hardware problem
In-Reply-To: <20050121023141.CBE005B73@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200501210705.j0L75DNE073042@m5p.com>

>From: Alan <alan at clueserver.org>
> I need to build a small dmz device.  I prefer it being small and cheap.
> I may have to "just use an old PC for it.
> 
> What I need is a device that runs Linux and has three ethernet ports.
> 
> I have two networks that are separate, but they want to share a printer.
> 
> What seems to be the only useful solution will be to build a small linux
> box with an iptables setup that will nat each network to a dmz network
> that has the printer.  (But not allow traffic between the two networks.)
> 
> Anyone know of a small cheap piece of hardware that will do this or am I
> stuck with an old PC and three ethernet cards?

Seems an inelegant solution, but if the above is *all* that is required
then a WRT54G could do the job. Have the uplink/WAN port be on one
network, and the printer being part of the other. The printer does appear
on one of the two networks, but the above doesn't strictly disallow this.

I'm unsure whether it will beat the price of the already suggested
options, but a pair of WRT54Gs could be used and make a full DMZ network
for the printer.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Jan 20 23:08:09 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 23:08:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1106291290.17226.19.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2005-01-20 at 23:21 -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> I'm running Bind 9.2 and I want to have the master send updates to the
> slaves.  I've been poking about and didn't find the exact docs on
> this.  Is there a simple flag I just turn on or do I need to setup
> trusting master and trusted slaves on both bind configs?

First, make sure you update that serial in your zone files when you
update the zone files.  :-)

Second, make sure your name servers are listed in the zone files.

Third, make sure the master server allows transfers from the slaves
(named.conf).

Fourth, make sure the slaves know where the master is (named.conf).

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From brent at servuhome.net  Thu Jan 20 23:15:08 2005
From: brent at servuhome.net (Brent Jones)
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 23:15:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>

If you've added the specified slave server as a server to send notifies, 
everytime the zone if modified it will automaticaly send a notify.

named.conf:

zone "somedomain.com" {
         type master;
         file "/chroot/blah/somedomain.com";
         allow-transfer { 66.66.66.66; 77.77.77.77; };
         };

And your slave should be set to receive the notify, by having a similar 
setup, by instead of type master; it will be type slave;
And so-forth.

Brent Jones
brent [at] servuhome [dot] net

Josh Orchard wrote:
> I'm running Bind 9.2 and I want to have the master send updates to the
> slaves.  I've been poking about and didn't find the exact docs on
> this.  Is there a simple flag I just turn on or do I need to setup
> trusting master and trusted slaves on both bind configs?
> 
> thanks.
> 
> Josh
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From brent at servuhome.net  Fri Jan 21 00:10:16 2005
From: brent at servuhome.net (Brent Jones)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 00:10:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>
	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <41F0B8E8.1020807@servuhome.net>

The slave shouldnt be asking for updates. Once the master loads a new 
zone file, restarts, or has a zone update, it will send a notify to all 
the slaves, and start a zone-transfer.

Brent Jones
brent [at] servuhome [dot] net

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Jan 21 00:09:51 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 00:09:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>
	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2005-01-20 at 23:57 -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Understand.  But is there a way that I can now tell the slave to go
> ask the master for changes and new files and have those transferred
> down?  Or have the Master send send record changes to the slave when
> they are created?
> 
> It seems with nsnotify I should be able to fun that or nsupdate and
> have the slave pull all the new records and changes down.

When BIND notices a new zone file (by the serial increase), it sends out
notifies to the slave zones mentioned in the zone file.  The slaves then
contact the master defined in their named.conf file and grab the new
zone file.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jan 21 08:09:43 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 08:09:43 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] URL viewer in Pine on Mac OS X
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501210759520.866@paul-heinleins-computer.local>

I recently switched jobs, and my main workstation these days is a 
PowerBook G4 running Mac OS X.

The Apple Mail application is pretty good, but I'm more or less hooked 
on pine and really don't want to change clients. So I compiled Pine 
4.62 and it runs great.

It took me a little while to figure out how to invoke Safari (the 
KHTML-based browser from Apple) from pine, but a little googling 
pointed me at the open(1) application and from there it was easy 
going. The resulting entry in my .pinerc is

url-viewers="/usr/bin/open _URL_"

open(1) will automatically figure out my preferred browser (I'm using 
Safaris but may switch to Firefox in the future) and feed it the URL. 
Pretty slick!

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Jan 21 10:23:15 2005
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 10:23:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>
	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> > When BIND notices a new zone file (by the serial increase), it sends
> > out notifies to the slave zones mentioned in the zone file.  The
> > slaves then contact the master defined in their named.conf file and
> > grab the new zone file.
> 
> Ah, that is what I was thinking should happen but wasn't seeing that. 
> I'll check over my files and make sure the Master knows about the
> Slave and the Slave knows about the Master.
> 
> Thanks. If I just restart Bind on the Slave then the Master after I
> have the configs right will they transfer over the files?

Note that if you aren't in control of your slave server, for instance
it's a secondary provided by your registrar, you can't force the slave
to start the transfer.  You can only send the notify and wait for the
secondary NS to initiate update.  This may take much longer than you'd 
like.  

If I recall correctly the secondary is allowed to defer requesting the
update until the refresh time limit has elapsed.  If you're planning 
network changes and wish for your DNS updates to propagate more quickly
cranking this value down in advance is one option for getting updates
propagated more quickly.  Just remember to reset it to a reasonable 
value after your environment has stabilized.

-- 
    Michael Rasmussen, Portland Oregon

	I just want to ride on my motorcy.

   I think I need to modify my cron jobs so they mount the exported

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Jan 21 12:10:08 2005
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:10:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Note that if you aren't in control of your slave server, for instance
>  it's a secondary provided by your registrar, you can't force the
> slave to start the transfer.  You can only send the notify and wait
> for the secondary NS to initiate update.  This may take much longer
> than you'd like.
>
> If I recall correctly the secondary is allowed to defer requesting
> the update until the refresh time limit has elapsed.  If you're
> planning network changes and wish for your DNS updates to propagate
> more quickly cranking this value down in advance is one option for
> getting updates propagated more quickly.  Just remember to reset it to
> a reasonable value after your environment has stabilized.

So say that I control both master and slave. I do.  Now say I want to
add a new slave or have added new records to the master and want to
tell the slave to add them as well.  The only way I've found so far is
to go to the slave and add the record and then it will keep the
updates in sync.  There doesn't seem to be a way to have the master
tell the slave to add a new record.

Is this normal?  Or is this just a big timing issue and for some of my
none controlled slaves it will just take a while?

thanks,

Josh



From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Jan 21 12:12:58 2005
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:12:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Backing Up Multiple Machines
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501211034140.10353@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501211034140.10353@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <4599.134.244.174.76.1106338378.squirrel@sautez.com>

> I want to confirm that if I want filesystems on a second workstation
> to be backed up on tape in a drive installed on another box, then the
> filesystems must be exported from the remote system and nfs-mounted on
> the system with the tape drive. Is this correct?
>
> I think I need to modify my cron jobs so they mount the exported
> filesystems before running the backup, then umount them afterwards.
>
> Thanks,
>
>
> Rich

Isn't that the only way the first drive will be able to see the second
computer?  Unless you are using some other protocol in your backup
util like ftp I'd have to think you will have to mount the drives
first.  We mount the drives here for that exact same reason.

Josh



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jan 21 11:55:32 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Backing Up Multiple Machines
In-Reply-To: <4599.134.244.174.76.1106338378.squirrel@sautez.com>

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan 21 12:15:02 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 Jan 2005 12:15:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backing Up Multiple Machines
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501211034140.10353@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501211034140.10353@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86acr2ilo9.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>    I want to confirm that if I want filesystems on a second
Rich> workstation to be backed up on tape in a drive installed on
Rich> another box, then the filesystems must be exported from the
Rich> remote system and nfs-mounted on the system with the tape
Rich> drive. Is this correct?

"must"?  no.

You can run tar on the remote (backed-up) machine and pipe it through
ssh and dd it onto tape, e.g.:

  ssh root at remotehost 'tar -C / clf - .' | dd of=/dev/nst0 obs=<tapeblocksize>

The corresponding compare pass is something like this:

  dd ibs=<tapeblocksize> if=/dev/nst0 | ssh root at remotehost 'tar -C / -dlf -'

Salt to taste.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jan 21 12:22:15 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:22:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backing Up Multiple Machines
In-Reply-To: <20050121194755.286BC5B8E@ulke.nakedape.cc>
References: <20050121194755.286BC5B8E@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <20050121202215.GA27580@gate.kl-ic.com>

Rich writes:

>    I want to confirm that if I want filesystems on a second workstation to be
> backed up on tape in a drive installed on another box, then the filesystems
> must be exported from the remote system and nfs-mounted on the system with
> the tape drive. Is this correct?

Of course, this very much depends on the tools you are using.  Rdump
will push data at a remote file, and the client process can be
initiated from a server by running a command with ssh.  It sounds
like you want to pull data with a server, in which case you will
indeed need to remote-mount the files on the server.

But those are all 1980's solutions;  expensive, slow, insecure,
inconvenient, inefficient, and a lot of other perjorative adjectives.
At the risk of sounding like a broken record, look at dirvish 
( www.dirvish.org ) or some other rsync-based disk-to-disk mechanism.
The savings in effort, cost, and time are spectacular, without even
getting into the security and indexing and ease-of-restore issues. 

I gave a dirvish presentation at the PANUG meeting last night, and
like the presentations last year at PLUG and at LinuxFest, it was
well received.  I will be giving a similar presentation next Thursday
( 2005-01-27 ) evening at the Oregon IEEE Consultant's Network
meeting, http://www.eeconsult.org/members/presentation.html .  Public
meeting, all are welcome - if they can tolerate IHOP food.   I also
would be glad to head out to Gresham/Troutdale and present, if someone
provides a venue and an audience of a dozen or more.

Cast OUT those Satanic tape drives!  Be reborn in BITS EVERLASTING! 
HEAL!  :-)

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From rich at paranoid.org  Fri Jan 21 12:51:14 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:51:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>
	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <41F16B42.1040201@paranoid.org>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> Now say I want to
> add a new slave or have added new records to the master and want to
> tell the slave to add them as well.  The only way I've found so far is
> to go to the slave and add the record and then it will keep the
> updates in sync.  There doesn't seem to be a way to have the master
> tell the slave to add a new record.

Hi Josh,

Are you talking about adding new zones? I don't think there's a way to 
have the master notify the slave about new zones that exist. The slave 
will need to have the new zone set up in it's conf file. The master will 
notify the slave about updates to zones the slave already knows about.

Of course I've been wrong before, if there is a way then I'm sure 
someone here will know :)

I used to work at an ISP, and sometimes we ran into weird situations 
where we wanted to get the slave to update immediately (like when 
someone on our end had screwed up a record). In those cases we would use 
the named-xfer command to manually slurp over the record. man named-xfer 
for more info.


Rich



From fixin at peak.org  Fri Jan 21 12:18:21 2005
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:18:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ssh less secure when PasswordAuthentication allowed?
Message-ID: <20050121201821.GZ27236@peak.org>

I always configure sshd to not allow PasswordAuthentication, believing
that it's most secure if I only accept connections from hosts whose
public keys I already have -- my work machine, my ISP's shell account
servers, etc.

Now I have a Nokia 9300 for which there's a version of Putty.
Unfortunately, that Putty doesn't support ssh2-compatible keys.  So if
I want to connect into my home network from my phone I have to allow
password authentication.  (That or allow ssh1, which seems like a
worse idea.)

I can't find any online explanation of how/whether disallowing
password authentication is any less secure.  Does anybody know of one
-- or just plain know?

BTW, Sourceforge.net's ssh configuration allowed me to connect, and I
was able to use emacs to add a new page to a website -- all from a
cellphone.  Pretty cool stuff!

--Eric

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Jan 21 12:59:51 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 12:59:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
Message-ID: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>

I've got a problem trying to get Apache to work my way.  I have several
virtual hosts, all of which map to J2EE Web app's (CGI, as far as Apache
is concerned).  Now, I want to have a certain base URL--relevant to site
A--to map to a different base URL (different hostname) that is relevant
to site B.  So,

  http://a.org/foo/bar/* --> http://b.net/fubar/*

mod_alias doesn't do it, because that only seems to work within a single
virtual host.  mod_rewrite changes the URL, but then it reports an error
400 "Bad Request" for the new URL, "http://b.net/fubar/whatever".

This is odd, because "http://b.net/fubar/whatever" works using wget on
the server itself.  Any idea what I'm missing?

I'm trying to avoid mod_proxy, because that seems indirect and
inefficient.  Is apache unable to rewrite a request to one virtual host
and then process it in another, without that external proxy action?

Thanks,

--Jason

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jan 21 13:01:08 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 21:01:08 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Automatic Slave updates for bind
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>
	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>
	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <slrncv2qia.i55.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-21, Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> wrote:
>
> So say that I control both master and slave. I do.  Now say I want to
> add a new slave or have added new records to the master and want to
> tell the slave to add them as well.  The only way I've found so far is
> to go to the slave and add the record and then it will keep the
> updates in sync.  There doesn't seem to be a way to have the master
> tell the slave to add a new record.
>
> Is this normal?  Or is this just a big timing issue and for some of my
> none controlled slaves it will just take a while?

No, this isn't normal.  Your slave should log when it receives a notify message
from the master, which should happen pretty much immediately when you reload
the master.  If you're editing zone files on the slave, you've either not
got a real slave or named cannot write to the zone files or something else.

I suggest spending a little time reading over the BOG (BIND Operations
Guide) and/or "DNS & BIND".

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
