From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jan 21 13:46:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 21:46:02 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Automatic Slave updates for bind
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>
	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>
	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F16B42.1040201@paranoid.org>
	<1128.134.244.174.76.1106342416.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <slrncv2tsv.i55.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-21, Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> wrote:
>
> Yes I would like to add new Zones.  I'd think that the slaves like a
> caching DNS server would be able to take directions from a Master. 
> Then again there has always been cases in history when the slaves
> revolt.  Maybe if I refer to them as clients then they would listen to
> and obey my primary server. :-)
>
> If this is truely the case then I'd be surprised as that would mean
> everytime a new Zone is added each slave has to also be manually
> updated.
>
> I'll look into named-xfer and see what I find.

Well, now you're talking about something different.  The master/slave
notification only applies to zones that are already configured.  When
you say "records", these are the NS, SOA, MX, A, PTR entries in each
zone; a zone maps roughly to a domain name--nakedape.cc for example.
When I set up DNS for nakedape.cc, I create an a zone file on the
master:

######
$TTL 14400
@ IN SOA dns1.nakedape.cc. hostmaster.nakedape.cc. (
                2004112801
                86400
                3600
                2592000
                14400
            )
                IN    NS    dns1.nakedape.cc.
                IN    NS    dns2.nakedape.cc.
                IN    MX    10    smtp1.nakedape.cc.
@               IN    A    63.105.18.11
www             IN    A    63.105.18.11
# etc
######

However, I *also* have to tell BIND about the zone:

# /etc/named.conf on the master
zone "nakedape.cc" IN {
    type master;
    file "master/nakedape.cc";
};

# /etc/named.conf on the slave
zone "nakedape.cc" IN {
    type slave;
    file "slave/nakedape.cc";
    masters { 63.105.18.11; };
};

And yes, there's not way within BIND itself to create this slave configuration.
I use rsync and some scripts manage the domains I host.  My /etc/named.conf
has 'include "master.conf"' or 'include "slave.conf"' depending on the host.
I run a script that generates the master.conf and slave.conf from a list of
zones on the master, than rsync all the files over to slave.  (In reality,
mine's a tad messier because I'm using views.)


Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Jan 21 13:48:08 2005

	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>
	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>

	<1128.134.244.174.76.1106342416.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <20050121214808.GB26015@patch.com>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> 
> Yes I would like to add new Zones.  I'd think that the slaves like a
> caching DNS server would be able to take directions from a Master. 
> Then again there has always been cases in history when the slaves
> revolt.  Maybe if I refer to them as clients then they would listen to
> and obey my primary server. :-)
> 
> If this is truely the case then I'd be surprised as that would mean
> everytime a new Zone is added each slave has to also be manually
> updated.

Let's make sure we're talking the same language here.

Zone:  a domain record

So when I add a new zone to my bind configuration, say myhotnewdomain.org,
just inserting the secondary's information in the zone file won't cause the
secondary to pick it up.  

Otherwise I'd be able to make Wil be a DNS secondary for all my domaains whether
he wanted to be or not.  

What I can expect is for the secondaries to reflect changes in zones/domains that
they are configured to carry.

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Jan 21 13:50:13 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 13:50:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211308560.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211308560.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>
Message-ID: <20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Paul Heinlein, on Fri, 21 Jan 2005 13:11:33 -0800 (PST):

> Within the VirtualHost entry for a.org (or in any relevant .htaccess 
> file), can't you just do a redirect?

Well, no, I can't do a client-side redirect for a couple of reasons. 
First, I want b.net to appear as part of a.org, so I just need the munge
those URLs correctly.  Second, b.net is not a real domain, just
something I put into my server's hosts file, so that the virtual host
will work.  (This is a hack, but I'm really not sure how else to do that
using virtual hosts).

So I want apache to back out of the a.org virtual host and invoke the
one for b.net, transparently to the client.

--Jason

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jan 21 13:57:38 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 13:57:38 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211308560.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>
	<20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211352190.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>

On Fri, 21 Jan 2005, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Quoth Paul Heinlein, on Fri, 21 Jan 2005 13:11:33 -0800 (PST):
>
>> Within the VirtualHost entry for a.org (or in any relevant 
>> .htaccess file), can't you just do a redirect?
>
> Well, no, I can't do a client-side redirect for a couple of reasons. 
> First, I want b.net to appear as part of a.org, so I just need the 
> munge those URLs correctly.  Second, b.net is not a real domain, 
> just something I put into my server's hosts file, so that the 
> virtual host will work.

In that case, I think mod_proxy (via mod_rewrite) is your only hope.

   # the first of these two is a workaround for IE
   RewriteRule  ^/foo/bar$       http://b.net/fubar/   [P]
   RewriteRule  ^/foo/bar/(.*)$  http://b.net/fubar/$1 [P]

That's the only solution I've ever been able to devise with the 
problem set you describe.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From rich at paranoid.org  Fri Jan 21 14:27:57 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 14:27:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ssh less secure when PasswordAuthentication allowed?
In-Reply-To: <20050121201821.GZ27236@peak.org>
References: <20050121201821.GZ27236@peak.org>
Message-ID: <41F181ED.3060903@paranoid.org>

Eric House wrote:

> I can't find any online explanation of how/whether disallowing
> password authentication is any less secure.  Does anybody know of one
> -- or just plain know?

Hi Eric,

The reason it's better to use keys if possible is that a password can be 
guessed or social engineered out of someone. When you have a key that's 
protected with a passphrase, then the attacker would is required to get 
both the key and the passphrase associated with it.

Using password authentication with SSH is pretty secure, though. The 
passwords are encrypted, so they are not vulnerable to being sniffed as 
plaintext telet or FTP passwords are. For protecting your home network, 
I think password authentication should be fine.

Just make sure to keep your sshd patched and up to date.


Rich




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Jan 21 15:17:15 2005

Message-ID: <1568.134.244.174.76.1106349435.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Josh Orchard wrote:
>
>>
>> Yes I would like to add new Zones.  I'd think that the slaves like
>> a caching DNS server would be able to take directions from a Master.
>>  Then again there has always been cases in history when the slaves
>> revolt.  Maybe if I refer to them as clients then they would listen
>> to and obey my primary server. :-)
>>
>> If this is truely the case then I'd be surprised as that would mean
>>  everytime a new Zone is added each slave has to also be manually
>> updated.
>
> Let's make sure we're talking the same language here.
>
>
> Zone:  a domain record
>
>
> So when I add a new zone to my bind configuration, say
> myhotnewdomain.org, just inserting the secondary's information in the
> zone file won't cause the secondary to pick it up.
>
> Otherwise I'd be able to make Wil be a DNS secondary for all my
> domaains whether he wanted to be or not.
>
> What I can expect is for the secondaries to reflect changes in
> zones/domains that they are configured to carry.

Well that isn't quite true because the Slave could be configured to
only accept transfers from a particular Master.  In fact, that is
already in place.  So to send a create Zone from the Trusted Master to
a Trusted Slave would make a lot of sense to me.  Having me have to
create a Master Zone record for example.com on the Master server then
go create a Slave Zone record for example.com on the Slave seems a
very inefficient process to acheive what everyone is going to want to
do any way.

But heck that is just me.  I expect slaves to listen to the master not
listen after I told them what to listen for.

Josh



From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Jan 21 15:23:35 2005
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 15:23:35 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211308560.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>
	<20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1621.134.244.174.76.1106349815.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Quoth Paul Heinlein, on Fri, 21 Jan 2005 13:11:33 -0800 (PST):
>
>
>> Within the VirtualHost entry for a.org (or in any relevant
>> .htaccess
>> file), can't you just do a redirect?
>
> Well, no, I can't do a client-side redirect for a couple of reasons.
> First, I want b.net to appear as part of a.org, so I just need the
> munge those URLs correctly.  Second, b.net is not a real domain, just
> something I put into my server's hosts file, so that the virtual host
>  will work.  (This is a hack, but I'm really not sure how else to do
> that using virtual hosts).
>
> So I want apache to back out of the a.org virtual host and invoke the
>  one for b.net, transparently to the client.

Jason,

I do this a lot with my computer.  I just use:

ProxyPass /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*
ProxyPassReverse /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*

inside the virtual host for a.org.  You mentioned something about not
wanting to use mod_proxy but this works great for me.  Don't know if
it won't work because of some J2EE items you may be using but I don't
see why not.  I have used it for my J2EE servers as well.

Josh

>
> And yes, there's not way within BIND itself to create this slave
> configuration. I use rsync and some scripts manage the domains I host.

Zone.  Sorry about the 'records' lingo use poor choice.

I would think that Bind would have thought about this and added the
creation call to the notification method in the master.  Sure would
save lots of time and would be really simple to achieve.  Or I would
think.

From rich at paranoid.org  Fri Jan 21 15:14:15 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 15:14:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <1568.134.244.174.76.1106349435.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F16B42.1040201@paranoid.org>	<1128.134.244.174.76.1106342416.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121214808.GB26015@patch.com>
	<1568.134.244.174.76.1106349435.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <41F18CC7.9030307@paranoid.org>

Josh Orchard wrote:

> But heck that is just me.  I expect slaves to listen to the master not
> listen after I told them what to listen for.

Personally, I'd rather add them by hand than have the chance that 
someone could get around Bind's security and add them for me. Some of 
the phishing attackers now are compromising DNS servers to make it seem 
as if users are really going to the domain they think they are. If they 
could trick servers to automatically add new zones that could be pretty 
ugly.

It only takes a few seconds to add a new zone, just yy a previous entry 
in vi and change the domain name. We had thousands of zones at the ISP I 
worked at and we managed to cope with this :)


Rich

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Jan 21 15:37:11 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)

Message-ID: <20050121153711.2d74ddce.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Josh Orchard, on Fri, 21 Jan 2005 15:23:35 -0800 (PST):

> I do this a lot with my computer.  I just use:
> 
> ProxyPass /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*
> ProxyPassReverse /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*

That may help, though according to apache.org, RewriteRule with "[P]" is
more powerful than ProxyPass.  By the way, what's the "...Reverse"
option for?

> inside the virtual host for a.org.  You mentioned something about not
> wanting to use mod_proxy but this works great for me.  Don't know if
> it won't work because of some J2EE items you may be using but I don't
> see why not.  I have used it for my J2EE servers as well.

As long as apache can munge the URL first and then forward on to the
servlet container, it should work.  I guess the reason I didn't want to
use mod_proxy is that I suppose it will incur a certain overhead, if it
actually makes a new HTTP connection (which seems like what a mod_proxy
would do).  I'd rather the process were more inline.

--Jason

Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <41F18CC7.9030307@paranoid.org>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F16B42.1040201@paranoid.org>	<1128.134.244.174.76.1106342416.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121214808.GB26015@patch.com>
	<1568.134.244.174.76.1106349435.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<41F18CC7.9030307@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <1898.134.244.174.76.1106358398.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Josh Orchard wrote:
>
>
>> But heck that is just me.  I expect slaves to listen to the master
>> not listen after I told them what to listen for.
>
> Personally, I'd rather add them by hand than have the chance that
> someone could get around Bind's security and add them for me. Some of
> the phishing attackers now are compromising DNS servers to make it
> seem as if users are really going to the domain they think they are.
> If they
> could trick servers to automatically add new zones that could be
> pretty ugly.
>
> It only takes a few seconds to add a new zone, just yy a previous
> entry in vi and change the domain name. We had thousands of zones at
> the ISP I worked at and we managed to cope with this :)
>
>
> Rich

Understand but doesn't everyone at ISP just live to write little
scripts, manually alter files, and configure systems all day so that
they can justify their existence?  ;-)

Josh



From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Jan 21 17:49:47 2005
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 17:49:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050121153711.2d74ddce.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.62.0501211308560.1105@paul-heinleins-computer.local>
	<20050121135013.69259c25.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1621.134.244.174.76.1106349815.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<20050121153711.2d74ddce.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1914.134.244.174.76.1106358587.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Quoth Josh Orchard, on Fri, 21 Jan 2005 15:23:35 -0800 (PST):
>
>
>> I do this a lot with my computer.  I just use:
>>
>>
>> ProxyPass /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*
>> ProxyPassReverse /foo/bar/* http://b.net/fubar/*
>>
>
> That may help, though according to apache.org, RewriteRule with "[P]"
> is more powerful than ProxyPass.  By the way, what's the "...Reverse"
> option for?
>
>> inside the virtual host for a.org.  You mentioned something about
>> not wanting to use mod_proxy but this works great for me.  Don't
>> know if it won't work because of some J2EE items you may be using
>> but I don't see why not.  I have used it for my J2EE servers as
>> well.
>
> As long as apache can munge the URL first and then forward on to the
> servlet container, it should work.  I guess the reason I didn't want
> to use mod_proxy is that I suppose it will incur a certain overhead,
> if it actually makes a new HTTP connection (which seems like what a
> mod_proxy would do).  I'd rather the process were more inline.
>
> --Jason

the ProxyPassReverse just allows all connections coming back to go
back to where they were requested from.  Yes, it may be another
connection. I never cared much to figure that all out as the solution
was fast, easy and not noticable on the server load I ran it.  If you
were talking a huge load then perhaps you do need to look into
rewrite.

Josh



From raanders at acm.org  Fri Jan 21 18:13:30 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri, 21 Jan 2005 18:13:30 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] postfix, dovecot, thunderbird?
In-Reply-To: <1106160132.7645.20.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501211734590.30296-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 19 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

> It isn't Thunderbird not seeing them, it's Dovecot ignoring them.  If
> the folder isn't created/subscribed in Dovecot, it doesn't exist to
> Dovecot.... you can edit /path/to/Maildir/root/.subscriptions manually
> to add these additional folders if you want to.

Back at it again after a few side trips.

I had something set up wrong.  It appears dovecot(/IMAP) wants the folders
to have a dot at the beginning (hidden) and procmail must deliver to them.
Not to the name created (sans the dot).  So I created a folder Test and 
have procmail deliver to .Test .

A bit more experimentation and I'll be switching.  Then to test pine using 
Maildir.

> I'd stop Dovecot while you do that, though.

Well dovecot has fit with lots of errors going to the procmail log file 
but as soon as I created the folder using Thunderbird it delivered the 
message.
 
> The way *I* set up new folders is I create them in my MUA *then* set up
> Procmail to send mail to them.

Well normally I don't edit my procmail recipes very often but I think a
script that made sure the right stuff was in .subscriptions , and other
places , per the procmail recipes would be nice.  Nice project for this 
week end!  YEah right.  The honey-do pot is full but I might find the 
time.

Have a great week end all.

Rod

used

Subject: [PLUG] Automatic Slave updates for bind
In-Reply-To: <1898.134.244.174.76.1106358398.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <4384.216.99.218.67.1106292113.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F0ABFC.9070509@servuhome.net>	<4584.216.99.218.67.1106294235.squirrel@sautez.com>	<1106294991.17224.28.camel@dell.linux.box>	<4749.216.99.218.67.1106296604.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121182315.GB22693@patch.com>	<4592.134.244.174.76.1106338208.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F16B42.1040201@paranoid.org>	<1128.134.244.174.76.1106342416.squirrel@sautez.com>	<20050121214808.GB26015@patch.com>	<1568.134.244.174.76.1106349435.squirrel@sautez.com>	<41F18CC7.9030307@paranoid.org>
	<1898.134.244.174.76.1106358398.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <41F21264.6070606@schluting.com>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> 
> 
> Understand but doesn't everyone at ISP just live to write little
> scripts, manually alter files, and configure systems all day so that
> they can justify their existence?  ;-)
> 
> Josh

That's what 'make' is for. It makes these things very quick and easy.
When I add a zone, I type "make dist" and it copies a newly generated 
secondary named.conf to 5 slaves, HUP's the daemon, and the world is happy.

And sure, you don't exist to do this, but if you aren't capable of 
completing the task efficiently... well, I'll stop there.

And, no, it makes no sense to have a slave automatically pick up new zones. 
Talk to Paul Vixie with ISC, he'll be happy to flame you about this :)

-Charlie


From rich at paranoid.org  Sat Jan 22 00:52:41 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Sat, 22 Jan 2005 00:52:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <200501220835.j0M8ZmA40285@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <200501220835.j0M8ZmA40285@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <41F21459.1070506@paranoid.org>

William A Morita wrote:
> Alan,
> 
> I do not believe I have IP chains turned on.  
> This is an out-of-the-box RH9 system with firewall disabled.
> Is it possible that there is a different password for CVS that the local uid
> login?

Hi Bill,

The "connection refused" error doesn't sound like a password problem. 
That's an error you typically get if you try to connect to a port where 
there's not a service running. Which is probably why Alan asked about a 
firewall.

One thing to check would be whether the CVS server is even accepting 
connections. It may not be running or may not be configured properly. 
You could try connecting to it from a shell on the server itself.

Are you running it from inetd or xinetd? If so, make sure that process 
is actually running and listening on the appropriate port.


Rich

> >> I

> >> and that returns successful my logs say he is sent the password
> >> prompt then it says he timesout.
> >>
> >> He reports to me the same behavior.  Any thoughts?  I have tried
> >> the same user/server and such from many different host and ftp
> >> clients and they all worked.  He is using WS_FTP Pro, Version 8.03.
> >> I've tried

> 2.6 kernel issue though.

More frustrating than scary, all OS's could ssh to the 2.6 kernel, and
both 2.4 and 2.6 kernels could hook to the ftp server, but none of
Bill's OS's could login to the ftp server (I tried several).

I changed back to a 2.4 kernel and Bill's OS's started behaving.

I didn't investigate any further, my client was willing to run the 2.4
kernel.

Derek Loree

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jan 22 11:21:54 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] how can I mount a partition that reiserfs won't replay the
	journal on..
In-Reply-To: <41F2A38D.6050703@spek.org>
References: <41F2A38D.6050703@spek.org>
Message-ID: <867jm5gtgt.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Brent" == Brent Rieck <bsr at spek.org> writes:

Brent> Hello, It looks like I have a bad disk and I need to get the
Brent> data that's on the disk off of the disk but reiserfsck
Brent> complains about bad blocks when replaying the journal and then
Brent> quits.  It also ignores the --no-journal-available option.
Brent> Does anybody know how I might get it mounted to get the data
Brent> off of it?

>From recent experience, you have two options:

  a) find the disk manufacturers repair floppy, boot that and let it
     "repair" bad sectors; or

  b) use dd_rescue to copy an image of the partition (as well as it
     can) off to good media.

and then run a reiserfsck repair on the image, possibly (probably??) a
--rebuild-tree.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From redhat at crisponions.com  Sat Jan 22 11:44:05 2005

unknown block(0,0)".  What I cant figure out is I am using the
same .config file that was created by the debian kernel package for my
2.6.8 kernel and all my options in grub are correct...

I know my way around RedHat and Gentoo pretty well, but Debian makes me
feel like I am starting all over again :-) I would really like to get
acquainted with it because it seems to be the distro all the gurus use,
so I think that says something. Any tips would be appreciated.

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Kenneth G. Stephens
Sent: Saturday, January 22, 2005 8:30 AM
To: General Linux discussion and assistance
Subject: Re: [PLUG] CVS Server Question

On Sat, 2005-01-22 at 00:52 -0800, Rich Burroughs wrote:
> William A Morita wrote:
> > Alan,
> > 
> > I do not believe I have IP chains turned on.  
> > This is an out-of-the-box RH9 system with firewall disabled.
> > Is it possible that there is a different password for CVS that the 
> > local uid login?
> 
> Hi Bill,
> 
> The "connection refused" error doesn't sound like a password problem. 
> That's an error you typically get if you try to connect to a port 
> where there's not a service running. Which is probably why Alan asked 
> about a firewall.
> 
> One thing to check would be whether the CVS server is even accepting 
> connections. It may not be running or may not be configured properly.
> You could try connecting to it from a shell on the server itself.
> 
> Are you running it from inetd or xinetd? If so, make sure that process 
> is actually running and listening on the appropriate port.
> 
> 
> Rich
Why not let ssh handle your authentication?
export CVSROOT=":ext:wamorita at frodo:/shares/cvs-repository"

The "ext" makes ssh do the authentication.  Pretty slick.

Setup key authentication by generating keys:  ssh-keygen2
in ~/.ssh2 directory
Edit/Create authorization  with
Key <key name>.pub
Edit/Create identification with
IDKey <key name>

Great Howto at http://www.faqs.org/docs/securing/chap16sec133.html
--
> Ken Stephens
> CAD 2 CAM




From wamorita at hevanet.com  Sat Jan 22 13:23:25 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Sat, 22 Jan 2005 13:23:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <41F21459.1070506@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <200501222123.j0MLNRA45835@pop.hevanet.com>

Rich, Ken,

I seem to be making some progress (I think).  I was missing file:
/etc/xinetd.d/cvspserver :
service cvspserver
{
        socket_type     = stream
        wait            = no
        user            = root
        group           = cvsusers
        env             = HOME=/shares/cvs-repository 
        server          = /usr/bin/cvs
        server_args     = -f --allow-root=/shares/cvs-repository
        disable         = no
}

Now the problem has changed to:

cvs [login aborted]: unrecognized auth response from frodo: Usage: cvs
[cvs-opti
ons] command [command-options-and-arguments]

Hopefully I have not headed up a dead end!

- Bill Morita

wamorita at hevanet.com 
Home: (503) 697-6994
Cell: (503) 260-3876



-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Rich Burroughs
Sent: Saturday, January 22, 2005 12:53 AM
To: General Linux discussion and assistance
Subject: Re: [PLUG] CVS Server Question

William A Morita wrote:
> Alan,
> 
> I do not believe I have IP chains turned on.  
> This is an out-of-the-box RH9 system with firewall disabled.
> Is it possible that there is a different password for CVS that the 
> local uid login?

Hi Bill,

The "connection refused" error doesn't sound like a password problem. 
That's an error you typically get if you try to connect to a port where
there's not a service running. Which is probably why Alan asked about a
firewall.

One thing to check would be whether the CVS server is even accepting
connections. It may not be running or may not be configured properly. 
You could try connecting to it from a shell on the server itself.

Are you running it from inetd or xinetd? If so, make sure that process is
actually running and listening on the appropriate port.


Rich


_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Sat Jan 22 15:58:15 2005
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Sat, 22 Jan 2005 15:58:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1106438295.6338.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2005-01-21 at 12:59 -0800, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I've got a problem trying to get Apache to work my way.  I have several
> virtual hosts, all of which map to J2EE Web app's (CGI, as far as Apache
> is concerned).  Now, I want to have a certain base URL--relevant to site
> A--to map to a different base URL (different hostname) that is relevant
> to site B.  So,
> 
>   http://a.org/foo/bar/* --> http://b.net/fubar/*
> 
> mod_alias doesn't do it, because that only seems to work within a single
> virtual host. 

Maybe I'm missing something, but I think mod_alias should do it:

        Alias directive
        
        Syntax: Alias URL-path file-path|directory-path
        Context: server config, virtual host

So, assuming that http://b.net/fubar/ is at /web/b.net/fubar/, this line
in the a.org virtualhost should do it:

Alias /foo/bar /web/b.net/fubar

It doesn't matter that /web/b.net/fubar is in the b.net virtualhost --
it's just another directory.

Evan



From drl at drloree.com  Sat Jan 22 16:09:07 2005
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat, 22 Jan 2005 16:09:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Newbie (to) debian help
In-Reply-To: <1106423045.7345.9.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
References: <1106423045.7345.9.camel@leonard.crisponions.com>
Message-ID: <1106438947.1320.19.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2005-01-22 at 11:44 -0800, David Phillips wrote:
> I have been (slowly) trying to get myself acquainted with debian.  Here
> is my issue, I cannot seem to mount any cifs/smb partitions, I get the
> "wrong fs or bad superblock" error.  So I read somewhere I should
> upgrade to the latest 2.6 kernel.  I have successfully built a 2.6.9
> kernel but cannot get the thing to boot.  Prior to this i was using
> 2.6.8-1.  The error I get is "VFS-cannot open root device "hdb2" or
> unknown block(0,0)".  What I cant figure out is I am using the
> same .config file that was created by the debian kernel package for my
> 2.6.8 kernel and all my options in grub are correct...
> 
> I know my way around RedHat and Gentoo pretty well, but Debian makes me
> feel like I am starting all over again :-) I would really like to get
> acquainted with it because it seems to be the distro all the gurus use,
> so I think that says something. Any tips would be appreciated.

This isn't really a debian specific problem, but more of a kernel
configuration/build problem.  My guess is that the disk controller
driver module isn't getting loaded by the time the kernel tries to read
the fstab file.  Since you are building your own, you might as well
configure the kernel to have the driver built in.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From baloo at ursine.dyndns.org  Sun Jan 23 05:20:10 2005

> I added unstable sources to sources.list for my Sarge
> installation and did a dist-upgrade. Nothing dramatic
> happened, although KDE 3.3 is noticeably different
> from 3.2 when it starts. All services are okay.
>

No, you need to explicitly tell it you want a new kernel by version and 
subarchitecture.
 
> My two enduring headaches are: I haven't been able to
> set up Java. I was hoping it would be easier than it
> turned out to be. Same for mplayer. The unofficial
> package gives me signal 11 errors, and building it
> from source is not an easy task.

Installing Sun's official version of Java by downloading it from sun.com 
worked for me.  Mplayer installed cleanly from the debian-marrillat 
source if you search for mplayer on apt-get.org for me.

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Sun Jan 23 10:26:56 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 10:26:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] On Going Unstable
In-Reply-To: <200501230520.12789.baloo@ursine.dyndns.org>
References: <20050121222448.54119.qmail@web50610.mail.yahoo.com>
	<200501230520.12789.baloo@ursine.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <41F3EC70.7010406@cesmail.net>

Paul Johnson wrote:

>>My two enduring headaches are: I haven't been able to
>>set up Java. I was hoping it would be easier than it
>>turned out to be. Same for mplayer. The unofficial
>>package gives me signal 11 errors, and building it
>>from source is not an easy task.
>>    
>>
>
>Installing Sun's official version of Java by downloading it from sun.com 
>worked for me.  Mplayer installed cleanly from the debian-marrillat 
>source if you search for mplayer on apt-get.org for me.
>  
>

As far as I know, Sun's Java Runtime Environment is the *only* one that 
supports a lot of Java apps. I've had lots of trouble with the others. 
The fly in the ointment is the "religious wars" over the 
non-free-as-in-freedom nature of the JRE. Debian and some Debian-based 
distros like Agnula avoid Java apps as much as possible for this reason. 
Gentoo, on the other hand, has excellent Java support. You have to 
download the Sun software manually from the Sun site, but after that, 
you can use a lot of Java apps that are in Portage but not Debian.


From wamorita at hevanet.com  Sun Jan 23 11:07:04 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 11:07:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question - Resolution
In-Reply-To: <200501222123.j0MLNRA45835@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <200501231907.j0NJ76A65536@pop.hevanet.com>

I final resolved this.  Somehow I dropped 'server' from the server_args
line.
Cvs login works just fine now.

- Bill

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org

Sent: Saturday, January 22, 2005 1:23 PM
To: 'General Linux discussion and assistance'
Subject: RE: [PLUG] CVS Server Question

Rich, Ken,

I seem to be making some progress (I think).  I was missing file:
/etc/xinetd.d/cvspserver :
service cvspserver
{
        socket_type     = stream
        wait            = no
        user            = root
        group           = cvsusers
        env             = HOME=/shares/cvs-repository 
        server          = /usr/bin/cvs
        server_args     = -f --allow-root=/shares/cvs-repository
        disable         = no
}

Now the problem has changed to:

cvs [login aborted]: unrecognized auth response from frodo: Usage: cvs
[cvs-opti ons] command [command-options-and-arguments]

Hopefully I have not headed up a dead end!

- Bill Morita

wamorita at hevanet.com

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Rich Burroughs
Sent: Saturday, January 22, 2005 12:53 AM
To: General Linux discussion and assistance
Subject: Re: [PLUG] CVS Server Question

William A Morita wrote:
> Alan,
> 
> I do not believe I have IP chains turned on.  
> This is an out-of-the-box RH9 system with firewall disabled.
> Is it possible that there is a different password for CVS that the 
> local uid login?

Hi Bill,

The "connection refused" error doesn't sound like a password problem. 
That's an error you typically get if you try to connect to a port where
there's not a service running. Which is probably why Alan asked about a
firewall.

One thing to check would be whether the CVS server is even accepting
connections. It may not be running or may not be configured properly. 
You could try connecting to it from a shell on the server itself.

Are you running it from inetd or xinetd? If so, make sure that process is
actually running and listening on the appropriate port.


Rich

From drl at drloree.com  Sun Jan 23 11:32:02 2005

> > > "wrong fs or bad superblock" error.  So I read somewhere I should
> > > upgrade to the latest 2.6 kernel.  I have successfully built a 2.6.9
> > > kernel but cannot get the thing to boot.  Prior to this i was using
> > > 2.6.8-1.  The error I get is "VFS-cannot open root device "hdb2" or
> > > unknown block(0,0)".  What I cant figure out is I am using the
> > > same .config file that was created by the debian kernel package for my
> > > 2.6.8 kernel and all my options in grub are correct...
> > > 
> > > I know my way around RedHat and Gentoo pretty well, but Debian makes me
> > > feel like I am starting all over again :-) I would really like to get
> > > acquainted with it because it seems to be the distro all the gurus use,
> > > so I think that says something. Any tips would be appreciated.
> > 
> > This isn't really a debian specific problem, but more of a kernel
> > configuration/build problem.  My guess is that the disk controller
> > driver module isn't getting loaded by the time the kernel tries to read
> > the fstab file.  Since you are building your own, you might as well
> > configure the kernel to have the driver built in.
> > 
> > Good Luck,
> > 
> > Derek Loree
> > 
> 
> Thats what I was thinking. But if I am using my same .config file as
> 2.6.8 kernel, why isnt it working?  They only things I have really added
> is switching samba and cifs fs from modules to built in.  So it should
> be loading the same things correct?

No, you are using the configuration file from a different kernel
version.  It may be a good starting point, but there will be some
differences between them -- they are different versions after all.  It
is up to you to do a sanity check on the more important settings.

Where did you get your kernel source?  Debian has kernel-source packages
that come with their own default config and have debian specific patches
applied, the settings are pretty conservative, but they work, most of
the time.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree



From redhat at crisponions.com  Sun Jan 23 11:46:59 2005
From: redhat at crisponions.com (Len Icks)
Date: Sun, 23 Jan 2005 11:46:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Newbie (to) debian help
Message-ID: <CC5738F2CE677746976EC06CBD6B9D98C7C5@toonces.crisponions.com>

I downloaded the debian sources via apt, I didn't realize they came with
their own config file.  I solved my main problem (smbfs) so at this
point I hopefully wont need to rebuild the kernel anyway.  System is
usable now for a desktop, so now I just need to spend the hours getting
familiar so maybe I can make a final transition.

Thanks for the tips.

an hour or so I'll know that the boards are OK and I just did not properly
charge the battery.

> it doesn't say "Welcome to Sid.")

sources.list file? AFAIK, there's no reason to still include testing
if you're intent on using unstable.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jan 23 19:31:03 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 03:31:03 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Posts from the future....
References: <20050122033552.63437.qmail@web52704.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <slrncv8p7q.i55.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-22, Jon LeVitre <jonlevitre at yahoo.com> wrote:
> Is it just me, or do other people dislike having to skip past the
> August 2019 and September 2006 lines on the plug Archives page.
>
> Is there any way we could make them go away (like changing the dates to
> the dates they were received)?

The current Mailman version detects bogus dates by requiring them to
fall within a smallish delta of the current time.  The previous
configuration also used the header's date, rather than the received
date.  So, it shouldn't happen any more.  I'll try to fiddle with the
re-generating the archives to fix the bad dates.

Wil

Planner is pretty lame compared to Microsoft Project, which itself is 
pretty lame compared with Prima Vera. You pretty much get what you pay 
for; if you have to do *real* project management, as opposed to just 
printing Gantt charts, there really isn't a free-as-in-freedom option.

Michael H. Collins wrote:

> http://www.egroupware.org/

There's a big difference between groupware, software project 
coordination and "project management". There is not an acceptable 
project management package in the free-as-in-freedom domain ... I spent 
weeks trying to find something that would do 1/10 of what Microsoft 
Project does. Maybe if enough developers join the Planner team, it will 
evolve that way. Meanwhile, if you have a non-software project to 
manage, you're stuck with Microsoft at the moment.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 24 07:09:48 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 07:09:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   Yesterday I had to shut down my machines to install the new UPS. They
seemed to reboot cleanly and completely. However, I cannot get privoxy going
again and I cannot figure out why.

   I noticed that I had neglected to add rc.privoxy to rc.local, so I started
it manually this morning -- as root, of course. However, I cannot connect to
any Web page (internal or external) when the proxy is enabled (same
localhost address and port as before). When the proxy is disabled everything
works.

   I've looked at the docs and see nothing that might have changed just by
shutting down the system. '/etc/rc.d/rc.privoxy status' shows nothing at
all. No privoxy process shows up in the process list.

   If someone can suggest diagnostics -- or a cure -- I'd greatly appreciate
the clue.

Thanks,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 24 07:16:13 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 07:16:13 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] GNU Project Management Software?
In-Reply-To: <41F50DBB.1020105@cesmail.net>

	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501220858110.16029@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

	<41F50DBB.1020105@cesmail.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240711090.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky wrote:

> There's a big difference between groupware, software project coordination
> and "project management". There is not an acceptable project management
> package in the free-as-in-freedom domain ... I spent weeks trying to find
> something that would do 1/10 of what Microsoft Project does. Maybe if
> enough developers join the Planner team, it will evolve that way.
> Meanwhile, if you have a non-software project to manage, you're stuck with
> Microsoft at the moment.

   Thank you, Ed. I used TimeLine to manage major hydroelectric dam
re-licensing projects with a cast of dozens, a large budget and several
hundred tasks. The ability to re-assign/re-level resources automatically
when things slipped, to recalculate the critial path and to produce weekly
expense reports comparing budgeted and spent amounts was vital. It just
ain't like a software project or a group of folks putting out a common memo.

   There is a knowledgeable local resource, but the reality is that those who
could produce a native linux version of TimeLine need to make a living, too.
Unless we can come up with a sponsor (and I have no ideas on who or why),
I'm afraid it just will not happen. Doing professional project management
software is a very far from trivial exercise. It probably equals in
complexity computational geometry for spatial analyses.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

scripts and other scripts which are supposed to do what I want but they 
all either segfault or don't do anything.
Then I thought I could maybe run them through SA with a procmail entry 
to send them off to never never land.  Could someone explain how to do 
this with both types of inboxes.  I think I know how with Maildir but am 
not so sure with the old mbox files.  If I don't need to fool with 
procmail so much the better.

This will probably remove 10 gigs of mail from what I need to archive.

From kls at merlot.com  Mon Jan 24 09:02:16 2005
From: kls at merlot.com (Kurt Sussman)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 09:02:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Rich Shepard (rshepard at appl-ecosys.com) typed this ...
>    If someone can suggest diagnostics -- or a cure -- I'd greatly appreciate
> the clue.

As root:

netstat -tanp

That will show you who's listening on each port. Look only at the ports
you care about by piping the netstat output to 'grep 80' or whatever
your port of choice might be.

--Kurt

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Jan 24 10:32:10 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 10:32:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <200501222001.j0MK1DA10442@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <1106411394.14699.18.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
	<200501222001.j0MK1DA10442@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <20050124103210.014c0fec.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth William A Morita, on Sat, 22 Jan 2005 12:01:11 -0800:

> When I do that and try CVS login I get:
> 
> cvs login: can only use `login' command with the 'pserver' method
> cvs [login aborted]: CVSROOT:
> :ext:wamorita at frodo:/shares/cvs-repository

Right, with :ext:, you log in once for every command, instead of using
"login".  Your local username is passed to the server by default, so
you'll just get a password prompt.  More tedious, but more secure.

--Jason

--
I'd give my right arm to be ambidextrous!


From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 24 10:41:46 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 10:41:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1106592106.17225.127.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 07:09 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>    If someone can suggest diagnostics -- or a cure -- I'd greatly appreciate
> the clue.

Does anything privoxy related appear in your logs when you try and start
it?

Look at the rc.privoxy script, under the start() section, for the exact
command used to start the proxy.  Run that manually and look for any
kind of error output.  You may have a stale lockfile or something
similar laying around that's causing grief.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 24 10:47:42 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 10:47:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106438295.6338.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1106592463.17230.132.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 10:19 -0800, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Yeah, mod_alias only works for exposing files directly, like symlinks. 
> But I have dynamic content being generated by different Java Web-app's
> in a servlet container, and it's those that I need to map to one
> another.
> 
> This is an uncommon problem, I'm sure; but I think I'll be able to solve
> it with mod_rewrite, somehow.  (I'm just not used to that black magic!)

If you're already writing dynamic content, you might as well code the
redirection stuff yourself.  It's not particularly difficult and leaves
you far more flexibility than mod_rewrite or mod_proxy can offer.

Your java web-apps (or something else you write) can send HTTP responses
back themselves.  All mod_rewrite does is send a 302 back to the client.

http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html ...has a list of
everything you could need, I think.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 24 11:03:46 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

> Does anything privoxy related appear in your logs when you try and start
> it?

   Apologies, Rob. I looked there (/var/log/messages) but neglected to
mention it. Nothing there.

> Look at the rc.privoxy script, under the start() section, for the exact
> command used to start the proxy.  Run that manually and look for any kind
> of error output.  You may have a stale lockfile or something similar
> laying around that's causing grief.

   I've been running it manually and I don't see any of the messages (i.e.,
"Starting ", "Retrying ..." or "Already running". Here's that section of the
script:

start () {
         # start daemon
         echo -n $"Starting $PRIVOXY_PRG: "

         if [ ! -f $PRIVOXY_PID ]; then
                 ($PRIVOXY --user $PRIVOXY_USER.$PRIVOXY_GROUP  --pidfile
$PRIVO
XY_PID 2>/dev/tty9 ) \
                         && echo " OK" \
                         && /bin/touch /var/lock/$PRIVOXY_PRG \
                         && RETVAL=0
         elif [ $check -lt 3 ]; then
                 echo "Zombie lock file found"
                 /bin/rm -f /var/lock/$PRIVOXY_PRG $PRIVOXY_PID
                 echo "Retrying..."
                 start
         else
                 echo "Already running"
         fi
         echo
}

and here's what I see when I try running it:

[root at salmo /etc/rc.d]# ./rc.privoxy start
[root at salmo /etc/rc.d]#

   Nobody's home.

Thanks,

Rich

   On host 'tux' (I was not inventive that day) I export /usr2, /usr3, and
/usr4; all are owned by root.users and have permissions 777.

   On host 'salmo' I try to mount them based on the entries in /etc/fstab:

tux:/usr2        /mnt/usr2        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
tux:/usr3        /mnt/usr3        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
tux:/usr4        /mnt/usr4        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0

   When I -- as root -- try to mount them I'm getting a permissions error:

[root at salmo ~]# mount /mnt/usr2
mount: tux:/usr2 failed, reason given by server: Permission denied

   I'm not seeing what permission is incorrect. A better pair of eyes would
be helpful.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 24 12:20:47 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 12:20:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] NFS mount glitch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241205130.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241205130.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501241217390.550@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   On host 'tux' (I was not inventive that day) I export /usr2, 
> /usr3, and /usr4; all are owned by root.users and have permissions 
> 777.

What does tux:/etc/exports have to say?

>   On host 'salmo' I try to mount them based on the entries in /etc/fstab:
>
> tux:/usr2        /mnt/usr2        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
> tux:/usr3        /mnt/usr3        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
> tux:/usr4        /mnt/usr4        nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
>
>   When I -- as root -- try to mount them I'm getting a permissions error:
>
> [root at salmo ~]# mount /mnt/usr2
> mount: tux:/usr2 failed, reason given by server: Permission denied

If /etc/exports on tux is in good shape, you'll want to make sure

1. that the portmapper is running on both tux and salmo

2. that the /etc/hosts.{allow,deny} files on tux don't restrict
    traffic (since portmap is compiled against libwrap)

3. that salmo has the IP address tux thinks it should have

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jan 24 12:46:03 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 20:46:03 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106592106.17225.127.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241100320.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106593557.17224.147.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241144460.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <slrncvan36.i55.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-24, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>
>> Does anything show up on /dev/tty9?  CTRL+ALT+F9.
>
>    Nah. Not even a login prompt. I didn't understand why errors are directed
> to tty9; still don't. Must be a SysAdmin secret.

Pretty straight-forward; just add to /etc/syslog.conf:

*.debug<TAB>/dev/tty9

(<TAB> must be a literal tab, not a space!)

Then HUP syslogd and you'll have a quick way to always get to log
messages.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *



From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Mon Jan 24 13:04:09 2005
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:04:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Batch Scheduling Software
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4293@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> Steve Daggett wrote:
> >  Does anyone have a recommendation for a *nix batch job scheduling 
> > software?  An Open Source tools with commercial support or 
> > commercial tools would be preferable.
> 
> Steve,
> 
>    Something beyond cron or at?
> 
  I real batch schedule tool is much more complex that cron.  Batch jobs
usually exist as queues or streams if individual.  Each job execution may be
dependant on one or more previous job ending successfully and creating the
correct output files.  A good job scheduler will monitor each job in turn.
It waits for the correct input files, make sure the job runs on time,
doesn't run too long, and creates the correct output files.  All with proper
logging and notification to the system operators.  It should alert the
operators when a batch stream gets stuck because a job failed or is waiting
for resources.  

  We've talked about writing something using Shell, Perl, and cron.  It
would be a lot easier to start with a batch scheduling tool and configure it
to our needs.  There are a couple of packages on SourceForge that might
work.  I was just wondering if somebody had a tool they were happy with.  

Steve D...

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 24 13:16:49 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:16:49 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] NFS mount glitch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241229080.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241205130.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.62.0501241217390.550@arrowhead.galois.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241229080.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501241306590.550@arrowhead.galois.com>

OK. It may be time for some surgery. I hate doing this, but on more 
than one occasion this is the only trick that worked.

   cd /var/lib
   tar cWvf /tmp/nfs-backup.tar ./nfs
   cd nfs
   grep -l salmo *

Now, carefully open all files returned by grep in a text editor that 
does NOT automatically wrap lines; vi will do the trick, as will "nano 
-w" or "pico -w". Excise all references to salmo and save the files in 
place.

   exportfs -rv

Then give it another spin. If things work, you can delete 
/tmp/nfs-backup.tar. If things go horribly awry, restore /var/lib/nfs 
from /tmp/nfs-backup.tar and try again.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 24 13:33:30 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:33:30 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] NFS mount glitch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501241306590.550@arrowhead.galois.com>

From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 13:56:03 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 13:56:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241100320.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<1106592106.17225.127.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241100320.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41F56EF3.905@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>    I've been running it manually and I don't see any of the messages (i.e.,
> "Starting ", "Retrying ..." or "Already running". Here's that section of the
> script:

The fact that nothing's listening on the right port when you look at the 
netstat output probably means the program just itsn't running. It may be 
a problem with a lockfile, or maybe something is just broken in the 
script. Perhaps one of the paths defined is not correct, or has changed.

Is this the first time you've rebooted the box since installing the 
software? It's not unusual to find problems when you reboot the first 
time after making a change, in that case it's usually the program's init 
script. That begs the question of how it got started up in the first 
place, but we won't know the answer to that.

Try running the start command that's in the script, manually. Don't run 
the script, run the command itself, type it out in your shell. You will 
need to subsitute the contents of those variables yourself when you do 
it, they should be defined in the script. In other words, instead of 
typing $PRIVOXY in the start command, type what is assigned to that 
variable earlier in the script.

Runnning the command by hand at the command line will be the best way to 
get feedback about what's happening.


Rich

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jan 24 14:03:07 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 24 Jan 2005 14:03:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Batch Scheduling Software
In-Reply-To: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4293@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982D4293@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <86vf9meb8k.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "SD" == Daggett, Steve <Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com> writes:

SD>   I real batch schedule tool is much more complex that cron.
SD> Batch jobs usually exist as queues or streams if individual.  Each
SD> job execution may be dependant on one or more previous job ending
SD> successfully and creating the correct output files.  A good job
SD> scheduler will monitor each job in turn.  It waits for the correct
SD> input files, make sure the job runs on time, doesn't run too long,
SD> and creates the correct output files.  All with proper logging and
SD> notification to the system operators.  It should alert the
SD> operators when a batch stream gets stuck because a job failed or
SD> is waiting for resources.

Sounds like you need a clever Makefile.  Maybe you could write a
script to write the Makefile with the right clauses to do what you
want. 


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

A few days ago I noticed Yahoo instant messenger started behaving

Checking `bindshell'... INFECTED (PORTS:  600)

I decided to run chkrootkit because of some interesting things from  
"netstat -tanp |more", which had been mentioned in another post. I wish 
that I had scripted to a file, so that I could post that output now. I 
have since killed a couple of suspicious processes, so the output 
doesn't have anything all that interesting anymore.  So, what should I 
do next, to ensure I closed this up and cleaned house?

From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 14:45:34 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 14:45:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241359460.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<1106592106.17225.127.camel@dell.linux.box>	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241100320.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<41F56EF3.905@paranoid.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241359460.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41F57A8E.1090000@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Rich Burroughs wrote:
> 

>>It may be a problem with a lockfile, or maybe something is just broken in
>>the script.  Perhaps one of the paths defined is not correct, or has
>>changed.
> 
>    I looked in /var/lock, but there's no privoxy lock file there.

Ok.

>    I followed the privoxy instructions, then manually ran
> /etc/rc.d/rc.privoxy. It fired up and chugged away at a low idle with no
> smoke or dripping oil.

Ok. Try running the command by hand. You can leave off the part 
redirecting stderr to tty9, that way you'll see stdout and stderr both 
right there in your window. It it's too much into to fit on one screen 
then send it to a file.

One other question is whether the service was configured properly to 
start and stop in the needed runlevels. I'm not sure what distro you're 
using, but usually there's a GUI tool for managing services in the 
different runlevels. If the box is using xdm/gdm/kdm then you're looking 
for runlevel 5. You can see the default runlevel in /etc/inittab.

If the service is not configured to stop automatically, then it would 
not have been shut down properly. You say you're not seeing a lockfile, 
so something else may have been messed up. If that's the case you may 
get better support from whatever mailing lists or forums exist for the 
privoxy software, since those are pretty specific questions.


Rich

of false positives that this combination receives a special entry in the FAQ.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 24 14:54:18 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 14:54:18 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Working Web proxie quit upon reboot -- SOLVED
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241359460.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501240702510.29356@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106592106.17225.127.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241100320.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F56EF3.905@paranoid.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241359460.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501241443070.12077@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Rich Shepard wrote:

> It may be a problem with a lockfile, or maybe something is just broken in
> the script.  Perhaps one of the paths defined is not correct, or has
> changed.

Rich, et al.:

   I tracked down the problem, and it is subtle. I'll document it here for
archive archeologists when they come up with the same situation.

SUMMARY: The initial configuration was done from the privoxy Web site, and
that's where it was configured and started. That process never made a local
copy of the config file. Privoxy will not start without a config file.

   Spelunking through /opt/privoxy/doc/text/user-manual.txt I learned that
the executable (/usr/local/sbin/privoxy) wants to find the config file in
/etc/privoxy/. That directory was not created during the installation and
tweaking process. Neither was the file in it.

   So, I created /etc/privoxy/ and created config. The user-manual.txt has
the requirements; confdir and logdir are mandatory, all else is optional.
Here's my config:

confdir		/etc/privoxy
logdir		/var/log/privoxy
actionsfile	standard
actionsfile	default
actionsfile	user
filterfile	default.filter
logfile		logfile
jarfile		jarfile
trustfile 
debug		8192
listen-address	127.0.0.1:8118
toggle		1

   Now, the application also wants to look at the action files. They're in
the directory where it was installed (/usr/local/etc/privoxy). So I made
softlinks from /etc/privoxy to /usr/local/etc/privoxy -- including the
template/ directory.

   Then I ran '/usr/local/sbin/privoxy /etc/privoxy/config' and it worked.
Oh, you need to turn on the proxy in your browser before firing it up.

   I don't know if I need to export the $PRIVOX_xxx environment variables for
the Slackware rc.privoxy script. Guess I'll find out when I next need to
reboot this box.

Excelsior! (Not the packing version.)

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 14:56:32 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 14:56:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <41F57D20.7020309@paranoid.org>

Mel Andres wrote:
> A few days ago I noticed Yahoo instant messenger started behaving 
> strange. I attempted to fix that by removing  and re-installing it, 
> which didn't resolve my problem. Today, I ran chkrootkit, and this 
> disturbing line was in the output:
> 
> Checking `bindshell'... INFECTED (PORTS:  600)
> 
> I decided to run chkrootkit because of some interesting things from  
> "netstat -tanp |more", which had been mentioned in another post. I wish 
> that I had scripted to a file, so that I could post that output now. I 
> have since killed a couple of suspicious processes, so the output 
> doesn't have anything all that interesting anymore.  So, what should I 
> do next, to ensure I closed this up and cleaned house?

Hi Mel,

You can get a sense of what's been replaced if you have Tripwire or a 
similar program installed. If you are using RPM, a quick and dirty check 
is rpm -Va, but that is not infallible. If someone insttalled an RPM 
with trojans in it, it would check out ok.

I did a quick Google and I'm not 100% sure that message means you've 
been hacked. I saw one post that identified that as a false positive, 
saying it was actually rpc.statd:

http://lists.debian.org/debian-user/2004/03/msg17020.html

Here's an article with some good suggestions on intrustion detection, it 
contains some info on using the RPM vrify:

http://www.linuxexposed.com/internal.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=571&mode=&order=0

If you do find you've been hacked, though, there's no reliable way to 
clean house on a compromised box. Once the tools you're using can't be 
trusted, then it's all downhill. You'll need to reinstall the OS from 
scratch and then apply all security patches for your release.


Rich




From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Jan 24 15:04:19 2005

Rich Burroughs wrote:
> 
> If you do find you've been hacked, though, there's no reliable way to 
> clean house on a compromised box. Once the tools you're using can't be 
> trusted, then it's all downhill. 


Those two statements don't logically tie together.  One can reinstall the 
tools - boot from a resuce CD so you are assured that RPM is OK. Once RPM
(or apt tools) are known good you can verify and reinstall any other system
binaries.

From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 15:06:27 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 15:06:27 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <20050124225200.GB31938@patch.com>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>	<1106606670.17225.150.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<20050124225200.GB31938@patch.com>
Message-ID: <41F57F73.6010907@paranoid.org>

Michael Rasmussen wrote:
>  Note, I'm the in minority of people who believe that an
> infected system can be cleaned and restored to safe behavior.  

I think that's possible if you have a method like Tripwire to check the 
integity of the system files, and you know what you're doing. But then 
you have to check for a lot of other things as well. Other backdoors, 
accounts with no passwords or UID 0, SUID copies of bash laying about, 
malicous cron jobs, init scripts and CGI scripts, and more. It's really 
hard to know that you've covered every possible scenario that could 
allow the attacker root access again.

For some people (especially people without a lot of practical security 
experience) wiping and installing from scratch will actually be easier 
than dealing with all of that. But, then again, if you don't investigate 
things you don't learn.

This may have been a false positive, and I'd certainly investigate that 
first before doing anything drastic.


Rich




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 24 15:19:31 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 15:19:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <20050124225200.GB31938@patch.com>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
	<1106606670.17225.150.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<20050124225200.GB31938@patch.com>
Message-ID: <1106608771.17225.159.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 14:52 -0800, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> AthlonRob wrote:
> > On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 14:49 -0800, Mel Andres wrote:
> > > So, what should I do next, to ensure I closed this up and cleaned house?
> > 
> > 1) Unplug the computer from the LAN, modem, whatever.
> > 2) Wipe your disk clean and re-install Linux.
> 
> please.  not required.

Perhaps not technically, but if the box actually *has* been rooted, it's
at least required practically.

> Mel, how much do you want to learn about your system?
> Start by searching the PLUG archives, there is at least one thread covering
> how to recover.  Note, I'm the in minority of people who believe that an
> infected system can be cleaned and restored to safe behavior.  

Sure it can.  After you verify virtually everything on the system is
infection free.  You need to verify *every* script, *every*
configuration file, *every* binary.  

Imagine you're a black-hat cracker interested in keeping a rooted box.
How many different ways would you go about protecting yourself?  I'd
trojan every ~/.bashrc, every crontab, every binary I could think of,
every script sourced at boot or log on.  I'd trojan lilo, you know it
can execute something upon startup?  I'd trojan inittab.  I'd trojan
everybody's .forward.  I'd trojan the aliases DB.  I'd figure out how to
add a DSO to Apache that would allow me access.

Hey, a lot of these things may only grant me user access... but if
you've been rooted once, how difficult do you think it's going to be for
an attacker to gain root privs from a mere mortal user?  Not very.

Sure you could check all these things and *not* wipe the box clean and
start over - but why would you want to?

> Also, check google for chkrootkit and bindshell - there are enough instances
> of false positives that this combination receives a special entry in the FAQ.

Indeed, of course you verify you *are* rooted before doing anything to
fix the problem.  You want to be 100% sure, I think....

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 15:22:10 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 15:22:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <20050124230419.GB32166@patch.com>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net> <41F57D20.7020309@paranoid.org>
	<20050124230419.GB32166@patch.com>
Message-ID: <41F58322.4080302@paranoid.org>

Michael Rasmussen wrote:

> Those two statements don't logically tie together.  One can reinstall the 
> tools - boot from a resuce CD so you are assured that RPM is OK. Once RPM
> (or apt tools) are known good you can verify and reinstall any other system
> binaries.

You can verify RPMs against known good packages if you have them all, 
yes. But doing the straight RPM verify from the RPM database is not 
enough to assure you things are ok.

Say I hack your box and get root. At that point I can install whatever 
RPMs I want. It's not hard to make an RPM that appears to be the real 
thing once it's installed, you can spoof all that info that shows up in 
rpm -qi for example, like the build host.

Now, when you as a sysadmin do RPM -va, the RPM I installed will show up 
as having the correct MD5 sums. That's because the sums that are checked 
are the ones from the package last installed, the trojaned one I 
installed, not the original package. The sums will be the same as the 
ones generated when I built the package, and RPM will not report a problem.

Of course I can't fake the signature, but rpm -Va doesn't check that.

If you're talking about reinstalling all the software, then that's 
pretty much what I was suggesting in the first place. I'm not saying you 
neccessarily need to wipe the disk clean, but you are probably looking 
at reinstalling the OS.

Now again, I'm not disagreeing with you that it's possible for someone 
who knows what they are doing to do a reasonably decent job of cleaning 
up after a box that's been hacked. But I think for the average person, 
reinstalling may be easier.

If it was a box that had valuable data on it, then I would want to back 
up the data, wipe it, and reinstall. Or replace it with a new box and 
migrate the data.



Rich




From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Jan 24 11:35:09 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 11:35:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <1106592463.17230.132.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106438295.6338.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106592463.17230.132.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <20050124113509.5b6a8aa2.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth AthlonRob, on Mon, 24 Jan 2005 10:47:42 -0800:

> If you're already writing dynamic content, you might as well code the
> redirection stuff yourself.  It's not particularly difficult and
> leaves you far more flexibility than mod_rewrite or mod_proxy can
> offer.

I don't see a particularly elegant solution there, frankly.  I guess I'd
either have to alter my servlet base class (for "a.org") to step in as
needed and forward somehow (can I even RequestDispatcher.forward() to a
different Web app'?), or I'd need to write a servlet filter.  Neither of
these is as clean as using mod_rewrite (once I get it right), and both
would taint my application proper.  (I certainly don't want to combine
these Web app's into one, for that would be senseless.  One of them is
blojsom, which is distributed as its own Web app'.)

> Your java web-apps (or something else you write) can send HTTP
> responses back themselves.  All mod_rewrite does is send a 302 back to
> the client.

I believe that depends on the value in brackets (e.g., "[PT]" for "pass
through") after each RewriteRule.  I'm using "[P]" for this, which uses
mod_proxy, so I don't think the 302 response applies there.  Indeed, I
want to avoid a second client connection altogether.

--Jason

--

"The great thing about mod_rewrite is it gives you all the
configurability and flexibility of Sendmail. The downside to mod_rewrite
is that it gives you all the configurability and flexibility of
Sendmail."  -- Brian Behlendorf


From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Jan 24 16:20:16 2005
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 16:20:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20050125002016.GA23977@rauhaus.org>

* Mel Andres <mel97215 at comcast.net> [050124 14:41]:
> A few days ago I noticed Yahoo instant messenger started behaving 
> strange. I attempted to fix that by removing  and re-installing it, 
> which didn't resolve my problem. Today, I ran chkrootkit, and this 
> disturbing line was in the output:
> 
> Checking `bindshell'... INFECTED (PORTS:  600)

Do you have the lsof utility? If so, what does "lsof -i :600" tell you?
If it shows a process id (pid) for whatever is bound to port 600, then
you can do a "ps -fp (PID)" - replace (PID) with the actual process id
you're looking for.

Granted, if you really are compromised, then certainly ps will have been
trojaned, and possibly also lsof. However, this method might turn up
something that would suggest you just have a false positive from
chkrootkit.

--Stafford



From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jan 24 16:31:18 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 16:31:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Maybe y'all can help with this.
In-Reply-To: <41F53994.6030402@linuxlink.com>
References: <41F53994.6030402@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <20050125003118.GA24722@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Jan 24, 2005 at 12:08:20PM -0600, Michael H. Collins wrote:
> I took over this email server late in 2003.  According to the nasd a 
> copy of all broker emails must be kept. At first we were using mbox and 
> now we use Maildir.  One user has a copy of all email including "[SPAM]" 
> mails.
> We have discussed it and want to remove all the mail marked as [SPAM] 
> and send it to the bit bucket before archiving it.  I found some perl 
> scripts and other scripts which are supposed to do what I want but they 
> all either segfault or don't do anything.

Hm.  Well procmail comes with a program called formail that can
process mboxes and maildirs, piping one email at a time to a program
using the -e command.  It's a great way to convert mboxes to maildir
and vice-versa.  I think it also can select emails based on header
info, so you could e.g. use it to archive messages and tell it to
ignore messages with "Subject: [SPAM].*" in the header when archiving.

Checkiddout.  I've found formail to be an amazingly useful tool.

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jan 24 17:37:31 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 17:37:31 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Dovecot and Thunderbird revisited
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501241717220.21340-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Well I'm happy to say that between all the excellant suggestions I got 
from this list and some serious re-reading I have postfix, procmail and  
dovecot ( mostly ) playing nicely together.  Mail goes in and gets filed 
in the correct folders.
   I've done one pass at loading my mbox formatted mail into the new 
account and it works as slick as can be.  For those that might be 
interested two directories are needed/used by Dovecot.  The actual named 
"folder" and a hidden version ".folder".  To make them show up 
automagically the actual name has to be in the file ".subscriptions".
   Down-ish side is they all show up as new messages but a quick Ctrl-A, 
right click, mark all as read and that was fixed.  I haven't gone hot with 
the server yet , just testing how things work.

I have one last question that I need enlightenment on.  How do I get ssl 
connections working?

I created the SSL certificates ( self signed I think they are called ) and
got them in the ( hopefully ) correct place.  Once or twice I could get
logged in by telling TB to use a ssl connection but got warnings about
certificate and host name missmatch.  I recreated the certificates with 
"better" information ( hostname, etc. ) and now get server timeouts.  So I 
whimped out and went with plain old IMAP for now.
   This mail server is running in a Linux-Vserver so I'm not sure if the 
main server's iptables is causing a problem or it is inside the vserver 
that is acting up.

I found a couple of HOWTOs for doing this but they tended to wander away
from what I wanted/needed -- too simple or too complex.  Anyone have a
pointer to a good HOWTO on Dovecot ( or IMAP in general ) SSL connections?


TIA,
Rod

    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

processes I killed off was fam, as I could think of no reason 
(application) for it to be running. And there was the peculiar change in 
the Yahoo messenger display, which is yet to be resolved. I've checked 
that I can still perform my job duties without firing up their WinXP 
laptop, so I think I am okay for the short term.  I know enough to be a 
little more than dangerous, but not enough to ease my mind about 
manually checking everything.
