(WinXP, Suse, future use) and have been planning to take a stab at 
installing debian on the remaining portion. That way I could mount my 
current linux filesystem, and copy over my email, and other personal 
stuff. Once comfortable with debian, and confident I won't need the suse 
filesystem, I'll blow it away and save it for the next upgrade/project.

buying a wireless router too, or what's the point when I work from home?

security, and my linux box won't have to do IP forwarding anymore. I'll

there will be more linux support for that.  And, that will be the next

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jan 24 18:00:02 2005
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 18:00:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <1106606670.17225.150.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>
	<1106606670.17225.150.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <2231-61735@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005 14:44:29 -0800, AthlonRob Wrote:

> 1) Unplug the computer from the LAN, modem, whatever.
> 2) Wipe your disk clean and re-install Linux.

I agree with Rob.  However, before going to all the trouble, verify
that you've really been hacked.  Disconnect the network and boot from
known good media (e.g. the Knoppix Security Tools Distribution
downloaded and burned from another computer. 
http://www.knoppix-std.org/) Run chkrootkit from the CD.  Nothing on
your original PC hard drive can be trusted.

The warning from chkrootkit by itself doesn't necessarily mean you've
been hacked.  The "suspicious" processes are of more concern.  The
info from the SANS Intrusion Detection "cheat sheet" might be helpful:

http://www.sans.org/score/checklists/ID_Linux.pdf

(This is also a good quick read for the PLUG list in general.)

Others also agree with Rob's quick summary:

http://www-jerry.oit.duke.edu/linux/HOWTO/what_to_do_if_hacked.html

Here is a nice series on incident response from techrepublic.com
offering in-depth advice that boils down to what Rob said:

http://techrepublic.com.com/5100-6264_11-5034937.html
http://techrepublic.com.com/5100-6264_11-5034945.html
http://techrepublic.com.com/5100-6264_11-5034940.html

The advice listed elsewhere on this list about booting from known good
media, downloading trusted RPM signatures, and checking every binary
on your system is good-intentioned but ultimately impractical.  There
is simply no way to ensure that every binary is good in less time that
it would take to re-install.

Your data files are probably fine-- e.g. images, MP3s, text files,
OpenOffice docs.  There's no harm saving them off someplace for a
later restore (e.g. CD-R).  Make two copies, since it really, really
sucks to find out that your entire digtal photo collection just
happened to be on that one CD-R that was bad.  There is a small but
nonzero chance that these could be used to re-compromise your system. 
However, this risk is so small and the effort to safely re-create the
data so large that these are either restored from backup or assumed to
be safe.

The SANS Institute (http://www.sans.org) method of incident response is simple:
1) Prepare (too late)
2) Identify (you just did)
3) Contain (the "unplug")
4) Eradicate (the "wipe and reinstall" plus eliminate the likely
causes of the intrusion)
5) Recover (hooking the network back up, copying in data files)
6) Lessons Learned

The most likely cause for the intrusion is an under-patched system. 
Retire those ancient Red Hat systems that aren't updated any more and
install something that is-- like CentOS or White Box Linux (both Red
Hat Enterprise clones.)

  -- Steve


From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Mon Jan 24 18:50:18 2005
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 18:50:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106438295.6338.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1106621418.3301.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 10:19 -0800, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Quoth Evan Heidtmann, on Sat, 22 Jan 2005 15:58:15 -0800:
> 
> > Maybe I'm missing something, but I think mod_alias should do it:
> 
> Yeah, mod_alias only works for exposing files directly, like symlinks. 
> But I have dynamic content being generated by different Java Web-app's
> in a servlet container, and it's those that I need to map to one
> another.

So you have some special directive making all request go straight to the
Java app, like this? (on a.org)

ScriptAlias / /path/to/cgi/script-a-org.cgi

Then put this on a.org:

ScriptAlias /a-org-mirror /path/to/cgi/script-a-org.cgi

Pick some pathname that you won't mind committing to this purpose. Users
won't see it (but could if they typed it in).

Then this rule would make /a-org-mirror/foo/bar appear at /fubar:

RewriteRule ^/fubar(.*) /a-org-mirror/foo/bar$1

You may need to adjust that to deal with trailing slashes or paths that
start with fubar.

I hope this helps,

Evan

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Jan 24 21:41:14 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 21:41:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How you know you've really been hacked
Message-ID: <20050125054114.GA5935@gate.kl-ic.com>


You know you've really been hacked when:

1)  You start getting phone calls from people ordering penis enlargers.

2)  Your online music collection is now Nigerian tribal music.

3)  You stop getting spam (it wastes bandwidth, you know).

4)  Kevin Mitnick sends you a birthday card.

5)  Your man pages are now in Russian and Korean.

6)  Inexplicable free hardware upgrades are delivered daily.

7)  You start getting 147 credit card bills.

8)  Which is all right, you now have the money from 147 mortgages to pay
    the bills with.

9)  Tripwire reports your system is clean - but you didn't RUN tripwire!

... and the main way you know you've really been hacked is:

10) You get supposedly humorous emails that end with long binary;pd$;3PHG\o"}#

From baumanpdx at comcast.net  Mon Jan 24 21:47:52 2005
From: baumanpdx at comcast.net (The Bauman Family)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 21:47:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Best motherboard with Linux
Message-ID: <41F5DD88.4090406@comcast.net>

Hello PLUG:

We're using Linux right now on a Dell machine, and it works fine, but we 
want to get a new AMD 64 computer. We visited Fry's and bought the combo 
Athlon 64 3000+ and Lanparty motherboard, among other things, and we 
asked the people at Fry's whether it would work. They said that they 
didn't know, but they knew Gigabyte motherboards worked and suggested we 
do some research and return it if it wouldn't work. We found no trace of 
a driver for the motherboard's onboard LAN (as the name suggests) and 
sound and also couldn't find anything for the video card we'd purchased.

We returned the motherboard, CPU, and video, (the CPU and motherboard 
had to be returned as a combo) and sought help for a motherboard that 
was known to work with Linux. The person we spoke to said it should work 
(it was based on the nVidia 3 chipset or something like that, and he 
used nVidia 2 and Linux worked fine for him). We were skeptical and 
decided to ask you what the best motherboard (and video card, although 
we could always use VESA) for Linux would be that works with AMD 64.

We look forward to your response.

Thanks,
Todd Bauman


From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 22:34:30 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 22:34:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>    In Slackware-10 I have nfsd and I think I read that it's run by the
> kernel. Could this still be an issue?

Rich, why are you using Slackware 10?  :)

I'm not one to get into distro wars, but I've heard you describe 
yourself in the past as kind of a reluctant sysadmin, someone who does 
it not because they want to but because it enables them to do their job. 
So if that is case (and I don't mean to put words in your mouth, if I'm 
wrong about that let me know), why would you pick the one distro that is 
probably the least user friendly of all of them?

I think you could get a list of all the other distros, close your eyes 
and point at one, and find something that way which is easier to use.

I started using RedHat when version 2.1 came out. I had been using 
Slackware before then, but I found that RPM is pretty cool and I have 
never looked back. Since then I've used many other distros, and there 
are some others I like a lot (Gentoo, Mandrake), but I can't imagine 
going back to Slackware. And I am someone who likes being a sysadmin, I 
chose it as a profession :)

In terms of your NFS question, someone here may know, but you might have 
better luck on the Slackware list. If there are big NFS problems with 
it, that will be a known issue.


Rich






From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 22:36:58 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 22:36:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been cracked
In-Reply-To: <200501242008.20000.baloo@ursine.dyndns.org>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net>	<1106606670.17225.150.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<200501242008.20000.baloo@ursine.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <41F5E90A.9010002@paranoid.org>

Paul Johnson wrote:

> 3) Learn that "hacked" is not synonymous with "compromised."
> 
> http://ursine.dyndns.org/hack
> http://ursine.dyndns.org/crack

I understand the distinction between hacker and cracker, but when 
someone says their box has been hacked they mean it's been compromised. 
There's really not another usage for the term in that context. They're 
not saying someone installed a Perl script for them that made their life 
a lot easier :)


Rich



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 24 22:47:26 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 22:47:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <1106635646.17224.214.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 22:34 -0800, Rich Burroughs wrote:
> why would you pick the one distro that is 
> probably the least user friendly of all of them?

I disagree with your assumption....

Slackware is *simple*.  There's nothing hiding you from the guts of the
thing.  It's just the admin and his box without any complicated tools
getting in the way.  It's about doing things the UNIX way - doing one
thing and doing it well.

For me, this makes it *very* user friendly.  It also makes me more Linux
friendly.  IMHO, there's nothing wrong with Slackware at all....

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From v_yau3 at hotmail.com  Mon Jan 24 22:32:30 2005
From: v_yau3 at hotmail.com (Vincent Yau)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 06:32:30 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
Message-ID: <BAY20-F32ED3E056EE014AF82275DB8860@phx.gbl>


Hi:

My Linux box crashed twice last week and I could not figure
out what had happened.  Any tips/pointers much aprpeciated.
Here is what happened:

The box is running kernel 2.6.6.  I got it through Fedora 2.
It has been running fine for at least a year and a half.  The box
is a P4 2.4 Ghz 800 Mhz FSB.  One GB of memory.  Recently,
we have setup and run Oracle 9i on it.   There are about 2 Oracle
users and they do run pretty heavy database reports out of the Oracle 
instance
installed on this box.  Last Thursday, it was business as usual and there
were some sort of Oracle work going on.  I had to burn a CD and
burning at a lower speed would take up less resources.  So I was burning
my CD at speed 8 using cdrecord.  All of a sudden, my screen turns blank, 
the
CD ejected itself but the CD burning job wasn't finish.  I cannot ssh or 
telnet into the
box and console screen is blank.  I had to press the reset button.  When it 
finished
booting, I looked into /var/log but could not find anything indicating 
problems in
any of the log file.  Then I looked at /etc/syslog.conf and found
that kernel.* wasn't being logged to anywhere.  So I added kernel.* into 
/var/log/messages.
Then I restarted Oracle and informed the 2 users to resume their work.     I 
then began
to burn the same CD that did not go through.  This time, I lowered the speed
to 4.  Again the same crash behavior appeared about 10 minutes later.  After
the box was rebooted, I once again look into /var/log for any clue.  And 
again,
nothing relevant was found.   There aren't anything major
running other than Oracle and my cdrecord process.  I have used cdrecord
on this system before and it worked fine.  Oracle has been running
for two months already and the box never crashed until last Thursday.


My questions:
Is there somewhere other than /var/log I should go and look for clues
as to what happened?  Is logging kernel.* inside /etc/syslog.conf enough
to debug this type of situation?

Luckily, the box is running just fine ever since.  I was able to burn the CD 
that I needed.
Nonetheless, I still want to know how I can debug so I know what to do
next time.

Thanks in advance for any tips...

--Vincent

_________________________________________________________________
Don?t just search. Find. Check out the new MSN Search! 
http://search.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200636ave/direct/01/



From rich at paranoid.org  Mon Jan 24 23:13:28 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Mon, 24 Jan 2005 23:13:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <1106635646.17224.214.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
	<1106635646.17224.214.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <41F5F198.4090403@paranoid.org>

AthlonRob wrote:

> I disagree with your assumption....
> 
> Slackware is *simple*.  There's nothing hiding you from the guts of the
> thing.  It's just the admin and his box without any complicated tools
> getting in the way.  It's about doing things the UNIX way - doing one
> thing and doing it well.
> 
> For me, this makes it *very* user friendly.  It also makes me more Linux
> friendly.  IMHO, there's nothing wrong with Slackware at all....

I'm not saying there's anything wrong with it. For me, I'm fairly 
atheistic when it comes to distros. I think they all have their 
strengths and weaknesses, and I like to choose the tool that's best for 
the job. For some jobs it's not even Linux - I like FreeBSD for web 
serving, and if I had to choose a *nix for an important firewall it 
would probably be OpenBSD.

I would rather use Slackware than Windoze any day, but I would not 
describe Slackware as "user friendly."

My point is that Rich is someone who has described himself as a 
reluctant syadmin (IIRC). For someone like that, I'm not sure a system 
with all the guts exposed is really the best fit. You mention 
complicated tools getting in the way - I think the majority of the tools 
than other distros add on make things easier, not harder. There is a 
reason people have added those tools. Things like package managemnt are 
good things, IMHO.

I am confortable editing text config files directly, and in many cases I 
prefer it. But again, I'm not a reluctant sysadmin, I'm anything but that.


Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 06:27:08 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 06:27:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250615480.6187@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Rich Burroughs wrote:

> Rich, why are you using Slackware 10?  :)

Rich,

   Because Patrick hasn't been well enough to get 10.1 out yet. The short
answer is stability and reliability.

> I'm not one to get into distro wars, but I've heard you describe yourself
> in the past as kind of a reluctant sysadmin, someone who does it not
> because they want to but because it enables them to do their job. So if
> that is case (and I don't mean to put words in your mouth, if I'm wrong
> about that let me know), why would you pick the one distro that is
> probably the least user friendly of all of them?

   I've had more grief with dependencies and bleeding-edge packages in Red
Hat (from 4.0-7.3) than I've had with Slackware (8.0-10.0, so far). Other
than security patches and the occasional productivity application (e.g.,
OO.o, R-statistical system, ncftp), I don't do any maintenance from one
release to the next. Like the energizer bunny it just keeps going ... and
going ... and going. No muss, no fuss, no bother.

> I think you could get a list of all the other distros, close your eyes and 
> point at one, and find something that way which is easier to use.

   All depends on one's point of view. I have found Slackware (once I got
used to the BSD-style init system) much easier than Red Hat. If you look at
the PLUG list archives from 1998 or 1999 you'll see a long thread initiated
by me about nfs and how a networked host would suddenly go AWOL from the
network. I don't recall if this was when RH went from 5.x to 6.0 or 6.x to
7.0; it was during the shift of nfsd to knfsd.

   The workstation that's giving me problems is quite new and while I've had
the two hosts networked without any problems, I've decided to move all
spatial and other data to the faster box with the speedier processor. That's
why I want to mount the three user filesystems via nfs.

   With regard to distributions, I see more gnashed teeth on the mail list
with fedora, debian, gentoo, and mandrake than I do with slackware. And, I'm
not the only one here running that distribution. Then again, my vehicles
have manual transmissions (and window winders), not automatic, and I prefer
to do things myself rather than having them delivered all prepared. So I
suppose that slackware fits this mindset better than do other distributions.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 06:34:16 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 06:34:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Best motherboard with Linux
In-Reply-To: <41F5DD88.4090406@comcast.net>
References: <41F5DD88.4090406@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250631310.6187@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, The Bauman Family wrote:

> We're using Linux right now on a Dell machine, and it works fine, but we want 
> to get a new AMD 64 computer. We visited Fry's and bought the combo Athlon 64 
> 3000+ and Lanparty motherboard, among other things, and we asked the people 
> at Fry's whether it would work. They said that they didn't know, but they 
> knew Gigabyte motherboards worked and suggested we do some research and 
> return it if it wouldn't work. We found no trace of a driver for the 
> motherboard's onboard LAN (as the name suggests) and sound and also couldn't 
> find anything for the video card we'd purchased.

   Fry's: feh!

> We look forward to your response.

   Three suggestions for you:

   1.) Either ENU, Inc or Pacific Solutions will give you local advice on
what runs well with linux.

   2.) Look at the ads in Linux Journal (and the articles, too) to learn what
combinations work. Also, check out the linux-oriented suppliers such as
Monarch Computers (http://www.monarchcomputers.com) to see what they package
together.

   3.) Rummage around the Linux Hardware Compatibility Web site.

HTH,

Rich

From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue Jan 25 08:49:34 2005

On Mon, Jan 24, 2005 at 09:47:52PM -0800, The Bauman Family wrote:
> Hello PLUG:
> 
> We're using Linux right now on a Dell machine, and it works fine, but we 
> want to get a new AMD 64 computer. We visited Fry's and bought the combo 
> Athlon 64 3000+ and Lanparty motherboard, among other things, and we 
> asked the people at Fry's whether it would work. They said that they 
> didn't know, but they knew Gigabyte motherboards worked and suggested we 
> do some research and return it if it wouldn't work. We found no trace of 
> a driver for the motherboard's onboard LAN (as the name suggests) and 
> sound and also couldn't find anything for the video card we'd purchased.

Huh.  I heard that nForce3 chipset's gigabit lan support was merged
into forcedeth a while ago.  But I know it can be a hassle to get
newer hardware working initially.

I haven't heard of a mobo that doesn't work with recent Linux x86 or
ath64 distros.  Yeah, the sound or LAN might not work 'til you run an
update and install a fresh kernel, but you can get by on a $5 PCI lan
card 'til then.

I just got some ath64 Ubuntu Linux CDs from shipit.ubuntu.org.  I'd
recommend trying it out.  Heck--I can hand one to you at a meeting.

> nothing relevant was found.   There aren't anything major

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 09:01:25 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 09:01:25 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: nfs
In-Reply-To: <20050125044439.BDBA68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20050125044439.BDBA68F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250847001.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Galen Seitz wrote:

> Did you try a local mount?  If that doesn't work, then fix that first
> before trying over the network.
>  mount -t nfs -r tux:/usr2 /mnt/somemountpoint
> The -r is just CYA safety.

   Interesting, Galen. Same error message. So, since I cannot mount tux:/usr2
on tux's /mnt, the permissions must be on /usr2, eh?

   Something is really screwy here. On tux:

   - /usr1 is on /dev/hda, /usr2-4 are all of /dev/hdb

   - I changed /etc/exports from 192.168.55/24(rw) to
salmo.appl-ecosys.com(rw), then ran /usr/sbin/exportfs -a. The results still
showed the numeric IP address.

   - Added /usr1 to /etc/exports (on a different hard drive), ran exportfs
with both the -a, then the -r (refresh) options. /usr1 did not show up in
the list.

   - Both before and after adding /usr1 /var/lib/nfs/xtab shows only /usr2-4
with the numeric IP address and not the domain_name address.

   - In /etc/fstab all hard drive partitions are mounted with default values
(rw, suid, dev, exec, auto, nouser, async).

   Sigh. Another new wedgie I've not before encountered. What might possibly
be going on here?

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From aaron at bavariati.org  Tue Jan 25 09:29:43 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 09:29:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <BAY20-F32ED3E056EE014AF82275DB8860@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY20-F32ED3E056EE014AF82275DB8860@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <20050125172943.GC30960@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Jan 25, 2005 at 06:32:30AM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> My Linux box crashed twice last week and I could not figure
> out what had happened.  Any tips/pointers much aprpeciated.

Well, it sounds like you're getting hard-freezes, which are hard to
diagnose since the system doesn't get a chance to log anything.  No
way to get around that.

Really, it should be safe to burn at any speed (yeah, 48x might impact
your users some) but if there's something hinky about the CD drive or
the controller, you'll get hard-freezes.

You might want to move the CD drive to another box to protect your
users from more crashes, then test at your leisure.  You might also
try a newer (2.6.9 or .10) kernel.

Also, CD burners are really cheap these days.  Weigh the value of your
time vs. the cost of a new burner.  Heck, might be time to upgrade to
DVD.

Good luck,
  Aaron


From rich at paranoid.org  Tue Jan 25 09:47:48 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 09:47:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250615480.6187@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <41F68644.4060100@paranoid.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Mon, 24 Jan 2005, Rich Burroughs wrote:

> Like the energizer bunny it just keeps going ... and
> going ... and going. No muss, no fuss, no bother.

Besides the fact you can't get NFS working? :)

>    With regard to distributions, I see more gnashed teeth on the mail list
> with fedora, debian, gentoo, and mandrake than I do with slackware.

That can be explained by statistics alone. Those other distros must have 
many times the installed base that Slackware has.

And I'm guessing the average user of Slackware at this point is going to 
be a more experienced Linux person, and less in need of asking lots of 
questions and gnashing teeth. Most newer users are going to start up 
with Fedora or Mandrake, or maybe even Gentoo or one of the Debian-based 
distros.

> And, I'm
> not the only one here running that distribution. Then again, my vehicles
> have manual transmissions (and window winders), not automatic, and I prefer
> to do things myself rather than having them delivered all prepared. So I
> suppose that slackware fits this mindset better than do other distributions.

Well, again, I was going off of previous comments you had made here. If 
I remember correctly you had characterized yourself as a reluctant 
admin, someone who was learning to use Linux because it helped them to 
do their other work. But it sounded like your preference would be to 
spend the time on the other work, not futzing around with Linux.

That doesn't sound like the description above, so perhaps I am 
misremembering it, or perhaps your mindset has changed.

In any case, it seems that you have been running into a lot of problems 
lately, so I'm not sure that the description of everything being smooth 
sailing with Slackware is accurate. This NFS problem, for example - I'm 
not sure if it's something with the distro, or something else (like a 
configuration issue). If it is shipping with a non-working NFS that 
would be bad, but it's hard to believe that.

Anyway, it's certainly up to you what distro you use. Just trying to add 
a helpful $0.02, but I'll zip it now :)


Rich

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Jan 25 10:19:58 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 10:19:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <41F68644.4060100@paranoid.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250615480.6187@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F68644.4060100@paranoid.org>
Message-ID: <1106677198.15290.5.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Tue, 2005-01-25 at 09:47 -0800, Rich Burroughs wrote:

> That can be explained by statistics alone. Those other distros must have 
> many times the installed base that Slackware has.

You might be surprised.  Your comment brings up an interesting issue...
figuring out how popular Linux, or a particular linux distribution, is.
It's not easy, and really not even possible, IMHO.  Due to the free
availability of most distributions, the complex mirroring systems, cheap
CDs available, you can't count downloads or sales.

Slackware is, I think, far more popular than most people give it credit
for.  It may not be up there with Mandrake or Debian, but on a ranking
scale, I think it isn't very far behind.

> And I'm guessing the average user of Slackware at this point is going to 
> be a more experienced Linux person, and less in need of asking lots of 
> questions and gnashing teeth. Most newer users are going to start up 
> with Fedora or Mandrake, or maybe even Gentoo or one of the Debian-based 
> distros.

You would be surprised at the number of folks who start off with
Slackware.  I, personally, used RedHat and Mandrake before finding
Slackware... but I didn't really *use* Linux until Slackware.

If you want to learn Linux, Slackware is the best beginner distribution
except perhaps LFS, if you count that as a distribution at all.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From jason at vancleve.com  Tue Jan 25 10:20:46 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 10:20:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Mod Q'
In-Reply-To: <1106621418.3301.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20050121125951.18c5fd3d.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106438295.6338.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<20050124101931.526c71bc.jason@vancleve.com>
	<1106621418.3301.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20050125102046.4066eb98.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Evan Heidtmann, on Mon, 24 Jan 2005 18:50:18 -0800:

> > > Maybe I'm missing something, but I think mod_alias should do it:
> > 
> > Yeah, mod_alias only works for exposing files directly, like
> > symlinks. But I have dynamic content being generated by different
> > Java Web-app's in a servlet container, and it's those that I need to
> > map to one another.
> 
> So you have some special directive making all request go straight to
> the Java app, like this? (on a.org)
> 
> ScriptAlias / /path/to/cgi/script-a-org.cgi

Thanks, but note that, as with Alias, the second argument for
ScriptAlias is a directory path, according to the doc's.  Java servlets
are not files that apache finds and hands off to a module:  apache just
hands over the URI to the servlet container plugin, so if I understand
it, mod_alias won't help me here.

--Jason

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 10:28:53 2005

Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 10:28:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question -- SOLVED
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251021090.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   Problem solved. In part I know why, in part I don't know why.

   On tux I changed /etc/exports to the host.domainname.tld(rw) rather than
Class C IP address(rw). Stopped and restarted nfsd. Checked
/var/lib/nfs/etab and that matched what showmount -e had to offer. Re-ran
exportfs -r and that sync'd /var/lib/nfs/xtab. Of course, rmtab was still
empty because no remote host had mounted any exported filesystem.

   On salmo (as root) I ran 'mount /mnt/usr2' and the same for usr3 and usr4.
No error messages about permissions. Only /mnt/usr2 was actually mounted.
Checked ownership of /mnt and discovered that /usr2 was owned by
rshepard.users and /usr3-4 was owned by root.root. Chown on 3 and 4 and they
are now all mounted.

   SUMMARY: For whatever reason, /etc/exports wants host.domain rather than
IP address. The mounting host wants the mount point to be owned by a user
(or, by root.users, but I didn't check that option as I'm the only one
working on this box).

Thanks -- particulary to Galen -- who taught me a couple of new options and
pointed me to the nfs.sourceforge.net page where the question about
permissions had no apparent relevance but made me experiment until I rolled
7 on the first try.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 10:37:56 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 10:37:56 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] An nfs question
In-Reply-To: <1106677198.15290.5.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501242024030.22544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F5E876.3040005@paranoid.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501250615480.6187@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41F68644.4060100@paranoid.org>
	<1106677198.15290.5.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251029200.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

>> That can be explained by statistics alone. Those other distros must have
>> many times the installed base that Slackware has.

   As Rob and others have seen, I refer to Slackware as The Quiet
Distribution.

> Slackware is, I think, far more popular than most people give it credit
> for.  It may not be up there with Mandrake or Debian, but on a ranking
> scale, I think it isn't very far behind.

> If you want to learn Linux, Slackware is the best beginner distribution
> except perhaps LFS, if you count that as a distribution at all.

   FWIW, as a part-time/strictly amateur SysAdmin, I've had absolutely no
problems installing Slackware or upgrading 8.0->8.1->9.0->9.1->10.0 on two
desktop and three portable machines (two of which are vintage 1999). I had
fits upgrading major Red Hat releases. Just my experience.

   I think that the most distinguishing characteristic of linux versus any
other OS on any platform past or present is the plethora of choices. There
must be a gazillion distributions, some forked from major brands such as Red
Hat and Debian, some based on the Leggo(R) principle. I don't know that one
could count the number of distributions and variants around.

   Then there are applications that run on top of all the various GNU tools.
Probably enough editors and scritping languages to stock the old dirigible
hanger in Tillamook from floor to ceiling. And, best of all, it doesn't
matter who likes what: it's mix-and-match and they all work. Even better,
they can be customized to express one's inner geek (or nerd as we used to be
called back in the early Pleistecene).

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

From wamorita at hevanet.com  Tue Jan 25 11:50:43 2005
From: wamorita at hevanet.com (William A Morita)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 11:50:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Networking Question
Message-ID: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>

I do not have a domain setup in my LAN.
The problem is that when I boot Linux, sendmail and sm-client each hang for
a considerable time.
The best I can deduce from the logs is that the system is spinning its
wheels looking for the domain server.
My /etc/hosts starts out:
127.0.0.1		Goku localhost.localdomain localhost

Is it looking for "localdomain"?
 
How to stop the big delays? 

- Bill Morita

wamorita at hevanet.com
Home: (503) 697-6994
Cell: (503) 260-3876 




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan 25 12:10:01 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 12:10:01 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Networking Question
In-Reply-To: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251159440.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, William A Morita wrote:

> My /etc/hosts starts out:
> 127.0.0.1		Goku localhost.localdomain localhost

> How to stop the big delays?

Bill,

   You're not running a local dns server so you need to point your system(s)
at an IP address where names can be resolved into numeric dot-quad (IP
address) format. Your ISP almost certainly has dns servers running and you
can put those names into /etc/resolv.conf.

   On my system I have:

nameserver 192.168.55.1		# I run DJB's dnscache here
nameserver 208.187.192.2
nameserver 208.187.226.2

   The first one won't do you any good, but you can use the others and those
of your ISP. Well, Hevanet hides it deeply (Tech
Support->Miscellaneous->Settings, but here're their DNS servers:

198.5.254.1  #Primary
198.5.254.5  #Secondary

You might want to use those in /etc/resolv.conf.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

(the comments in this file talk more about it)

That's what the hosts file is for.
Make sure it checks /etc/hosts first, though. This is normally defined in 
nsswitch.conf.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jan 25 13:56:49 2005
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 13:56:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Networking Question
In-Reply-To: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>
References: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <41F6C0A1.1070103@dimstar.net>

William A Morita wrote:

>I do not have a domain setup in my LAN.
>The problem is that when I boot Linux, sendmail and sm-client each hang for
>a considerable time.
>  
>
First question...

If you don't have a domain setup on your lan, why are you running 
sendmail and sm-client?

If you don't need them, then you should shut them off.

>The best I can deduce from the logs is that the system is spinning its
>wheels looking for the domain server.
>  
>
Yes, spinning wheels..

Trying to determine it's fully qualified domain name (fqdn).

Since you don't have one, it won't be able to find one. Either tell it 
to use something you specify in it's config file or turn it off.

>My /etc/hosts starts out:
>127.0.0.1		Goku localhost.localdomain localhost
>
>Is it looking for "localdomain"?
>  
>
No, the hosts file is one of the places that are used for lookup. 
Unfortunately, I believe sendmail doesn't use the /etc/hosts file, so it 
won't fine anything there.

Russ


From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jan 25 15:01:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 23:01:02 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Networking Question
References: <200501251950.j0PJojM14931@pop.hevanet.com>
	<41F6C0A1.1070103@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <slrncvdjr3.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-25, Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> wrote:
> William A Morita wrote:
>
>>I do not have a domain setup in my LAN.
>>The problem is that when I boot Linux, sendmail and sm-client each hang for
>>a considerable time.
>>  
>>
> First question...
>
> If you don't have a domain setup on your lan, why are you running 
> sendmail and sm-client?
>
> If you don't need them, then you should shut them off.

For sending local messages, like those from cron.  It looks like he's using
a Fedora or Red hat setup, which initially configures them to listen only
on localhost, so it's not really a security problem.  (Although he should
make sure to alias mail for root to his account.)

Wil
--

Message-ID: <41F6EFD1.9000106@paranoid.org>

Russ Johnson wrote:

> I was under the impression that cron, et al would send them through 
> /sbin/sendmail.

And what about mail that ended up in the queue? You could set up a cron 
job to flush the queue periodically, but I don't think it's set up that 
way by default. Granted, that shouldn't happen with local mail, but I 
agree with Wil. It should be restricted to local connections if he's 
using Fedora, so I don't see it as a problem to have it running.


Rich

force you to baby them nearly as often with security fixes.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Jan 25 19:54:42 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 19:54:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Governor backs plan to aid open source movment
In-Reply-To: <1106708195.29253.18.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <20050126011648.36308.qmail@web53603.mail.yahoo.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251733200.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200501251744.54113.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251804270.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106708195.29253.18.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0501251939270.6107@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:

> Getting them to migrate off Exchange would be like trying to get a 
> cat to migrate off catching birds.

I can't speak for the state of Oregon, and I'd never wish on anyone
the job of Exchange Administrator, but I know the frustration of 
looking for a bona fide calendaring solution that can stack up with 
Exchange.

Oracle makes one (well, Mr. Ellison opened his pocket book and bought 
Steltor's product) that's quite good, but it's not terribly well 
integrated with any clients save its own. MeetingMaker has one that's 
used at Synopsis (among other places), but I haven't installed the 
demo yet. Of course, these are both proprietary products.

We in the Free Software community haven't written a good replacement 
yet. UW is working on a Java-based product, but it's too fragile at 
this stage, and I don't know if its feature set really matches the 
needs of corporate scheduling.

IOW, Exchange offers more than e-mail transport and delivery: its 
users have a best-of-breed calendaring server. There just isn't a 
suite of Free software products that can replace it. For now, anyway.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>


From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Jan 25 19:56:48 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 19:56:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Full-time DB2 UDB DBA position in downtown Portland, OR
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0501251955510.6107@pecos.madboa.com>

Seen on another list earlier today...

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Full-time DB2 UDB DBA position in downtown Portland, OR

DB2 Guru

CollegeNET, Inc now provides software and web transaction services to
over 1100 higher education institutions and 400 non-profits worldwide.
We operate a modern, Linux environment: no Cobol, no mainframe, no
offshoring, no AS400, no Oracle, no SAP, no Peoplesoft, no JD Edwards,
no travel. We are seeking a seasoned DB2 UDB DBA to assist with
managing and tuning our DB2 LUW databases for 24x7 e-commerce web
services. Document existing and new database assets and policies,
assist with data modeling, and query optimization. Write shell scripts
and batch jobs for system maintenance. Coordinate disaster recovery
scenarios with sysadmins. Test new releases of DB2 and evaluate
third-party products. Work with a team to design and implement
operational data stores and ETL for reporting applications. Seeking at
least four years experience running DB2 UDB LUW in a production
environment, preferably 24x7.   We provide a beautiful office
environment, full benefits, and wages commensurate with ability and
performance. Please email your resume to resumes at collegenet.com.

On Tue, 2005-01-25 at 18:56 -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Tue, 2005-01-25 at 18:06 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >    I know that OSU's mail server runs linux/postfix; I see that in the
> > headers of messages I receive. ODOT also runs linux on IBM mainframes
> > (zSeries a.k.a. S/390). But, there's a lot more that can be done with
> > minimal disruption.
> 
> AFAIK, most government entities (Federal, State, and Local) in Oregon
> run Exchange for their mail servers.  It costs so much more than Postfix
> it must be better.

Ditto Paul's comments on the dearth of decent Free calendaring.
Comparing Postfix to Exchange is like comparing an F1 engine to a
Trabant. No one here doubts the greatness of the F1 engine or the
badness of the Trabant, but let's be frank, the Trabant will take you
places that sitting on an engine block just can't. [1]

Exchange, so much more than a bad MTA!

We desperately need something that offers delegation, meaning the access
model of WebDAV and Mozilla Calendar doesn't cut it.

On the bright side, there are always projects getting our hopes up.
Here's something interesting from Shuttleworth and friends:

http://www.schooltool.org/schoolbell/

     1. I use postfix and have never touched Exchange, thank the maker.

On Tuesday 25 January 2005 7:46 pm, Jack Morgan wrote:
> On Tuesday 25 January 2005 18:42, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > On Tuesday 25 January 2005 6:36 pm, Jack Morgan wrote:
> > > On Tuesday 25 January 2005 18:06, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > > > ? ?Like e-mail? Wonder if Thunderchicken has been ported to Microsoft.
> > >
> > > Yup, we use it at work as it includes a spell checker. A default install
> > > of win2k doesnt include one which makes Outlook Express unusable.
> >
> > The lack of a spell-checker makes OE unusable??
> 
> Lacking the ability to correct your spelling in a business setting is a 
> serious problem, IMHO. The bigger issue I was trying to point out was that 
MS 
> requires you to purchase MS-Office or similar to have that ability. It's not 
> included by default.

How about having decent language skills? Spell checkers are very fallible. 
That's why you see weirdo punctuation, bad grammar, lose/loose, 
you/your/you're, it's/its and similar confusions. Most spelling and 
grammatical errors are at a middle-school level, not rare and exotic things 
that only grammar geeks grok.

Not that I want to encourage anyone to use OE- it is malware-friendly and uses 
a closed, non-compatible mailbox format. 

> 
> > Funny, all of a sudden I'm remembering Cyril Kornbluth's "The Marching
> > Morons."
> 
> Sorry, I don't understand your point here?
> 

The story is available in lots of anthologies, it's not hard to find. It's a 
satirical look at a society that has become populated by a large majority of 
stupid people, and the few remaining intelligent people are forced by 
compassion to act as their babysitters and protectors, mostly protecting them 
from themselves. Sure, it's a long leap from ranting against spell-checkers 
to such a scenario. Or maybe not such a long leap....

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Tue Jan 25 20:48:23 2005
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 20:48:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <1106708281.29252.20.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <200501251842.44676.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1106708281.29252.20.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <200501252048.24891.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Tuesday 25 January 2005 6:58 pm, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Tue, 2005-01-25 at 18:42 -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > If you were tasked with selecting a cross-platform Web browser to 
standardize 
> > on for developing Web apps, would you choose Mozilla or Firefox? Or 
something 
> > else entirely?  Firefox is all fashionable now, but how do they compare 
for 
> > developers?
> 
> What kind of web apps?  Why would they require a specific browser,
> period, or be coded such that two cousin browsers like Moz/FF couldn't
> both work?
> 

In my experience, and I've probably been hanging out with the wrong crowd, web 
app developers target a single browser. (Usually IE. :P) 

Every Web browser has its own idiosyncracies, extensions, and quirks, which is 
another reason developers like to choose one as their main target, instead of 
going insane trying make everything work perfectly in all of them. For 
example javascript handling is notoriously non-uniform. Mozilla and Firefox 
each support extensions, pretty much the same set, but these don't work in 
other browsers.

So another way of asking the question is how do you avoid getting locked-in to 
a particular platform? Obviously Aieee is the king of lockin, and migrating 
away from it is going to cause pain and expense. Suppose you wake up one fine 
day, decide Firefox sucks, and want to move your Web apps to something else- 
how painful would it be? Can you really design complex Web applications to be 
browser-agnostic?

--

Carla Schroder

and sysadmin's guide! http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxckbk/

standalone mail clients, including outlook. IMO it is superior to MS 
Exchange.

On Tuesday 25 January 2005 9:00 pm, Wil Cooley wrote:
> In gmane.org.user-groups.linux.portland, you wrote:
> >
> > How about having decent language skills?
> >
> 
> You mean such as not mis-using the word "decent" to mean "adequate;
> sufficient; acceptable" instead of "morally upright" &c?

May I draw your attention to #4.
And if it were the wrong word, a spellchecker would not have caught it.

Main Entry: de?cent 
 Pronunciation: 'dE-s&nt
 Function: adjective
 Etymology: Middle French or Latin; Middle French, from Latin decent-, decens, 
present participle of decEre to be fitting; akin to Latin decus honor, dignus 
worthy, Greek dokein to seem, seem good
 1 archaic a : APPROPRIATE b : well-formed : HANDSOME
2 a : conforming to standards of propriety, good taste, or morality b : 
modestly clothed
3 : free from immodesty or obscenity
4 : fairly good but not excellent : ADEQUATE, SATISFACTORY <decent wages>
5 : marked by moral integrity, kindness, and goodwill <hard-working and decent 
folks>
synonym see CHASTE
- de?cent?ly adverb

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Jan 25 21:46:50 2005
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue, 25 Jan 2005 21:46:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <BAY20-F32ED3E056EE014AF82275DB8860@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY20-F32ED3E056EE014AF82275DB8860@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <1106718410.14042.8.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2005-01-25 at 06:32 +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> Hi:
> 
> My Linux box crashed twice last week and I could not figure
> out what had happened.  Any tips/pointers much aprpeciated.
> Here is what happened:

[snip]
>   All of a sudden, my screen turns blank, 
> the
> CD ejected itself but the CD burning job wasn't finish.  I cannot ssh or 
> telnet into the
> box and console screen is blank.  I had to press the reset button.  

This is most likely a hardware problem, probably an overheating issue.
Pull the case cover off and check your fans, excessive dirt, etc.  Then
give your users a break and pull the burner.  Setup an old pentium box
to do the burning for you, you can even run it headless with VNC or an
exported X-session.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260633270.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, Dan Young wrote:

> We desperately need something that offers delegation, meaning the access
> model of WebDAV and Mozilla Calendar doesn't cut it.

Dan,

   You folks in the professional linux community know much better than do I
how to get this need in front of the right people. Now is the time to do so
for three major reasons:

   1.) There is a demonstrable need and the lack of such an application to
run on linux and the *BSDs is a serious hinderance to greater F/OSS adoption
in the private and public sectors.

   2.) OSDL has the official backing of Beaverton and the state to promote
and facilitate such projects in the new, Round incubator.

   3.) Large computer companies, IBM in particular and probably H-P, too,
sell a package of services and this is one that they need in their sales
kit. They may well be willing to fund the development because it removes one
sales objection (a legitimate one, you all tell us).

   There are also a number of under- and un-employed SysAdmin and application
programmers (I count two among my friends; one local one in the mid-west)
who can help make this happen. Rather than wringing hands about the
deficiency in the toolbox, look at this as an opportunity for fun and
profit.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>   Voice: 503-667-4517   Fax: 503-667-8863

On Tue, Jan 25, 2005 at 06:42:43PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> If you were tasked with selecting a cross-platform Web browser to standardize 
> on for developing Web apps, would you choose Mozilla or Firefox? Or something 
> else entirely?  Firefox is all fashionable now, but how do they compare for 
> developers?
> 
> -- 

For developing web apps, I'd go with Mozilla.  It has a much richer set of
tools to aid in development, whereas Firefox, as it's simply a browser, can 
only be used to test the app.

(Now, with that said, I have to admit that that whenever I write web pages
or apps, I do it with Emacs.)

Ali


From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 26 09:36:02 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 09:36:02 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <200501251842.44676.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501260921590.2415-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, Carla Schroder wrote:

> If you were tasked with selecting a cross-platform Web browser to
> standardize on for developing Web apps, would you choose Mozilla or
> Firefox? Or something else entirely?  Firefox is all fashionable now,
> but how do they compare for developers?

Carla,

I've read the other replies and will offer this.  I see on the css-d list 
that web apps should be developed using a standards compliant browser (ie. 
Mozilla and I believe Firefox ) and once it displays and performs 
correctly there fix the bug-a-boos that show up in IE and other 
non-compliant browsers.  By compliant I mean XHTML 1.0 ( or at the least 
HTML 4.01 ).

As side note I just fiddled some Javascript to automatically generate 
class dates and when it is displayed in Moz and friends it gets the year 
correct ( var theYear = StartDate.getYear() + 1900 ) in IE it comes out as 
3905.  I just discovered this when the non-HTML class used IE to look at 
it.  The HTML class all used Firefox and Mozilla.

So now I get to do cross browser hacks.


Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

From publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 26 09:45:15 2005
From: publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com (Ovid)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 09:45:15 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501260921590.2415-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

--- "Roderick A. Anderson" <raanders at acm.org> wrote:
> On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > Firefox is all fashionable
> > now, but how do they compare for developers?

> Mozilla and I believe Firefox ) and once it displays and performs 
> correctly there fix the bug-a-boos that show up in IE and other 
> non-compliant browsers.

Er, having cleaned out my mailbox prior to seeing the other responses,
I apologize if this has already been covered.

Whether or not I want to port an application to IE depends upon whether
or not I want to give up the benefits of Mozilla and Firefox. 
Specifically, if I am trying to develop a serious application and not
just "another Web app", XUL is a very powerful tool.  I've only had the
opportunity to work with it on one project, but when I did, it made my
life much easier.  When the company saw what I could do with XUL, they
simply said "no IE."

Of course, the company is now bankrupt, but that's another story :)

Cheers,
Ovid

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 26 10:52:50 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 10:52:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <20050126162922.GA10816@zaphod.axian.com>
References: <200501251842.44676.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<20050126162922.GA10816@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <20050126185250.1B2CD18F7@haus.nakedape.cc>

In gmane.org.user-groups.linux.portland, you wrote:
>
> For developing web apps, I'd go with Mozilla.  It has a much richer set of
> tools to aid in development, whereas Firefox, as it's simply a browser, can 
> only be used to test the app.
>
> (Now, with that said, I have to admit that that whenever I write web pages
> or apps, I do it with Emacs.)

There are Firefox extensions to support web development.  Since there
have been questions about what the original question meant, here are a
few things you can use these extensions for, regardless of which editor
you use to actually create the content:

    o Document tree modeling; you can select parts of your page or code
    and it will highlight the part of the page or code containing that
    part of the sub-structure.

    o CSS examination; since styles can be inherited, it can be
    confusing to find which attributes are inherited or not.

    o JavaScript console; will show you errors and exceptions from
    JavaScript

    o JavaScript debugger (at least, I think there's one); most of the
    things you'd expect from a regular debugger.

    o Automated submission to various validators

Here's one Moz/Firefox extension:

http://www.chrispederick.com/work/firefox/webdeveloper/

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 10:52:50 -0800, Wil Cooley wrote:

> There are Firefox extensions to support web development.  Since there
> have been questions about what the original question meant, here are a
> few things you can use these extensions for, regardless of which editor

The HTML Validator plugin for Firefox is one of my favorites:

http://users.skynet.be/mgueury/mozilla/

If HTML Tidy likes the content, odds are it will render fine on MSIE,
Mozilla, Firefox, Netscape, Opera, Safari, Konqueror, Lynx, IBM
WebExplorer, Bob's Big Browser, etc.

From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Wed Jan 26 11:18:01 2005
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:18:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
Message-ID: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>

> 
> Quoth William A Morita, on Sat, 22 Jan 2005 12:01:11 -0800:
> 
> > When I do that and try CVS login I get:
> > 
> > cvs login: can only use `login' command with the 'pserver' method
> > cvs [login aborted]: CVSROOT:
> > :ext:wamorita at frodo:/shares/cvs-repository
> 
> Right, with :ext:, you log in once for every command, instead of using
> "login".  Your local username is passed to the server by default, so
> you'll just get a password prompt.  More tedious, but more secure.
> 
> --Jason
> 

If you use ssh keys to authenticate, you will never need to enter a password when running cvs commands.

-Rob Anderson



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Jan 26 11:56:05 2005
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:56:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>
References: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>
Message-ID: <3681-61046@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:18:01 -0800, Anderson, Rob wrote:

> If you use ssh keys to authenticate, you will never need to enter a password when running cvs commands.

Rob is correct, this is by far the easiest way to use CVS.

1) Set up ssh authorized_keys so you don't need a password to log in
2) Set CVSROOT=user at host:/path/to/cvsroot
3) Set CVS_RSH=ssh
4) Use CVS, no "cvs login" needed

Here is a quick guide to setting up an SSH "no password" login:

http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~mbonati/WIRC/manual/DATARED/setting_up_no-password_ssh.html

For improved security use ssh-agent to only enter the pass phrase once
while maintaining pass phrases on your keys.  See:

http://www.phy.bnl.gov/computing/gateway/ssh-agent.html

This is WAY easier to maintain than CVS pserver.

  -- Steve


From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 26 12:04:19 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 12:04:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Expert System
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501261148460.3676-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Or more probably a simple decision support system.

We have a few common problems that crop up just infrequently enough that
we ('I') can't keep all the answers in the head.  So I was hoping to come
up with a simple expert(ity) system to take us through the hoops.  Some of
the branches would require access to servers that only a few of us have
access to ( but could be accessed via (CGI) scripts ) so a web based
system would be great.

My Google search turned up mostly commercial stuff ; freshmeat only had
three entries , none suitable , and on CPAN I didn't find any example
applications ( since they were AI modules -- and assume you knew what you
were doing ;-).

Anyone know of web based , (preferrably perl coded ) , expert or decision 
support system software?


Once again thanks for all the help,
Rod

From publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com  Wed Jan 26 12:25:16 2005
From: publiustemp-plug at yahoo.com (Ovid)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 12:25:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Expert System
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501261148460.3676-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <20050126202516.40573.qmail@web60802.mail.yahoo.com>

--- "Roderick A. Anderson" <raanders at acm.org> wrote:
> Anyone know of web based , (preferrably perl coded ) , expert or
> decision support system software?

Ah, crud.  If you ask again in a few months, I'll have AI::Prolog
(http://search.cpan.org/~ovid/AI-Prolog-0.03/) stable and you'd be able
to whip it out with that.  Unfortunately, I have a job and only work on
it in my spare time, so it's only alpha and still requires that you
know Prolog :/

However, depending upon your needs, you could quite possibly use
FSA::Rules (http://search.cpan.org/~dwheeler/FSA-Rules-0.21/) for
something like this.  Plus, if you have a GraphViz installed, it can
print a graph of the underlying state machine so you can see if you've
modeled it correctly.  An example is at
http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/images/pg_rules.png.  Those are the
rules we are using at work to control how PostgreSQL gets installed.  I
wrote a lot of that module, so you have questions, you could shoot them
to me.

Yet another option, though it takes some work since the docs are awful:

Language::Prolog::Yaswi
(http://cpan.uwinnipeg.ca/htdocs/Language-Prolog-Yaswi/Language/Prolog/Yaswi.html).
 It's an interface to SWI-Prolog.  There are some caveats to using it
and I've written a bit about it at
http://use.perl.org/~Ovid/journal/22708.    It's the fastest of the
bunch, but it's unmaintained and requires an older version of
SWI-Prolog.

Cheers,
Ovid

=====
If this message is a response to a question on a mailing list, please send
follow up questions to the list.

Web Programming with Perl -- http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/cgi_course/

Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <200501252048.24891.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200501251842.44676.carla@bratgrrl.com>	<1106708281.29252.20.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<200501252048.24891.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <41F80B92.8080006@easystreet.com>

Carla Schroder wrote:

>Every Web browser has its own idiosyncracies, extensions, and quirks, which is 
>another reason developers like to choose one as their main target, instead of 
>going insane trying make everything work perfectly in all of them. For 
>example javascript handling is notoriously non-uniform. Mozilla and Firefox 
>each support extensions, pretty much the same set, but these don't work in 
>other browsers.
>
>So another way of asking the question is how do you avoid getting locked-in to 
>a particular platform?  <snip> 
>
Well, for simple HTML and CSS, I like to use these validation tools:

   http://validator.w3.org/     and    http://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/

Granted these two won't even begin to deal with all the complexities of 
dynamic web
pages.  I'm somewhat surprised there aren't more complex (and probably 
costly) page
validators available that will do more comprehensive checks.

From chaz at bctonline.com  Wed Jan 26 14:06:23 2005
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 14:06:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <BAY20-F25245CCAAC566731DC4C11B8870@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <B0004771286@bct-mail.bctonline.com>

Vincent,
I would tend to suspect a power or RAM limitation more than overheating.
You should throw a power meter on the box (I use Watts-Up) and see how
close to the edge it's running.
Be aware that Oracle tends to lock up RAM for it's own use.  I'd look at
the Oracle config to see how much RAM it's grabbing for the SGA, etc.
-chaz
Charles L. Sliger,    Information Systems Engineer,    chaz at bctonline.com
"no matter where you go, there you are..."

From nix at petelancashire.com  Wed Jan 26 14:50:01 2005
From: nix at petelancashire.com (Pete Lancashire)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 14:50:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <B0004771286@bct-mail.bctonline.com>
References: <B0004771286@bct-mail.bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <1106779800.7129.213.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

How about a another set of eyes ?

Software

  Has the system been stable with Oracle before ?

  What kernel settings do you have ? Ah .. may sound dumb, but
  how much RAM did the BIOS find vs what you have ? Loose a
  stick and of the SGA is too big, but that should give some
  sort of message.

  Oh .. what about the oracle logs ?

  BTW What version of Oracle ?

  I'm running 10g on three boxes at home, soon to be redone
  useing CRS. So far been stable, but then I'm not stressing anything.

Hardware

  Do a full inspection, fans, re-seat all connectors, chips etc.

  What size power supply ? What quality PS ? I had a cheap case
  drive me nuts till I replaced the PS.

  What type RAM ? Speed etc. Does the BIOS detect the RAM
  correctly ?

  Are you 'stressing' anything with BIOS settings. Safe vs Fastest.

  Back to heat, make sure the CPU heat sink is attached well, dosn't
  take much to shake one loose. your MB tell what the CPU temp is ?

  Loose or over sized MB mounting screw heads. I fixed a friends
  box that went crazy after a couple years, ended up one MB screw
  head was touching a trace, took 2 years to finally make contact.

  Force overtemp condition but be careful, this should be a last
  resort if not done before. I use to do it as a job :).


Thats all can rattle off for now

-pete

From jason at vancleve.com  Wed Jan 26 14:56:17 2005

Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question

Quoth Steve Bonds, on Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:56:05 -0800:

> > If you use ssh keys to authenticate, you will never need to enter a
> > password when running cvs commands.

Interesting.  Two things wonder me:

> 1) Set up ssh authorized_keys so you don't need a password to log in

According to the (very poorly edited) instructions at caltech.edu, I
must "generate a public/private key pair, and copy the public part into
the appropiate place on the server side".  So the no-password trick will
require some server changes, correct, even if I'm already using :ext:?

> 2) Set CVSROOT=user at host:/path/to/cvsroot

I use several different CVS servers on a regular basis, so I would not
want to set this to any default.  Maybe that step is unnecessary?

--Jason

From rich at paranoid.org  Wed Jan 26 15:09:14 2005
From: rich at paranoid.org (Rich Burroughs)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 15:09:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <BAY20-F25245CCAAC566731DC4C11B8870@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY20-F25245CCAAC566731DC4C11B8870@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <41F8231A.8070109@paranoid.org>

Vincent Yau wrote:
> 
> Thanks for all the overheat suggestion.  I will take a look at that 
> possibility.
> I would have thought that if the CPU overheated, the box will shutdown.
> In my case, the box is still running, I just could not access it in any 
> way.
> 
> I was not aware that burner can overheat too.  Will look into that.

Hi Vincent,

When I was referring to drives overheating, I was thinking more of hard 
drives. But, if the burner was getting hot it's possible it could effect 
the other hardware.

It's also possible the problem is not thermal at all, as others have 
mentioned. I've seen various results from CPUs and drives overheating, 
including crashes and spontaneous reboots.

Certainly any kind of hardware diagnostics you can run will be good, and 
the other suggestions in the thread are very good as well. 
Unfortunately, a lot of times with this sort of problem you won't get a 
log message that will point a clear finger at what is causing the crash. 
Many times it's an issue of checking out a lot of potential problems and 
ruling them out one by one.

I would look at moving the burner to another box, though, that was a 
very good suggestion of Derek's.


Rich





From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 26 15:16:04 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 23:16:04 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CVS Server Question
References: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>
	<3681-61046@sneakemail.com>
	<20050126145617.6cc58038.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <slrncvg927.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-26, Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> wrote:
> Quoth Steve Bonds, on Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:56:05 -0800:
>
>> > If you use ssh keys to authenticate, you will never need to enter a
>> > password when running cvs commands.
>
> Interesting.  Two things wonder me:
>
>> 1) Set up ssh authorized_keys so you don't need a password to log in
>
> According to the (very poorly edited) instructions at caltech.edu, I
> must "generate a public/private key pair, and copy the public part into
> the appropiate place on the server side".  So the no-password trick will
> require some server changes, correct, even if I'm already using :ext:?

Changes in your home directory on the server, but not to the SSH server itself.
You run 'ssh-keygen -t dsa', which creates ~/.ssh/id_dsa an ~/.ssh/id_dsa.pub.

You then copy ~/.ssh/id_dsa.pub to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 on the server.
SSH is usually pretty strict about permissions, so your home directory must
not be group or world writable, and your ~/.ssh and ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2
shouldn't be group or world writable or readable.  (I forget the exact
requirements.)

>> 2) Set CVSROOT=user at host:/path/to/cvsroot
>
> I use several different CVS servers on a regular basis, so I would not
> want to set this to any default.  Maybe that step is unnecessary?

You can use a shell function or alias to switch between CVS servers;
it's much easier than having to type that after -d everytime:

function cvs-home {
  export CVSROOT=blah
  export CVS_RSH=ssh
}

function cvs-work {
  export CVSROOT=blurg
  unset CVS_RSH
}

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *



From jason at vancleve.com  Wed Jan 26 15:29:34 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Re: CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <slrncvg927.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

	<3681-61046@sneakemail.com>

Message-ID: <20050126152934.4133f29b.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth Wil Cooley, on Wed, 26 Jan 2005 23:16:04 +0000 (UTC):

> You then copy ~/.ssh/id_dsa.pub to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 on the
> server. SSH is usually pretty strict about permissions, so your home
> directory must not be group or world writable, and your ~/.ssh and
> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 shouldn't be group or world writable or
> readable.  (I forget the exact requirements.)

Thanks, that's useful.

> You can use a shell function or alias to switch between CVS servers;
> it's much easier than having to type that after -d everytime:
> 
> function cvs-home {
>   export CVSROOT=blah
>   export CVS_RSH=ssh
> }
> 
> function cvs-work {
>   export CVSROOT=blurg
>   unset CVS_RSH
> }

Okay, but why set CVSROOT at all?  Normally I work with CVS from within
a local checkout.  From there, CVS can determine the CVSROOT from the
current "./CVS/Root" file.  Is it different with this RSH trick?

Your solution does fit for me, anyway, because I already use aliases
like "cvs-update" and "cvs-add".

--Jason

From douglas.davis at gmail.com  Wed Jan 26 06:57:35 2005
From: douglas.davis at gmail.com (Doug Davis)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 09:57:35 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla v. Firefox
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260651280.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <200501251842.44676.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<1106708281.29252.20.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<200501252048.24891.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260651280.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <135c2178290a5535f132276cc6ee9d97@gmail.com>

On Jan 25, 2005, at 11:48 PM, Carla Schroder wrote:
>
> So another way of asking the question is how do you avoid getting 
> locked-in to
> a particular platform? Obviously Aieee is the king of lockin, and 
> migrating
> away from it is going to cause pain and expense. Suppose you wake up 
> one fine
> day, decide Firefox sucks, and want to move your Web apps to something 
> else-
> how painful would it be? Can you really design complex Web 
> applications to be
> browser-agnostic?
>
>
>

If you just build a valid website using w3c standards, this is way less 
of an issue. XHTML and CSS are your friends. You still have to deal 
with things such as how IE breaks the box model, but in general your 
app will at least render and you can use the workarounds to deal with 
IE. Designing with Web Standards by Jeffrey Zeldman is a good starter 
book on the hows and whys. http://www.zeldman.com

Your main issues with requiring a specific browser come mostly from 
developing using asps and .Net. Mozilla, Firefox and safari all should 
render about the same. (the latest versions anyhow.)

--
Doug



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Jan 26 16:19:48 2005
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 16:19:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <20050126152934.4133f29b.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>
	<3681-61046@sneakemail.com>
	<20050126145617.6cc58038.jason@vancleve.com>
	<slrncvg927.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<20050126152934.4133f29b.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <16759-88460@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 15:29:34 -0800, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Okay, but why set CVSROOT at all?  Normally I work with CVS from within
> a local checkout.  From there, CVS can determine the CVSROOT from the
> current "./CVS/Root" file.  Is it different with this RSH trick?

The CVSROOT is useful if you're checking out a new module, otherwise
as you noted it gets the root from the already checked-out CVS/Root
file.  It's the same when using CVS_RSH=ssh.

  -- Steve

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Jan 26 17:26:46 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 17:26:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Think I've been hacked
In-Reply-To: <20050124230419.GB32166@patch.com>
References: <41F57B90.4070908@comcast.net> <41F57D20.7020309@paranoid.org>
	<20050124230419.GB32166@patch.com>
Message-ID: <1106789206.10509.28.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 15:04 -0800, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> Rich Burroughs wrote:
> > 
> > If you do find you've been hacked, though, there's no reliable way to 
> > clean house on a compromised box. Once the tools you're using can't be 
> > trusted, then it's all downhill. 
> 
> 
> Those two statements don't logically tie together.  One can reinstall the 
> tools - boot from a resuce CD so you are assured that RPM is OK. Once RPM
> (or apt tools) are known good you can verify and reinstall any other system
> binaries.

As long as the rooted filesystem does not have the immutable bit set. 

And you found all the backdoors.

And you found all the binaries that have been modified.

And the additional processes that the system now loads.

And the rootkits.

Etc, etc, etc.

In my experience, I have found that it is VERY hard to find them all
unless you have some very good tools and no additional users on the box.
Some of the current rootkits add a HUGE number of backdoors and hidden
little gotchas.

It is a REAL bad idea to not reformat and start over.  (Unless you are
into creating a honeypot.)

--

 report to me and it will be prohibited.
 So shall it be! This is the Land of the Free!"
                  - George W. Firefly



From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Jan 26 17:31:58 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 17:31:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Best motherboard with Linux
In-Reply-To: <41F5DD88.4090406@comcast.net>
References: <41F5DD88.4090406@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1106789518.10509.35.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Mon, 2005-01-24 at 21:47 -0800, The Bauman Family wrote:
> Hello PLUG:
> 
> We're using Linux right now on a Dell machine, and it works fine, but we 
> want to get a new AMD 64 computer. We visited Fry's and bought the combo 
> Athlon 64 3000+ and Lanparty motherboard, among other things, and we 
> asked the people at Fry's whether it would work. They said that they 
> didn't know, but they knew Gigabyte motherboards worked and suggested we 
> do some research and return it if it wouldn't work. We found no trace of 
> a driver for the motherboard's onboard LAN (as the name suggests) and 
> sound and also couldn't find anything for the video card we'd purchased.

What lan chipset and what distribution.

> We returned the motherboard, CPU, and video, (the CPU and motherboard 
> had to be returned as a combo) and sought help for a motherboard that 
> was known to work with Linux. The person we spoke to said it should work 
> (it was based on the nVidia 3 chipset or something like that, and he 
> used nVidia 2 and Linux worked fine for him). We were skeptical and 
> decided to ask you what the best motherboard (and video card, although 
> we could always use VESA) for Linux would be that works with AMD 64.

http://www.nvidia.com/ has AMD64 drivers for the nvnet chipset.  You
have to get it from their site.  It is a binary-only driver with an
installer. http://www.nvidia.com/object/linux_nforce_amd64_1.0-0292.html

I have used it on one machine.  Seems to work fairly well.  (It has some
odd error messages due to Win2k sending out bad packets, but it just
drops those.)

-- 
"If any sign of pleasure is exhibited,
 report to me and it will be prohibited.

If you buy a Dell or Compaq server thats all they are. Server Works M/B,
a Asian P/S, some easy to punch/bend/spot weld metal, and either black
or tan paint, identical kit.

the discussion on the openbios mailing list, and when finally find a
job, I am very  interested in someday building a
baby cluster.

From nix at petelancashire.com  Wed Jan 26 18:13:00 2005
From: nix at petelancashire.com (Pete Lancashire)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 18:13:00 -0800
Subject: Forgot   -- RE: [PLUG] How do I debug Linux crash
In-Reply-To: <B0004771286@bct-mail.bctonline.com>
References: <B0004771286@bct-mail.bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <1106791979.7129.267.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

do you have another box with a serial port ? or an old
dumb tty ?

set up this bad box to getty out the serial port, connect
to it that way. this will eliminate the display/keyboard/mouse
and all the assoc stuff to drive the display. May also help
isolate network as well.

On 2005-01-27, Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> wrote:
> All,
>
> I have a remote machine and without opening it up for someone how do I
> tell which Motherboard or Ram type they have installed?  I want to
> upgrade with more Ram but don't know the details of the Motherboard.

Try dmidecode.  If you have a modernish system (anything i686-class, at
least), you should be able to get all kinds of information.
