From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 26 18:31:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 02:31:02 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: FOSS Cal and Sched -- Re: Governor backs plan to aid
	open source movment
References: <20050126011648.36308.qmail@web53603.mail.yahoo.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251733200.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200501251744.54113.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251804270.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106708195.29253.18.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<1106714211.6486.36.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260633270.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261707570.27822@well.com>
	<1106790138.7129.224.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
Message-ID: <slrncvgkau.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-27, Pete Lancashire <nix at petelancashire.com> wrote:
> How about meeting 1/2 way.
>
> What is Novel/Evolution and Mozilla/Thunderbird up to ?
>
> Can a cal./sched. package be added to their packages ?
>
> Can the skills and talent of those creating other time
> based packages be used such as project tools.
>
> Just thinking why reinvent what is out there ?
>
> How about first doing a survey of what is out there, and
> then contacting all the players and then seeing if there
> is a chance to create something locally ?

This is all already in progress.  On the server side, there are at least
two projects with reasonably mature codebases:
    o OpenGroupware.org[1]
    o Open-Xchange[2] (*not* owned by SuSE/Novell; Netline actually owns
        it--SuSE just integrated it and sold it with their distro)

Both provide all the stuff you'd expect--calendar, schedule, lots of
other stuff.

There are also a few proprietary servers, such as Novell Groupwise[3] and
Samsung Contact[4] (formerly HP OpenMail).  Both run on Linux.

On the client side, Mozilla Sunbird[5] and Novell/Ximian Evolution are
developing to either support ical over WebDAV or more native interfaces for
the servers.  OpenOffice.org has a groupware project, part of which is called
Glow[6]; I don't know how much activity is has now; it's also Java-based.

There are other solutions, too, like the Kolab[7] server and the Bynari[8]
Insight Connector.  Both seem to be oriented towards storing information on
an IMAP server, which doesn't seem to be a good way to go IMO.  Also, Bynari
is an Outlook plugin for using a Linux srever--it doesn't help Linux desktops.
Kollab seems mainly oriented towards KDE (as you might guess).

1. http://www.opengroupware.org (in case you couldn't guess)
2. http://mirror.open-xchange.org/ox/EN/community/
3. http://www.novell.com/products/groupwise/index.html
4. http://www.samsungcontact.com/en/
5. http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/
6. http://groupware.openoffice.org/glow/
7. http://kolab.org/
8. http://www.bynari.net/

There is still a lot of work to be done, but it's getting there.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

I agree that re-invetion of what is already out there would be a waste.

Would it be within the scope of the new Beaverton center to try to bring
these projects together?

I can see something in the line of a full evaluation of what is already
there and the possibly creating any necessary 'glues' to put these
together to form something that is easily plug/play and yet robust.

I am curious, I see that there is some sentiment that LDAP on the back
end may not be suitable.

What would be a suitable back end storage of calendar and adressbook
type data?

I though that LDAP would be ideal as it can be used for authentication
as well.

Would a better solution be a relational database such as postgres/my/sql
for the data and ldap/kerberos for authentication?

Mark

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jan 26 18:55:04 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 18:55:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] which motherboard and ram do I have? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 26 Jan 2005 18:17:11 PST."
	<2414.216.99.218.67.1106792231.squirrel@sautez.com> 
Message-ID: <20050127025509.EE8A98F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> wrote:

> All,
> 
> I have a remote machine and without opening it up for someone how do I
> tell which Motherboard or Ram type they have installed?  I want to
> upgrade with more Ram but don't know the details of the Motherboard.
> 

This might be possible by reading the SPD data from the currently
installed RAM via the SMBus.  This would involve building the lm_sensors
stuff if not already available, running sensors-detect, loading the
appropriate module, determining the SMBus address of the installed RAM,
reading the SPD contents of the RAM, and decoding the SPD data.  If
all of this sounds foreign to you, it's probably best not to try it.

You may be able to figure out what you need to know just by determining
the motherboard chipset.  This can be done by running lspci and looking
for the part number of the host bridge.  For example, here's my machine:

tinman:~$ /sbin/lspci
00:00.0 Host bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT8363/8365 [KT133/KM133] (rev 03)
00:01.0 PCI bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT8363/8365 [KT133/KM133 AGP]
00:04.0 ISA bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super South] (rev 40)
00:04.1 IDE interface: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C586/B/686A/B PIPC Bus Master IDE (rev 06)
00:04.2 USB Controller: VIA Technologies, Inc. USB (rev 16)
00:04.3 USB Controller: VIA Technologies, Inc. USB (rev 16)
00:04.4 Bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI] (rev 40)
00:04.5 Multimedia audio controller: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 AC97 Audio Controller (rev 50)
00:09.0 Ethernet controller: Digital Equipment Corporation DECchip 21140 [FasterNet] (rev 22)
00:0a.0 SCSI storage controller: LSI Logic / Symbios Logic 53c895 (rev 01)
00:11.0 Unknown mass storage controller: Promise Technology, Inc. 20265 (rev 02)
01:00.0 VGA compatible controller: Matrox Graphics, Inc. MGA G400 AGP (rev 82)


The host controller is a VIA VT8363 or VT8365.  Since the motherboard's
memory controller usually resides in the host bridge, it should be
possible to determine what type of memory is needed.  A few searches 
should tell you what you need to know.  If you post the output of lspci,
I can probably help.  No guarantees though.

galen

> developing to either support ical over WebDAV or more native interfaces for
> the servers.  OpenOffice.org has a groupware project, part of which is called
> Glow[6]; I don't know how much activity is has now; it's also Java-based.
>
> There are other solutions, too, like the Kolab[7] server and the Bynari[8]
> Insight Connector.  Both seem to be oriented towards storing information on
> an IMAP server, which doesn't seem to be a good way to go IMO.  Also, Bynari
> is an Outlook plugin for using a Linux srever--it doesn't help Linux desktops.
> Kollab seems mainly oriented towards KDE (as you might guess).
>
> 1. http://www.opengroupware.org (in case you couldn't guess)
> 2. http://mirror.open-xchange.org/ox/EN/community/
> 3. http://www.novell.com/products/groupwise/index.html
> 4. http://www.samsungcontact.com/en/
> 5. http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/
> 6. http://groupware.openoffice.org/glow/
> 7. http://kolab.org/
> 8. http://www.bynari.net/
>
> There is still a lot of work to be done, but it's getting there.
>
> Wil
> --
> Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
> Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
> * * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
>

  FEA, ray tracing etc. basically pthreads, PVM, MPI.
  This to learn the APIs etc.

  should be easy, Oracle 10g w/CRS (already done but
  removed to rebuild the PCs). And MySQL,
  especially now that 4.1.8+ is out. But to me that
  not the type of cluster I'm thinking off.

  math, the financial world.

  tools

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Jan 26 19:06:09 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 19:06:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] which motherboard and ram do I have?
In-Reply-To: <20050127025006.EE0335C6A@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200501270306.j0R3695f086857@m5p.com>

> From: "Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com>
> I have a remote machine and without opening it up for someone how do I
> tell which Motherboard or Ram type they have installed?  I want to
> upgrade with more Ram but don't know the details of the Motherboard.

Another approach is to run `lspci`, given knowledge of the "Northbridge"
you can at a minimum cut it down to two types (likely one).

First line should look something like:

00:00.0 Host bridge:  ...

From larry.brigman at gmail.com  Wed Jan 26 15:09:46 2005
From: larry.brigman at gmail.com (Larry Brigman)
Date: Wed, 26 Jan 2005 15:09:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Server Question
In-Reply-To: <20050126145617.6cc58038.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <222FBCCAC9AF784BADFD104E8451550BE294CD@beavertn-svr-jk.nike.com>
	<3681-61046@sneakemail.com>
	<20050126145617.6cc58038.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <ca516553050126150972a9d9a9@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 14:56:17 -0800, Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> wrote:
> Quoth Steve Bonds, on Wed, 26 Jan 2005 11:56:05 -0800:
> 
> > > If you use ssh keys to authenticate, you will never need to enter a
> > > password when running cvs commands.
> 
> Interesting.  Two things wonder me:
> 
> > 1) Set up ssh authorized_keys so you don't need a password to log in
> 
> According to the (very poorly edited) instructions at caltech.edu, I
> must "generate a public/private key pair, and copy the public part into
> the appropiate place on the server side".  So the no-password trick will
> require some server changes, correct, even if I'm already using :ext:?
> 
> > 2) Set CVSROOT=user at host:/path/to/cvsroot
> 
> I use several different CVS servers on a regular basis, so I would not
> want to set this to any default.  Maybe that step is unnecessary?

If you provide the root on the command line to other servers cvs keeps track of
the login info in .cvspass.
So once you checkout a project you don't have to specify all the
parameters again
provided you are in the project directory or don't wipe out .cvspass.


From nix at petelancashire.com  Wed Jan 26 19:16:12 2005
From: nix at petelancashire.com (Pete Lancashire)

	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260633270.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261707570.27822@well.com>
	<1106790138.7129.224.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
	<slrncvgkau.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261844570.14026@well.com>
Message-ID: <1106795771.7129.299.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

I think you hit the proverbial nail on the head.

We, the FOSS community have basically reached critical mass with
technical talent. But what I believe is missing is organization
talent. What I think would be great is a group that is skilled
at getting support i.e. $'s. And that same group or another that
is skilled at not only formulating a team, but keeping that team
together.

If there was such a shop, where I could get paid a decent wage,
health bennies, and an annual Tri-Met ticket :), I would jump
at the opportunity. [Wait, I don't want to be a programmer again,
but they would need a sys admin :) ]

I keep reading about places like software job shops, but
they all seem to be closed project centric.

I would think something like such a organization would work much
better then something owned by one of the biggies.

OSDL is an example for the technical side, but what is needed
is a business side.

It would be a good PSU Business School project to do a business case
class on starting such a company and getting it funded. Hmmm only
if I could afford right now to goto PSU ..

-pete

On Wed, 2005-01-26 at 18:49, Mark Allyn wrote:
> I agree that re-invetion of what is already out there would be a waste.
> 
> Would it be within the scope of the new Beaverton center to try to bring
> these projects together?
> 
> I can see something in the line of a full evaluation of what is already
> there and the possibly creating any necessary 'glues' to put these
> together to form something that is easily plug/play and yet robust.
> 
> I am curious, I see that there is some sentiment that LDAP on the back
> end may not be suitable.
> 
> What would be a suitable back end storage of calendar and adressbook
> type data?
> 
> I though that LDAP would be ideal as it can be used for authentication
> as well.
> 
> Would a better solution be a relational database such as postgres/my/sql
> for the data and ldap/kerberos for authentication?
> 
> Mark
> 
> On Thu, 27 Jan 2005, Wil Cooley wrote:
> 
> > On 2005-01-27, Pete Lancashire <nix at petelancashire.com> wrote:
> > > How about meeting 1/2 way.
> > >
> > > What is Novel/Evolution and Mozilla/Thunderbird up to ?
> > >
> > > Can a cal./sched. package be added to their packages ?
> > >
> > > Can the skills and talent of those creating other time
> > > based packages be used such as project tools.
> > >
> > > Just thinking why reinvent what is out there ?
> > >
> > > How about first doing a survey of what is out there, and
> > > then contacting all the players and then seeing if there
> > > is a chance to create something locally ?
> >
> > This is all already in progress.  On the server side, there are at least
> > two projects with reasonably mature codebases:
> >     o OpenGroupware.org[1]
> >     o Open-Xchange[2] (*not* owned by SuSE/Novell; Netline actually owns
> >         it--SuSE just integrated it and sold it with their distro)
> >
> > Both provide all the stuff you'd expect--calendar, schedule, lots of
> > other stuff.
> >
> > There are also a few proprietary servers, such as Novell Groupwise[3] and
> > Samsung Contact[4] (formerly HP OpenMail).  Both run on Linux.
> >
> > On the client side, Mozilla Sunbird[5] and Novell/Ximian Evolution are
> > developing to either support ical over WebDAV or more native interfaces for
> > the servers.  OpenOffice.org has a groupware project, part of which is called
> > Glow[6]; I don't know how much activity is has now; it's also Java-based.
> >
> > There are other solutions, too, like the Kolab[7] server and the Bynari[8]
> > Insight Connector.  Both seem to be oriented towards storing information on
> > an IMAP server, which doesn't seem to be a good way to go IMO.  Also, Bynari
> > is an Outlook plugin for using a Linux srever--it doesn't help Linux desktops.
> > Kollab seems mainly oriented towards KDE (as you might guess).
> >
> > 1. http://www.opengroupware.org (in case you couldn't guess)
> > 2. http://mirror.open-xchange.org/ox/EN/community/
> > 3. http://www.novell.com/products/groupwise/index.html
> > 4. http://www.samsungcontact.com/en/
> > 5. http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/
> > 6. http://groupware.openoffice.org/glow/
> > 7. http://kolab.org/
> > 8. http://www.bynari.net/
> >
> > There is still a lot of work to be done, but it's getting there.
> >

	aid open source movment

	<slrncvgkau.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261844570.14026@well.com>
Message-ID: <1106796780.7129.311.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>

On Wed, 2005-01-26 at 18:49, Mark Allyn wrote:
> I agree that re-invetion of what is already out there would be a waste.
> 
> Would it be within the scope of the new Beaverton center to try to bring
> these projects together?
> 
> I can see something in the line of a full evaluation of what is already
> there and the possibly creating any necessary 'glues' to put these
> together to form something that is easily plug/play and yet robust.
> 
> I am curious, I see that there is some sentiment that LDAP on the back
> end may not be suitable.



> What would be a suitable back end storage of calendar and adressbook
> type data?
> 
> I though that LDAP would be ideal as it can be used for authentication
> as well.
> 
> Would a better solution be a relational database such as postgres/my/sql
> for the data and ldap/kerberos for authentication?

I agree, keep out of LDAPs DB.

I wish i had saved it, I had a report on a big company, I remember
something over 20,000 desktops. And the size of the cal/sked database.
Wow ... Think of what it must look like at IBM.

To me, it should use ANSI SQL. Keep it down to the basics. This would
allow one to use everything from tinySQL, MySQL, or if the company was
an 'Oracle Shop', then Oracle, or IIS. Remember at may companies it is
not technology that wins, it is who sales team wears the most expensive
suits, and gives out the most Blazer tickets. Back to technology :)

LDAP would work, but I wouldn't want to clutter LDAP's database with
transitory things. Think Windows registry.

To even simplify it, embed or distribute it with a small DB engine,
tinySQL or something like that, or something like DB4.

And don't forget, the most important, totally transparent
import/conversion from MS. It has to be there.

-pete

Vram wrote:

> domain-name-portfolios.net[194.154.178.229]: Connection refused (port
> 25)
> 
> 
> I have this same message every 30 minutes for hours.

Generally, it means that the service/daemon isn't running on that port. 
Perhaps you are behind a NAT and you don't have port 25 forwarded to you?

I want to put an overline over some signal names to indicate active-low
logic.  To my knowledge, the only way to get an overline is to use math
mode.

$\overline {ACTIVELOWSIGNAL}$

This works, but the text style looks different due to being in math
mode.  It appears to be slanted or in italics.  Is there a way to make
it use the 'normal', non-math text style?  What is the 'normal' text
style?

BTW, I'm using Evil Red Text in Lyx.

thanks,
galen

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 26 21:31:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 05:31:02 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: FOSS Cal and Sched -- Re: Governor backs plan to aid
	open source movment
References: <20050126011648.36308.qmail@web53603.mail.yahoo.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251733200.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<200501251744.54113.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501251804270.15473@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1106708195.29253.18.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<1106714211.6486.36.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501260633270.3019@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261707570.27822@well.com>
	<1106790138.7129.224.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
	<slrncvgkau.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>
	<Pine.GSO.4.58.0501261844570.14026@well.com>
Message-ID: <slrncvguqk.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-27, Mark Allyn <allyn at well.com> wrote:
>
> I agree that re-invetion of what is already out there would be a waste.
>
> Would it be within the scope of the new Beaverton center to try to bring
> these projects together?
>
> I can see something in the line of a full evaluation of what is already
> there and the possibly creating any necessary 'glues' to put these
> together to form something that is easily plug/play and yet robust.
>
> I am curious, I see that there is some sentiment that LDAP on the back
> end may not be suitable.
>
> What would be a suitable back end storage of calendar and adressbook
> type data?
>
> I though that LDAP would be ideal as it can be used for authentication
> as well.
>
> Would a better solution be a relational database such as postgres/my/sql
> for the data and ldap/kerberos for authentication?

LDAP has its place; storing calendar and scheduling information is probably
not it.  I cannot necessarily say why, but WebDAV seems to be the direction
most of the afforementioned projects are headed.  OpenGroupware.org uses a
relational database to store the calendar data and publishes it through a
WebDAV interface.

One part that's not mentioned is group-centric addressbooks.  The ability to
have department-wide and company-wide addressbooks is generally considered
to be a requirement; LDAP is perfect for this.  It's already supported as
an addressbook source by almost every MUA.

The part that isn't very easy, currently, is actually getting contact
info into LDAP.  There are, of course, a number of web-based addressbook
applications that will manage LDAP contacts, but that adds a number of
steps over having the MUA manage contacts directly.  Evolution is the only
MUA I know of that will actually write to an LDAP directory; with a little
fiddling you can even differentiate between personal and shared contacts.
It's not easy to setup; I broke mine upgrading and moving stuff around a
few months ago and haven't bothered to fix it yet.

Open-Xchange uses OpenLDAP for addressbooks; OpenGroupware.org doesn't:
it publishes contacts as vCards through WebDAV.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

   Good for you for using LyX! I've no idea why it's called ERT when it's
just plain ol' LaTeX. Anywho, you can make the math mode type style upright
(roman) via the menus. Hold on while I fire up lyx ...

   OK, I'm back again. Look in Insert -> Math -> Font change and pick what
you like.

If your machines can boot DVDs, check out Quantian at

http://dirk.eddelbuettel.com/quantian

Quantian is a LiveDVD built on clusterKnoppix. It has clustering and 
large-scale scientific and computational finance tools out of the box, 
can be installed to hard disk like any Knoppix version, etc.

If your machines can't boot DVDs, you can download the ISO and "unpack" 
it onto your hard drive and boot it directly, then install to hard disk 
if you wish.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Jan 27 08:05:25 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)

Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX digital logic question

Rogan Creswick <creswick at gmail.com> wrote:

> On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 20:25:13 -0800, Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:
> > $\overline {ACTIVELOWSIGNAL}$
> > 
> > This works, but the text style looks different due to being in math
> > mode.  It appears to be slanted or in italics.  Is there a way to make
> > it use the 'normal', non-math text style?  What is the 'normal' text
> > style?
> 
> I believe this works:
> 
> $\overline {\mathrm{ACTIVELOWSIGNAL}}$
> 
> probably not the best way though.

Thanks for the suggestion.  That got me pointed in the right direction.
Here's what I did.

\newcommand{\negate}[1]{$\overline\textrm{#1}$}
\negate{MYACTIVELOWSIGNAL}


galen


From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Jan 27 08:26:33 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 08:26:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX digital logic question 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 27 Jan 2005 05:35:40 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501270532070.5850@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20050127162638.4218A8F0D@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

> On Wed, 26 Jan 2005, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > To my knowledge, the only way to get an overline is to use math mode.
> 
> Galen,
> 
>    Yup.
> 
> > $\overline {ACTIVELOWSIGNAL}$
> >
> > This works, but the text style looks different due to being in math
> > mode.  It appears to be slanted or in italics.  Is there a way to make
> > it use the 'normal', non-math text style?  What is the 'normal' text
> > style?
> 
>    \text{roman}
> 
> > BTW, I'm using Evil Red Text in Lyx.
> 
>    Good for you for using LyX! I've no idea why it's called ERT when it's
> just plain ol' LaTeX. Anywho, you can make the math mode type style upright
> (roman) via the menus. Hold on while I fire up lyx ...
> 
>    OK, I'm back again. Look in Insert -> Math -> Font change and pick what
> you like.
> 

Just so you know, I was sparing everyone the details.  The Lyx menus
aren't helpful in this instance.  I'm using the bytefield package.
  http://www.ctan.org/tex-archive/macros/latex/contrib/bytefield/
My actual LaTeX code looks something like this:

\newcommand{\negate}[1]{$\overline\textrm{#1}$}
\begin{center}
\scriptsize
\settowidth{\bitwidth}{CCCCCCCi}  % some field names are very wide
\begin{bytefield}{8} \bitheader[b]{0-7} \\
\bitbox{8}{\negate{P4}}
\\
\bitbox{4}{\negate{COL}} &
\bitbox{4}{\negate{ROW}}
\end{bytefield}
\end{center}

This creates a nice diagram of two 8 bit registers, the first having a 
single 8 bit field, and the second having two 4 bit fields.  The
bytefield package is particularly good for documenting things like
protocol headers and such.

Thanks to everyone for their help.
galen

On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 17:47:38 -0800, Pete Lancashire wrote:

> Anyone taken a look at
> 
> http://www.mozilla.org/projects/calendar/
> 
> ....We are striving to build a cross-platform fully standards based
> calendar client based on the open iCal standard....
> 
> ....Sunbird [stand alone version]

I've used the browser-based version connected to a WebDAV/HTTPS
server.  The last version I looked at was about 6 months ago, and it
was pretty unstable.

It seemed adequate for basic calendar functions-- e.g. holidays,
appointments, but I wouldn't want to use it for anything serious.

I've been meaning to look into Sunbird in order to avoid losing my
whole browser when it eats itself, but so far laziness has won out.

  -- Steve

From lowbassman at gmail.com  Thu Jan 27 13:32:26 2005
From: lowbassman at gmail.com (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 14:32:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ulimit weirdness
Message-ID: <9e0a357805012713329d295f2@mail.gmail.com>

I'm trying to change the max number of open files for a user (oracle).
 This is on a RedHat ES 3 box.  I've modifed /etc/security/limits.conf
and set the soft and hard limits for "nofile" for the oracle user.  If
I login directly as oracle then I get:

-bash: ulimit: open files: cannot modify limit: Operation not permitted

However, if I "su - oracle" then the new ulimit values are set.  The
PAM config files, system-auth and login, both contain pam_limits.so.

Any ideas what's going on here?
Thanks,
~M

-- 
Get Firefox!
http://getfirefox.com/

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jan 27 15:01:05 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 23:01:05 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: ulimit weirdness
References: <9e0a357805012713329d295f2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <slrncvis67.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-27, Matt Alexander <lowbassman at gmail.com> wrote:
> I'm trying to change the max number of open files for a user (oracle).
>  This is on a RedHat ES 3 box.  I've modifed /etc/security/limits.conf
> and set the soft and hard limits for "nofile" for the oracle user.  If
> I login directly as oracle then I get:
>
> -bash: ulimit: open files: cannot modify limit: Operation not permitted
>
> However, if I "su - oracle" then the new ulimit values are set.  The
> PAM config files, system-auth and login, both contain pam_limits.so.
>
> Any ideas what's going on here?

Yes, you're trying to change them over SSH, aren't you?  What happens is that
the limits built in for your shell (forked through sshd, at least indirectly)
are already set and sshd is running with privilege separation, so by the time
you've logged in, the limits cannot be raised.  Try disabling privsep in sshd
and see if that helps.  If so, add ulimit commands to your sshd init script,
re-enable privsep, and restart sshd after doing a full su to root.

If that sounds a little muddled, it's because it is.  I ran into it a few
months ago and the details are a little fuzzy, but I'm fairly certain that
both increasing the ulimits in the init script and disabling privsep in sshd
fixed it, in different ways.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *



From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Jan 27 15:01:32 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 15:01:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OS X: when good consoles go bad
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501271436560.3796@dyn-50-66.galois.com>

I'm such a Mac newbie that I'm reluctant to post messages like this 
for fear that my supervisors might figure out that I shouldn't even be 
touching these machines, but here goes nothing. :-)

Our two OS X rack-mount servers are connected to a KVM. One of our 
long-time Mac users was showing me the cool ">console" login trick, 
whereby you can get a text-mode login screen.

In our setup, for some reason, the text-mode screen disappears after 
about five seconds, leaving me with a blank blue GUI screen. I.e., the 
console was gone, the mouse was active, but no windows or mouse 
actions were available. I have a feeling that the problem is related 
to our KVM, but I haven't confirmed that.

Otherwise, however, the machine was operating normally. I was able to 
use ssh to login to it without any trouble, and all services were 
functioning normally. If it were a Linux box, I'd say that X was 
running but xdm/gdm/kdm was hung somewhere.

We tried all sorts of keyboard tricks to get a login screen (text or 
GUI, we didn't care), all to no avail.

Finally, I logged in using ssh and poked around the process table. I 
saw this bit floating around:

root     11204   0.0  0.0    18072    292  ??  Ss+   1:39PM   0:00.12 
/usr/libexec/getty std.9600 console

Once I killed it, the regular GUI login window reappeared.

So I tried it again, thinking that maybe I needed to keep the 
keystokes a-flowin' to avoid the timeout. No luck. I got my username 
entered when, like before, I got a blank GUI screen. This time, 
however, the stuck process was login:

root     11191   0.0  0.0    27408    516  ??  Ss+   2:17PM   0:00.14 
login -p1 heinlein

Once I killed that process, the login window materialized once again.

Wierd, eh?

The only thing that occurs to me is that our KVM might not provide all 
the feedback necessary for maintaining a 9600 baud getty session, 
though I don't know where the hangup would be.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

> On Tue, 25 Jan 2005, AthlonRob wrote:
> 
> > Getting them to migrate off Exchange would be like trying to get a 
> > cat to migrate off catching birds.
> 
> I can't speak for the state of Oregon, and I'd never wish on anyone
> the job of Exchange Administrator, but I know the frustration of 
> looking for a bona fide calendaring solution that can stack up with 
> Exchange.
> 
> Oracle makes one (well, Mr. Ellison opened his pocket book and bought 
> Steltor's product) that's quite good, but it's not terribly well 
> integrated with any clients save its own. MeetingMaker has one that's 
> used at Synopsis (among other places), but I haven't installed the 
> demo yet. Of course, these are both proprietary products.
> 
> We in the Free Software community haven't written a good replacement 
> yet. UW is working on a Java-based product, but it's too fragile at 
> this stage, and I don't know if its feature set really matches the 
> needs of corporate scheduling.
> 
> IOW, Exchange offers more than e-mail transport and delivery: its 
> users have a best-of-breed calendaring server. There just isn't a 
> suite of Free software products that can replace it. For now, anyway.
> 
> -- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Tue, 25 Jan 2005 17:35:58 -0800 (PST), Rich Shepard wrote:

>    Pardon my cynicism, but he's grabbing a political moment from something
> that's already happening whether or not he makes a campaign issue from it.

Poor, cynical Rich is correct.  This plan was announced by Beaverton
in their green flyers last year sometime.  I wish I'd saved it so I
could quote verbatim.  Perhaps another Beaverton resident whose wife
is less proactive about recycling could comment on what I remember
with solid facts?
 
>    Note this quote from the article: "...unveiled plans for an Open
> Technology center that is designed to boost the adoption of open technology
> among developers and industries." Nothing about adoption by state, county or
> local governments is there? And who would benefit most from the cost savings
> in this era of tight budgets?

The original Beaverton City article, as best I can remember, described
this as a business incubator fund.  I.e. Beaverton will provide space
and what amounts to angel round venture capital funding for companies
trying to make a go at something related to Open Source.  It was not
about trying to convince governments to use Open Source software.

I have not been able to find anything on the Beaverton City website to
back up my recollection, though.  I was hoping at least to find forms
or information about how one might get into the program.  If someone
here can find this, maybe some of you unemployed PLUGgers can get a
business case together and form up an Open Source business with
funding from the city?

  -- Steve


From ron at braithwaites.net  Thu Jan 27 16:15:15 2005
From: ron at braithwaites.net (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 16:15:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Certification At Free Geek
Message-ID: <1106871315.6257.38.camel@hermes.braithwaites.net>

That's right! You can get that magic piece of paper really cheap from
Free Geek.

Free Geek is going to offer the Linux Professional Institute
(http://www.lpi.org/) Linux Certification exams on Sunday, March 6, 2005
at 1:00pm.

Actually, we just had a bunch of folks take the test this last Sunday,
but there were quite a few of folks who weren't able to take that test
or, like me, took only one of the two tests. And, of course, there is
the whole Level 2 test to look forward to as well.

We had cram sessions on Tuesday and Thursday evenings the last couple of
weeks before the test and we'll do that again, too. These won't be
classes, per se, but will instead focus on going over the subject areas
covered in some of the different training materials and sharing each
other's knowledge in advance of the test.

An important note! There are various books out there on the LPI exam,
but only one is current. That is Exam Cram 2 LPIC I by Que ISBN
0-7897-3127-4. The O'Reilly book is seriously out of date. This book
isn't perfect, but it does parallel the test pretty closely. Also, the
test software in the book is broken, but Chaz Sliger chased down the
real deal. Contact him or me off line and one of will get you the good
copy.

In keeping with the Free Geek tradition of trying to make technology
available to everyone, we have worked out a very special deal with LPI
on the test pricing so we only need to charge $40 for each exam.

Because we have to let LPI know a few weeks in advance how many people
are going to take the test (there are _very_ rigid rules around taking
the test), we need you to sign up right away.

We can give the test to up to 35 people, so we will sign up the first 35
people to contact Laurel Hoyt (ideath at freegeek.org), the Free Geek
Education Coordinator, with a cut-off date of 14 Feb 2005. Once we hit
the cutoff number or date, that's it.

I have a hunch that this will fill up quickly, so please don't wait.

-Ron

-- 
Ron Braithwaite
Technical Consulting Services
ron at braithwaites.net
+01-503-267-3250
4110 SE Hawthorne Blvd #228, Portland, OR 97214 USA
1917 W 4th Ave #549, Vancouver, B.C. V6J 1M7 Canada

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jan 27 16:46:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 00:46:02 +0000 (UTC)

> the whole Level 2 test to look forward to as well.

Oh, the Level 2 cert test is going to be given?  I took 102 this last time
and am pretty confident that I passed (I took 101 at OSCON '03).  Anyone else
considering the Level 2 cert?

> We can give the test to up to 35 people, so we will sign up the first 35
> people to contact Laurel Hoyt (ideath at freegeek.org), the Free Geek
> Education Coordinator, with a cut-off date of 14 Feb 2005. Once we hit
> the cutoff number or date, that's it.

You might also mention that Laurel is on vacation for another week or so.

Wil

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Thu Jan 27 18:59:51 2005

Subject: [PLUG] which motherboard and ram do I have?
In-Reply-To: <1106792018.7129.270.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
References: <2414.216.99.218.67.1106792231.squirrel@sautez.com>
	<1106792018.7129.270.camel@l1.pdxeng.com>
Message-ID: <1643.134.244.174.76.1106881191.squirrel@sautez.com>

Thanks all.  I have found a solution from Wil's suggestions.  I don't
know if I posted it to the list but the dmidecode program returned to
me the motherboard model which I could then look up and determine the
memory and other info.

thanks again.  I've figured out that my GB's of Simms will not work in
the DDR server this has.  :-(  Oh, well, buy yet another round of
memory.

Josh

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Thu Jan 27 19:40:52 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 19:40:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Expert System
In-Reply-To: <20050126202516.40573.qmail@web60802.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20050126202516.40573.qmail@web60802.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <41F9B444.6060203@cesmail.net>

There is a fairly comprehensive knowledge base tool called Protege 
that's "sorta" free. It's written in Java, so if you're willing to 
accept Sun's JRE/JDK license, the rest of it is free. The documentation 
is pretty good, but you really need to know "knowledge engineering" to 
use it.

Ovid wrote:

>--- "Roderick A. Anderson" <raanders at acm.org> wrote:
>  
>
>>Anyone know of web based , (preferrably perl coded ) , expert or
>>decision support system software?
>>    
>>
>
>Ah, crud.  If you ask again in a few months, I'll have AI::Prolog
>(http://search.cpan.org/~ovid/AI-Prolog-0.03/) stable and you'd be able
>to whip it out with that.  Unfortunately, I have a job and only work on
>it in my spare time, so it's only alpha and still requires that you
>know Prolog :/
>
>However, depending upon your needs, you could quite possibly use
>FSA::Rules (http://search.cpan.org/~dwheeler/FSA-Rules-0.21/) for
>something like this.  Plus, if you have a GraphViz installed, it can
>print a graph of the underlying state machine so you can see if you've
>modeled it correctly.  An example is at
>http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/images/pg_rules.png.  Those are the
>rules we are using at work to control how PostgreSQL gets installed.  I
>wrote a lot of that module, so you have questions, you could shoot them
>to me.
>
>Yet another option, though it takes some work since the docs are awful:
>
>Language::Prolog::Yaswi
>(http://cpan.uwinnipeg.ca/htdocs/Language-Prolog-Yaswi/Language/Prolog/Yaswi.html).
> It's an interface to SWI-Prolog.  There are some caveats to using it
>and I've written a bit about it at
>http://use.perl.org/~Ovid/journal/22708.    It's the fastest of the
>bunch, but it's unmaintained and requires an older version of
>SWI-Prolog.
>
>Cheers,
>Ovid
>
>=====
>If this message is a response to a question on a mailing list, please send
>follow up questions to the list.
>
>Web Programming with Perl -- http://users.easystreet.com/ovid/cgi_course/
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
>  
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jan 27 19:56:06 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 27 Jan 2005 19:56:06 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Expert System
In-Reply-To: <41F9B444.6060203@cesmail.net>
References: <20050126202516.40573.qmail@web60802.mail.yahoo.com>
	<41F9B444.6060203@cesmail.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501271953400.10014@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 27 Jan 2005, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky wrote:

> There is a fairly comprehensive knowledge base tool called Protege that's 
> "sorta" free. It's written in Java, so if you're willing to accept Sun's 
> JRE/JDK license, the rest of it is free. The documentation is pretty good, 
> but you really need to know "knowledge engineering" to use it.

   Then there's CLIPS (and FuzzyCLIPS) from Natural Resources Canada and JESS
(Java Expert System Shell; from the folks at Sandia Labs). Bill Siler sells
his FLOPS (windows only and good for pattern detection). There are other
expert system shells out there for crisp logic.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

In-Reply-To: <20050125054114.GA5935@gate.kl-ic.com>

from a friend:

11.  Your man pages appear female.

-----------------------------------------------

> You know you've really been hacked when:
>
>
> 1)  You start getting phone calls from people ordering penis
> enlargers.
>
> 2)  Your online music collection is now Nigerian tribal music.
>
>
> 3)  You stop getting spam (it wastes bandwidth, you know).
>
>
> 4)  Kevin Mitnick sends you a birthday card.
>
>
> 5)  Your man pages are now in Russian and Korean.
>
>
> 6)  Inexplicable free hardware upgrades are delivered daily.
>
>
> 7)  You start getting 147 credit card bills.
>
>
> 8)  Which is all right, you now have the money from 147 mortgages to
> pay the bills with.
>
> 9)  Tripwire reports your system is clean - but you didn't RUN
> tripwire!
>
> ... and the main way you know you've really been hacked is:
>
>
> 10) You get supposedly humorous emails that end with long

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan 28 09:52:56 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 28 Jan 2005 09:52:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] space left on tape, a "clever" idea
Message-ID: <86fz0lv3t3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


In my various recent struggles with the tape drive failures, I have
been refamiliarized with the tape utilities (mostly scripted long ago)
and reminded by its little inadequacies.  Chief among those, at least
with the DDS drives I possess, is the uncertainty regarding tape
usage.  That is, "how much space did I just use?" or "how much more
data could I fit on the tape?" or similar rephrasings.  In the world
of DDS, the tape only ejects when fully rewound, so you have no way to
judge visually.  And since there is typically compression involved,
you can't judge from how much data you wrote since compression rates
are wildly variable.

It suddenly occurred to me today (possibly after others have
repeatedly suggested this in the past, I am afraid to look), that one
way to judge how much space is left after a backup is simply to write
zeroes with datcompression off and let dd tell you how many blocks go
out before hitting the end of media.

For example:

  # mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 2
  # tar -C / -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # tar -C / -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1
  # tar -C /aux -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1
  # tar -C /aux -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 2
  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 0
  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=32768
  dd: writing `/dev/nst0': No space left on device
  34295+0 records in
  34294+0 records out

Then do the math:

  $ clisp -q -x '(format nil "~R bytes" (* 34294 32768))'
  "one billion, one hundred and twenty-three million, seven hundred and forty-five thousand, seven hundred and ninety-two bytes"

So, a little over a gig of space free on a native 12 gig cartridge.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``Hey, I know.  Let's have lunch at the Place des Vosges!''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jan 28 11:24:27 2005

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jan 28 11:45:39 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 11:45:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] space left on tape, a "clever" idea
Message-ID: <20050128194539.GA15752@gate.kl-ic.com>


On 28 Jan 2005, Russell Senior writes:

>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 2
>  # tar -C / -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>  # tar -C / -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0

>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1

Are these two commands necessary?  An nst0 (no-rewind st0) tape
device should be positioned at the end of the first record after it
was written or read.  Perhaps DDS doesn't know how to do that...

>  # tar -C /aux -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1

>  # tar -C /aux -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 2

... and this is *why* you probably don't want to rewind, at this point.
If you forget the fsf command, or accidentally enter fsf 1 rather than
fsf 2, you write zeros all over one of the tars you just made.  Yikes!

>  # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 0
>  # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=32768
>  dd: writing `/dev/nst0': No space left on device
>  34295+0 records in
>  34294+0 records out

Clever, yes.  But now, how do you figure how many real records you
have on the tape, next time you decide to write on that tape?  Just
assume the last record is all zeros?  Just read a bit of each record
and look for a long string of zeros, then decide?  I suppose you 
could write lots of info on the tape label.

I hate tape labels, almost as much as I hate unlabelled tapes.

Back when I was still using tapes, the real issue was figuring out
whether an about-to-launch set of backups would *fit* on a tape.
With compression, it was always a bit indeterminate.  The strategy
became "try it and see", or else just assume it would be "about the
same as last time".  This really became a problem when dealing with
not-that-regular incremental backups.

Tapes:  Just Say No.  :-)

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan 28 12:46:45 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 28 Jan 2005 12:46:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] space left on tape, a "clever" idea
In-Reply-To: <20050128194539.GA15752@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050128194539.GA15752@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <868y6duvre.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768 
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 2 
>> # tar -C / -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .  
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind 
>> # tar -C / -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind 
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1

Keith> Are these two commands necessary?  An nst0 (no-rewind st0) tape
Keith> device should be positioned at the end of the first record
Keith> after it was written or read.  Perhaps DDS doesn't know how to
Keith> do that...

Necessary?  Maybe not.  But safer?  Definitely.  I once (long ago when
I was writing my backup script) played with doing relative tape
movements, but found that mt and the tape drive could find themselves
in disagreement and determined that the only reliable way to establish
position (at least with these drives) was to rewind and fsf.  These
are scripted backups, running overnight, so a little extra time spent
for robust tape positioning was worth it.

>> # tar -C /aux -b 64 -clf /dev/nst0 .
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind 
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 1

>> # tar -C /aux -b 64 -dlf /dev/nst0 
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind 
>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 fsf 2

Keith> ... and this is *why* you probably don't want to rewind, at
Keith> this point.  If you forget the fsf command, or accidentally
Keith> enter fsf 1 rather than fsf 2, you write zeros all over one of
Keith> the tars you just made.  Yikes!

My scripts never forget!

>> # mt -f /dev/nst0 datcompression 0 
>> # dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/nst0 bs=32768 
>> dd: writing `/dev/nst0': No space left on device 
>> 34295+0 records in 
>> 34294+0 records out

Keith> Clever, yes.  But now, how do you figure how many real records
Keith> you have on the tape, next time you decide to write on that
Keith> tape?  Just assume the last record is all zeros?  Just read a
Keith> bit of each record and look for a long string of zeros, then
Keith> decide?  I suppose you could write lots of info on the tape
Keith> label.

These are just full backups, so there are only ever two real tape
files.  To determine how much slack there is on the end, you'd just:  

  # dd if=/dev/nst0 of=/dev/null bs=32768

and wait for dd to tell you how many blocks it read, or perhaps
consult the log file from the corresponding backup where this
information will already exist.

Keith> I hate tape labels, almost as much as I hate unlabelled tapes.

I am assuming you are referring to adhesive backed labels stuck onto
the exterior of the cartridge rather than some data plunked on some
portion of the tape.  I've been using these for years:

  <http://www.labelonce.com/>

Write on with ultra fine point sharpie, erase (without a trace) with a
regular white eraser and write again.

Keith> Back when I was still using tapes, the real issue was figuring
Keith> out whether an about-to-launch set of backups would *fit* on a
Keith> tape.  With compression, it was always a bit indeterminate.

Yes.  This "clever" idea doesn't totally solve the problem, but it
does provide a little bit more clue than the old "try it and see".

Keith> Tapes: Just Say No.  :-)

These are legacy backups, particularly where offsite storage in a 43.8
gram package is a desideratum.  The tape drive is a sunk cost.  Once
we exceed tape capacity, backup-to-disk will be the logical next step
in this application.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From larry.brigman at gmail.com  Fri Jan 28 13:59:58 2005
From: larry.brigman at gmail.com (Larry Brigman)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 13:59:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Code Protection
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501280656590.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501280656590.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <ca51655305012813593aaf37d7@mail.gmail.com>

I know that this might get me flamed but this is the best place I know
to start to get a question like this answered.  My google searches didn't yield
any useful results.

So some background.

I'm in the process of building an embedded box to do VOIP using Linux and other
tools.  The system will be using a compact flash device as it's hard drive but
will be limited to the amount of writing that will be done to the device except
for a system upgrade.  Because of the niche market that these boxes will be
going into, it is very likely that some of the boxes will be opened and the 
flash removed to determine if they could just place this code elsewhere on
an old PC and use the system.  The result after that would be copying or selling
something that would undercut or stop our sales altogether.  I am being asked
to lock the code down to the hardware such that it would not run if
the detection
methods failed resulting in a kernel panic (root not found).  I fully
expect to have
to share all the sources (that I have) except the lock down portion.

I really don't want this to turn into a lecture about the virtues of
the GPL license.

So the real question,  what does one do for code protection in this
type of case?
Anyone on the list have opinions; done this before, etc?


From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jan 28 14:56:45 2005
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 14:56:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Code Protection
In-Reply-To: <ca51655305012813593aaf37d7@mail.gmail.com>

	<ca51655305012813593aaf37d7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501281452410.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 28 Jan 2005, Larry Brigman wrote:

> I really don't want this to turn into a lecture about the virtues of the
> GPL license.

   There's a lot of good, proprietary code sold for use on linux. WordPerfect
was an example, the XessSE spreadsheet's another and VMware is probably the
best known. The software I'm developing will also be proprietary.

> So the real question,  what does one do for code protection in this type
> of case? Anyone on the list have opinions; done this before, etc?

   Let me offer the solution that was suggested to me: a dongle! I'm sure you
can work with the dongleteer to provide a physical connection that will work
only on your hardware. As a matter of fact, several vendors provide an
add-in card that puts the dongle inside the box.

   When you've built a better mousetrap you want to be the big cheese, at
least for a while. :-)

Rich

From fixin at peak.org  Fri Jan 28 15:12:47 2005
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 15:12:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] bash question: can variable contain a variable?
Message-ID: <20050128231247.GK21327@peak.org>

I want to write a bash function that takes a parameter containing the
name of a variable, to test that that variable is bound to a path to
an existing file, and to print an error with the variable name if it's
not found.  If bash's vars were like perl's, it'd look like this:

function checkispath {
    if [ ! -f $$1 ]; then echo "path $$1 in var $1 not found"; exit 1; fi
}

APATH=/tmp/somedir/somefile.txt
checkdir APATH                          # NOT checkdir "$APATH"

But the $$1 (and ${$1}, etc.) doesn't work in bash.  Is this even
possible in bash?  If so, what's the syntax?  For bonus credit, what the
heck do you google for to answer a question like this? :-)

Thanks,

--Eric
-- 
******************************************************************************
* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*          Crosswords 4.1 for PalmOS now ARM-native: xwords.sourceforge.net  *
******************************************************************************


From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jan 28 15:43:32 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 15:43:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] bash question: can variable contain a variable?
In-Reply-To: <20050128231247.GK21327@peak.org>
References: <20050128231247.GK21327@peak.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.62.0501281527230.7306@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Fri, 28 Jan 2005, Eric House wrote:

> I want to write a bash function that takes a parameter containing 
> the name of a variable, to test that that variable is bound to a 
> path to an existing file, and to print an error with the variable 
> name if it's not found.  If bash's vars were like perl's, it'd look 
> like this:
>
> function checkispath {
>    if [ ! -f $$1 ]; then echo "path $$1 in var $1 not found"; exit 1; fi
> }
>
> APATH=/tmp/somedir/somefile.txt
> checkdir APATH                          # NOT checkdir "$APATH"
>
> But the $$1 (and ${$1}, etc.) doesn't work in bash.  Is this even 
> possible in bash?

I think you'll want to eval it, e.g.,

   function checkispath {
     eval FILENAME=$`echo $1`
     if test ! -f "$FILENAME"; then ...; fi
   }

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>


From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jan 28 15:46:02 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 23:46:02 +0000 (UTC)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: bash question: can variable contain a variable?
References: <20050128231247.GK21327@peak.org>
Message-ID: <slrncvlj1a.a6b.wcooley@rheingold.nakedape.priv>

On 2005-01-28, Eric House <fixin at peak.org> wrote:
> I want to write a bash function that takes a parameter containing the
> name of a variable, to test that that variable is bound to a path to
> an existing file, and to print an error with the variable name if it's
> not found.  If bash's vars were like perl's, it'd look like this:
>
> function checkispath {
>     if [ ! -f $$1 ]; then echo "path $$1 in var $1 not found"; exit 1; fi
> }
>
> APATH=/tmp/somedir/somefile.txt
> checkdir APATH                          # NOT checkdir "$APATH"
>
> But the $$1 (and ${$1}, etc.) doesn't work in bash.  Is this even
> possible in bash?  If so, what's the syntax?  

See G3: http://www.faqs.org/faqs/unix-faq/shell/bash/

I'm not using ${!var} syntax because I didn't know about it until the other
day; I've been using plain-old 'eval', like this:

#
# path_append - Appends a path element to any PATH-like variable.
#
# Pass it the name of the PATH-like variable and the string to append.
#
function path_append {
    if [ $# -ne 2 ]; then
        printf 'path_append <PATH_LIKE> <path_element>\n'
        return 1
    fi
    
    local x
    eval x=\$$1
    
    if [ -n "$x" ]; then
        eval $1=$x:$2
    else
        eval $1=$2
    fi
}
###


> For bonus credit, what the
> heck do you google for to answer a question like this? :-)

faqs.org is a good place to start.  The newsgroup comp.unix.shell (which you
can search through Google Groups) has lots of this kind of thing; there are
other FAQs that are posted there regularly.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *

From ron at braithwaites.net  Fri Jan 28 16:05:44 2005

On Fri, 2005-01-28 at 13:59 -0800, Larry Brigman wrote:
> So the real question,  what does one do for code protection in this
> type of case?

Rich's suggestion of a dongle is a very good one. Another alternative is
using a signed MD5 (or SH1) hash of the MAC address. That wouldn't cost
you beyond your effort.

And, yes, I have done similar stuff in the past.

-Ron

From aaron at bavariati.org  Fri Jan 28 18:48:42 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Fri, 28 Jan 2005 18:48:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Code Protection
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501281753120.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501281524050.17530-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501281753120.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20050129024842.GI30960@bavariati.org>

On Fri, Jan 28, 2005 at 05:54:13PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 28 Jan 2005, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
> >An "If you break this seal" license, a copyright and some hidden
> >identification in the code could help.  Depends on whether your company
> >wants to pursue legal action.
> 
> Isn't it better to prevent the crime rather than to prosecute
> after the fact?

It depends on how much effort it takes to prevent it, how effective
the prevention is, how likely it is to actually happen, and the
consequences of not preventing it.

IMO, getting around the licensing issues in protecting something
that's probably built entirely out of GPL software (I'll bet an Ubuntu
CD that we're talking about an Asterisk-based system) is a major task.
And the fact is, folks who'd hack/pirate this appliance system are the
same folks who'd build their own instead of buying one.

And if they just repurpose the box, why care?  You got paid, and your
support costs just went down.  If your business model is based on a
hardware loss-leader, start looking for another one 'cos that's a
great way to burn through your funding.

So put some copyrighted Perl scripts in there and if there's
significant piracy going on, prosecute.  Otherwise, you're just adding
to development (and maybe unit) costs and pushing the ship date out.
That'll cost you sales just like piracy can.

Besides, breaking the GPL makes baby Jesus cry.

Feeling pundit-y,
  Aaron

>    I'm looking for pgp4pine. The latest google finds is version 4.1 
from
> 2000. Is this what folks use? Does it matter that it's that old since 
it is
> supposed to be an interface between gpg and pine?

Folks that use PGP and need a console mail reader use gnus or mutt.  
PINE is dead, and has been since UW killed it by switching the license 
a while back.

I would seriously consider looking at alternatives.  PINE Is Newbie 
Emailer.  By needing PGP, you've graduated.  8:o)

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jan 30 10:28:54 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 30 Jan 2005 10:28:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies
In-Reply-To: <86r7kmpnb2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20050109185706.2D7F95B90@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20050109212701.GA31152@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<864qhqgt9p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86mzvfw6b7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86acrdvkhi.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86zmzcsi6c.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<86vfa0scys.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <86r7kmpnb2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <863bwisrdl.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


Another (near closure, I think) update on the tape-backup-power-off
behavior.  We replaced the power supply with a 350W model.  Since
then, we've had no more poweroff events.  Then we noticed that we
couldn't write without errors, we replaced the tape drive.  Oddly,
during the first weeks of this saga, we *could* write to that tape
drive, the power-off failure occurred after hours of activity.  When,
even with the replacement tape drive, we still got errors though not
immediately, we replaced the SCSI card ($10, thank you Free Geek!) and
with it the driver, we got a clean backup two nights in a row.

I have tested the first tape drive on a different box and have the
same problems there.  Basically, the inability to write anything.
I've tried four different shrink wrapped (though not exactly new)
cartridges.  I suppose some of this could be explained by bad media,
but who knows?


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From kens at cad2cam.com  Sun Jan 30 10:50:48 2005

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Tape Drives and Power Supplies

On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 10:28 -0800, Russell Senior wrote:
> Another (near closure, I think) update on the tape-backup-power-off
> behavior.  We replaced the power supply with a 350W model.  Since
> then, we've had no more poweroff events.  Then we noticed that we
> couldn't write without errors, we replaced the tape drive.  Oddly,
> during the first weeks of this saga, we *could* write to that tape
> drive, the power-off failure occurred after hours of activity.  When,
> even with the replacement tape drive, we still got errors though not
> immediately, we replaced the SCSI card ($10, thank you Free Geek!) and
> with it the driver, we got a clean backup two nights in a row.
> 
> I have tested the first tape drive on a different box and have the
> same problems there.  Basically, the inability to write anything.
> I've tried four different shrink wrapped (though not exactly new)
> cartridges.  I suppose some of this could be explained by bad media,
> but who knows?
> 
> 
Have you tried some aggressive cleaning of the tape head?

On Sunday 30 January 2005 10:29 am, Russell Senior wrote:
> What software do people use for recording from line-in?

gramofile

While I haven't recorded anything for several months, I've been working on and 
off  for a few years, on converting my LP's to mp3's and storing them on a 
40Gb hard drive on a machine in the basement (RH 7.0 on 200MHz Pentium). With 
my music database project (see my web site), I have a servicable juke box 
system. The line in and line out are wired to the stereo in the living room. 
Any machine in the house with a web browser can start playing a recording 
that is heard on the living room stereo.

From charlie at schluting.com  Sun Jan 30 13:12:04 2005
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 13:12:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] comast++
Message-ID: <41FD4DA4.1090007@schluting.com>

I felt the need to share this with the list, for some reason :)

Rumor said that comcast upgraded residential customers to 4 Mb/s download 
speed last weds. This is true. On friday night I power cycled my "modem" 
and after it came back, I was getting 4 Mb/s (about 500KB/s).
Current speed: 4.0 Mb/384 Kb

Rumor also said that I could upgrade to 6.0 Mb/768 Kb! This costs $10 
more/month. I called them, and in less than 10 minutes that cablem modem 
rebooted, and I was downloading at 6 Mb/s. Amazing. That's 2x the speed I 
had early friday (up and down) for $10 more :-D

Some people don't like cable, and have delusions of speeds varying based on 
congestion. I can assure you, this never happens to most people. Every time 
I download something from my server at PSU I'm always getting the full 
speed. And about 19ms latency between home <-> PSU! And, I've had the same 
IP address for over a year now, btw.

Good stuff.
If you have cable tv already, you get a discount of $10 (total: $45/mo).
Add $10 for amazing speeds, and you're back at $55/mo. I believe this is 
comcast's response to verizon(?) upgrading to 3 Mb/s.
Good job, comcast!

-Charlie


From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Jan 30 13:40:15 2005
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 13:40:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] recording audio from line-in
Message-ID: <20050130214015.GA12926@gate.kl-ic.com>


On 30 Jan 2005, Russell Senior writes:
> What software do people use for recording from line-in?

I am experimenting with this right now - copying a audio tape of
my mother's memorial service to CD.

What came with the Redhat 9 on my laptop was "gnome sound recorder"
and "record".  The gnome program was broken as delivered, and I
had to revert to the Redhat 8 version.  It works, but is poorly
thought out.  It records the file as /tmp/untitled.raw, then converts
it as /tmp/untitled.tmp (which you can then rename).  Since raw-format
audio consumes 10MB/minute, a 45 minute cassette side requires 900MB
of storage available in /tmp ... before you save the file where you
really need it.

"record" looks better.  A command line program, it makes a little
ASCII graphic VU meter, which is handy for setting levels.  It looks
like just the sort of thing for driving from a cron script to record
a radio show, for example.

There are probably newer, more capable tools, but a .wav file is
a .wav file.  Next, I learn about building mp3's with "lame".  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Sun Jan 30 14:11:44 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 14:11:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] recording audio from line-in
In-Reply-To: <20050130214015.GA12926@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050130214015.GA12926@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <200501301411.44347.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

On Sunday 30 January 2005 1:40 pm, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> "record" looks better.  A command line program, it makes a little
> ASCII graphic VU meter, which is handy for setting levels.  It looks
> like just the sort of thing for driving from a cron script to record
> a radio show, for example.

I'm pretty sure that gramofile uses record to capture audio. Gramofile adds 
post processing with a number of standard filters to reduce noise, such as 
what you get from a scratched LP.

> There are probably newer, more capable tools, but a .wav file is
> a .wav file.  Next, I learn about building mp3's with "lame".

IIRC, lame is a front end to bladeenc. I haven't used lame, but I've been 
quite happy with bladeenc. It's a simple, command line program, called 
thusly:

 bladeenc [global switches] input1 [output1 [switches]] input2 ...  

I don't remember what the switches do; all I use is:
 
 bladeenc INPUT1 OUTPUT1 -br 256000

You can set the sampling rate to what you prefer. Our music collection is 
mostly classical, and we weren't happy with the lower rates. On the other 
hand, we couldn't tell the difference between 256000 and 3xxxxx (I forget 
what CD quality is, but it starts with a 3, and has six digits!). Saves a 
little space without noticeable loss of quality.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/


From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Sun Jan 30 15:10:42 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 15:10:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
Message-ID: <200501301510.42873.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

Some of you will recall my ongoing saga of finding a keyboard with the right 
touch for my wife. Yesterday, she finally couldn't take it any longer, so we 
went over to Pacific Solutions to see what they had. 

Linda was running the store, as she often is, and plugged in several different 
brands of keyboard for my wife to try out. None of them were satisfactory, 
for one reason or another. Then, Linda recommended trying the keyboard she 
had plugged into her POS computer. While not as wonderful as the old Wyse 
keyboards my wife loves, that Kensington brand keyboard was acceptable.

As it happens, that unit came in a box of product samples Pacific Solutions 
got from Kensington, so there wasn't a new one in a box. Not to worry, 
though. Linda happily sold us her "broken in" keyboard.

So, add this to the growing list of good experiences with that establishment.

Personally, while I can tell the difference between keyboards, it doesn't 
matter that much to me. However, my wife was able to shave 1/2 hour from a 2 
hour transcription project once she had this new keyboard installed.

I haven't given up on the Wyse, yet. A friend of mine designs embedded 
circuits, and has offered to have me bring one over some day, so we can find 
out what thing puts out. Then, maybe we'll be able to design a small circuit 
to go between the Wyse keyboard and a PS/2 port. Maybe I'll be able to get 
one working for an anniversary present (March), but more likely I'll just 
manage to get it done for Christmas!

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

modem. I've only been able to get 3.5 Mbits/sec down in 
Azureus/Bittorrent, though. I haven't tried anything else, though. And I 
think the 384K up is a speed increase too; I think I was getting 256K up 
in Azureus/Bittorrent before.

I think I'll pay the extra ten bucks for six :) I'll pass on the TV though.

Verizon's upgrade to 3 MB/s was *their* response to Comcast's 3 MB/s. :) 
Of course the reason I went with Comcast in the first place is that the 
Verizon line to my house was too old for DSL. :)

The keyboards I have were made for a 286 computer. The connection was by means 
of a telephone-like cable and RJ-?? connectors (not RJ-11, the smaller ones 
that go from the handset to the phone base). While one could use a Wyse 
supplied adapter to connect a standard PC keyboard to the 286, it doesn't 
work the other way around.

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Jan 30 21:27:23 2005
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 21:27:23 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
In-Reply-To: <20050131050916.B82EA5918@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200501310527.j0V5RNTM053268@m5p.com>

>From: Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net>
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> > On Sun, 30 Jan 2005, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> >
> >> of a telephone-like cable and RJ-?? connectors (not RJ-11, the 
> >> smaller ones
> >
> >                                    ^^
> >                                    45
> 
> No, an RJ-45 is bigger. Richard was speaking of the smaller ones that 
> are used in a telephone handset. Those are RJ-12.

Just to add yet another differing belief. RJ-45 can be up to 10 pins
despite only 8 of those being used for most purposes. The one used by
phones is RJ-14 which is 6. The smaller one used for phone handsets is
RJ-11 with 4 pins.

From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Sun Jan 30 21:38:47 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 21:38:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
In-Reply-To: <41FDBD66.4060205@dimstar.net>
References: <200501301510.42873.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501302009060.7074@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41FDBD66.4060205@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <200501302138.47123.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

On Sunday 30 January 2005 9:08 pm, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> > On Sun, 30 Jan 2005, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> >> of a telephone-like cable and RJ-?? connectors (not RJ-11, the
> >> smaller ones
> >
> >                                    ^^
> >                                    45
>
> No, an RJ-45 is bigger. Richard was speaking of the smaller ones that
> are used in a telephone handset. Those are RJ-12.

RJ-45 is what most ethernet cables use.

From a quick look for RJ-12 on Google, it looks like it is a 6-wire version of 
the RJ-11. A picture at: http://www.drahtex.com/pdf_drac/16.pdf shows one 
between an RJ-11 and an RJ-45. It looks to be as wide as a 45, but not as 
heavy. Probably good for three line telephone, but not enough wires for 
CAT-5.

A not so quick look on Google has me more confused than before. References to 
telephone handset cords talk about them having "standard RJ-11" plugs.

Well, I've spent way too much time on it, so I will in the future refer to 
them as "telephone handset plugs or jacks" and leave it at that. :-)

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

Open Source WYSIWYG HTML/XML Editor
which would have all or some of the following functionalities,
listed in the order of importance:

1. Uses primarely CSS for page layouts
2. True page layout representation
3. Support for Perl scripting
4. Does not use any proprietary or non-standard tags

Thanks in advance for any information

Alex

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jan 31 07:54:32 2005
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 07:54:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Code Protection
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.61.0501281753120.20432@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501310745200.3140-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Fri, 28 Jan 2005, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Rod,
> 
>    Isn't it better to prevent the crime rather than to prosecute after the
> fact?

Yes.  But speaking from experience ( unsuccessful though it was ) I was
able to recover a script I wrote that was never paid for by the requester,
stolen by his 'partners', and the original code was lost during a company
reorganization ( went out of business ) before I could grab a copy.  I
found it on another hosting company's computer for a domain that I
recognized as the thieves.  I recognized it by the coding style and notes 
in the code ( CGI script ).  Not very good thieves, they didn't even file 
the serial number off.

Still being able to identify your code, besides helping in legal matters,
could be a deterent if it was "leaked" hidden idetifiers were in the code.  
And I probably shouldn't have brought it up but it still gets my dander up
when I think of it.  ( This is my button! :-)


Rod

From znmeb at cesmail.net  Mon Jan 31 07:43:35 2005
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)

>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

One place you might look is the Gentoo home page. (www.gentoo.org). 
Their web pages and documentation are mostly written in XML and use CSS. 
If you do some digging, you'll probably find out what tools they're 
using. Of course, it might turn out they use Emacs or some other tool 
designed for folks like me with a well-developed auditory modality. :)

There are plenty of open-source WYSIWYG editors that will *make* an HTML 
document, using LaTeX as an intermediary. Check out LyX and TeXmacs, for 
example. And someone also mentioned Amaya.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Jan 30 23:04:04 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun, 30 Jan 2005 23:04:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] GNU WYSIWYG HTML/XML Editor (need your opinion)
In-Reply-To: <200501302225.49612.alex@daniloff.com>
References: <200501302225.49612.alex@daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1107155044.20648.13.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 22:25 -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Could somebody please recommend an 
> Open Source WYSIWYG HTML/XML Editor

AFAIK, nvu is about your only option.  http://nvu.com

It's based around Mozilla Composer code.

> which would have all or some of the following functionalities,
> listed in the order of importance:
> 
> 1. Uses primarely CSS for page layouts

nvu *does* use CSS, but it also doesn't seem to understand <div> tags
very well and utilizes tables for basic layout (which, imho, is very
icky, even if "everybody else does it").

> 2. True page layout representation

I guess it supports this.

> 3. Support for Perl scripting

There's definitely no Perl support in nvu.  You'll have a hard time
finding a WYSIWYG editor that supports scripting like that for dynamic
content period.  FrontPage supports FrontPage extensions (I don't think
it supports ASP) and I *think* DreamWeaver has some rudimentary PHP
support.  IMHO, dynamic content is best done in a text editor of some
sort, not a WYSIWYG editor.

I like Eclipse for my PHP/MySQL/HTML jobs.

> 4. Does not use any proprietary or non-standard tags

Like what?

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From plug at merlot.com  Mon Jan 31 09:00:10 2005
From: plug at merlot.com (plug at merlot.com)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 09:00:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] mutt configuration question
Message-ID: <20050131170010.GN31264@merlot.com>

I use mutt (version 1.5.6+20040907i). I love mutt. It does what I want
it to do. Almost.

I have been told that a send-hook or folder-hook can be used to set my
outgoing ('From ') address based on who I'm sending to or which folder
I'm in. What I'm doing doesn't work for me.

  send-hook "~t plug at lists\.pdxlinux\.org" my_hdr "From: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"
  send-hook "~t plug at lists\.pdxlinux\.org" my_hdr "Sender: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"

The result of these two send-hooks is the wrong 'From' address on almost
all outgoing email, as if most email is seen by mutt as going to
'plug at lists.pdxlinux.org'. I have not yet found a pattern that will
allow me to predict when the address will be set incorrectly. 

I've also tried this:

  folder-hook =plug$ my_hdr "From: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"
  folder-hook =plug$ my_hdr "Sender: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"

and this

  folder-hook plug my_hdr "From: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"
  folder-hook plug my_hdr "Sender: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"

with the same results.

There's also a setting that is supposed to use the 'To' address in the
message I'm replying to as the 'From' address of the reply. That almost
never works. I see no pattern there either.

Any ideas?

TIA

--Kurt

> If you are asking whether your universal card is 5V or 3.3V, your

> used in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.  That's why the edge connector of
> your card has two cutouts.  This is to allow it to be installed
> in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.
