From rsteff.l at comcast.net  Mon Jan 31 09:16:38 2005
From: rsteff.l at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 09:16:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
In-Reply-To: <1107154518.20649.6.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <200501301510.42873.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<200501302138.47123.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<1107154518.20649.6.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <200501310916.38526.rsteff.l@comcast.net>

On Sunday 30 January 2005 10:55 pm, AthlonRob wrote:

> Is there a minimum number of pairs necessary for CAT5?

I can't put my hands on it right now, but somewhere I have a booklet that 
defines CAT-5 in its various flavors. IIRC there's TIA568-A and TIA568-B, the 
difference being which pairs are connected to which pins. I'm pretty sure the 
standard requires four pairs, but I also remember reading somewhere that they 
aren't all used in some situations.

Each pair has a different number of twists per foot, which I understand is one 
of the ways to prevent interference between pairs. It just looks like wire, 
but there's some serious engineering behind it.

So, could you get away with just two pair of telephone wire? Over a short 
distance (a few feet) maybe. But across the room, or to the other end of the 
building, probably not.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/

From aaron at bavariati.org  Mon Jan 31 09:51:36 2005
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 09:51:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
In-Reply-To: <1107154518.20649.6.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <200501301510.42873.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501302009060.7074@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41FDBD66.4060205@dimstar.net>
	<200501302138.47123.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<1107154518.20649.6.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <20050131175136.GB31362@bavariati.org>

On Sun, Jan 30, 2005 at 10:55:18PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 21:38 -0800, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> > Probably good for three line telephone, but not enough wires for 
> > CAT-5.
> 
> Is there a minimum number of pairs necessary for CAT5?

Cat5 itself is a cabling spec.  Four pairs of Unshielded Twisted-Pair,
such-and-such impedence, crosstalk and capacitance for such-and-such
signal bandwidth.

100 Mbps ethernet (100Base-T) uses two of those four pairs.  You can
run 10Mbps (10Base-T) over two pairs of Cat3, which is your typical
phone-grade 4-pair UTP.



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Jan 31 10:38:29 2005
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 10:38:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI 2.2 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 31 Jan 2005 09:15:25 PST."
	<Pine.LNX.4.33.0501310906150.3608-100000@main.cyber-office.net> 
Message-ID: <20050131183834.1060D8F12@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

> On Wed, 19 Jan 2005, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > If you are asking whether your universal card is 5V or 3.3V, your
> > question doesn't make sense.  A universal card is just that.  It can be
> > used in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.  That's why the edge connector of
> > your card has two cutouts.  This is to allow it to be installed
> > in either a 5V or 3.3V PCI slot.
> 
> As a follow up I received the card and it has an installation sheet that 
> says either a 3.3 or 5 volt slot.  Now my only issues is to whether the 
> PCI bus is 2.2 or greater.  During the boot I haven't noticed this, the 
> CMOS doesn't say anything either and after booting I see nothing from 
> lspci that states what version.  I assume that I can determine from the MB 
> manufacturer so I'll check the the model ( an ASUS PIII system) this 
> evening and see what I can find on the site.  In the mean time is there a 
> common method to determine the PCI version?
> 

The PCI 2.1 spec was released 6/1/95.  The PCI 2.2 spec was released
12/18/98.  The 2.2 spec incorporates 17 ECNs(Engineering Change Notices)
to the 2.1 spec.  None of them are particularly earth shattering.  Six
of the seventeen ECNs are mechanical.  The remaining eleven ECNs cover
fairly specialized cases.

Any PCI equipment built within the last four or five years probably
conforms to 2.2.  Plus, I suspect your board would work fine when
installed in a 2.1 host system.

galen



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 31 11:03:44 2005
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 11:03:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Another good experience with Pacific Solutions
In-Reply-To: <20050131175136.GB31362@bavariati.org>
References: <200501301510.42873.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.61.0501302009060.7074@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<41FDBD66.4060205@dimstar.net>
	<200501302138.47123.rsteff.l@comcast.net>
	<1107154518.20649.6.camel@dell.linux.box>
	<20050131175136.GB31362@bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <1107198224.20649.33.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2005-01-31 at 09:51 -0800, Aaron Burt wrote:
> On Sun, Jan 30, 2005 at 10:55:18PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> > On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 21:38 -0800, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> > > Probably good for three line telephone, but not enough wires for 
> > > CAT-5.
> > 
> > Is there a minimum number of pairs necessary for CAT5?
> 
> Cat5 itself is a cabling spec.  Four pairs of Unshielded Twisted-Pair,
> such-and-such impedence, crosstalk and capacitance for such-and-such
> signal bandwidth.
> 
> 100 Mbps ethernet (100Base-T) uses two of those four pairs.  You can
> run 10Mbps (10Base-T) over two pairs of Cat3, which is your typical
> phone-grade 4-pair UTP.

Not entirely accurate.  CAT5 doesn't really tell us anything about the
number of pairs.  My question was somewhat rhetorical, although I'm not
honestly sure if one or two pairs could be turned in to CAT5.  So I
asked the question.

CAT5 just defines the number of twists per distance and the basics (like
each wire is insulated, stuff like that)... it doesn't tell us how many
pairs are there.  I had a friend ask me a few years back if I wanted
some extra ~48 pair CAT5.  I think it was 48 pairs, it may have been
more or less.  I declined... I don't have much use for something like
that.  :-)

Note Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat5) doesn't mention how
many pairs there are, either.

-- 
Rob                    |  If not safe,
  http://rob.axpr.net  |    one can never be free.



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jan 31 11:07:21 2005
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 11:07:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: mutt configuration question
In-Reply-To: <20050131170010.GN31264@merlot.com>
References: <20050131170010.GN31264@merlot.com>
Message-ID: <20050131190721.A554C2D01@haus.nakedape.cc>

In gmane.org.user-groups.linux.portland, you wrote:
> I use mutt (version 1.5.6+20040907i). I love mutt. It does what I want
> it to do. Almost.
>
> I have been told that a send-hook or folder-hook can be used to set my
> outgoing ('From ') address based on who I'm sending to or which folder
> I'm in. What I'm doing doesn't work for me.
>
>   send-hook "~t plug at lists\.pdxlinux\.org" my_hdr "From: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"
>   send-hook "~t plug at lists\.pdxlinux\.org" my_hdr "Sender: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"
>
> The result of these two send-hooks is the wrong 'From' address on almost
> all outgoing email, as if most email is seen by mutt as going to
> 'plug at lists.pdxlinux.org'. I have not yet found a pattern that will
> allow me to predict when the address will be set incorrectly. 

The problem is that Mutt doesn't reset the headers you change in
send-hook, so you have to also include a match-all send-hook to reset
the header.  Also, I've always done all the changes for a particular
send-hook in one statement; I'm not sure if you can match multiple ones.

send-hook . \
    'my_hdr From: "Kurt Sussman <whatever at merlot.com>";
    my_hdr Sender: "Kurt Sussman <whatever at merlot.com>"'

send-hook '~t plug at lists\.pdxlinux\.org' \
    'my_hdr From: "Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>";
    my_hdr Sender: "Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>"'

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

AthlonRob (AthlonRob at axpr.net) typed this ...
> On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 21:38 -0800, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> > Probably good for three line telephone, but not enough wires for 
> > CAT-5.
> 
> Is there a minimum number of pairs necessary for CAT5?

Sorry to inject another hack vs. crack discussion, but do you mean 'cat5
the cable that connects e.g. a NIC to a switch' (the common usage), or
'cat5 the electical spec' (the technically correct usage)?

Two pairs for the former, 4 pairs for the latter.

From jason at vancleve.com  Mon Jan 31 14:20:42 2005
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 14:20:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] recording audio from line-in
In-Reply-To: <41FD4183.9070004@cesmail.net>
References: <86y8earcri.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <41FD3842.7010201@earthlink.net>
	<867jlur7es.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <41FD4183.9070004@cesmail.net>
Message-ID: <20050131142042.609edeca.jason@vancleve.com>

Quoth M. Edward (Ed) Borasky, on Sun, 30 Jan 2005 12:20:19 -0800:

> jack audio connection kit and the 2.6.10 kernel, for starters. Do a 
> Google search for "Dave Phillips Linux Audio" and enjoy the feast!! :)

Working with audio in Linux is not for the feint of heart.  Jack is only
needed for demanding applications:  those needing low latency and
synchronization with other audio app's.  Otherwise, I'd skip jack and
just use alsa.

I'm trying to put together something myself, and I've got rosegarden
working with jack/alsa.  I'm even running a preemptible 2.6 kernel with
the realtime patch, so that I can run 'jackd -R' as a normal user.  MIDI
is working too, but I still can't record audio!  I have an SBLive
Platinum, and jack won't let me connect the 1/4" mic' input (the one on
the LiveDrive) to rosegarden.

This stuff is tricky, and jack makes it trickier; so just be sure you
really need jack.

--Jason

--
Jesus is coming!  Look busy.

hoping!  Otherwise I have another low end server!

it sounds to good to be true, then what's the catch?"

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Jan 31 15:05:49 2005
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 15:05:49 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUNCEMENT: February PLUG Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0501311503230.4814@sco302.DavidMandel.com>




                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Thursday Feb 3, 2005
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)

      **********************************************************
          
                                 PRESENTATION

                               An Introduction
                                      to
                              Computer Recycling

                                      by

                               Richard Seymour
                                     and
                                Jhasen Cooper
                                     from
                                 FreeGeek.org


      Jhasen will discuss a lot of computer recycling issues,
      including a description of the bad things in computer
      equipment, what needs recycled, some of the obstacles
      to recycling, and so on.
      Richard will discuss the role of OpenSource software in
      making recycling a practical alternative to simply tossing
      everything out.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:
          
              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects 
                   including PLUG's monthly Advanced Topics meetings, 
                   PLUG's monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for Education,
                   etc.
                   We will also discuss ways of finding speakers for
                   future meetings.

              7:30 - 8:30  Presentation
          
                   See above
          
              9:00 - ...  Beer
                                  The Lucky Labrador Brewing Company
                                  915 SE Hawthorne
          
          
          
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          560 SE Alexander
                                          Corvallis, Oregon 97333
                                          (541) 684-4644 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 mobile
                                          dmandel at pdxLinux.org
          
          
          P.S.  Biznix which specializes in Linux and UNIX support for 
                the Business Computer User meets on the second 
                Thursday of the month at the Novell offices in Tigard.
                See http://www.Bizix.org for details.
                
          P.S.  PDXLUG provides a less formal alternative to PLUG 
                emphasizing the needs of new users.   PDXLUG meets 
                every second Thursday of the month in southeast Portland.
                See http://www.PDXLUG.org for details.

          P.S.  The Mid Willamette Valley Linux Users Group meets at
                Oregon State University (generally Owen Hall room 101)
                on the first Tuesday of the month.
                See http://www.mwvlug.org/ for details.
          
          P.S.  The Eugene Linux Users Group meets several times a month.
                See http://www.euglug.org for details.

   ======================================================================
   David Mandel, Instructor            http://www.PioneerPacific.edu

   David Mandel                        http://www.DavidMandel.com

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Jan 31 16:14:03 2005
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 16:14:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] recording audio from line-in
In-Reply-To: <20050130214015.GA12926@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20050130214015.GA12926@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1107216843.4359.1.camel@dagon.fnordora.org>

On Sun, 2005-01-30 at 13:40 -0800, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> On 30 Jan 2005, Russell Senior writes:
> > What software do people use for recording from line-in?
> 
> I am experimenting with this right now - copying a audio tape of
> my mother's memorial service to CD.
> 
> What came with the Redhat 9 on my laptop was "gnome sound recorder"
> and "record".  The gnome program was broken as delivered, and I
> had to revert to the Redhat 8 version.  It works, but is poorly
> thought out.  It records the file as /tmp/untitled.raw, then converts
> it as /tmp/untitled.tmp (which you can then rename).  Since raw-format
> audio consumes 10MB/minute, a 45 minute cassette side requires 900MB
> of storage available in /tmp ... before you save the file where you
> really need it.
> 
> "record" looks better.  A command line program, it makes a little
> ASCII graphic VU meter, which is handy for setting levels.  It looks
> like just the sort of thing for driving from a cron script to record
> a radio show, for example.
> 
> There are probably newer, more capable tools, but a .wav file is
> a .wav file.  Next, I learn about building mp3's with "lame".  

There is a Knopix variant that is designed to record sound.  It is
called DoCoMo or something similar.  I got it on the cover of a European
Linux magazine.  I will make a copy and bring it to the meeting.

--

 report to me and it will be prohibited.
 So shall it be! This is the Land of the Free!"
                  - George W. Firefly

I can't speak for their speed/uptime, but for $6/mo, it can't really hurt to 
check them out :)

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jan 31 17:59:22 2005

Subject: [PLUG] MAC Mini running Linux?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501311742070.7108-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

There are a couple MAC fanatics here and they got me looking at the new 
mini macs.  Cute for sure.  Also got me thinking that they'd make really 
neat appliances.  Heard one of them say he read that they were going into 
the trunks of cars to run the sound system , hooked up to in-house 
sound systems , TV (PVR) etc.
   So I figured if they could run Linux they'd be way better!  :-)

Anyone tried it yet or thinking of porting Linux to the mini-Mac?

I have a Powerbook for work that I dual-boot with Ubuntu. I prefer Linux 
on PPC, when using a distribution that supports PPC properly.

OS X has no real package management to speak of. A bunch of .pkg files 
does not a package manager make. Anything that's not a .app is a 
question mark in terms of upgrades.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 31 18:36:52 2005
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 18:36:52 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] MAC Mini running Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0501311742070.7108-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 31 Jan 2005, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> Anyone tried it yet or thinking of porting Linux to the mini-Mac?

I remember reading that one of the Gentoo developers got the PPC port 
working on a mini.

They are nice little devices, that's for sure: not much bigger than a 
Linksys or Netgear firewall/router and pretty quiet. I think they'd 
make a tremendous little server.

Somewhat astoundingly, given Apple's usual pricing scheme, the $500 or 
600 it'll set you back isn't out of line for what you'd pay for a 
whisper-quiet PC with a tiny form factor.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>


From mel97215 at comcast.net  Mon Jan 31 18:44:32 2005
From: mel97215 at comcast.net (Mel Andres)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 18:44:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] debian on dell inspiron 1100
Message-ID: <41FEED10.2000706@comcast.net>

Yesterday I attempted to get debian installed on the laptop. So, 
re-partitioned, et al then started the sarge net inst. I got a base OS 
installed without too many issues. As I have been on an RPM based 
system, the apt-get method is new to me, but I kept getting packages as 
I went along when the system indicated they were needed. My final hurdle 
(well maybe not, I don't know what I don't know yet.) is getting X to 
start. When I issue the startx command, the screen goes blank for a bit 
then displays a "no screens found" message complaining that there are no 
Video BIOS modes for chosen depth. Looking in /var/log/XFree86.0.log, I 
can see that the Intel 82845GM is detected during the PCI scan, detects 
12288kb vidioram which it attempts to tell the BIOS about. Then, where 
the I810 driver checks for attached monitors, TV's and such, the LFP 
line has FALSE for attached and present. Just a little below that, the 
I810 reports Currently active displays on Pipe A, an LFP but complains 
of no display size information. I don't know where to go from here. Any 
pointers, hand-holding, hints greatly appreciated.

   Mel



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 31 18:52:13 2005

From sean.whitney at gmail.com  Mon Jan 31 19:38:00 2005
From: sean.whitney at gmail.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 19:38:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] debian on dell inspiron 1100
In-Reply-To: <41FEED10.2000706@comcast.net>
References: <41FEED10.2000706@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1107229080.4395.4.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I would try these of tactics.

1) look for the (EE) messages in the log file, then let google track
that down for you.

2) man XFree86, look for the -configure option.  It's worked for me on
Debian on more than one occasion.
 
3) Look at the Linux-on-laptops website and find a webpage for the model
you have.  Sometimes they will post the X config file they are using, or
the author will mail it to you.


Sean

> > does not a package manager make. Anything that's not a .app is a 
> > question mark in terms of upgrades.
> 
> What's wrong with fink? http://fink.sf.net
> (I don't have a Mac, so I'm seriously wondering about this because I can't 
> test it. Doesn't fink work as described?)

Nothing is wrong with fink. I've used fink and DarwinPorts but that's
not what I'm talking about.

Mac OS X, out of the box, has no sane package management. Anything not
in fink? Sorry, you're out of luck.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jan 31 20:45:05 2005
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 31 Jan 2005 20:45:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] recording audio from line-in
In-Reply-To: <86y8earcri.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86y8earcri.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86wttsnb1q.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> What software do people use for recording from line-in?

Thanks all, for the suggestions.  I ended up using Audacity.  It
didn't work so well on the laptop (I think there was an impedence
problem on the jack, maybe a microphone rather than line-in input?),
so I strung a couple 20-foot extensions upstairs to my EMU10k1 sound
card and it worked much better.  I also used gramofile to filter the
wav file.

These were a couple old vinyl records (1960s british comedy).  I
noticed that one of them had a pretty significant periodic squiggle in
the signal, a low frequency wavelet.  Of course, because it is low
frequency you don't notice it audibly (unless you are an elephant),
but it it pretty obvious visually.

Thanks again!

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jan 31 22:01:34 2005
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon, 31 Jan 2005 22:01:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] debian on dell inspiron 1100
In-Reply-To: <41FEED10.2000706@comcast.net>
References: <41FEED10.2000706@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1107237694.2635.10.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2005-01-31 at 18:44 -0800, Mel Andres wrote:
> Yesterday I attempted to get debian installed on the laptop. So, 
> re-partitioned, et al then started the sarge net inst. I got a base OS 
> installed without too many issues. As I have been on an RPM based 
> system, the apt-get method is new to me, but I kept getting packages as 
> I went along when the system indicated they were needed. My final hurdle 
> (well maybe not, I don't know what I don't know yet.) is getting X to 
> start. When I issue the startx command, the screen goes blank for a bit 
> then displays a "no screens found" message complaining that there are no 
> Video BIOS modes for chosen depth. Looking in /var/log/XFree86.0.log, I 
> can see that the Intel 82845GM is detected during the PCI scan, detects 
> 12288kb vidioram which it attempts to tell the BIOS about. Then, where 
> the I810 driver checks for attached monitors, TV's and such, the LFP 
> line has FALSE for attached and present. Just a little below that, the 
> I810 reports Currently active displays on Pipe A, an LFP but complains 
> of no display size information. I don't know where to go from here. Any 
> pointers, hand-holding, hints greatly appreciated.
> 
Try running "dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86".  You may have to try
several times before you get the right monitor settings.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

http://www.webhostingtalk.com/

Their support is first-rate- trouble tickets are answered quickly, and they 
are very reliable.
